description: The Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification is designed for anyone responsible for managing Apple computers and devices in a business environment. The exam is made up of content from the Support Essentials ACSP course, as well as content from the Server Essentials course which is covered in this show. Technologies covered include topics like network deployment, policy management, troubleshooting and using Open Directory for centralized user management.
name: Certified Technical Coordinator 10.10
subtitle: OS X Server Essentials 10.10

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification. He takes a look at the topics covered, as well as basic information on how to take the exam.
episodes.title: Apple ACTC Overview

Some of the other exam vendors
out there like Microsoft,

156

157
00:07:24,180 --> 00:07:27,100

you're not positive of

scored questions on the exam

00:08:06,400 --> 00:08:07,490

177
00:08:08,650 --> 00:08:14,080
Now the exam covers a wide range of
topics and [LAUGH] they lay it out

00:08:14,080 --> 00:08:19,670
in just like painful detail right here
across 30 pages or something like that.

00:08:19,670 --> 00:08:22,290
But I'm gonna go up to the table of
contents, it's a little bit easier to take

180
00:08:22,290 --> 00:08:26,570

181
00:08:26,570 --> 00:08:30,840

185
00:08:42,620 --> 00:08:44,660
So we can bring that out
with a server app, but

186
00:08:44,660 --> 00:08:47,760
we need to understand, how do we install
it, how do we get it configured,

187
00:08:47,760 --> 00:08:50,390
how do we get it running, and
how do we keep it running.

188
00:08:50,390 --> 00:08:52,130
And that's what that first section covers.

189
00:08:52,130 --> 00:08:54,120
This is the biggest section
of the entire exam.

190
00:08:54,120 --> 00:08:57,050
A lot of the exam content comes from
right out of this very first part.

191
00:08:58,290 --> 00:09:02,620
Then it divides the rest of the content
into more specific areas, right.

192
00:09:02,620 --> 00:09:04,450
Part two is configuring accounts.

193
00:09:04,450 --> 00:09:06,090
These are local user accounts for

194
00:09:06,090 --> 00:09:10,280

195
00:09:10,280 --> 00:09:13,659

it's very powerful and

197

00:09:19,435 --> 00:09:23,580

00:09:23,580 --> 00:09:26,810

00:09:28,120 --> 00:09:30,640

203
00:09:33,750 --> 00:09:38,720

create a standard configuration for

204
00:09:38,720 --> 00:09:42,450

00:09:45,070 --> 00:09:47,801

00:09:47,801 --> 00:09:51,055
configured the way that we want it,
it already has the software we need and

208
00:09:51,055 --> 00:09:52,803
it's ready to run right out of the box.

209
00:09:54,219 --> 00:09:55,311
Part four is sharing files.

00:09:55,311 --> 00:09:57,425
Right.
How do we exchange information between our

00:09:57,425 --> 00:09:59,547

that one's pretty straight forward,

212

218
00:10:17,500 --> 00:10:19,980

221

01:04:55,780 --> 01:04:58,700

1328
01:05:03,980 --> 01:05:07,640

01:05:53,000 --> 01:05:57,110

00:09:12,150 --> 00:09:13,535

00:09:13,535 --> 00:09:15,470

00:09:15,470 --> 00:09:18,221

178
00:09:18,221 --> 00:09:23,710
There's 13 servers that sit out there on

179
00:09:23,710 --> 00:09:27,180
Behind each one there's really clusters,
so there's hundreds of these servers.

180
00:09:27,180 --> 00:09:31,330
But there's 13 names that we see,
that represent these root servers.

181
00:09:31,330 --> 00:09:32,720
And when we do a lookup for something,

182
00:09:32,720 --> 00:09:37,040
like if I do a lookup for apple.com,
it reaches out to the root hint server,

183
00:09:37,040 --> 00:09:40,410
and it says hey,
can you tell me who's in charge of .com?

184
00:09:40,410 --> 00:09:42,590

00:09:42,590 --> 00:09:44,350
And the root hint servers say oh,
yeah, .com,

186
00:09:44,350 --> 00:09:48,050

the Internet, you got to go talk to them.

00:09:48,050 --> 00:09:50,240

00:09:50,240 --> 00:09:51,260

00:09:51,260 --> 00:09:52,750

00:09:52,750 --> 00:09:57,140

00:09:57,140 --> 00:09:59,310

00:09:59,310 --> 00:10:02,850

00:10:02,850 --> 00:10:05,940
And then they point us over to Apple,

00:10:05,940 --> 00:10:08,200
Apple says oh, yeah, www,

195
00:10:09,310 --> 00:10:13,408
So when you do a DNS lookup, you're
actually bouncing through a multiple

196
00:10:13,408 --> 00:10:16,940

00:10:16,940 --> 00:10:19,060

00:10:19,060 --> 00:10:20,577

00:10:24,211 --> 00:10:27,008

00:10:46,770 --> 00:10:49,500
That iterative query, that search that

00:10:49,500 --> 00:10:53,210

00:24:47,300 --> 00:24:49,900
I can reach out to the 13

00:24:53,720 --> 00:24:56,480

00:24:58,810 --> 00:25:02,250
So If I go over to my client, nope that's

00:25:02,250 --> 00:25:03,725

00:25:03,725 --> 00:25:07,210

00:25:15,960 --> 00:25:19,030
But that can take a little while,

00:25:19,030 --> 00:25:20,210

00:25:20,210 --> 00:25:21,538
If we want things to be faster,

00:25:38,520 --> 00:25:42,413

8.8.8 and 8.8.8.4.

00:25:48,600 --> 00:25:50,683

00:25:50,683 --> 00:25:55,392

00:25:55,392 --> 00:25:56,558
So we can specify these.

00:25:56,558 --> 00:26:00,200
Now what I'm doing is I'm

00:26:00,200 --> 00:26:03,570

00:26:03,570 --> 00:26:05,070
Unless the first one fails.

00:26:05,070 --> 00:26:07,560
Then it will go to the second one,

00:26:07,560 --> 00:26:08,840
Then it will go to the third one.

00:26:08,840 --> 00:26:12,120
But it'll never go to the next server

00:26:12,120 --> 00:26:16,330
So you don't normally need to put a ton of

00:26:16,330 --> 00:26:18,630

00:26:18,630 --> 00:26:20,200

00:26:21,210 --> 00:26:22,340

00:26:22,340 --> 00:26:24,540
Now I've got a couple

00:26:24,540 --> 00:26:28,580
So any time I get a request,

00:26:28,580 --> 00:26:31,090

00:26:32,560 --> 00:26:33,980
The other things that we can do,

00:26:33,980 --> 00:26:37,470

00:26:37,470 --> 00:26:42,660

00:26:43,760 --> 00:26:44,650

00:26:44,650 --> 00:26:48,150

00:26:48,150 --> 00:26:50,570

00:26:50,570 --> 00:26:52,590

00:26:52,590 --> 00:26:55,190

00:26:55,190 --> 00:26:57,390

00:26:57,390 --> 00:27:00,810

00:27:00,810 --> 00:27:02,260

00:27:02,260 --> 00:27:04,190
It's anybody out there on the internet.

00:27:04,190 --> 00:27:06,070

00:27:06,070 --> 00:27:10,030

00:27:10,030 --> 00:27:13,080

00:27:13,080 --> 00:27:16,400

00:27:16,400 --> 00:27:20,240
And you can say, the server itself,

00:27:20,240 --> 00:27:21,670
Those are the default.

00:27:21,670 --> 00:27:26,430

00:27:26,430 --> 00:27:28,460

00:27:31,960 --> 00:27:34,190

00:27:34,190 --> 00:27:36,660

00:27:36,660 --> 00:27:41,250

Or I might have other private

You put in all the networks that

00:28:01,281 --> 00:28:02,016

If you wanna do a single host, you can.

You can come in and

00:28:07,070 --> 00:28:10,820

00:28:12,190 --> 00:28:15,508

00:28:15,508 --> 00:28:18,160

00:28:18,160 --> 00:28:23,380
So you can pick and choose who's allowed

00:28:23,380 --> 00:28:27,320
When you're done, you just hit OK,

00:28:27,320 --> 00:28:28,975

00:28:30,391 --> 00:28:33,416

DNS there's not too much more to do.

When you look at it, you can set your

But when you hit that gear and

You can create machine records that's

00:29:47,660 --> 00:29:51,280
Other records that we can make,

00:29:51,280 --> 00:29:54,770

00:29:54,770 --> 00:29:57,500

00:29:57,500 --> 00:30:00,560

00:30:01,780 --> 00:30:03,180

00:30:06,933 --> 00:30:11,770

00:30:11,770 --> 00:30:17,016

00:30:17,016 --> 00:30:20,445

00:30:20,445 --> 00:30:23,815

00:30:23,815 --> 00:30:26,670
These are, where we're not

00:30:26,670 --> 00:30:29,420

00:30:29,420 --> 00:30:32,370

00:30:32,370 --> 00:30:35,290
And you'll use these with things

00:30:35,290 --> 00:30:37,850

00:30:37,850 --> 00:30:38,840
All right?

00:30:38,840 --> 00:30:41,810

00:30:41,810 --> 00:30:44,010
Primary zones, and secondary zones.

00:30:45,050 --> 00:30:51,160
When I created

00:30:51,160 --> 00:30:55,130

589
00:30:55,130 --> 00:30:58,380
That means that I control that zone,
I control that domain.

590
00:30:58,380 --> 00:31:02,400

I can change it, I can add records,

591
00:31:02,400 --> 00:31:03,530
I can do whatever I want.

592
00:31:03,530 --> 00:31:05,260
I'm the primary.

593
00:31:05,260 --> 00:31:07,020
But what happens if my DNS server fails?

594
00:31:07,020 --> 00:31:08,910
If this server goes offline?

595
00:31:08,910 --> 00:31:12,480
Nobody can get to it, and
if nobody can get to it, that's a problem.

596
00:31:12,480 --> 00:31:16,950
So what I probably wanna do is set
up a second DNS server somewhere,

597
00:31:16,950 --> 00:31:18,860
that has a copy of this zone.

598
00:31:18,860 --> 00:31:22,370
And when you do that, you're setting
up what's called a secondary server,

599
00:31:22,370 --> 00:31:26,900
and a secondary server just maintains
a copy of all the records on the primary.

600
00:31:26,900 --> 00:31:29,820
But the copy is Read Only.

601
00:31:29,820 --> 00:31:30,750
You can't write to it.

602
00:31:30,750 --> 00:31:31,880
You can't change the records.

603
00:31:31,880 --> 00:31:33,840
You you have to go to
the primary to change things.

604
00:31:33,840 --> 00:31:35,780
But you can read from the secondary.

605
00:31:35,780 --> 00:31:39,030
So if the primary fails,
people are still able to do lookups.

606
00:31:39,030 --> 00:31:41,310
They are still find your server and
reach out to them.

607
00:31:41,310 --> 00:31:42,930
That's called a secondary.

608
00:31:42,930 --> 00:31:45,110
And so, the primary was created for me.

609
00:31:45,110 --> 00:31:47,770
If I want to be a secondary,
I have to come in here and add that.

610
00:31:47,770 --> 00:31:49,627
And add a secondary zone.

611
00:31:49,627 --> 00:31:53,838
When you do that your secondary
zone will connect to a primary, and

612
00:31:53,838 --> 00:31:55,804
it will copy the records over.

613
00:31:55,804 --> 00:31:57,476
It's called a zone transfer.

614
00:31:57,476 --> 00:32:01,654
We're transferring or copying all
those records to the other server.

00:32:01,654 --> 00:32:04,320
If I want to set that up,

00:32:05,740 --> 00:32:07,540
And I can fire up the server on this one.

But I can add this one as a secondary.

00:32:20,630 --> 00:32:24,300
So that it'll have a copy of

00:32:24,300 --> 00:32:25,710

00:32:25,710 --> 00:32:29,850
And if my primary fails, I can go and

00:32:29,850 --> 00:32:31,980

00:32:31,980 --> 00:32:35,370
Or if the primary is dead for good,

00:32:38,180 --> 00:32:40,730
So there's a couple of neat things

00:32:40,730 --> 00:32:42,240

Signing off for ITproTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

920
00:47:36,688 --> 00:47:46,688
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates the various ways that you can remotely manage a machine running the OS X Server App. He demonstrates SSH, screen sharing and remotely executing the Server App itself.
episodes.title: Remote Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,295 --> 00:00:22,461
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,461 --> 00:00:33,295
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,295 --> 00:00:36,087
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,087 --> 00:00:38,671
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,671 --> 00:00:39,963
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:39,963 --> 00:00:44,290
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

8
00:00:44,290 --> 00:00:48,700
We're gonna be diving into a neat topic
today, which is remote management.

9
00:00:48,700 --> 00:00:51,320
If you just have one
server that you're using,

10
00:00:51,320 --> 00:00:53,460
one Mac that you're using as a server.

11
00:00:53,460 --> 00:00:55,600
You're running OS X,
you install the server app, and

12
00:00:55,600 --> 00:00:57,100
you get it setup, and that's it.

13
00:00:57,100 --> 00:00:59,990
When you go to manage it, you probably
just walk up to that box, sit down,

14
00:00:59,990 --> 00:01:01,820
login, and use it.

15
00:01:01,820 --> 00:01:02,630
Or if you're like me, and

16
00:01:02,630 --> 00:01:05,890
you're running the server app on your
own laptop, then that's your server.

17
00:01:05,890 --> 00:01:08,000
So you're logged into it, and that's it.

18
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:09,880
But what if you have a hundred servers?

19
00:01:09,880 --> 00:01:11,500
What if you have a thousand servers?

20
00:01:11,500 --> 00:01:14,100
You don't want to have to go and connect
into each one of those individually

21
00:01:14,100 --> 00:01:16,030
whenever you want to change something.

22
00:01:16,030 --> 00:01:20,370
So instead, what you can do is
remotely manage those servers.

23
00:01:20,370 --> 00:01:23,860
You can sit at your own laptop or
desktop, connect to the servers and

24
00:01:23,860 --> 00:01:25,470
completely manage and configure them.

25
00:01:25,470 --> 00:01:27,580
It really does work out well.

26
00:01:27,580 --> 00:01:31,740
Apple gives us a number of different
ways that we can remotely connect and

27
00:01:31,740 --> 00:01:32,860
manage the systems.

28
00:01:32,860 --> 00:01:34,600
Let's take a look at those settings.

29
00:01:34,600 --> 00:01:37,200
So, I'm on a server right here,
so this is my server.

30
00:01:37,200 --> 00:01:39,010
I called it OSX-server 1.

31
00:01:39,010 --> 00:01:44,660
I'm running Max OS 10.10 Yosemite, and
I've installed the server app on it.

32
00:01:44,660 --> 00:01:50,200
So if I fire up my server app and
get connected, I can get logged in.

33
00:01:50,200 --> 00:01:53,120
And it's pretty much just at
all the default settings.

34
00:01:53,120 --> 00:01:56,650
Now on your main screen when you
get logged into the server app,

35
00:01:56,650 --> 00:01:58,400
you'll see a couple of tabs.

36
00:01:58,400 --> 00:02:00,630
And one of the tabs is settings.

37
00:02:00,630 --> 00:02:01,400
This button right here.

38
00:02:01,400 --> 00:02:03,640
And if I choose settings.

39
00:02:03,640 --> 00:02:05,960
Here's the remote management options.

40
00:02:05,960 --> 00:02:09,020
Now by default,
none of them are turned on.

41
00:02:09,020 --> 00:02:13,970
So by default, if you want to manage
an OS X server, you've gotta go and

42
00:02:13,970 --> 00:02:15,220
login to it directly.

43
00:02:15,220 --> 00:02:17,600
You gotta go and sit down in front
of that machine, login and use it.

44
00:02:18,620 --> 00:02:23,190
But if you've got a hundred Mac Minis
acting as servers jammed in Iraqi,

45
00:02:23,190 --> 00:02:25,400
you don't necessarily have a keyboard and
mouse and

46
00:02:25,400 --> 00:02:27,110
monitor hooked up to every one of them.

47
00:02:27,110 --> 00:02:29,300
So you need a way to be able
to remotely manage them.

48
00:02:29,300 --> 00:02:31,870
And Apple gives us a few choices.

49
00:02:31,870 --> 00:02:38,300
If all you need is command line access,
logging in via SSH is a great option.

50
00:02:38,300 --> 00:02:41,220
SSH stand for secure shell.

51
00:02:41,220 --> 00:02:45,350
When you open up the terminal
on your system, right here.

52
00:02:45,350 --> 00:02:50,750
Remember that Mac OS, and OS X in general,
is running Unix/BSD under the hood.

53
00:02:50,750 --> 00:02:53,210
So it's running this BSD operating system.

54
00:02:53,210 --> 00:02:55,240
When you open up the terminal
that's what you're exposing,

55
00:02:55,240 --> 00:02:57,930
you see that BSD operating system,
and you can start to work with it.

56
00:02:57,930 --> 00:02:59,220
You can look at your files,

57
00:02:59,220 --> 00:03:03,410
change permissions do all that other good
stuff right here, from the terminal.

58
00:03:03,410 --> 00:03:08,960
What SSH does is it allows you to open up
a terminal like this, on a remote server,

59
00:03:08,960 --> 00:03:13,350
so you can start working on that
other system as if you were there.

60
00:03:13,350 --> 00:03:15,870
And from that command line,
SSH is a great way to do it.

61
00:03:15,870 --> 00:03:19,750
It's a fully encrypted session
between you and the other host.

62
00:03:21,920 --> 00:03:26,239
Another option that we have is enable
screen sharing and remote management.

63
00:03:27,240 --> 00:03:27,840
What is that?

64
00:03:27,840 --> 00:03:31,320
Well, screen sharing,
that's Apple screen sharing.

65
00:03:31,320 --> 00:03:34,950
All Mac OS systems have a VNC
server built into them.

66
00:03:34,950 --> 00:03:36,640
That's virtual network computing.

67
00:03:36,640 --> 00:03:38,510
It's a little screen sharing utility.

68
00:03:38,510 --> 00:03:42,390
If you've ever used Back to My Mac, or
the screen sharing feature in the Finder,

69
00:03:42,390 --> 00:03:43,390
that's what it's using.

70
00:03:43,390 --> 00:03:44,310
It's VNC.

71
00:03:44,310 --> 00:03:46,770
Now the authentication
mechanism is special on it, so

72
00:03:46,770 --> 00:03:50,300
it's not your normal VNC, but
that is basically what's built there, and

73
00:03:50,300 --> 00:03:53,310
you can turn on support for
normal VNC if you want.

74
00:03:53,310 --> 00:03:54,830
You can't do it here, through the GUI, but

75
00:03:54,830 --> 00:03:57,090
you can do it through some
of the other screens.

76
00:03:57,090 --> 00:03:59,230
So when you go to enable
remote management,

77
00:03:59,230 --> 00:04:02,440
if you just need the basic functionality,
this screen works out great, but

78
00:04:02,440 --> 00:04:05,700
there are some times that we do need to
jump back to the system preferences to set

79
00:04:05,700 --> 00:04:07,339
this stuff up, and
I'll show you why here in a moment.

80
00:04:08,820 --> 00:04:11,150
So if I want screen sharing,
I can turn that on.

81
00:04:11,150 --> 00:04:11,990
The other option,

82
00:04:11,990 --> 00:04:16,230
though, is one of the best, which is
allow remote administration using server.

83
00:04:16,230 --> 00:04:20,950
And what that means is, I can go to my
client and I can install the server app.

84
00:04:20,950 --> 00:04:25,680
And when I run the server app, instead
of setting up my laptop as a server,

85
00:04:25,680 --> 00:04:28,720
I can connect to other
servers that are out there.

86
00:04:28,720 --> 00:04:32,560
So maybe I have OSX-server1
all the way through server 99.

87
00:04:32,560 --> 00:04:38,310
I could connect to any one of them and
manage it all from within the server GUI.

88
00:04:38,310 --> 00:04:41,140
Without actually running
a server on my own laptop.

89
00:04:41,140 --> 00:04:42,390
That's the best way.

90
00:04:42,390 --> 00:04:47,260
The server app creates a secure connection
between the app on your system, and

91
00:04:47,260 --> 00:04:50,530
the actual server, and gives you
a nice communication means there.

92
00:04:50,530 --> 00:04:53,290
So it really does work out pretty well.

93
00:04:53,290 --> 00:04:56,430
The last option is,
enable Apple push notifications, and

94
00:04:56,430 --> 00:04:58,880
that's if you're doing management
through Apple's servers.

95
00:04:58,880 --> 00:05:02,270
If you've got this connected up to iCloud,
and you're using things like,

96
00:05:02,270 --> 00:05:06,460
Apple Remote Desktop, or the profile
manager linked up through Apple.

97
00:05:06,460 --> 00:05:09,520
You'll get push notifications when
your policies get updated and

98
00:05:09,520 --> 00:05:10,350
you need to enable that.

99
00:05:10,350 --> 00:05:11,730
I'm gonna leave that blank for

100
00:05:11,730 --> 00:05:14,390
right now because we'll deal with
that in the Profile Manager episodes.

101
00:05:16,160 --> 00:05:21,490
So now that I've got those set,
my server is ready to be remotely managed.

102
00:05:21,490 --> 00:05:25,050
I can jump over to a client and start
to connect and work with this server.

103
00:05:25,050 --> 00:05:28,490
So let's do that, let's run through each
of these and kind of see what happened.

104
00:05:28,490 --> 00:05:33,220
So if I jump over, here's my client,
and I'll start with Terminal.

105
00:05:33,220 --> 00:05:34,380
So I'm gonna open up Terminal.

106
00:05:34,380 --> 00:05:37,840
Whoops, I'm gonna open up
Dictionary cuz I can't type.

107
00:05:37,840 --> 00:05:41,560
There we go [LAUGH].
So I'm gonna up the Terminal, and

108
00:05:42,690 --> 00:05:45,370
by default,
you are logged into your own system,

109
00:05:45,370 --> 00:05:47,980
so if I do host name,
I can see I'm on Helps-iMac.

110
00:05:47,980 --> 00:05:52,340
Help Desk was the first account I created,
so this machine's called Helps iMac.

111
00:05:52,340 --> 00:05:57,910
So I'm right here, I'm my own client,
but I can type SSH followed

112
00:05:57,910 --> 00:06:03,620
by a username, @, and then the IP address
of the server that I want to connect to.

113
00:06:03,620 --> 00:06:08,050
So Help Desk is the username I'm
gonna use, and then 10.1.230.248,

114
00:06:08,050 --> 00:06:10,086
that's the IP address of the server.

115
00:06:10,086 --> 00:06:13,056
If it's got a DNS name attached,
you can do the DNS name also,

116
00:06:13,056 --> 00:06:14,550
whichever one you want.

117
00:06:14,550 --> 00:06:16,336
I'm doing the IP.

118
00:06:16,336 --> 00:06:21,560
Now it's gonna build a secure, encrypted
tunnel between me and the other side.

119
00:06:21,560 --> 00:06:25,640
Now when you installed the server app,
it created a self signed certificate.

120
00:06:25,640 --> 00:06:27,380
And we've got an episode
on certificates coming up.

121
00:06:27,380 --> 00:06:28,830
So we'll cover it more later.

122
00:06:28,830 --> 00:06:32,710
But it's downloading that certificate and
it's saying do you trust that certificate?

123
00:06:32,710 --> 00:06:33,860
Is it somebody you know?

124
00:06:33,860 --> 00:06:35,836
And I'll say yes, I trust it.

125
00:06:35,836 --> 00:06:40,180
It's gonna add it to my system, and
now it's asking for my password.

126
00:06:40,180 --> 00:06:42,270
So I'll punch in the password for
the help desk account.

127
00:06:43,530 --> 00:06:47,340
And now I'm connected up,
and notice my prompt.

128
00:06:47,340 --> 00:06:49,063
It's showing up that I'm
on that other server, and

129
00:06:49,063 --> 00:06:51,100
I can use the host name
command to verify that.

130
00:06:51,100 --> 00:06:56,110
I'm on that server, and I can start
doing work as if I was on that server.

131
00:06:56,110 --> 00:07:00,480
If I change to Desktop,
and I create a file,

132
00:07:00,480 --> 00:07:06,740
like notes.txt, and I edit that file,
and I'll put something in it.

133
00:07:07,860 --> 00:07:09,490
So this is a test.

134
00:07:11,090 --> 00:07:12,720
I used the Vie editor.

135
00:07:12,720 --> 00:07:16,400
The Vie editor's actually running
over there on the other server.

136
00:07:16,400 --> 00:07:17,580
It's not running here for me.

137
00:07:17,580 --> 00:07:22,320
It's running on the other server, and I'm
just gonna save that file real quick but

138
00:07:22,320 --> 00:07:23,910
I'm gonna keep it open.

139
00:07:23,910 --> 00:07:26,590
If I jump back over to the server.

140
00:07:26,590 --> 00:07:28,780
Whoops.
[LAUGH] There we go.

141
00:07:28,780 --> 00:07:30,660
I'm gonna give everybody motion sickness.

142
00:07:30,660 --> 00:07:33,600
And then after that if I
jump back over to my server.

143
00:07:33,600 --> 00:07:34,795
I can see right here, on my desktop.

144
00:07:34,795 --> 00:07:36,040
Notes.txt appeared.

145
00:07:36,040 --> 00:07:37,820
That came from the remote client.

146
00:07:37,820 --> 00:07:39,190
That put it in there.

147
00:07:39,190 --> 00:07:43,170
And if I pull up my activity monitor,
and I start diving into my processes.

148
00:07:43,170 --> 00:07:45,920
I will find a process in here somewhere.

149
00:07:45,920 --> 00:07:50,880
Which will show my terminal session
that's open from that client.

150
00:07:50,880 --> 00:07:52,450
The VTY that's being built up.

151
00:07:52,450 --> 00:07:53,895
This virtual connection
that is coming across.

152
00:07:53,895 --> 00:07:57,960
So these are sessions that
are coming in from that client.

153
00:07:57,960 --> 00:08:00,003
If I go into my own terminal.

154
00:08:00,003 --> 00:08:02,540
And let's see if I can
remember the command for this.

155
00:08:02,540 --> 00:08:06,310
I think it ps -aux, nope no x.

156
00:08:06,310 --> 00:08:08,351
Oops, well, ps -a.

157
00:08:10,768 --> 00:08:14,018
There we go, ps -ax,
I knew I'd hit it after 10 or 20 tries.

158
00:08:14,018 --> 00:08:18,635
This is the Unix command that shows all
the processes that are running, and

159
00:08:18,635 --> 00:08:22,120
notice I see a process right here,
vi./notes.txt.

160
00:08:22,120 --> 00:08:23,660
I'm not running that.

161
00:08:23,660 --> 00:08:25,030
Well, technically I am.

162
00:08:25,030 --> 00:08:26,900
I'm running it from that remote session.

163
00:08:26,900 --> 00:08:30,470
And so it shows up it's running in
the background on this server, and

164
00:08:30,470 --> 00:08:32,820
that's the client that's doing it.

165
00:08:32,820 --> 00:08:34,160
So that's SSH.

166
00:08:34,160 --> 00:08:35,460
Pretty easy to get setup,

167
00:08:35,460 --> 00:08:40,500
really works well if you're just trying
to get command line access to the server.

168
00:08:41,780 --> 00:08:43,010
But what if I want more?

169
00:08:43,010 --> 00:08:44,270
What if I want screen sharing?

170
00:08:44,270 --> 00:08:46,690
I want to actually see the screen
to that remote computer.

171
00:08:47,770 --> 00:08:49,850
Well, I turned that option on.

172
00:08:49,850 --> 00:08:53,350
So if I go into the Finder, in my Finder,

173
00:08:53,350 --> 00:08:56,960
it should find OS X server
one on the network.

174
00:08:56,960 --> 00:08:58,400
There it is.

175
00:08:58,400 --> 00:09:02,460
And if I choose it, the share screen
button is right there, and I can

176
00:09:02,460 --> 00:09:07,002
hit share screen and it's gonna connect to
it and try to display that screen for me.

177
00:09:07,002 --> 00:09:11,260
I'm gonna have to punch in my username and
password for the other system.

178
00:09:11,260 --> 00:09:12,810
So I'll punch that in.

179
00:09:12,810 --> 00:09:13,830
And hit connect.

180
00:09:13,830 --> 00:09:17,670
It's gonna connect to that server, and
it's gonna display its screen right here.

181
00:09:17,670 --> 00:09:20,640
Now it's just like I'm sitting
in front of that machine.

182
00:09:20,640 --> 00:09:24,180
That machine might not have a keyboard
attached, it might not have a mouse,

183
00:09:24,180 --> 00:09:25,580
it might not have a monitor.

184
00:09:25,580 --> 00:09:28,630
But I see it, and I'm able to work
with it right here from my laptop

185
00:09:28,630 --> 00:09:30,520
as if I were sitting at that machine.

186
00:09:30,520 --> 00:09:32,600
That's the nice part about screen sharing.

187
00:09:32,600 --> 00:09:33,130
Okay?

188
00:09:33,130 --> 00:09:38,710
So pretty straightforward there
getting connected for that.

189
00:09:38,710 --> 00:09:42,130
But the best one is to
actually use the server app.

190
00:09:42,130 --> 00:09:43,930
And I turned that option on too.

191
00:09:43,930 --> 00:09:50,200
So here on my client, if I just run the
server app, well when you run the server

192
00:09:50,200 --> 00:09:54,850
app, the default option is to hit continue
and set this machine up as a server.

193
00:09:54,850 --> 00:09:57,510
Well I don't wanna be a server,
I'm on my laptop.

194
00:09:57,510 --> 00:09:59,450
I wanna connect to a server.

195
00:09:59,450 --> 00:10:02,470
And so you've got that button over here,
Other Mac.

196
00:10:02,470 --> 00:10:05,570
You can choose that, and
it will browse the network and

197
00:10:05,570 --> 00:10:07,810
give you a list of
the servers that it found.

198
00:10:07,810 --> 00:10:12,060
It found my other server, and
I can choose that and hit continue.

199
00:10:12,060 --> 00:10:14,290
And it's gonna ask for
a user name and a password.

200
00:10:14,290 --> 00:10:16,630
So I will provide my credentials.

201
00:10:17,750 --> 00:10:19,280
And then it's gonna connect up.

202
00:10:19,280 --> 00:10:23,900
And I will be in the server GUI without
actually being a server myself.

203
00:10:23,900 --> 00:10:25,960
Now if pulling that certificate.

204
00:10:25,960 --> 00:10:28,490
And again, we'll cover the certificates
in the certificate episode.

205
00:10:28,490 --> 00:10:30,530
But it's asking do I
trust that certificate.

206
00:10:30,530 --> 00:10:32,270
I am gonna go ahead and
hit continue because I do.

207
00:10:33,690 --> 00:10:36,606
And now, it's gonna reach out to it,
connect, and,

208
00:10:36,606 --> 00:10:40,760
eventually [LAUGH] I'll see the GUI.

209
00:10:40,760 --> 00:10:43,540
What it's doing is it's building
up that secure encrypted tunnel

210
00:10:43,540 --> 00:10:45,020
between my system and the other side.

211
00:10:45,020 --> 00:10:47,250
And it takes it a moment to build that up.

212
00:10:47,250 --> 00:10:50,410
Once it's done, the GUI will come up and
I'll be managing.

213
00:10:50,410 --> 00:10:54,930
Now Apple recommends,
that you don't manage the same server.

214
00:10:54,930 --> 00:10:56,790
From more than one
client at the same time,

215
00:10:56,790 --> 00:11:00,780
cuz people can start to make changes and
bump into each other.

216
00:11:00,780 --> 00:11:03,690
But if I'm the only one working,
I can connect up to it and get to work.

217
00:11:03,690 --> 00:11:08,340
It actually won't stop you from using more
than one client at the same time, but

218
00:11:08,340 --> 00:11:11,200
think about what would happen if,
I was configuring DNS, and

219
00:11:11,200 --> 00:11:14,670
you were configuring DNS at the same time,
we might overwrite each other settings,

220
00:11:14,670 --> 00:11:16,170
so that's why they make
that recommendation.

221
00:11:17,630 --> 00:11:20,260
All right, well, I'm getting a little
impatient waiting for that one to connect.

222
00:11:20,260 --> 00:11:23,340
So while I'm waiting,
let's talk about something else.

223
00:11:23,340 --> 00:11:27,630
When I turned on this functionality,
I went into the server app and

224
00:11:27,630 --> 00:11:28,740
I configured it in here.

225
00:11:28,740 --> 00:11:31,750
I went to settings and
I turned the options on all right here.

226
00:11:32,790 --> 00:11:35,240
But I didn't have to do it from here,

227
00:11:35,240 --> 00:11:37,300
I could have done it
from system preferences.

228
00:11:37,300 --> 00:11:39,360
This is certainly
the easiest way to do it.

229
00:11:39,360 --> 00:11:41,300
I just checked three boxes and I was done.

230
00:11:41,300 --> 00:11:42,340
Right?

231
00:11:42,340 --> 00:11:45,670
But if I want to do anything advanced,
I need to go and

232
00:11:45,670 --> 00:11:46,830
do it from System Preferences.

233
00:11:46,830 --> 00:11:48,260
Now, what do I mean by advanced?

234
00:11:48,260 --> 00:11:49,900
Well, I mean permissions.

235
00:11:49,900 --> 00:11:53,930
When I turned this on, did it ask me
who was gonna be allowed to use SSH?

236
00:11:53,930 --> 00:11:57,070
Did it ask who was gonna be
allowed to use Screen Sharing or

237
00:11:57,070 --> 00:11:59,110
who was gonna be allowed
to use the server app?

238
00:11:59,110 --> 00:12:01,690
No, it used some default permissions.

239
00:12:01,690 --> 00:12:05,900
If I wanna tweak those permissions in any
way, I need to do it from the server app.

240
00:12:05,900 --> 00:12:08,330
Okay?
I need to jump over and do it from there.

241
00:12:08,330 --> 00:12:11,018
So I'm gonna go into
my System Preferences.

242
00:12:12,690 --> 00:12:16,760
And in my System Preferences
these settings are under Sharing.

243
00:12:16,760 --> 00:12:20,450
And if I go under Sharing, you'll see
the different things that we can share.

244
00:12:20,450 --> 00:12:24,720
And see how it turned on,
remote login and remote management.

245
00:12:24,720 --> 00:12:26,010
Those weren't on before.

246
00:12:26,010 --> 00:12:28,340
I know I didn't show it, but
the default is they're all turned off.

247
00:12:28,340 --> 00:12:29,380
That's how I know.

248
00:12:29,380 --> 00:12:31,820
And so, remote login was turned on.

249
00:12:31,820 --> 00:12:33,518
Well, that was SSH.

250
00:12:33,518 --> 00:12:38,810
To login to this computer remotely,
type in SSH Help Desk at 10.1.230.248.

251
00:12:38,810 --> 00:12:39,770
That's exactly what I typed, right?

252
00:12:40,800 --> 00:12:45,972
And allow access for anyone in the
administrators group, that's the default.

253
00:12:45,972 --> 00:12:49,550
All right, maybe I don't want
it to just be administrators.

254
00:12:49,550 --> 00:12:51,800
Maybe I want it to be a specific person.

255
00:12:51,800 --> 00:12:54,190
Or a couple of specific people.

256
00:12:54,190 --> 00:12:56,670
If I want it to be more
than just administrators,

257
00:12:56,670 --> 00:12:58,522
I've got to come in to
the system preference to do it.

258
00:12:58,522 --> 00:13:00,510
All right, that's one of
the main reasons we come in here.

259
00:13:01,700 --> 00:13:03,570
On remote management, same thing.

260
00:13:03,570 --> 00:13:05,643
Right?
We've got where we can tailor the users.

261
00:13:05,643 --> 00:13:09,540
And see under remote management,
how it only approved help desk.

262
00:13:09,540 --> 00:13:11,670
It didn't even approve
the administrators group.

263
00:13:11,670 --> 00:13:15,990
So if I want to approve that group,
then I'd need to come in here to add.

264
00:13:15,990 --> 00:13:17,710
And I can come in and
I can add that group.

265
00:13:17,710 --> 00:13:19,600
Now notice the groups don't show up.

266
00:13:19,600 --> 00:13:22,330
Well, apparently that group is
not supported on this screen.

267
00:13:22,330 --> 00:13:25,680
So if I had other administrators I would
need to pick them individually and

268
00:13:25,680 --> 00:13:26,490
add them to the list.

269
00:13:26,490 --> 00:13:27,450
All right?

270
00:13:27,450 --> 00:13:30,560
Different services have different
features that are configured.

271
00:13:30,560 --> 00:13:33,490
So we might have to come in and
modify those, all right.

272
00:13:33,490 --> 00:13:34,830
So changing permissions.

273
00:13:34,830 --> 00:13:37,410
That's the number one reason we'd
need to go to system preferences.

274
00:13:37,410 --> 00:13:39,720
The other one is on the screen sharing.

275
00:13:39,720 --> 00:13:43,140
Remember how I mentioned that Apple
devices have VNC built into them.

276
00:13:43,140 --> 00:13:44,710
But it's not quite the normal VNC.

277
00:13:44,710 --> 00:13:47,470
It's got some extra
authentication stuff stuck on it.

278
00:13:47,470 --> 00:13:49,530
What if I want to use regular VNC?

279
00:13:49,530 --> 00:13:50,860
I have some Windows clients or

280
00:13:50,860 --> 00:13:53,400
Linux clients that I wanna be able
to remotely manage the system.

281
00:13:53,400 --> 00:13:55,280
Well they can't use the Apple stuff.

282
00:13:55,280 --> 00:13:57,440
So I might need to enable the regular VNC.

283
00:13:57,440 --> 00:14:01,940
And for that you've gotta do it right
here through the system preference.

284
00:14:01,940 --> 00:14:05,950
If you go up here to screen sharing,
notice how it's telling me screen sharing

285
00:14:05,950 --> 00:14:09,640
is currently being controlled by
the Remote Management service,

286
00:14:09,640 --> 00:14:13,690
Remote Management down here is
providing that screen sharing service.

287
00:14:14,990 --> 00:14:17,260
And if you take a look at
your computer settings,

288
00:14:17,260 --> 00:14:20,160
right in here you'll see the VNC options.

289
00:14:20,160 --> 00:14:23,550
And we can say, VNC viewers may
control screen with password.

290
00:14:23,550 --> 00:14:27,310
And we just need to provide a password for
that client to use.

291
00:14:27,310 --> 00:14:31,750
You plug it in, and now a Windows or a
Linux box can use whatever VNC client they

292
00:14:31,750 --> 00:14:36,320
get, pointed at this server and provide
that passport, and they'll see the screen.

293
00:14:36,320 --> 00:14:39,680
Because they can't run the server app,
they don't have the Screen Sharing or

294
00:14:39,680 --> 00:14:42,240
Back to My Mac features,
they don't have any of that.

295
00:14:42,240 --> 00:14:43,490
They just need to use regular VNC.

296
00:14:43,490 --> 00:14:46,110
So you've got that option right there.

297
00:14:46,110 --> 00:14:47,870
You got a few other options
in here that are kinda neat,

298
00:14:47,870 --> 00:14:50,620
like the Show Remote Management Status
menu bar.

299
00:14:50,620 --> 00:14:53,090
That's a nice one, cause you can
see when people are connected,

300
00:14:53,090 --> 00:14:55,250
to know if somebody's actually
working with your system.

301
00:14:57,270 --> 00:15:00,190
So I'll go and hit OK on that, and
now we've customized those settings

302
00:15:00,190 --> 00:15:03,200
a little more, but those are all things
that we can't do from the server app, but

303
00:15:03,200 --> 00:15:04,840
we have to do here,
from system preferences.

304
00:15:04,840 --> 00:15:07,720
All right,
let's go see if my client ever connected.

305
00:15:07,720 --> 00:15:08,230
Oh, it did.

306
00:15:08,230 --> 00:15:09,100
There we go.

307
00:15:09,100 --> 00:15:11,450
The first time you connect it
does take a little bit longer.

308
00:15:11,450 --> 00:15:12,810
There it goes.
It's connected.

309
00:15:12,810 --> 00:15:16,760
I'm on my client but
I'm working with server one.

310
00:15:16,760 --> 00:15:19,010
And so now I see all the different
settings, if I want to go and

311
00:15:19,010 --> 00:15:22,500
manage DNS, here's the DNS settings for
server one.

312
00:15:22,500 --> 00:15:24,940
And I can go in here and
I can start to adjust some of this.

313
00:15:24,940 --> 00:15:27,430
I can say show all records and
I start to see my records.

314
00:15:27,430 --> 00:15:31,425
And now I'm working with that system
even though the system is remote.

315
00:15:31,425 --> 00:15:35,720
These are all different ways that we
can remotely manage that server, or

316
00:15:35,720 --> 00:15:39,690
a group of servers, because you may
have many, many different servers.

317
00:15:39,690 --> 00:15:42,432
Here we just fire up the appropriate tool,
and we get connected.

318
00:15:42,432 --> 00:15:45,643
Really straightforward and
pretty neat stuff, all right.

319
00:15:45,643 --> 00:15:49,341
One word of caution, if you turn
on the firewall inside of Mac OS,

320
00:15:49,341 --> 00:15:52,518
it is possible to block some
of these services, right.

321
00:15:52,518 --> 00:15:55,198
SSH uses TCP port 22.

322
00:15:55,198 --> 00:15:57,915
VNC uses TCP port 5900.

323
00:15:57,915 --> 00:16:01,362
Each of these services use different
port numbers to communicate.

324
00:16:01,362 --> 00:16:03,210
So, if you turn on the firewall,

325
00:16:03,210 --> 00:16:07,650
you need to make sure you approve
the server app to communicate through it.

326
00:16:07,650 --> 00:16:09,490
Otherwise these start to get blocked.

327
00:16:09,490 --> 00:16:10,600
And that's pretty straightforward.

328
00:16:10,600 --> 00:16:15,400
If I go back to my server and I go to
my System Preferences, if I go into

329
00:16:15,400 --> 00:16:21,120
System Preferences and Security and
Privacy, I can go to firewall.

330
00:16:21,120 --> 00:16:24,530
And if I turn that firewall on,
let me just unlock this real quick.

331
00:16:26,780 --> 00:16:31,680
If I turn that firewall on, I'll be able
to approve software to pass through it.

332
00:16:31,680 --> 00:16:36,250
And if I look at my software see how it's
already added SSH, remote management,

333
00:16:36,250 --> 00:16:37,400
screen sharing.

334
00:16:37,400 --> 00:16:39,520
Well that was the server
app GUI that did that.

335
00:16:39,520 --> 00:16:41,355
It added each of those for me.

336
00:16:41,355 --> 00:16:42,370
Okay?

337
00:16:42,370 --> 00:16:45,900
So it's got them in there and
they're set to allow, right?

338
00:16:45,900 --> 00:16:49,830
After that it's saying automatically
allow signed software to receive incoming

339
00:16:49,830 --> 00:16:53,140
communications while your server
app is signed software so

340
00:16:53,140 --> 00:16:55,130
it's going to be able to receive that.

341
00:16:55,130 --> 00:16:59,470
But if you've turned that option off,
now our server app is getting blocked.

342
00:16:59,470 --> 00:17:03,890
And so we need to add that in up here to
the list to make sure that it was allowed.

343
00:17:03,890 --> 00:17:06,230
So you could come through here and
pick that server app, and

344
00:17:06,230 --> 00:17:10,420
get it kind of green light, or
green lit, green lighted, whatever.

345
00:17:10,420 --> 00:17:12,410
So it'll allow those communications.

346
00:17:12,410 --> 00:17:14,920
You can also specify other
things like DNS and so on,

347
00:17:14,920 --> 00:17:16,460
if you want to get really advanced.

348
00:17:16,460 --> 00:17:20,410
But you want to make sure you do
that option, so that it's approved.

349
00:17:20,410 --> 00:17:23,810
So just be aware that the firewall can
block communication for remote management.

350
00:17:26,310 --> 00:17:29,550
All right, you know I feel like there
was one other thing I needed to mention.

351
00:17:29,550 --> 00:17:31,630
And I can't seem to remember what it was.

352
00:17:31,630 --> 00:17:32,130
Shoot.

353
00:17:33,330 --> 00:17:35,480
Oh, I know what it was.

354
00:17:35,480 --> 00:17:40,900
Now, if we're planning on remote managing
a server, all right, the temptation is,

355
00:17:40,900 --> 00:17:46,150
when I build up a new server, to never
actually log into it locally at all.

356
00:17:46,150 --> 00:17:48,010
And unfortunately, you can't do that.

357
00:17:48,010 --> 00:17:53,020
If you try and fire up your server app and
connect to a server where you've never

358
00:17:53,020 --> 00:17:57,000
run the server app, not even a single
time, well it hasn't actually enabled

359
00:17:57,000 --> 00:18:00,310
any of the server services yet and
you won't be able to connect to it.

360
00:18:00,310 --> 00:18:03,780
So regardless of whether you plan to
remote manage it every now and then, or

361
00:18:03,780 --> 00:18:07,730
remote manage it all the time, you're
going to have to launch the server app

362
00:18:07,730 --> 00:18:10,850
on the physical server at least one time,
right?

363
00:18:10,850 --> 00:18:15,860
You launch it one time and hit continue
to start the server services, all right?

364
00:18:15,860 --> 00:18:17,820
Otherwise, they're not
even gonna be in there.

365
00:18:17,820 --> 00:18:21,660
So the very first time, you do have
to log in to the actual server box,

366
00:18:21,660 --> 00:18:24,940
run the server app, and turn on whatever
management options you want, and

367
00:18:24,940 --> 00:18:27,930
from then on, you can manage it remotely.

368
00:18:27,930 --> 00:18:29,190
Just remember that for the exam.

369
00:18:29,190 --> 00:18:31,480
If they have a server that's
never launched the server app,

370
00:18:31,480 --> 00:18:32,620
you're not gonna be able
to remote manage it.

371
00:18:33,770 --> 00:18:35,880
So, a couple of key
things to remember there.

372
00:18:35,880 --> 00:18:38,730
But otherwise, pretty straightforward,
and easy to do.

373
00:18:38,730 --> 00:18:41,350
So, I'll tell you, I've worked in
a number of environments where we had

374
00:18:41,350 --> 00:18:44,120
hundreds of servers in server rooms.

375
00:18:44,120 --> 00:18:47,200
And the server rooms had loud
air conditioning units and

376
00:18:47,200 --> 00:18:48,330
uncomfortable chairs.

377
00:18:48,330 --> 00:18:50,960
And you didn't want to be in that
server room if you didn't have to.

378
00:18:50,960 --> 00:18:55,690
So, to be able to sit in the comfort of
your own office, with no giant fans and

379
00:18:55,690 --> 00:18:57,480
air conditioners running near you,

380
00:18:57,480 --> 00:19:01,180
you launch your app right here on your
desktop, and you manage those servers.

381
00:19:01,180 --> 00:19:02,270
It's really nice.

382
00:19:02,270 --> 00:19:05,965
And being able to quickly and easily jump
between those servers is even nicer.

383
00:19:05,965 --> 00:19:09,100
Cause if you walk into a server
room with a thousand servers,

384
00:19:09,100 --> 00:19:12,940
which rack has OSX-server112?

385
00:19:12,940 --> 00:19:15,430
Which server is it in that rack?

386
00:19:15,430 --> 00:19:17,960
Just finding a server can
be challenging sometimes.

387
00:19:17,960 --> 00:19:20,485
Doing it logically like
this makes life a lot easy.

388
00:19:21,950 --> 00:19:24,040
All right,
well that's about it on remote management.

389
00:19:24,040 --> 00:19:27,880
We did see a little about certificates
right there, and I definitely want you

390
00:19:27,880 --> 00:19:30,920
guys to stay tuned cause we're gonna
do a whole episode on certificates.

391
00:19:30,920 --> 00:19:33,520
There's ways that we can do trusted
certificates where we don't get those

392
00:19:33,520 --> 00:19:35,490
warnings, we just
automatically trust them.

393
00:19:35,490 --> 00:19:38,240
So we'll get a chance to see
that in a followup episode,

394
00:19:38,240 --> 00:19:40,140
definitely stay tuned for that.

395
00:19:40,140 --> 00:19:42,210
But this is a good point
to wrap this episode up,

396
00:19:42,210 --> 00:19:44,050
so let me just remind you guys.

397
00:19:44,050 --> 00:19:48,240
If you have any questions on what I
talked about, please feel free to ask.

398
00:19:48,240 --> 00:19:49,060
Live during the show,

399
00:19:49,060 --> 00:19:53,900
you can go to itpro.tv/live and you'll see
the chat room right beneath the video.

400
00:19:53,900 --> 00:19:57,620
Post your questions there, and
I monitor and answer during the show.

401
00:19:57,620 --> 00:20:00,900
If you have questions after
the show use our Q&A forums.

402
00:20:00,900 --> 00:20:04,039
At the top of every page on ITProTV
you'll see a link that says Q&A,

403
00:20:04,039 --> 00:20:08,030
it'll take you to the forums, you can post
your questions there and we monitor and

404
00:20:08,030 --> 00:20:09,480
answer after the show.

405
00:20:09,480 --> 00:20:12,360
It's a great way to get answers to your
questions so take advantage of that.

406
00:20:13,510 --> 00:20:15,280
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

407
00:20:15,280 --> 00:20:19,520
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the various uses for certificates in Mac OS X Server. He demonstrates the self-signed certificates created by the Server App, as well as the process for securing publicly trusted certificates for use in Server App services
episodes.title: Certificates
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:32,962 --> 00:00:36,201
All right good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:36,201 --> 00:00:38,390
Welcome back to another
episode to ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,390 --> 00:00:40,410
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,410 --> 00:00:44,470
Back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

6
00:00:44,470 --> 00:00:47,790
In this episode we're gonna
take a look at certificates.

7
00:00:47,790 --> 00:00:51,230
And certificates are a pretty important
part of any modern computer system but

8
00:00:51,230 --> 00:00:55,980
especially so on servers, because they
serve so many different purposes.

9
00:00:55,980 --> 00:00:58,860
Now before we dive into Apple's
implementation let's just talk a little

10
00:00:58,860 --> 00:01:02,380
bit about certificates themselves and
why we should care about them, right.

11
00:01:02,380 --> 00:01:04,590
It is very common today for

12
00:01:04,590 --> 00:01:07,870
us to transmit data across a network
that's of a sensitive nature, right.

13
00:01:07,870 --> 00:01:09,420
Now what do I mean by that?

14
00:01:09,420 --> 00:01:13,540
Well you know it could be things like
medical records or financial transactions

15
00:01:13,540 --> 00:01:17,680
but even putting that out of our mind,
simply your username and password, right.

16
00:01:17,680 --> 00:01:21,200
When you log into a website,
when you log into an email server.

17
00:01:21,200 --> 00:01:25,190
When you log into anything there's
a credential exchange that happens.

18
00:01:25,190 --> 00:01:28,070
You're having to send your username and
password, or

19
00:01:28,070 --> 00:01:32,270
a hash based on your password, across the
network to another server somewhere else,

20
00:01:32,270 --> 00:01:33,660
and they have to validate you.

21
00:01:33,660 --> 00:01:36,490
And to do that it needs to be secure.

22
00:01:36,490 --> 00:01:37,330
Well in the old days

23
00:01:37,330 --> 00:01:40,170
you could come up with all sorts of
proprietary technologies for that.

24
00:01:40,170 --> 00:01:43,480
But in today's world we need
provide services to people

25
00:01:43,480 --> 00:01:47,030
all over the globe that are running
different operating systems,

26
00:01:47,030 --> 00:01:50,130
different web browsers
different systems altogether.

27
00:01:50,130 --> 00:01:53,980
And we need something that works and
is nice and compatible across the board.

28
00:01:53,980 --> 00:01:57,440
And the way that's been
achieved is through the use of

29
00:01:57,440 --> 00:01:59,350
certificate based systems.

30
00:01:59,350 --> 00:02:01,820
A certificate,
it's an interesting idea, right.

31
00:02:03,130 --> 00:02:07,000
What it does, is it basically
creates a digital signature.

32
00:02:07,000 --> 00:02:09,650
And a digital signature is just
a string of letters and numbers,

33
00:02:09,650 --> 00:02:11,840
it's not anything too terribly fancy.

34
00:02:11,840 --> 00:02:17,350
But that string of letters and numbers can
be used as part of a mathematical formula.

35
00:02:17,350 --> 00:02:21,950
And you can take any data and
run it through this formula with that

36
00:02:21,950 --> 00:02:26,820
string of numbers and letters, and
it creates an all new set of data.

37
00:02:26,820 --> 00:02:29,140
You're encrypting the data.

38
00:02:29,140 --> 00:02:32,697
And somebody somewhere
else can decrypt the data,

39
00:02:32,697 --> 00:02:35,270
if they know the right string to use.

40
00:02:35,270 --> 00:02:38,510
The right letters and numbers to feed into
that formula to get the data back out.

41
00:02:39,550 --> 00:02:42,330
That's the basic principle
behind encryption.

42
00:02:42,330 --> 00:02:47,020
It's not a complex idea, it's very
complex if you're trying to break it, but

43
00:02:47,020 --> 00:02:50,080
the way that it actually works as far as
performing the encryption itself is pretty

44
00:02:50,080 --> 00:02:51,130
straightforward.

45
00:02:51,130 --> 00:02:54,490
So we need a system that's
able to do that for

46
00:02:54,490 --> 00:02:57,008
us and to do it on the fly where
it's invisible to the end user.

47
00:02:57,008 --> 00:03:00,300
And the certificate-based system

96
00:05:31,210 --> 00:05:33,490

00:05:33,490 --> 00:05:37,580

00:05:37,580 --> 00:05:40,580

numbers, and

99
00:05:40,580 --> 00:05:45,660

decrypt data.

100
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:47,070
The private key can do both, right.

101
00:05:47,070 --> 00:05:50,170
So it's a very powerful thing
because it can encrypt and decrypt.

102
00:05:50,170 --> 00:05:54,870
If somebody gets ahold of that private
key, they can decrypt your data, and that

103
00:05:54,870 --> 00:05:59,200
would be bad, right, they'd be able to see
everything that was being transmitted.

104
00:05:59,200 --> 00:06:01,480
But then they take that private key and

105
00:06:01,480 --> 00:06:04,280
based on that key they
generate a public key.

106
00:06:04,280 --> 00:06:09,780
So there's actually two keys involved
here, a private key and a public key,

107
00:06:09,780 --> 00:06:14,240
and the public key is only
capable of encrypting,

108
00:06:14,240 --> 00:06:17,220
it can't decrypt, it can just encrypt.

109
00:06:17,220 --> 00:06:21,790
So we can generate data, we can encrypt it
with that public key and send it to Apple.

110
00:06:21,790 --> 00:06:26,570
And then Apple can use their private
key and decrypt it and see the data.

111
00:06:26,570 --> 00:06:31,130
If somebody intercepts the data in
transit, they just see encrypted data,

112
00:06:31,130 --> 00:06:35,920
and if they steal the public key, well
great, that means they can encrypt things,

113
00:06:35,920 --> 00:06:38,830
but they can't decrypt, so
my data is safe, right.

114
00:06:38,830 --> 00:06:43,760
That's basically how these systems work,
is they're encrypting your data in a way

115
00:06:43,760 --> 00:06:48,470
that it can't be decrypted, except for
the person who you expect to get it.

116
00:06:48,470 --> 00:06:53,180
That's the basic function of doing

00:37:12,470 --> 00:37:16,560

00:37:42,650 --> 00:37:45,460

00:38:04,410 --> 00:38:08,340

All right.
Here I can change my bit length.

955
00:49:05,810 --> 00:49:08,930
It defaults to 2048 which is the
strongest, that's normally what we want,

956
00:49:08,930 --> 00:49:11,110
but you can use weaker bit
lengths if you need to.

957
00:49:11,110 --> 00:49:15,160
Not a great idea but you can you
can also choose your algorithm.

958
00:49:15,160 --> 00:49:17,484
RSA is the best one for right now,
so we'll normally stick with that.

959
00:49:19,056 --> 00:49:21,260
And then what it can be used for.

960
00:49:21,260 --> 00:49:25,410
Used for signatures, used for certificate
signing, encipher, decipher, right?

961
00:49:25,410 --> 00:49:27,370
You've got all sorts of
different options here.

962
00:49:27,370 --> 00:49:30,760
Because I told it web server earlier,
it's defaulted to the web server options,

963
00:49:30,760 --> 00:49:35,640
and that's good enough for me, but you can
specify what that's gonna be used for.

964
00:49:37,620 --> 00:49:40,440
And then when it's done.

965
00:49:40,440 --> 00:49:43,290
[LAUGH] There we go.

966
00:49:43,290 --> 00:49:45,520
When it's done,
it will generate the certificate for us.

967
00:49:45,520 --> 00:49:48,190
So it's just asking a couple more
questions here about constraints.

968
00:49:48,190 --> 00:49:51,350
Most of these are options that we don't
want to change, but you can go in and

969
00:49:51,350 --> 00:49:52,860
add things like extensions.

970
00:49:52,860 --> 00:49:55,080
Which are for custom use certificates.

971
00:49:55,080 --> 00:50:00,140
If you need special values attached in
there for custom use like, if you have RSA

972
00:50:00,140 --> 00:50:03,700
secure ID tokens, those little key chains
with the security codes that appear and

973
00:50:03,700 --> 00:50:07,180
disappear, those are use for
authentication mechanisms.

974
00:50:07,180 --> 00:50:08,920
They use certificates just like these,

975
00:50:08,920 --> 00:50:12,640
but they have special extensions on
them that support what their use is.

976
00:50:12,640 --> 00:50:13,840
I'm gonna leave these at the default,

977
00:50:13,840 --> 00:50:16,200
I don't wanna dive into
any of that crazy stuff.

978
00:50:16,200 --> 00:50:17,070
There we go.

979
00:50:17,070 --> 00:50:19,070
So now it's generated that certificate,
and

980
00:50:19,070 --> 00:50:21,640
I've got a new self signed certificate.

981
00:50:21,640 --> 00:50:24,810
It's warning here about whether or not I
want to add it to my key chain, and I do.

982
00:50:25,910 --> 00:50:30,850
And now I've got it right there,
www.lab.itpro.tv self signed.

983
00:50:30,850 --> 00:50:35,090
And I can tell my services, hey, I want
you guys to start using that certificate.

984
00:50:35,090 --> 00:50:40,490
Start using that one because it's the one
that's got this custom post name or

985
00:50:40,490 --> 00:50:42,050
whatever on it.

986
00:50:42,050 --> 00:50:46,211
So, pretty easy to work with these things,
you'll typically wanna go and buy one from

987
00:50:46,211 --> 00:50:49,982
an actual provider though to make sure
that everyone out there trusts them so.

988
00:50:51,993 --> 00:50:56,030
James in the chat room asked about can you
get a list of ciphers the server is using.

989
00:50:57,050 --> 00:51:00,920
From the GUI you can't, but
from the command line you can.

990
00:51:00,920 --> 00:51:02,840
And I know where you're going on that.

991
00:51:02,840 --> 00:51:08,910
We've had several exploits lately like the
Ghost was one of them, and what was the?

992
00:51:08,910 --> 00:51:13,030
I can't believe I'm forgetting it, the big
one that was just a few months ago.

993
00:51:13,030 --> 00:51:16,190
There have been a few exploits where
hackers have targeted the weaker

994
00:51:16,190 --> 00:51:17,800
ciphers of the server.

995
00:51:17,800 --> 00:51:20,340
Apple's been really good about
pushing patches out for that, so

996
00:51:20,340 --> 00:51:23,440
if you're up to date, they've already
trimmed off those weaker ciphers.

997
00:51:23,440 --> 00:51:27,020
But there is a command line utility
you can run to find that out.

998
00:51:27,020 --> 00:51:30,010
The Qualis scan guard has
a little script that you can use.

999
00:51:30,010 --> 00:51:30,890
There's a few others.

1000
00:51:30,890 --> 00:51:32,570
I'll try to find one and
put one in the show notes.

1001
00:51:32,570 --> 00:51:33,780
I don't have one off hand.

1002
00:51:33,780 --> 00:51:39,860
But you can drop to the terminal and you
can find that information right in there.

1003
00:51:39,860 --> 00:51:40,440
All right.
Well,

1004
00:51:40,440 --> 00:51:42,130
I think that's all I've
got on certificates.

1005
00:51:42,130 --> 00:51:44,380
Well let's see do I have anything else?

1006
00:51:44,380 --> 00:51:45,420
Yeah that's about it.

1007
00:51:45,420 --> 00:51:49,430
We are gonna revisit certificates later on
in the show as we start to do things like

1008
00:51:49,430 --> 00:51:54,750
open directory and some of the other
technologies that use SSL and

1009
00:51:54,750 --> 00:51:56,730
certificate based authentication.

1010
00:51:56,730 --> 00:51:59,460
So we'll get to see those a little
bit more, but for the most part

1011
00:51:59,460 --> 00:52:02,400
those are the certificate functions
they want you to know for the exam.

1012
00:52:03,672 --> 00:52:05,750
Al lright so
that's a good spot to wrap things up.

1013
00:52:05,750 --> 00:52:08,810
Let me remind you guys,
if you have questions on any of this,

1014
00:52:08,810 --> 00:52:13,437
live during the show you can jump into
our chatroom at http://itpro.tv/live, and

1015
00:52:13,437 --> 00:52:16,130
you'll see the chatroom
right beneath the video.

1016
00:52:16,130 --> 00:52:19,030
We love it when people jump in there and
post questions or answers.

1017
00:52:19,030 --> 00:52:19,790
James Heartbleed.

1018
00:52:19,790 --> 00:52:20,710
That's the one I was thinking of.

1019
00:52:20,710 --> 00:52:21,530
James just posted in there.

1020
00:52:21,530 --> 00:52:23,710
Heartbleed was the exploit
a few months ago.

1021
00:52:23,710 --> 00:52:28,170
That targeted weak SSL cyphers and
you want those disabled.

1022
00:52:28,170 --> 00:52:28,960
So those do happen.

1023
00:52:30,390 --> 00:52:33,850
So live during the show, make use of
that chatroom, it's a great resource.

1024
00:52:33,850 --> 00:52:36,580
If you're watching this recorded,
we also have the Q and A forums.

1025
00:52:36,580 --> 00:52:38,430
They're there to cover you
even when we're not live.

1026
00:52:38,430 --> 00:52:42,340
At the top of every page on itpro.tv
you'll see a link that says Q and A.

1027
00:52:42,340 --> 00:52:43,080
Click on it.

1028
00:52:43,080 --> 00:52:46,300
It'll you take into the forums,
you can post your questions there.

1029
00:52:46,300 --> 00:52:47,920
We monitor and answer after the show.

1030
00:52:47,920 --> 00:52:49,750
It's a great resource.

1031
00:52:49,750 --> 00:52:51,750
Make the best use of it.

1032
00:52:51,750 --> 00:52:53,770
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

1033
00:52:53,770 --> 00:52:57,963
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

1034
00:52:57,963 --> 00:53:07,963
[MUSIC]

1035
00:53:11,738 --> 00:53:17,335
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the three primary methods for monitoring an OS X Server to ensure it is online and healthy. He covers logging for past monitoring, statistics for real-time monitoring, and alerts for future monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring OS X Server
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:22,826 --> 00:00:33,243
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:33,243 --> 00:00:35,971
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

4
00:00:35,971 --> 00:00:38,200
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:38,200 --> 00:00:40,260
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

6
00:00:40,260 --> 00:00:44,850
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

7
00:00:44,850 --> 00:00:47,705
I'm so emotional about ACTC,
I'm getting choked up here.

8
00:00:47,705 --> 00:00:51,930
[LAUGH] That's the passion that
we bring [LAUGH] at ITProTV, or

9
00:00:51,930 --> 00:00:54,380
the fact that I can't swallow my
own spit in any orderly fashion.

10
00:00:54,380 --> 00:00:58,320
So [LAUGH] now let's jump
into our content today.

11
00:00:58,320 --> 00:01:02,240
We got a great episode cuz we're gonna
talk about monitoring our server, and

12
00:01:02,240 --> 00:01:04,760
let me tell you,
this is a really important piece.

13
00:01:04,760 --> 00:01:07,710
We spend a lot of time getting
servers set up, right.

14
00:01:07,710 --> 00:01:11,300
Getting all the services configured,
the security set, all the functions and

15
00:01:11,300 --> 00:01:13,390
software copied around and put in place.

16
00:01:13,390 --> 00:01:15,670
And then we turn it loose on the wild,
right.

17
00:01:15,670 --> 00:01:17,370
We let our end users get in there.

18
00:01:17,370 --> 00:01:21,720
And once the end users get in there, it is
amazing the amount of damage they can do,

19
00:01:21,720 --> 00:01:25,430
we need some way to keep an eye
on our server, to watch it,

20
00:01:25,430 --> 00:01:28,590
to make sure that things are moving the
way that they're supposed to be moving,

21
00:01:28,590 --> 00:01:31,930
and if things aren't,
if something's going wrong, ideally,

22
00:01:31,930 --> 00:01:34,890
we wanna know about it
before end users do.

23
00:01:34,890 --> 00:01:39,040
So we need some kind of systems in place
to do that, and Apple's thought of that.

24
00:01:39,040 --> 00:01:42,140
We have a lot of that right here
in our very own server app.

25
00:01:42,140 --> 00:01:44,190
So that's what we're gonna
look at in this episode.

26
00:01:44,190 --> 00:01:48,890
What are the tools that Apple
gives us to monitor our server.

27
00:01:48,890 --> 00:01:52,340
Now the way I look at it is, it's kind
of divided up into a few pieces, and

28
00:01:52,340 --> 00:01:56,420
it always reminds me of that
Charles Dickens, A Christmas Carol.

29
00:01:56,420 --> 00:01:57,600
Right, where you've got the.

30
00:01:57,600 --> 00:02:00,400
The ghost of Christmas past,
present, future.

31
00:02:00,400 --> 00:02:02,310
That's kind of how we monitor our servers,
right?

32
00:02:02,310 --> 00:02:04,620
So we'll be Ebenezer Scrooge for

33
00:02:04,620 --> 00:02:08,320
the episode and walk through
[LAUGH] our life in perspective.

34
00:02:08,320 --> 00:02:11,290
And we'll start with that ghost
of Christmas past, right?

35
00:02:11,290 --> 00:02:15,520
How do we see what's already
happened on our server?

36
00:02:15,520 --> 00:02:16,790
You get a call from a user and

37
00:02:16,790 --> 00:02:21,310
they say, hey I can't log into my email,
or is the server down.

38
00:02:21,310 --> 00:02:22,330
I can't get into it.

39
00:02:22,330 --> 00:02:24,740
Right.
How do we look to see what happened?

40
00:02:24,740 --> 00:02:26,070
Some problem happened.

41
00:02:26,070 --> 00:02:27,400
And this is the thing with problems.

42
00:02:27,400 --> 00:02:28,640
A lot of times they're intermittent.

43
00:02:28,640 --> 00:02:30,990
The problem happened, and now it's gone.

44
00:02:30,990 --> 00:02:32,660
Hey, Don, last night I
couldn't get into the website.

45
00:02:32,660 --> 00:02:33,580
This morning it's working fine.

46
00:02:34,800 --> 00:02:35,560
Okay?
Great,

47
00:02:35,560 --> 00:02:37,430
well let me go look at what's wrong.

48
00:02:37,430 --> 00:02:40,800
Website looks just fine to me,
I guess it was a glitch or a fluke.

49
00:02:40,800 --> 00:02:43,500
Well wouldn't it be nice
to look into the past?

50
00:02:43,500 --> 00:02:47,460
See the past of our server and what the
world would be like without them [LAUGH].

51
00:02:47,460 --> 00:02:52,109
So we can do that using the logging
system, right, inside of our server app.

52
00:02:52,109 --> 00:02:56,273
Let's take a look at this server that I've
got, so here is my server that I bought up

53
00:02:56,273 --> 00:03:00,140
for the show, and right here into
the servers section, you'll see alerts,

54
00:03:00,140 --> 00:03:02,340
certificates, logs, and stats.

55
00:03:02,340 --> 00:03:04,570
I'm concerned about logs.

56
00:03:04,570 --> 00:03:08,400
If I go to logs,
I'm gonna see the log files for my system.

57
00:03:08,400 --> 00:03:11,340
What's going on in my system,
not just now.

58
00:03:11,340 --> 00:03:12,880
But in the past.

59
00:03:12,880 --> 00:03:15,930
This is my way to see where
the server has been in the past.

60
00:03:15,930 --> 00:03:18,500
And if somebody says, hey last night
at 3 AM things weren't working so

61
00:03:18,500 --> 00:03:20,630
well I can jump in here.

62
00:03:20,630 --> 00:03:22,163
And I can look at these log messages.

63
00:03:22,163 --> 00:03:24,120
And I can see right here, 10:59 AM.

64
00:03:24,120 --> 00:03:26,090
That's what time it is right now.

65
00:03:26,090 --> 00:03:31,570
So if I start scrolling back, I can look
to see what was going on earlier, right?

66
00:03:31,570 --> 00:03:33,030
And even days in the past.

67
00:03:33,030 --> 00:03:36,130
Today is March 10th, but
I am now back into March 9th.

68
00:03:36,130 --> 00:03:38,730
And go back even further and
see those previous days.

69
00:03:38,730 --> 00:03:39,900
There's March 8th.

70
00:03:39,900 --> 00:03:41,110
And see what was going on.

71
00:03:41,110 --> 00:03:41,680
So hey,

72
00:03:41,680 --> 00:03:45,150
last night at 10 o'clock I was trying
to get to the website and I couldn't.

73
00:03:45,150 --> 00:03:48,630
Well, let me go back here to
10 o'clock last night, and

74
00:03:48,630 --> 00:03:50,520
see what log messages were generated.

75
00:03:50,520 --> 00:03:53,070
The log messages can often steer
us in the right direction,

76
00:03:53,070 --> 00:03:55,510
telling us where there's a problem.

77
00:03:55,510 --> 00:03:59,720
Now these log messages,
are no different than the ones displayed

78
00:03:59,720 --> 00:04:04,580
in the console app that's a part of
Mac OS, even if you're not running server.

79
00:04:04,580 --> 00:04:07,930
So even if you're not running server you
can just launch console, and you can get

80
00:04:07,930 --> 00:04:11,520
into all of these various logs,
they're all just buried away in here.

81
00:04:11,520 --> 00:04:15,390
The difference though, is here you
have to know what you're looking for.

82
00:04:15,390 --> 00:04:19,830
So like if I want to look for a website
problem, when I go into the console log,

83
00:04:19,830 --> 00:04:22,980
I have to know that the website
is actually powered by Apache.

84
00:04:22,980 --> 00:04:26,140
And I can drill down and I can find
Apache, and I can start to take a look at

85
00:04:26,140 --> 00:04:29,450
the error logs for my Apache server,
which is surprisingly full.

86
00:04:29,450 --> 00:04:32,520
Looks like I've got quite a bit
of problems [LAUGH] in mine.

87
00:04:32,520 --> 00:04:35,170
So you can jump in there and
see that information and

88
00:04:35,170 --> 00:04:36,460
start to troubleshoot it out.

89
00:04:36,460 --> 00:04:39,890
Well the server app makes it a lot easier.

90
00:04:39,890 --> 00:04:42,480
At the bottom of the server app,
there's this drop down box.

91
00:04:42,480 --> 00:04:43,270
And you can click on it.

92
00:04:43,270 --> 00:04:46,410
And that lets you pick
the log you want to look at.

93
00:04:46,410 --> 00:04:51,460
The default log, the one that it goes into
right here, is called the system log.

94
00:04:51,460 --> 00:04:54,690
And that's a log for the whole system,
for the whole operating system.

95
00:04:54,690 --> 00:04:56,570
You get a lot of data in there.

96
00:04:56,570 --> 00:04:58,220
Some of it related to server.

97
00:04:58,220 --> 00:04:59,730
Some of it not.

98
00:04:59,730 --> 00:05:02,410
The rest of this let's us filter it down.

99
00:05:02,410 --> 00:05:03,540
All right.

100
00:05:03,540 --> 00:05:04,720
See these grey entries?

101
00:05:04,720 --> 00:05:06,880
The grey entries are a category name.

102
00:05:06,880 --> 00:05:10,650
So I've got a category called DNS,
a category called file sharing.

103
00:05:10,650 --> 00:05:15,190
And inside of those categories,
I may have one or more logs.

104
00:05:15,190 --> 00:05:19,450
When I look at DHCP,
all I have is a service log and that's it.

105
00:05:19,450 --> 00:05:22,660
But when I look at profile manager,
I've got a migration log,

106
00:05:22,660 --> 00:05:25,200
a server helper log and service log.

107
00:05:25,200 --> 00:05:27,210
Normally it's the service
log that we want.

108
00:05:27,210 --> 00:05:30,770
That's the log messages for
all the stuff that that server has done,

109
00:05:30,770 --> 00:05:34,840
if you don't see any logs, that usually
means that service isn't turned on.

110
00:05:34,840 --> 00:05:39,900
So if I don't see any DNS logs,
I'm probably not running DNS.

111
00:05:39,900 --> 00:05:41,450
But if I go over here and I turn it on,

112
00:05:41,450 --> 00:05:45,700
so I go under Advanced > DNS and
I'll turn that on.

113
00:05:45,700 --> 00:05:49,020
No that I've turned on DNS,
it's gonna start logging.

114
00:05:49,020 --> 00:05:54,080
And when I go back up here to my logs,
I'll be able to hit that drop down box,

115
00:05:54,080 --> 00:05:59,040
and now DNS that had nothing before,
has a service log, and when I go in there,

116
00:05:59,040 --> 00:06:03,520
it's gonna filter my system logs so
I only see DNS related events.

117
00:06:03,520 --> 00:06:06,550
That really helps with troubleshooting,
all right, and

118
00:06:06,550 --> 00:06:11,050
I can see right here that as of 11:03 AM,
DNS came up.

119
00:06:11,050 --> 00:06:13,240
It's got one zone for the local host.

120
00:06:13,240 --> 00:06:14,650
And it's running.

121
00:06:14,650 --> 00:06:18,050
And as I start performing
activities inside of DNS,

122
00:06:18,050 --> 00:06:19,650
log entries are made for that.

123
00:06:19,650 --> 00:06:23,925
So, if I go inside of DNS here,
and add a new record for

124
00:06:23,925 --> 00:06:28,775
www.lab.itpro.tv and
I punch in an address of whatever,

125
00:06:28,775 --> 00:06:34,930
I'll just make one up here,
1.1.1.1 and I create that, right?

126
00:06:34,930 --> 00:06:37,210
I see that it was created,
it's right there.

127
00:06:37,210 --> 00:06:39,740
But a lot of stuff happened
behind the scenes.

128
00:06:39,740 --> 00:06:43,630
And if I go to my logs,
now I've got additional information here.

129
00:06:43,630 --> 00:06:47,270
I can see it created a reverse
lookup zone for 1.1.1.

130
00:06:47,270 --> 00:06:49,650
It created a forward lookup zone,

131
00:06:49,650 --> 00:06:53,450
which is in here somewhere,
for lab.itpro.tv right there.

132
00:06:53,450 --> 00:06:55,770
And I can it registered that host,

133
00:06:55,770 --> 00:07:00,300
which was www, which that'll be
in here somewhere else also.

134
00:07:00,300 --> 00:07:03,390
Now, I'm having a hard
time spotting that one.

135
00:07:03,390 --> 00:07:07,870
The more data that's in the logs,
the harder it becomes to find entries, so

136
00:07:07,870 --> 00:07:10,770
sometimes visually scanning
it is not appropriate.

137
00:07:10,770 --> 00:07:13,210
Visually scanning has one big advantage.

138
00:07:13,210 --> 00:07:15,590
You can see not just the message
you're looking for, but

139
00:07:15,590 --> 00:07:17,180
the ones above it and below it.

140
00:07:17,180 --> 00:07:20,660
Often times it's related messages that
go along with what you're looking for.

141
00:07:20,660 --> 00:07:22,940
So a visual scan is what
I normally try first.

142
00:07:22,940 --> 00:07:28,330
But if I just cannot find what I'm looking
