a blue line for inbound traffic,
so you can tell the difference.

369
00:18:58,700 --> 00:19:01,800
Most network adapters are full duplex.

370
00:19:01,800 --> 00:19:06,268
So if you have a gigabit card, that means
it can send one gigabit of traffic while

371
00:19:06,268 --> 00:19:09,150
at the same time receiving
one gigabit of traffic.

372
00:19:09,150 --> 00:19:10,330
That's full duplex.

373
00:19:10,330 --> 00:19:12,350
That's why it monitors these separate.

374
00:19:12,350 --> 00:19:15,590
Cuz you could actually have two gigabits
of traffic going over that line.

375
00:19:15,590 --> 00:19:17,520
Just half of it it's outgoing,
half of it it's incoming.

376
00:19:21,180 --> 00:19:25,990
And then the last one that we can
monitor on here is bytes served, and

377
00:19:25,990 --> 00:19:29,800
bytes served, that's really helpful for
monitoring our disk access.

378
00:19:29,800 --> 00:19:32,670
This is the amount of data we've
been pushing over the network,

379
00:19:32,670 --> 00:19:34,710
so as people come in with
their file shares and

380
00:19:34,710 --> 00:19:38,450
other access like that,
how much of that data that we're removing.

381
00:19:38,450 --> 00:19:40,060
If you have just one hard drive,

382
00:19:40,060 --> 00:19:42,730
this equates to how much data we
had to read off of that drive.

383
00:19:42,730 --> 00:19:45,850
If you have multiple hard
drives it gets aggregated, but

384
00:19:45,850 --> 00:19:49,340
that's really handy when you're talking
about something like an Xsan appliance.

385
00:19:49,340 --> 00:19:49,860
Right?

386
00:19:49,860 --> 00:19:52,460
Where you might have 14
hard drives in there, and

387
00:19:52,460 --> 00:19:53,380
you're reading from all of them.

388
00:19:53,380 --> 00:19:56,140
You need to understand how much
data you're pushing it across that

389
00:19:56,140 --> 00:19:57,590
thunderbolt cable, or fiber, or

390
00:19:57,590 --> 00:20:01,210
whatever it is that runs to your Xsan,
you need to be able to measure that.

391
00:20:01,210 --> 00:20:03,160
And we'd get that right
here from bytes served.

392
00:20:04,710 --> 00:20:08,200
Now, there is one other piece of storage
that we might wanna monitor that it's not

393
00:20:08,200 --> 00:20:10,765
listing here, and that's utilization.

394
00:20:10,765 --> 00:20:15,835
If I have a one terabyte drive,
how much space is left available on it?

395
00:20:15,835 --> 00:20:17,395
Well, it doesn't tell me that.

396
00:20:17,395 --> 00:20:19,665
Bytes served,
that's how much data I'm copying,

397
00:20:19,665 --> 00:20:23,163
how much data I'm moving on the file
system, not how much data I actually have.

398
00:20:23,163 --> 00:20:28,635
If I wanna see my actual utilization,
I can go back up to my server here,

399
00:20:28,635 --> 00:20:32,600
under the Server Manager, and
you have a storage button right there.

400
00:20:32,600 --> 00:20:34,250
And it'll show you your drives, and

401
00:20:34,250 --> 00:20:36,770
you can get an idea of how
much space is in use on them.

402
00:20:36,770 --> 00:20:40,410
So I've got my Macintosh HD,
that's where my operating system is.

403
00:20:40,410 --> 00:20:46,580
And I can see that it's at about,
I don't know, 25%, maybe 30% utilization.

404
00:20:46,580 --> 00:20:49,350
And I've got my service data
drive that's barely used at all.

405
00:20:49,350 --> 00:20:50,950
And it tells me how much
space is available.

406
00:20:50,950 --> 00:20:52,240
So I can see that right here.

407
00:20:52,240 --> 00:20:54,500
You can also navigate into
the drive if you want.

408
00:20:54,500 --> 00:20:58,200
If you're bored and wanna browse around
and see what's in there, you can do that

409
00:20:58,200 --> 00:21:03,880
but there's not a whole lot of reason to
do it other than, I don't know, to do it.

410
00:21:03,880 --> 00:21:06,232
[LAUGH] So we can see that
utilization right there though and

411
00:21:06,232 --> 00:21:08,350
get an idea of how much
disk space we're consuming.

412
00:21:11,080 --> 00:21:13,700
There's one last statistic we have
that was all the way at the bottom of

413
00:21:13,700 --> 00:21:15,110
that list.

414
00:21:15,110 --> 00:21:18,200
Under File Sharing > Connected users.

415
00:21:18,200 --> 00:21:20,480
If I'm sharing folders on my system,

416
00:21:20,480 --> 00:21:24,130
how many end users
are connected to me right now.

417
00:21:24,130 --> 00:21:28,520
Now this doesn't include website users,
or open directory authenticators,

418
00:21:28,520 --> 00:21:29,790
it doesn't include those.

419
00:21:29,790 --> 00:21:32,100
This is based on file sharing.

420
00:21:32,100 --> 00:21:36,360
So people that have connected to my AFP,
or SMB, or NFS shares,

421
00:21:36,360 --> 00:21:39,350
whatever it is that we've set up,
anybody who is connecting to that,

422
00:21:39,350 --> 00:21:42,890
it will give us a count here so
we can see how many people on our system.

423
00:21:42,890 --> 00:21:44,718
That's useful for a few reasons.

424
00:21:44,718 --> 00:21:47,500
If you're gonna be
rebooting your server or

425
00:21:47,500 --> 00:21:51,000
taking a backup, you might want to look
to see are there people in the system?

426
00:21:51,000 --> 00:21:54,310
Are there people working with files right
now cuz we don't want to interrupt them.

427
00:21:54,310 --> 00:21:56,270
We can see it right here under Statistics.

428
00:21:57,420 --> 00:21:58,180
All right.

429
00:21:58,180 --> 00:22:02,470
So those are the ways that we
got right here inside of our

430
00:22:02,470 --> 00:22:06,670
server manager to see what's
going on on the server right now.

431
00:22:06,670 --> 00:22:08,360
This is great cuz it works remotely.

432
00:22:08,360 --> 00:22:11,220
You can run the server app on your
laptop or desktop and pull this up and

433
00:22:11,220 --> 00:22:12,510
see it remotely.

434
00:22:12,510 --> 00:22:14,950
If you wanna see even more detail or

435
00:22:14,950 --> 00:22:19,190
even more information though, the Activity
Monitor's really the place to go.

436
00:22:19,190 --> 00:22:21,920
Unfortunately for the activity monitor,
the best way to do that

437
00:22:21,920 --> 00:22:26,510
is really to remote into the server,
to do screen sharing into the server.

438
00:22:26,510 --> 00:22:30,770
And then on the server itself you
can run the activity monitor.

439
00:22:30,770 --> 00:22:34,440
And in the activity monitor you have
all that same data that we just saw in

440
00:22:34,440 --> 00:22:36,330
the server app, it's all in here too.

441
00:22:37,570 --> 00:22:42,020
We have CPU memory and so on, and you can
tweak this to add additional information.

442
00:22:42,020 --> 00:22:47,160
Same data's here, but
it is a lot more intensive.

443
00:22:47,160 --> 00:22:50,960
It's loading a lot of information, and
we've got to know what we're looking for.

444
00:22:50,960 --> 00:22:53,650
So when you go here and you start
to run these various diagnostics,

445
00:22:53,650 --> 00:22:57,930
looking at information in here,
it can be a little overwhelming sometimes.

446
00:22:57,930 --> 00:23:01,200
But you do get some nice little charts and
graphs and things like that.

447
00:23:01,200 --> 00:23:04,300
But the bulk of what we need is
right there in the server manager.

448
00:23:04,300 --> 00:23:05,470
It's got nice little charts and

449
00:23:05,470 --> 00:23:08,920
graphs here too, that show us the key
things we need to monitor on a server.

450
00:23:11,800 --> 00:23:15,430
All right now, everything I've talked
about so far were things that we do for

451
00:23:15,430 --> 00:23:17,510
troubleshooting problems
that happened in the past or

452
00:23:17,510 --> 00:23:18,790
problems that are happening right now.

453
00:23:19,790 --> 00:23:21,370
But what about problems in the future?

454
00:23:21,370 --> 00:23:23,270
What about problems that
haven't happened yet?

455
00:23:23,270 --> 00:23:25,890
Well, we actually have a system for
that too.

456
00:23:25,890 --> 00:23:29,290
But, looking at the clock this is a pretty
good spot to stop and take a break.

457
00:23:29,290 --> 00:23:33,030
So let's pause here, when we get back
we're gonna look at the monitoring system

458
00:23:33,030 --> 00:23:36,160
for watching for things that haven't
happened yet, which is kind of neat.

459
00:23:36,160 --> 00:23:37,460
It's like predicting the future.

460
00:23:37,460 --> 00:23:40,644
So we'll get a chance to see that
when we get back in just a few.

461
00:23:40,644 --> 00:23:47,450
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Server Maintenance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,540 --> 00:00:22,911
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,911 --> 00:00:33,460
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,460 --> 00:00:36,391
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,391 --> 00:00:38,640
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,640 --> 00:00:40,900
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:40,900 --> 00:00:45,046
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

8
00:00:45,046 --> 00:00:48,750
Today we're going to be jumping into
a very important topic which is

9
00:00:48,750 --> 00:00:51,830
doing proper maintenance of your server.

10
00:00:51,830 --> 00:00:55,080
Now when you install the server
app on your Mac OS device,

11
00:00:55,080 --> 00:00:56,640
now it becomes a server.

12
00:00:56,640 --> 00:00:59,520
And you set up all your various services
and you get that configured and

13
00:00:59,520 --> 00:01:03,500
you get it up and running and
then it just does what it does, right.

14
00:01:03,500 --> 00:01:05,170
We walk away, we let it run.

15
00:01:05,170 --> 00:01:07,350
Well that's true for the most part, but

16
00:01:07,350 --> 00:01:10,740
there's certain things we need to
do to keep the server healthy.

17
00:01:10,740 --> 00:01:13,430
And in our last episode we talked about
some of the different ways that we can

18
00:01:13,430 --> 00:01:18,850
monitor the servers as far as watching
our logs and errors and so on.

19
00:01:18,850 --> 00:01:22,200
But there's other routine activities that
we didn't talk about in that episode that

20
00:01:22,200 --> 00:01:23,690
I want to talk about right here.

21
00:01:23,690 --> 00:01:28,690
One of the most important things
is keeping our server up to date.

22
00:01:28,690 --> 00:01:29,370
All right.

23
00:01:29,370 --> 00:01:31,550
Apple is constantly releasing patches and

24
00:01:31,550 --> 00:01:34,900
updates to keep your system secure and
stable.

25
00:01:34,900 --> 00:01:36,290
When Apple pushes an update,

26
00:01:36,290 --> 00:01:38,140
it's usually those two things
that they're shooting for.

27
00:01:38,140 --> 00:01:40,950
There's really three types of
updates you get from Apple.

28
00:01:40,950 --> 00:01:42,330
There's security updates.

29
00:01:42,330 --> 00:01:43,690
Those you definitely want.

30
00:01:43,690 --> 00:01:45,720
You want those as soon as they come out.

31
00:01:45,720 --> 00:01:50,710
That means that some kind of vulnerability
has been detected inside of Mac OS and

32
00:01:50,710 --> 00:01:51,780
they've got a fix for that right?

33
00:01:51,780 --> 00:01:54,200
They're pushing out something
to close off that vulnerability.

34
00:01:55,245 --> 00:01:58,345
Now just some quick terminology
here to be aware of.

35
00:01:58,345 --> 00:02:02,127
To hear people talk about
vulnerabilities and exploits.

36
00:02:02,127 --> 00:02:04,525
All right, and a lot of people
use the terms interchangeably.

37
00:02:04,525 --> 00:02:07,205
They'll say oh you need to patch your
server, there's an exploit out there.

38
00:02:07,205 --> 00:02:09,710
Or you need to patch your server,
there's a vulnerability out there.

39
00:02:09,710 --> 00:02:11,880
And what's the difference?

40
00:02:11,880 --> 00:02:16,270
Well, a vulnerability,
that's a weakness in your system but

41
00:02:16,270 --> 00:02:20,690
nobody's quite figured out how to use that
weakness to take advantage of it yet, or

42
00:02:20,690 --> 00:02:22,110
nobody that we know of.

43
00:02:22,110 --> 00:02:22,750
Somebody might have,

44
00:02:22,750 --> 00:02:25,200
somebody out there might have figured
out a way to take advantage of that and

45
00:02:25,200 --> 00:02:26,450
we just don't know about it yet.

46
00:02:26,450 --> 00:02:29,710
But it's called a vulnerability
until there is a documented

47
00:02:29,710 --> 00:02:32,220
case of somebody using it for bad stuff.

48
00:02:32,220 --> 00:02:36,730
And when somebody can use it for bad
stuff, that is when it becomes an export.

49
00:02:36,730 --> 00:02:39,860
But, as far as we're concerned
with our server updates,

50
00:02:39,860 --> 00:02:41,640
I don't care if it is a vulnerability or
an export.

51
00:02:41,640 --> 00:02:43,470
I want to patch it as soon as I can.

52
00:02:43,470 --> 00:02:45,980
And I'd love to patch it while
it was a vulnerability, right?

53
00:02:45,980 --> 00:02:48,100
That means nobody has
taken advantage of it.

54
00:02:48,100 --> 00:02:50,140
So, How do we patch our servers.

55
00:02:50,140 --> 00:02:51,650
How do we keep them up to date.

56
00:02:51,650 --> 00:02:53,620
Well Apple's given us
a couple of tools for that.

57
00:02:53,620 --> 00:02:56,330
Or actually before I move on I
forgot to mention the other two.

58
00:02:56,330 --> 00:02:59,560
The first one I mentioned was security
update, the most important one.

59
00:02:59,560 --> 00:03:01,190
I should have saved that for last.

60
00:03:01,190 --> 00:03:03,910
The other one's,
we've got stability improvements.

61
00:03:03,910 --> 00:03:07,280
Occasionally there are bugs and
things that make it into the servers,

62
00:03:07,280 --> 00:03:10,220
where you might have services crash,
or freeze up,

63
00:03:10,220 --> 00:03:15,080
or not be able to provide functions like
they should so those kind of bug fixes,

64
00:03:15,080 --> 00:03:18,460
those things we definitely want
to apply as soon as we can too.

65
00:03:18,460 --> 00:03:21,370
The third type of update
though is a feature update.

66
00:03:21,370 --> 00:03:24,120
One that adds feature to your system.

67
00:03:24,120 --> 00:03:27,840
Not necessarily fixing bugs or
anything but add something new.

68
00:03:27,840 --> 00:03:31,190
Now these we might not
necessarily want right away.

69
00:03:31,190 --> 00:03:35,260
The problem with adding new features is
new features normally bring along a couple

70
00:03:35,260 --> 00:03:37,450
of their own bugs with them, right.

71
00:03:37,450 --> 00:03:39,860
And we probably don't
want that on a server.

72
00:03:39,860 --> 00:03:42,230
On a desk top, on our iPhone,
or iPad, or whatever.

73
00:03:42,230 --> 00:03:43,410
It's a different story.

74
00:03:43,410 --> 00:03:46,540
But on your servers you want them nice and
stable.

75
00:03:46,540 --> 00:03:51,460
So, we typically won't do updates if
they're just bringing along new features.

76
00:03:51,460 --> 00:03:57,540
So, Apple releases the new health kit
software of the research kit or whatever.

77
00:03:57,540 --> 00:04:00,340
You don't need that on your server and
so, don't push that update.

78
00:04:00,340 --> 00:04:04,872
You're not in a big hurry, it's just going
to introduce a larger attack service.

79
00:04:04,872 --> 00:04:06,810
All right so
where do these updates come from?

80
00:04:06,810 --> 00:04:12,270
Well updating is really one of the things
Apple's made really, really easy for us.

81
00:04:12,270 --> 00:04:15,740
It has changed over the years though,
so if you're an old school Mac user,

82
00:04:15,740 --> 00:04:17,780
things are different now
than they used to be.

83
00:04:17,780 --> 00:04:20,810
Now our updates are all
managed through the App Store.

84
00:04:21,860 --> 00:04:22,580
On our Mac,

85
00:04:22,580 --> 00:04:27,580
like here I'm on a server here and I'm
just up running this is my OSX-server1.

86
00:04:27,580 --> 00:04:29,350
I'm running OS 10.10 Yosemite.

87
00:04:29,350 --> 00:04:34,900
I got the system up and running and if I
want to do updates, well, I can wait and

88
00:04:34,900 --> 00:04:38,880
eventually an alert will show up that
will let me know an update is available.

89
00:04:38,880 --> 00:04:41,690
And I can go and perform that update
right here through the Server app.

90
00:04:41,690 --> 00:04:44,150
That's one way to go about it, but

91
00:04:44,150 --> 00:04:48,380
the Server app isn't actually what's
going out and checking for the updates.

92
00:04:48,380 --> 00:04:52,310
It's actually the App Store, that if I
fire up the App Store on this system,

93
00:04:53,610 --> 00:04:56,548
when I launch it,
it's going to reach out to Apple Services.

94
00:04:56,548 --> 00:04:59,050
It's going to look to see if
there's update available, and

95
00:04:59,050 --> 00:05:02,370
if there is,
the update'll show right here.

96
00:05:02,370 --> 00:05:06,730
On the updates tab, and see I've clicked
on it, now it's checking for updates.

97
00:05:06,730 --> 00:05:08,860
It's going to go out and
it's going to find that.

98
00:05:08,860 --> 00:05:11,590
Now I'm certain there's going to be some
updates, I don't think I've patched this

99
00:05:11,590 --> 00:05:14,980
machine from its initial install, so there
should be at least one update out there.

100
00:05:14,980 --> 00:05:16,880
We'll see what it finds.

101
00:05:16,880 --> 00:05:19,140
Now while waiting on that,
well, there we go.

102
00:05:19,140 --> 00:05:20,690
Didn't have to wait that long at all.

103
00:05:20,690 --> 00:05:23,010
Looks like there is a software
update available for me and

104
00:05:23,010 --> 00:05:25,010
it just says updates are available.

105
00:05:25,010 --> 00:05:28,170
There's an update for
the remote desktop, client update 3.8.2.

106
00:05:28,170 --> 00:05:31,560
There's a security update and
there's more.

107
00:05:31,560 --> 00:05:34,278
So there's actually more than one
update in this little roll up.

108
00:05:34,278 --> 00:05:37,060
I'm going to expand that out so
I can see what it is.

109
00:05:37,060 --> 00:05:40,580
I guess that's actually about it we've
got Security Update 2015-0021.0.

110
00:05:40,580 --> 00:05:45,360
So here's a security
update they've released,

111
00:05:45,360 --> 00:05:48,050
and it's letting me know
they've improved security.

112
00:05:48,050 --> 00:05:52,320
I probably want to apply it, but it's not
really telling me what it's going to do.

113
00:05:52,320 --> 00:05:55,130
And they always give you a nice
little link that you can click on and

114
00:05:55,130 --> 00:05:57,940
it'll take you to their website, and they
provide additional information about what

115
00:05:57,940 --> 00:06:01,342
that security update actually performs for
your system.

116
00:06:01,342 --> 00:06:04,520
All right now if you just have
one server and this is it,

117
00:06:04,520 --> 00:06:07,060
you'll probably just go ahead and
apply the update.

118
00:06:07,060 --> 00:06:10,120
But if you've got a hundred servers,
if you've got sensitive,

119
00:06:10,120 --> 00:06:12,440
critical applications on your network,

120
00:06:12,440 --> 00:06:15,350
you need to ensure those
applications stay up and running.

121
00:06:15,350 --> 00:06:18,470
And so when you apply an update
could it break your software?

122
00:06:18,470 --> 00:06:20,890
Could it make things function
differently than they used to?

123
00:06:20,890 --> 00:06:21,910
Absolutely.

124
00:06:21,910 --> 00:06:25,070
So it's always a good
idea to test the updates.

125
00:06:25,070 --> 00:06:29,800
Test the updates on one server,
or preferably on a test server.

126
00:06:29,800 --> 00:06:32,710
So you actually have a server
set up specifically for testing.

127
00:06:32,710 --> 00:06:34,400
Test it out in your test environment.

128
00:06:34,400 --> 00:06:37,910
And only when you've seen the update
is safe, you then roll it out for

129
00:06:37,910 --> 00:06:38,630
the rest of the network.

130
00:06:38,630 --> 00:06:41,470
And when I say safe you're
getting the update from Apple.

131
00:06:41,470 --> 00:06:44,220
So you know it doesn't have malware or
viruses in it or

132
00:06:44,220 --> 00:06:45,400
anything like that, right?

133
00:06:45,400 --> 00:06:48,080
Apple has signed it,
it's a protected file.

134
00:06:48,080 --> 00:06:49,430
So you know that's safe.

01:12:17,070 --> 01:12:20,910
To restore service data first,
then restore the rest of the system.

1500
01:12:20,910 --> 01:12:22,490
And you'll be in business, all right?

1501
01:12:22,490 --> 01:12:24,240
So not too terribly painful.

1502
01:12:24,240 --> 01:12:26,340
I keep this article right here.

1503
01:12:26,340 --> 01:12:27,850
I keep this bookmarked.

1504
01:12:27,850 --> 01:12:30,930
You don't have to restore from time
machine very often on a server right?

1505
01:12:30,930 --> 01:12:34,090
It's only when things are critical and
I like to have these commands nice and

1506
01:12:34,090 --> 01:12:34,980
ready to go.

1507
01:12:34,980 --> 01:12:38,310
So I keep this bookmarked and ready,
I reference this any time I have to go and

1508
01:12:38,310 --> 01:12:39,360
do a recovery.

1509
01:12:39,360 --> 01:12:43,460
And it's got all the commands you need
right there and nice thing to have.

1510
01:12:43,460 --> 01:12:44,900
I'll post the link to
that with the show notes.

1511
01:12:46,850 --> 01:12:50,920
All right, well that's about all
I've got for backup and recovery.

1512
01:12:50,920 --> 01:12:53,570
Let's just kind of recap,
we talked about a lot in this episode.

1513

We started talking about software updates,
and I walked you kind of through how

1514
01:12:57,270 --> 01:13:01,430
to do the update for the Server App in
the event that you update the host OS.

1515
01:13:01,430 --> 01:13:05,340
We saw some of the settings that we
could do to customize automatic updates.

1516
01:13:05,340 --> 01:13:08,220
And I gave us a quick introduction
to the software update

1517
01:13:08,220 --> 01:13:11,240
role inside of the Server App,
and how it functions, and

1518
01:13:11,240 --> 01:13:13,500
how we can use it to meter
which updates roll out.

1519
01:13:13,500 --> 01:13:16,550
And then the last part of the show,
we took a look at backups and

1520
01:13:16,550 --> 01:13:19,460
we got that chance to see how
to back up our server and

1521
01:13:19,460 --> 01:13:21,610
how to restore it to recover from failure.

1522
01:13:21,610 --> 01:13:24,980
All pretty good information to have,
and definitely something you'll want to

1523
01:13:24,980 --> 01:13:27,930
perform in real life to keep
your servers running and happy.

1524
01:13:27,930 --> 01:13:31,970
And to help you recover from failure
faster when a disaster does occur.

1525
01:13:31,970 --> 01:13:34,440
You need those things to be
under your belt, nice and

1526
01:13:34,440 --> 01:13:36,000
comfortable, easy to deal with.

1527
01:13:37,050 --> 01:13:40,530
All right well, that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap this episode up.

1528

So let me remind you guys if you have

1529

talked about this episode, or any episode

episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:14,799 --> 00:00:22,417
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,417 --> 00:00:32,911
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:32,911 --> 00:00:36,000
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:38,711
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,711 --> 00:00:40,840
I'm your host Don Pezete,

7
00:00:40,840 --> 00:00:44,980
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

8
00:00:44,980 --> 00:00:49,250
Today we're gonna be diving into the
wonderful world of user authentication.

9
00:00:49,250 --> 00:00:51,170
In our previous episodes,

10
00:00:51,170 --> 00:00:54,980
we've really been focusing on getting
our servers set up and running.

11
00:00:54,980 --> 00:00:58,620
But one of the big challenges that we've
experienced is, you set up all these great

12
00:00:58,620 --> 00:01:03,280
services, all this really cool stuff on
your server, how do people get to it?

13
00:01:03,280 --> 00:01:06,280
And when people get to it
how do you keep it secure?

14
00:01:06,280 --> 00:01:10,710
You don't want, necessarily you don't want
all of your users to just have free reign

15
00:01:10,710 --> 00:01:11,620
on your servers.

16
00:01:11,620 --> 00:01:15,630
We need to be able to restrict their
access and limit what they can get to.

17
00:01:15,630 --> 00:01:18,300
Well, before we can dive into that,

18
00:01:18,300 --> 00:01:23,110
we need to understand how Mac OS
authenticates people in the first place.

19
00:01:23,110 --> 00:01:28,170
Now keep in mind that Mac OS itself
has been around a long time.

20
00:01:28,170 --> 00:01:30,870
It was really developed in the late 70s or
early 80s.

21
00:01:30,870 --> 00:01:32,390
It evolved a ton.

22
00:01:32,390 --> 00:01:36,850
It went through the big change
between OS 9, or System 7,

23
00:01:36,850 --> 00:01:40,780
and OS 9, and then, now we got OS 10.

24
00:01:40,780 --> 00:01:43,150
Huge changes throughout that period.

25
00:01:43,150 --> 00:01:47,970
And now what we end up with is
Mac OS running on top of BSDs, so

26
00:01:47,970 --> 00:01:50,890
we have Unix elements that
are brought into the backend too.

27
00:01:50,890 --> 00:01:53,530
And while that sounds really complex, and

28
00:01:53,530 --> 00:01:57,440
it kinda sounds like a bad thing,
it's actually a really, really good thing.

29
00:01:57,440 --> 00:02:02,370
It means that Mac OS is built on top
of a very versatile, very stable and

30
00:02:02,370 --> 00:02:04,090
secure operating system.

31
00:02:04,090 --> 00:02:05,940
And it gives us a lot of power.

32
00:02:06,990 --> 00:02:08,930
Well, the big challenge
here is it gives us so

33
00:02:08,930 --> 00:02:11,100
much power that sometimes
is hard to keep track of.

34
00:02:11,100 --> 00:02:14,290
But for the exam they expect
you to be able to do just that.

35
00:02:14,290 --> 00:02:17,550
So we need to make sure we've got
some good basic understanding of

36
00:02:17,550 --> 00:02:18,660
authentication.

37
00:02:18,660 --> 00:02:23,320
So in this episode, I'm not gonna focus
on how to do a lot of this stuff,

38
00:02:23,320 --> 00:02:27,360
we're gonna do that in the next episode,
but I wanna focus on just the concepts.

39
00:02:27,360 --> 00:02:30,830
The principles to make sure we got
a good foundational knowledge of

40
00:02:30,830 --> 00:02:35,910
what user authentication is and
what Mac OS is capable of.

41
00:02:35,910 --> 00:02:39,170
If you already have a good understanding
of that exactly how Mac OS functions for

42
00:02:39,170 --> 00:02:42,120
that and you're just looking for the how
to side of things, you won't hurt my

43
00:02:42,120 --> 00:02:45,160
feelings if you skip this episode and
just jump to the next one.

44
00:02:45,160 --> 00:02:49,440
But if you're gonna take the exam
this is a really important episode.

45
00:02:49,440 --> 00:02:54,240
One of the first comments I want to hit,
on is really what is authentication.

46
00:02:54,240 --> 00:02:58,220
Authentication's really easy to mix up
with another concept called authorization.

47
00:02:58,220 --> 00:03:00,740
And when you're reading text books and
online,

48
00:03:00,740 --> 00:03:05,740
you'll normally see them combined,
authentication and authorization together.

49
00:03:05,740 --> 00:03:06,970
Well, what the heck are they?

50
00:03:06,970 --> 00:03:09,330
Well let's start with authentication.

51
00:03:09,330 --> 00:03:11,870
With authentication what you're doing is,

52
00:03:11,870 --> 00:03:16,320
you're basically verifying a user is,
who they say they are.

53
00:03:16,320 --> 00:03:18,630
When a user goes to log into a computer,

54
00:03:18,630 --> 00:03:21,180
they have to let that computer know
that they are a certain person.

55
00:03:21,180 --> 00:03:25,550
When I logged into my laptop this morning,
I said hey computer, I'm Don Pezet.

56
00:03:25,550 --> 00:03:28,370
And the computer has to say well,
how do I know that?

57
00:03:28,370 --> 00:03:30,550
How can I prove that you are Don Pezet?

58
00:03:30,550 --> 00:03:33,210
And there's any number of techniques that

59
00:03:33,210 --> 00:03:35,240
are out there that are available for
doing that.

60
00:03:35,240 --> 00:03:37,840
The most common is a username and
a password.

61
00:03:37,840 --> 00:03:41,460
And that's exactly how I logged in this
morning, I typed in my username and

62
00:03:41,460 --> 00:03:42,640
my password.

63
00:03:42,640 --> 00:03:46,010
And the computer verified the password
against its password database.

64
00:03:46,010 --> 00:03:49,290
And it said, yeah that's right,
and he knows the password.

65
00:03:49,290 --> 00:03:50,140
It must be Don.

66
00:03:50,140 --> 00:03:53,030
No one else on the entire planet
would know Don's password.

67
00:03:53,030 --> 00:03:54,430
It must be him.

68
00:03:54,430 --> 00:03:57,590
Well, as you can imagine,
that's not always a guarantee.

69
00:03:57,590 --> 00:03:59,770
I could've shared my
password with somebody.

70
00:03:59,770 --> 00:04:03,000
So there's other types of
authentication that are out there too.

71
00:04:03,000 --> 00:04:05,630
There's things like certificate
based authentication.

72
00:04:05,630 --> 00:04:08,380
Instead of a password,
I send a digital certificate.

73
00:04:08,380 --> 00:04:11,180
So I've got some sign key that I use.

74
00:04:11,180 --> 00:04:12,940
Or there's biometrics.

75
00:04:12,940 --> 00:04:16,700
Again, an iPhone or an iPad,
they all have the touch ID now right.

76
00:04:16,700 --> 00:04:19,370
The little thumb print or
fingerprint scanner that's on them.

77
00:04:19,370 --> 00:04:21,010
So you got that possibility.

78
00:04:21,010 --> 00:04:24,250
Retinal scans, all sorts of other
different ways that you can identify that

79
00:04:24,250 --> 00:04:26,330
people are who they say they are.

80
00:04:26,330 --> 00:04:28,680
But a username and
password is the most common.

81
00:04:28,680 --> 00:04:33,620
So when we talk about authentication,
we're talking about verifying somebody is,

82
00:04:33,620 --> 00:04:35,170
who they say they are.

83
00:04:35,170 --> 00:04:37,340
So where does authorization fit in that?

84
00:04:37,340 --> 00:04:42,000
Well, once the computer knows who you are,
you're now authenticated and

85
00:04:42,000 --> 00:04:44,460
you start to perform actions.

86
00:04:44,460 --> 00:04:47,690
Well, are you allowed to
perform those actions or not?

87
00:04:47,690 --> 00:04:49,850
That's where authorization comes in.

88
00:04:49,850 --> 00:04:52,600
Authorization is saying all right,
you authenticated it, so

89
00:04:52,600 --> 00:04:54,560
I know you're Don Pezet.

90
00:04:54,560 --> 00:04:56,640
Now that I know that,
what are you allowed to do?

91
00:04:56,640 --> 00:05:00,170
Are you allowed to browse to
this one folder over here?

92
00:05:00,170 --> 00:05:02,020
Are you allowed to shut the computer down?

93
00:05:02,020 --> 00:05:04,780
Are you allowed to install
third-party software?

94
00:05:04,780 --> 00:05:06,810
Are you allowed to empty the recycle bin?

95
00:05:06,810 --> 00:05:08,460
What are you allowed to do?

96
00:05:08,460 --> 00:05:09,970
That's authorization.

97
00:05:09,970 --> 00:05:14,460
Are you authorized to perform that
activity or access that resource, or

98
00:05:14,460 --> 00:05:15,729
whatever it is that you're trying to do?

99
00:05:16,740 --> 00:05:18,670
The two of them work hand in hand.

100
00:05:18,670 --> 00:05:23,890
We can't authorize users unless we
know they are who they say they are.

101
00:05:23,890 --> 00:05:27,070
And we can't just authenticate a user and
then give them carte blanche access to our

102
00:05:27,070 --> 00:05:31,090
system we need to be able to filter
what they can do, restricted access.

103
00:05:31,090 --> 00:05:33,380
Otherwise things just go to pot real fast.

104
00:05:33,380 --> 00:05:35,700
So we need the two together.

105
00:05:35,700 --> 00:05:38,410
Authentication and authorization.

106
00:05:38,410 --> 00:05:39,890
Now if you read any security manuals,

107
00:05:39,890 --> 00:05:42,860
a lot of times they'll stick a third
one on there called accounting.

108
00:05:42,860 --> 00:05:47,650
And accounting is simply keeping a record
of what people do while they're logged in.

109
00:05:47,650 --> 00:05:50,770
So a user authenticates and
they start performing actions.

110
00:05:50,770 --> 00:05:53,150
And as they do those actions,
you keep a record of it.

111
00:05:53,150 --> 00:05:54,240
That's accounting.

112
00:05:54,240 --> 00:05:57,360
So you'll hear this referred
to as Triple A sometimes.

113
00:05:57,360 --> 00:06:01,220
Authentication, authorization,
and accounting, right?

114
00:06:01,220 --> 00:06:04,700
But on the exam, they'll really just call
out the first two, authentication, and

115
00:06:04,700 --> 00:06:06,250
authorization.

116
00:06:06,250 --> 00:06:10,660
Now, authorization inside of Mac land
can take several different forms, but

117
00:06:10,660 --> 00:06:13,270
most commonly we see it as
file permissions, right?

118
00:06:13,270 --> 00:06:14,910
You can set permissions on folders and

119
00:06:14,910 --> 00:06:17,670
files to dictate who has access and
who doesn't.

120
00:06:17,670 --> 00:06:20,690
But we'll see it later in
the server app when we can restrict

121
00:06:20,690 --> 00:06:22,820
who has access to certain services?

122
00:06:22,820 --> 00:06:26,672
Maybe your user is allowed to access
the web service, but another user isn't.

123
00:06:26,672 --> 00:06:28,390
That's authorization.

124
00:06:28,390 --> 00:06:30,570
You're authorizing certain
users to have that access.

125
00:06:31,820 --> 00:06:36,770
On the authentication side, though,
this is where Mac OS gets really powerful.

126
00:06:38,310 --> 00:06:42,840
For the exam, you need to be aware of some
of the different ways that Mac OS can

127
00:06:42,840 --> 00:06:46,450
authenticate users and the authentication
systems that are part of it,

128
00:06:46,450 --> 00:06:50,490
and they actually have support for
five different systems.

129
00:06:50,490 --> 00:06:53,900
Now, on the exam and in the exam
objectives, they call out five.

130
00:06:53,900 --> 00:06:56,660
One of them is not really
an authentication method but

131
00:06:56,660 --> 00:06:58,334
let's kind of run through
the five that we need to know.

132
00:06:59,520 --> 00:07:01,480
Some of these are older,
some of these are newer so

133
00:07:01,480 --> 00:07:03,810
I'll just kind of highlight
the differences with each.

134
00:07:03,810 --> 00:07:08,520
The first one they caught in the exam
objectives is what's called a hash.

135
00:07:08,520 --> 00:07:09,380
What's a hash?

136
00:07:09,380 --> 00:07:12,970
Well, when you go to log
into a network system

137
00:07:12,970 --> 00:07:15,960
you've gotta send your user
credentials over the network.

138
00:07:15,960 --> 00:07:17,450
Is the network safe?

139
00:07:17,450 --> 00:07:18,240
Maybe.

140
00:07:18,240 --> 00:07:20,770
If you're on your home network and
you control all the devices,

141
00:07:20,770 --> 00:07:22,360
it's a pretty safe network.

142
00:07:22,360 --> 00:07:24,130
But if you're at Starbucks and

143
00:07:24,130 --> 00:07:27,590
you're on a public wireless network,
is that a safe network?

144
00:07:27,590 --> 00:07:28,830
It really isn't.

145
00:07:28,830 --> 00:07:31,250
So, do you wanna send your username and

146
00:07:31,250 --> 00:07:35,120
password over that network,
in plain text or in the clear?

147
00:07:35,120 --> 00:07:37,830
No, you need to protect that data.

148
00:07:37,830 --> 00:07:41,490
So one of the challenges we have is, when
you send a password across a network in

149
00:07:41,490 --> 00:07:43,310
plain text,
somebody could intercept it and get it.

150
00:07:44,510 --> 00:07:48,280
And on the server, if the password is
stored in plain text on the server,

151
00:07:48,280 --> 00:07:50,710
somebody could break into the server and
get your password.

152
00:07:50,710 --> 00:07:54,450
If that happens, you've got other
problems too, but it's still bad.

153
00:07:54,450 --> 00:07:58,808
So, instead of storing passwords in
plain text, what a lot of servers do,

154
00:07:58,808 --> 00:08:03,667
is they take the password, and they run
it through a little mathematical formula.

155
00:08:03,667 --> 00:08:07,250
They run it through this formula and
they create what's called a hash.

156
00:08:07,250 --> 00:08:12,180
Now hashes are non-reversible hashes.

157
00:08:12,180 --> 00:08:14,760
The formula can only be run one way.

158
00:08:14,760 --> 00:08:19,310
If you think about it if I gave you
a math problem, if I said 3 + 3 + 3 = 9.

159
00:08:19,310 --> 00:08:22,820
Well if you look at that 3
+ 3 + 3 that equals nine,

160
00:08:22,820 --> 00:08:27,340
I don't think anybody is gonna
argue me on that one, right.

161
00:08:27,340 --> 00:08:31,760
But if I gave you nine, and
I said take this nine, and

162
00:08:31,760 --> 00:08:34,190
what was the formula I
used to get to that?

163
00:08:34,190 --> 00:08:36,670
Well it could be three
plus three plus three.

164
00:08:36,670 --> 00:08:38,230
It could be six plus three.

165
00:08:38,230 --> 00:08:40,910
It could be five plus two plus two.

166
00:08:40,910 --> 00:08:43,160
All of those equal nine.

167
00:08:43,160 --> 00:08:47,300
So with just the final result, you can't
figure out what originally went into it,

168
00:08:47,300 --> 00:08:48,840
and that's how a hash works.

169
00:08:48,840 --> 00:08:53,430
If I take a password and I run it through
a formula, it generates a hash value

170
00:08:53,430 --> 00:08:57,020
that can't be reversed to create
the password again, all right.

171
00:08:57,020 --> 00:09:00,730
And so what happens is,
the server stores this hash.

172
00:09:00,730 --> 00:09:03,490
This nonreversible form of the password.

173
00:09:03,490 --> 00:09:05,480
So if somebody breaks
in they get the hash,

174
00:09:05,480 --> 00:09:08,250
and they can't figure out what it was,
right.

175
00:09:08,250 --> 00:09:13,480
And when I go to login,
I can send my password, and then at

176
00:09:13,480 --> 00:09:18,810
the server it takes what I just sent it,
and it runs it through the same formula.

177
00:09:18,810 --> 00:09:22,395
And it looks at the hash that it
gets of this new password, and

178
00:09:22,395 --> 00:09:26,365
it compares it to the hash
that its had stored, and

179
00:09:26,365 --> 00:09:31,255
if they match, then it knows they're
the same and it let's us in, okay.

180
00:09:31,255 --> 00:09:34,965
By doing this it doesn't have
to store a password unencrypted,

181
00:09:34,965 --> 00:09:38,935
or reversible on the drive, and
that gives us a good degree of security.

182
00:09:38,935 --> 00:09:41,155
Well in Apple devices,

183
00:09:41,155 --> 00:09:46,310
we use hashes, but also in
Microsoft Windows devices we use hashes.

184
00:09:46,310 --> 00:09:50,480
So we authenticate against Macs, and when

00:19:03,160 --> 00:19:06,200

00:19:11,530 --> 00:19:15,560

00:19:15,560 --> 00:19:20,230
A standalone server is any Mac that is

363
00:19:20,230 --> 00:19:24,060
It has local user accounts and
local groups and that's it.

00:19:24,060 --> 00:19:28,210
It has no connection to the Open Directory

00:19:28,210 --> 00:19:30,630

00:19:30,630 --> 00:19:32,510

00:19:33,640 --> 00:19:37,000

that's what we just saw.

00:19:37,000 --> 00:19:39,950
That's the one that controls
the Opened Directory Data base.

00:19:39,950 --> 00:19:44,120
It has local accounts and
centralized Open Directory Accounts and

00:19:44,120 --> 00:19:46,390

00:19:47,880 --> 00:19:50,890

00:19:50,890 --> 00:19:53,460

00:19:53,460 --> 00:19:56,620

00:19:56,620 --> 00:20:01,210
It's maintaining a copy of that

375
00:20:01,210 --> 00:20:04,260
It can authenticate people,

00:20:04,260 --> 00:20:09,040

00:20:09,040 --> 00:20:14,070
A Replica server has local accounts as

00:20:17,040 --> 00:20:20,590

00:20:20,590 --> 00:20:22,980

00:20:42,180 --> 00:20:43,110

That's called Binding.

00:20:44,360 --> 00:20:47,810
And you bind your work stations

00:20:47,810 --> 00:20:51,680

00:20:51,680 --> 00:20:53,500

00:21:03,180 --> 00:21:05,280

00:21:05,280 --> 00:21:11,010
In all four scenarios, Standalone,

00:21:25,410 --> 00:21:27,980
And if you're a member you

00:21:27,980 --> 00:21:29,990

00:47:29,070 --> 00:47:31,500
It's another replica that's out there and
that's it.

899
00:47:31,500 --> 00:47:34,680
So I've now flipped those roles,
and I can take my time and

900
00:47:34,680 --> 00:47:37,740
bring that replica back
online when I have a chance.

901
00:47:37,740 --> 00:47:40,370
But if I'm joining new computers
to the open directory and stuff,

902
00:47:40,370 --> 00:47:42,450
I can do that right now,
the open directory is up and

903
00:47:42,450 --> 00:47:45,430
running and happy,
things are working great.

904
00:47:45,430 --> 00:47:49,701
So, that's really easy If
we have the back up, right?

905
00:47:49,701 --> 00:47:52,592
What if you never made an archive
of your open directory?

906
00:47:52,592 --> 00:47:53,579
What then?

907
00:47:53,579 --> 00:47:55,981
You wouldn't have been able to do this,
okay?

908
00:47:55,981 --> 00:47:59,952
Even if the archive is a little old,
it's still got what you need.

909
00:47:59,952 --> 00:48:01,540
It's got those private keys in there.

910
00:48:01,540 --> 00:48:03,200
That's the real important part.

911
00:48:03,200 --> 00:48:05,990
Even if you've added user accounts
since that archive was made,

912
00:48:05,990 --> 00:48:10,130
when you load it in here, it won't
remove the new accounts, it keeps those.

913
00:48:10,130 --> 00:48:11,480
So you're not gonna lose any data,

914
00:48:11,480 --> 00:48:13,940
the replica becomes the master,
everybody's up and running.

915
00:48:13,940 --> 00:48:17,070
You didn't lose any data,
things work great, right.

916
00:48:17,070 --> 00:48:19,070
But you gotta remember to
make that archive, right.

917
00:48:19,070 --> 00:48:19,740
I usually go and

918
00:48:19,740 --> 00:48:24,480
update that archive every couple of weeks,
just to make sure it's fairly current.

919
00:48:24,480 --> 00:48:27,450
Because it's so much faster
than dealing with Time Machine.

920
00:48:27,450 --> 00:48:29,745
If I go into a Time Machine
restore on the new hardware,

921
00:48:29,745 --> 00:48:31,170
that's gonna take me awhile, right?

922
00:48:31,170 --> 00:48:35,140
It'll take me an hour, maybe more, to get
a machine ready, and restore Time Machine.

923
00:48:35,140 --> 00:48:37,430
This just took a matter of minutes.

924
00:48:37,430 --> 00:48:40,665
If you've got the archive.

925
00:48:40,665 --> 00:48:43,580
There's one more thing that I want to
mention on Open Directory before we

926
00:48:43,580 --> 00:48:44,610
wrap this up.

927
00:48:44,610 --> 00:48:46,360
And that is locales.

928
00:48:46,360 --> 00:48:48,540
You might have noticed this
button up here that says Locales.

929
00:48:48,540 --> 00:48:50,050
What the heck is that?

930
00:48:50,050 --> 00:48:54,250
Well at the very beginning of the episode,
when I started covering DNS,

931
00:48:54,250 --> 00:48:57,710
I mentioned that we needed DNS in
case we had more than one network.

932
00:48:57,710 --> 00:49:00,260
What if I had a headquarters
here in Gainesville, and

933
00:49:00,260 --> 00:49:04,960
I had a branch office in New York,
and a branch office in Los Angeles?

934
00:49:04,960 --> 00:49:07,850
Well, if I have a computer in Los Angeles,

935
00:49:07,850 --> 00:49:10,720
I want it to log into
a replica in Los Angeles.

936
00:49:10,720 --> 00:49:13,590
I don't wanna have to come all
the way over here to Gainesville.

937
00:49:13,590 --> 00:49:17,280
And if you're in New York, I want you
to log in on a replica in New York.

938
00:49:17,280 --> 00:49:19,960
I don't want you to come all the way to
Gainesville or all the way to Los Angeles.

939
00:49:21,190 --> 00:49:26,110
How do machines know when a replica
is in the same network as them?

940
00:49:26,110 --> 00:49:27,100
Well, the short answer is, they don't.

941
00:49:27,100 --> 00:49:30,790
They have no idea, so they just look for
the first one they can find,

942
00:49:30,790 --> 00:49:34,170
which is often whichever one
they bound to originally.

943
00:49:34,170 --> 00:49:35,900
Usually this master, right?

944
00:49:35,900 --> 00:49:38,310
So, it's not very efficient by default.

945
00:49:38,310 --> 00:49:41,150
We can use locales to fix that.

946
00:49:41,150 --> 00:49:45,520
With locales, you define the IP
subnets in your network, and

947
00:49:45,520 --> 00:49:48,710
you assign your replicas to the subnets.

948
00:49:48,710 --> 00:49:50,320
It's a pretty simple process.

949
00:49:50,320 --> 00:49:53,190
When a client comes up and says,
Hey, this is my IP address.

950
00:49:53,190 --> 00:49:55,446
What locale is my IP address in?

951
00:49:55,446 --> 00:50:00,030
Then it'll go and take that, and
it'll find the Open Directory replica or

952
00:50:00,030 --> 00:50:05,740
master that's in that same locale, and
that's who it'll use to authenticate on.

953
00:50:05,740 --> 00:50:07,470
And that's usually what
we want with this stuff,

954
00:50:07,470 --> 00:50:12,120
we want it to be able to
connect to that local server.

955
00:50:12,120 --> 00:50:15,490
But it does require us to
define all of that information.

956
00:50:15,490 --> 00:50:19,030
If we don't define it, it has no
way of figuring it out on it's own.

957
00:50:19,030 --> 00:50:23,330
Because technologies like Bonjour,
Bonjour doesn't pass through routers.

958
00:50:23,330 --> 00:50:26,350
It can't pass through
routers to find those other

959
00:50:26,350 --> 00:50:29,060
Open Directory servers that are out there,
so we kind of have to coach it along.

960
00:50:30,160 --> 00:50:34,040
Let me show you the locales and how
they're set up, it's actually pretty easy.

961
00:50:34,040 --> 00:50:37,720
If I go into my server app here,
I can go to Locales, and

962
00:50:37,720 --> 00:50:40,060
you see that I've got one locale
that's created automatically.

963
00:50:41,270 --> 00:50:43,960
I usually want to rename this
to match my headquarters.

964
00:50:43,960 --> 00:50:47,550
So if my headquarters is here in
Gainesville, I can edit that, and

965
00:50:47,550 --> 00:50:49,370
this will be the Gainesville location.

966
00:50:49,370 --> 00:50:51,890
And the default subnet
here is just all zeros.

967
00:50:51,890 --> 00:50:53,938
That means all networks.

968
00:50:53,938 --> 00:50:56,170
So everybody's gonna use this location,

969
00:50:56,170 --> 00:51:00,120
unless there's another network out
there that's better for it, okay.

970
00:51:00,120 --> 00:51:05,350
Well, I can leave that be if I want, and
then start to add in my other networks.

971
00:51:05,350 --> 00:51:08,160
Now the other networks are usually
gonna be a lot more specific

972
00:51:08,160 --> 00:51:09,980
to particular subnets.

973
00:51:09,980 --> 00:51:12,920
So let's say for
example I want to add in New York.

974
00:51:14,120 --> 00:51:16,080
All right, so I've got a New York office.

975
00:51:16,080 --> 00:51:21,590
And in the New York office all of
my computers are 10.1.220.0/24,

976
00:51:21,590 --> 00:51:24,512
that's the network that I use in New York.

977
00:51:26,250 --> 00:51:31,430
And for them, I want them to
authenticate against Server 3.

978
00:51:31,430 --> 00:51:34,600
Maybe Server 3 is up there
in New York with them.

979
00:51:34,600 --> 00:51:39,670
So if you're on the 10.1.220 network,
log in to this server.

980
00:51:40,830 --> 00:51:43,620
If it's available, if it's not
available use whoever you can find.

981
00:51:43,620 --> 00:51:46,690
But if this server's available,
that's the one you want to use.

982
00:51:48,450 --> 00:51:53,180
Then I can add another locale, and
I'll call this one Los Angeles.

983
00:51:54,730 --> 00:51:59,620
Maybe in the Los Angeles network
I have several networks.

984
00:51:59,620 --> 00:52:05,424
Maybe I have 10.1.240.0.

985
00:52:05,424 --> 00:52:07,182
And maybe I've also got 10.1.250.0, and

986
00:52:07,182 --> 00:52:08,950
whatever other networks that
I might have out there.

987
00:52:08,950 --> 00:52:11,600
I come through and
I specify each of those.

988
00:52:11,600 --> 00:52:14,830
And for them, I want them to
authenticate against Server 1.

989
00:52:14,830 --> 00:52:17,210
If Server 1 is available,
authenticate against that one.

990
00:52:17,210 --> 00:52:19,061
If it's not,
just find whoever you can, but

991
00:52:19,061 --> 00:52:20,880
that's the guy I want
you to normally go to.

992
00:52:20,880 --> 00:52:24,810
And now if you're in New York,
that's who you're gonna hit.

993
00:52:24,810 --> 00:52:26,440
If you're in Los Angeles,
that's who you're gonna hit.

994
00:52:26,440 --> 00:52:27,850
So you're gonna reach out and pull those.

995
00:52:27,850 --> 00:52:31,574
And apparently I must have hit
my Plus button too many times,

996
00:52:31,574 --> 00:52:33,260
it created a little extra.

997
00:52:33,260 --> 00:52:35,150
Let me just get rid of that.

998
00:52:35,150 --> 00:52:38,440
I don't, oh, well,
I'll just add it to this one.

999
00:52:38,440 --> 00:52:40,830
This one's 10.1.230.

1000
00:52:40,830 --> 00:52:41,970
That's the network that I'm on,
it's gone ahead and added that for me.

1001
00:52:41,970 --> 00:52:43,730
I'm just gonna edit that and
change its name.

1002
00:52:43,730 --> 00:52:44,820
I'll call it Gainesville.

1003
00:52:46,080 --> 00:52:50,070
So in Gainesville, maybe I don't have
any specific servers here at all and so

1004
00:52:50,070 --> 00:52:53,620
I go in and just add everybody to that
one, or whatever it is that I want.

1005
00:52:53,620 --> 00:52:55,480
So I can punch those in.

1006
00:52:55,480 --> 00:52:58,760
Now everybody knows what server to use.

1007
00:52:58,760 --> 00:53:00,005
These are called locales and

1008
00:53:00,005 --> 00:53:02,500
they're intended to be used
with geographic regions.

1009
00:53:02,500 --> 00:53:05,740
If these guys are all in the same
building, I don't really care what

1010
00:53:05,740 --> 00:53:08,850
server they authenticate against,
it's all right here in the same building.

1011
00:53:08,850 --> 00:53:13,080
But if this is a wide area network, I
don't want them going across slow links to

1012
00:53:13,080 --> 00:53:16,710
authenticate when there's a server right
there in the building with them, right?

1013
00:53:16,710 --> 00:53:20,570
So we can use locales to teach
people what is near them,

1014
00:53:20,570 --> 00:53:23,410
what they can reach out to and
what they can get to, all right.

1015
00:53:23,410 --> 00:53:24,900
That's an important thing.

1016
00:53:24,900 --> 00:53:26,820
When they first log in,

1017
00:53:26,820 --> 00:53:31,240
the very first time they're gonna reach
out to whatever server you bind them to.

1018
00:53:31,240 --> 00:53:34,350
But when they log in,
they'll query the locales.

1019
00:53:34,350 --> 00:53:36,120
And from then on out,

1020
00:53:36,120 --> 00:53:40,650
they'll always go to a server that's in
their locale, unless it's not available.

1021
00:53:40,650 --> 00:53:43,530
If it's not available they'll reach
out to whoever they can find.

1022
00:53:43,530 --> 00:53:46,160
But as long as it's available
it'll keep them compartmentalized.

1023
00:53:46,160 --> 00:53:48,440
That's how we divide up our network right.

1024
00:53:48,440 --> 00:53:51,040
If you have a small company or
a medium company and

1025
00:53:51,040 --> 00:53:54,380
you're all in one building, you don't
care about this in the slightest.

1026
00:53:54,380 --> 00:53:57,980
But if you're a large company and you
have offices in many different cities, or

1027
00:53:57,980 --> 00:53:59,525
if you're like a school board and

1028
00:53:59,525 --> 00:54:01,570
you've got a bunch of different
schools around your county.

1029
00:54:02,570 --> 00:54:06,032
Each school could have its own replica,
and the machines in each school could

1030
00:54:06,032 --> 00:54:08,491
authenticate against the local
replica that school.

1031
00:54:08,491 --> 00:54:12,537
That would keep all the authentication
traffic off your wide area network.

1032
00:54:12,537 --> 00:54:15,480
And now it would just be the replica
replicating with the master.

1033
00:54:15,480 --> 00:54:18,230
That's the only traffic you'd really
see over that wide area network.

1034
00:54:18,230 --> 00:54:19,220
Makes things a lot more efficient.

1035
00:54:20,500 --> 00:54:24,520
So as far as setting up our masters and
our replicas, configuring locales is kind

1036
00:54:24,520 --> 00:54:28,360
of an important piece of that, if you've
got more than one geographic location.

1037
00:54:30,600 --> 00:54:35,380
All right, well that's about it for
getting Open Directories set up.

1038
00:54:35,380 --> 00:54:39,360
It's very powerful software, we
are gonna see more about Open Directory.

1039
00:54:39,360 --> 00:54:42,990
You might have noticed that
Open Directory is a user database, and

1040
00:54:42,990 --> 00:54:46,070
yet I never even created
a single user account.

1041
00:54:46,070 --> 00:54:48,940
And that's because we're gonna do
a whole show on user accounts,

1042
00:54:48,940 --> 00:54:51,030
it actually will probably
be the next episode.

1043
00:54:51,030 --> 00:54:53,118
[LAUGH] We'll get a chance to
see those and how they work,

1044
00:54:53,118 --> 00:54:56,040
cuz there's some special user accounts and
things we can do there.

1045
00:54:56,040 --> 00:54:58,260
So we're not done with Open Directory.

1046
00:54:58,260 --> 00:55:01,090
But as far as getting
Open Directory installed, up and

1047
00:55:01,090 --> 00:55:04,340
running, backing it up and
restoring it, we are.

1048
00:55:04,340 --> 00:55:06,300
We've covered all of that in this episode.

1049
00:55:06,300 --> 00:55:09,340
And that's really key stuff to just
getting the infrastructure in place and

1050
00:55:09,340 --> 00:55:10,050
getting it up and running.

1051
00:55:11,290 --> 00:55:14,570
All right, well that's a good spot for
us to wrap this episode up.

1052
00:55:14,570 --> 00:55:18,015
So let me remind you guys,
if you have questions on any of this,

1053
00:55:18,015 --> 00:55:20,880
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1054
00:55:20,880 --> 00:55:25,040
And you'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

1055
00:55:25,040 --> 00:55:28,940
Post you questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1056
00:55:28,940 --> 00:55:32,227
If you have questions after the show,
like if you're watching this recorded,

1057
00:55:32,227 --> 00:55:33,460
you're not left out.

1058
00:55:33,460 --> 00:55:35,080
You can use our Q&A forums.

1059
00:55:35,080 --> 00:55:38,220
At the top of every page on itpro.tv
you'll see a link that says Q&A,

1060
00:55:38,220 --> 00:55:40,150
it'll take you to the forums.

1061
00:55:40,150 --> 00:55:44,862
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer after the show.

1062
00:55:44,862 --> 00:55:48,380
Take advantage of that resource.

1063
00:55:48,380 --> 00:55:49,019
It is there for you.

1064
00:55:49,019 --> 00:55:49,599
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

1065
00:55:49,599 --> 00:55:53,117
Signing of off ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

We're diving right back into
the world of Mac OS Server today, and

10

00:00:49,710 --> 00:00:51,410
If you've been watching
all of our episodes,

in our last episode we were talking
about the Apple open directory and

13
00:00:54,790 --> 00:00:58,180
how we can set up

14
00:00:58,180 --> 00:01:01,290
A user database is shared
across all of our computers so

15
00:01:01,290 --> 00:01:03,990
that when you log in to computer A or
computer B or

16
00:01:03,990 --> 00:01:07,640
computer C, it's the same user
account that you're using on each one.

17
00:01:07,640 --> 00:01:12,950
It's all synchronized, all nice in
one central location, easy to manage.

18
00:01:12,950 --> 00:01:15,430
Now, if you watched that
whole episode there

19
00:01:15,430 --> 00:01:17,770
might have been a question in the back
of your mind as you were thinking,

20
00:01:19,170 --> 00:01:22,100
Don showed us how to set up
the centralized database but

21
00:01:22,100 --> 00:01:26,090
he never actually made any user accounts,
and you're absolutely right.

22
00:01:26,090 --> 00:01:29,630
Throughout that whole episode we never
actually made the user account that is so

23
00:01:29,630 --> 00:01:31,280
important to the Open Directory.

24
00:01:31,280 --> 00:01:32,550
We talked about how they authenticate.

25
00:01:32,550 --> 00:01:34,140
We talked about how to
build up the server,

26
00:01:34,140 --> 00:01:38,220
how to get the Open Directory running,
but we never actually used it, and

27
00:01:38,220 --> 00:01:41,160
this episode here's where
we're going to use it.

28
00:01:41,160 --> 00:01:43,860
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna
take a look at these user accounts and

29
00:01:43,860 --> 00:01:47,090
how they function, what they do,
the different ways to setting them up, and

30
00:01:47,090 --> 00:01:51,980
how we use them on our workstations to
achieve that truly centralized database.

31
00:01:51,980 --> 00:01:56,170
Now in MacOS there's two
primary types of user accounts.

32
00:01:56,170 --> 00:01:57,880
There's actually I don't know five or

33
00:01:57,880 --> 00:02:00,890
six different types of user accounts but
there's two primary ones.

34
00:02:00,890 --> 00:02:04,968
There is what are called Local Users,
and then there's Local Network Users.

35
00:02:04,968 --> 00:02:09,040
And the name is a little bit confusing but
let me show you what I mean.

36
00:02:09,040 --> 00:02:12,200
When I fire up the server app,
we get this screen, right?

37
00:02:12,200 --> 00:02:15,560
This is my general overview and in
the episode when we were setting up open

38
00:02:15,560 --> 00:02:20,490
directory well, we did that all way down
here under advanced and Open Directory.

39
00:02:20,490 --> 00:02:22,850
Here's where we came in to set that up and

40
00:02:22,850 --> 00:02:26,410
after we ran that setup wizard there
really wasn't much more to do in here,

41
00:02:26,410 --> 00:02:29,750
other than maybe mess with locales
if you need to configure those.

42
00:02:29,750 --> 00:02:32,635
Or we did a little a little
bit of archiving, right?

43
00:02:32,635 --> 00:02:34,795
Backup and recoveries,
we did things like that.

44
00:02:34,795 --> 00:02:38,945
But, you don't see user accounts in here.

45
00:02:38,945 --> 00:02:44,185
Well, user accounts are up here,
under the account section, up top.

46
00:02:44,185 --> 00:02:47,685
They're not nested under Open Directory
and you might ask yourself, why not?

47
00:02:47,685 --> 00:02:51,230
Why not have it all combined right there
into one place where it makes sense and

48
00:02:51,230 --> 00:02:55,850
the reason is well, it's actually
more than one type of user account.

49
00:02:55,850 --> 00:02:58,460
It's not just open directory accounts.

50
00:02:58,460 --> 00:03:01,570
When you click on Users,
the default thing for

51
00:03:01,570 --> 00:03:05,195
it to do is to show you a list
of all of the user accounts.

52
00:03:05,195 --> 00:03:09,045
And if I hit that drop down box it'll

out there, this will apply to them.

957
00:48:35,060 --> 00:48:37,670
Now, be aware of two things.

958
00:48:37,670 --> 00:48:42,120
First off, the password policy does not
apply to administrators, all right.

959
00:48:42,120 --> 00:48:43,850
Apple never wants you to
get into a situation,

960
00:48:43,850 --> 00:48:46,550
where your administrator
account is locked out, right.

961
00:48:46,550 --> 00:48:49,580
If you get your system locked out
of the administrator account,

962
00:48:49,580 --> 00:48:51,390
you can't get in to administer the system.

963
00:48:51,390 --> 00:48:55,600
And that's a pretty bad spot to be in, so
it doesn't apply to the administrator.

964
00:48:55,600 --> 00:49:01,490
The second thing is, it doesn't
apply to pre-existing user accounts.

965
00:49:01,490 --> 00:49:05,850
These users that I made, Dave Mustaine,
David Elston, they've never logged in.

966
00:49:05,850 --> 00:49:07,340
So the first time they log in,

967
00:49:07,340 --> 00:49:10,900
if I set that password must be reset,
well that will take effect.

968
00:49:10,900 --> 00:49:15,920
But if a user has logged in even one time,
then the password policy that

969
00:49:15,920 --> 00:49:20,780
we just set will not take effect until
they change their password, all right.

970
00:49:20,780 --> 00:49:22,850
Well, they may not choose
to change their password.

971
00:49:22,850 --> 00:49:25,840
They might say, you know what, forget
that, I'm not gonna change my password.

972
00:49:25,840 --> 00:49:30,010
Well, if they don't, then they're in
effect not under your password policy.

973
00:49:30,010 --> 00:49:32,200
So that's where you have to go
to the user account itself,

974
00:49:32,200 --> 00:49:34,800
and force them to change
their password next time.

975
00:49:34,800 --> 00:49:37,850
If you edit that user,
you can choose the option.

976
00:49:37,850 --> 00:49:38,590
Or wait, not edit it.

977
00:49:38,590 --> 00:49:40,720
You have to do it in a little gear.

978
00:49:40,720 --> 00:49:41,844
But we can tell them,

979
00:49:41,844 --> 00:49:45,165
with the Change Password to force
it to something that we know.

980
00:49:45,165 --> 00:49:47,690
And then set it to require that
password to change at the next login.

981
00:49:47,690 --> 00:49:49,640
So that's how we kind of force that along.

982
00:49:49,640 --> 00:49:51,140
We're doing the password change for

983
00:49:51,140 --> 00:49:53,570
them here, and
changing it to something that we know.

984
00:49:53,570 --> 00:49:55,660
So that's a little bit of a headache.

985
00:49:55,660 --> 00:49:59,260
The key way to make that not
a headache is to do it early, right?

986
00:49:59,260 --> 00:50:03,090
Make sure you set your password policy
early, before you start creating all your

987
00:50:03,090 --> 00:50:05,070
accounts, and
getting people in the system.

988
00:50:05,070 --> 00:50:07,460
But if you just got hired somewhere
that has an existing network,

989
00:50:07,460 --> 00:50:08,310
and put this in place.

990
00:50:08,310 --> 00:50:11,640
You've just got to remember that it
doesn't actually apply to people

991
00:50:11,640 --> 00:50:13,250
until the first time they
change their password.

992
00:50:15,900 --> 00:50:17,960
All right, so
that's basically a password policy, and

993
00:50:17,960 --> 00:50:19,542
how they work, pretty straight forward.

994
00:50:19,542 --> 00:50:22,886
Now, David had a great comment
in the chat room there.

995
00:50:22,886 --> 00:50:26,487
That the fact that this policy doesn't
apply to administrators is a great example

996
00:50:26,487 --> 00:50:28,950
as to why administrator
accounts get attacked so much.

997
00:50:28,950 --> 00:50:30,400
And that's absolutely true,

998
00:50:30,400 --> 00:50:33,500
most people will exclude administrators
from this type of policy.

999
00:50:33,500 --> 00:50:37,400
That's why Apple doesn't give us
a default administrator name, right.

1000
00:50:37,400 --> 00:50:39,914
You know in systems like in
Unix you have that root user,

1001
00:50:39,914 --> 00:50:41,367
that everybody knows is there.

1002
00:50:41,367 --> 00:50:43,310
And in Windows you have a user
called administrator, and

1003
00:50:43,310 --> 00:50:44,850
everybody knows it's there.

1004
00:50:44,850 --> 00:50:47,170
Well in Apple, you've got that root user.

1005
00:50:47,170 --> 00:50:49,780
But it's hidden away, and
you can't use it, right.

1006
00:50:49,780 --> 00:50:52,900
And so you create your own administrator
with your own name, and so

1007
00:50:52,900 --> 00:50:55,260
it's different, and
that makes it a little bit harder.

1008
00:50:55,260 --> 00:50:58,304
It's not true security,
it's security through obscurity, but

1009
00:50:58,304 --> 00:50:59,671
it does achieve a little bit.

1010
00:50:59,671 --> 00:51:02,863
But if somebody tries to brute
force your administrator account,

1011
00:51:02,863 --> 00:51:04,570
well it won't lock it out.

1012
00:51:04,570 --> 00:51:06,480
And so you do still have to be careful,
right.

1013
00:51:06,480 --> 00:51:10,070
That's why you need to have two user
accounts for your administrators.

1014
00:51:10,070 --> 00:51:13,621
One actual administrator account,
and one regular user account.

1015
00:51:13,621 --> 00:51:16,980
And they need to be using the regular user
account for their day to day activities.

1016
00:51:16,980 --> 00:51:19,810
And only use the administrator
account when they're actually

1017
00:51:19,810 --> 00:51:21,050
administering things.

1018
00:51:21,050 --> 00:51:25,040
So it creates that separation, and
it helps to minimize that exposure.

1019
00:51:26,952 --> 00:51:31,050
All right, well, that's about all
I've got on password policies.

1020
00:51:31,050 --> 00:51:33,770
The other thing that we
sort of glanced over, but

1021
00:51:33,770 --> 00:51:37,560
didn't spend a lot of time on were groups.

1022
00:51:37,560 --> 00:51:39,320
Inside of our server app,

1023
00:51:39,320 --> 00:51:42,650
we don't just have user accounts
that we manage, we have groups.

1024
00:51:42,650 --> 00:51:45,580
And groups are special little accounts,

1025
00:51:45,580 --> 00:51:49,300
that we can use to combine users together,
right.

1026
00:51:49,300 --> 00:51:51,660
Now, groups work kind of a neat way.

1027
00:51:51,660 --> 00:51:56,610
What a group does, is it works under
this idea of, we have user accounts,

1028
00:51:56,610 --> 00:51:58,600
because we need to assign permissions.

1029
00:51:58,600 --> 00:52:01,380
I want certain users to be
able to get to a folder.

1030
00:52:01,380 --> 00:52:03,940
Or I want certain users to
be able to use this printer.

1031
00:52:03,940 --> 00:52:06,660
Or I want certain users
to do this one activity.

1032
00:52:06,660 --> 00:52:10,480
Well, if I have five users,
I can just go and

1033
00:52:10,480 --> 00:52:14,390
manually give those five users permission
to access that folder, or that file.

1034
00:52:14,390 --> 00:52:17,990
But if I have 500 users,
I don't wanna do it 500 times.

1035
00:52:17,990 --> 00:52:21,300
And if every time I hire a new user,
I have to go through this whole

1036
00:52:21,300 --> 00:52:25,030
deal of setting permissions,
that becomes quite a headache pretty fast.

1037
00:52:25,030 --> 00:52:27,440
So groups help me avoid that.

1038
00:52:27,440 --> 00:52:29,630
I can create a group myself.

1039
00:52:29,630 --> 00:52:31,917
I can put the user accounts in that group.

1040
00:52:31,917 --> 00:52:36,203
And now when I assign permissions, I can
give permissions to the group instead of

1041
00:52:36,203 --> 00:52:39,610
giving permissions to
each individual user.

1042
00:52:39,610 --> 00:52:42,920
So for example, if I wanna create
a group here in the server app.

1043
00:52:42,920 --> 00:52:45,010
If I go to the Accounts and

1044
00:52:45,010 --> 00:52:48,860
Group section, you'll see there is
one Group created automatically.

1045
00:52:48,860 --> 00:52:53,150
When you install Open Directory,
it creates a group called Workgroup.

1046
00:52:53,150 --> 00:52:57,130
And if you take a look at the Workgroup,
it includes all of your users.

1047
00:52:57,130 --> 00:53:00,800
Every user that gets created
goes in the Workgroup group.

1048
00:53:00,800 --> 00:53:06,410
So, the reason they create that is if
you wanna give permissions to everybody,

1049
00:53:06,410 --> 00:53:08,560
well, you use that Workgroup group.

1050
00:53:08,560 --> 00:53:10,150
It's there for you, right?

1051
00:53:10,150 --> 00:53:13,450
But, we can create on our own
that's a little bit more specific.

1052
00:53:13,450 --> 00:53:16,992
So, I might create a group and
it's much like creating a user.

1053
00:53:16,992 --> 00:53:19,105
When you go to create a group,
you hit the plus symbol.

1054
00:53:19,105 --> 00:53:22,155
And you can pick between a Local Group,
and a Local Network Group.

1055
00:53:22,155 --> 00:53:25,285
The Local Network Group is
what's in the open directory.

1056
00:53:25,285 --> 00:53:26,545
You give it a full name.

1057
00:53:26,545 --> 00:53:28,218
So I'll call this The Band, right.

1058
00:53:28,218 --> 00:53:29,615
These are the guys that are in The Band.

1059
00:53:29,615 --> 00:53:32,385
And it'll get a Unix group name.

1060
00:53:32,385 --> 00:53:35,735
And then we can specify if we're gonna
use it for a mailing list, right.

1061
00:53:35,735 --> 00:53:37,645
If this is gonna be a mailing list.

1062
00:53:37,645 --> 00:53:40,015
You send an email to it and
the email goes to all of these people,

1063
00:53:40,015 --> 00:53:42,085
you can check that off,
and you can have that set.

1064
00:53:42,085 --> 00:53:42,890
I'm not gonna do that.

1065
00:53:42,890 --> 00:53:45,150
And then I'll hit Create, right.

1066
00:53:45,150 --> 00:53:48,500
That's gonna create the group,
but nobody's in the group.

1067
00:53:49,538 --> 00:53:53,990
I can double-click on that group, and
then I can add in the members right here.

1068
00:53:53,990 --> 00:53:58,900
I can just hit the little plus symbol,
and I can start to type in the users

1069
00:54:00,700 --> 00:54:03,230
and get them added one by one, all right?

1070
00:54:03,230 --> 00:54:07,260
If I'm adding a bunch of users to a group,
this is the easiest way to do it, right?

1071
00:54:07,260 --> 00:54:10,880
We come through, and we find each of
the users that we want to put in here.

1072
00:54:10,880 --> 00:54:14,319
And, we add them into that list, right.

1073
00:54:14,319 --> 00:54:18,643
But, if I wanna add one user
to five different groups,

1074
00:54:18,643 --> 00:54:21,230
this isn't so convenient.

1075
00:54:21,230 --> 00:54:24,440
Cuz I don't think I wanna edit all
five groups and add in that one user.

1076
00:54:24,440 --> 00:54:26,960
So we can actually do
this the opposite way.

1077
00:54:26,960 --> 00:54:30,500
You can add users to group right here,
by editing the group.

1078
00:54:30,500 --> 00:54:34,400
But you can also add a user to
a group by editing the user.

1079
00:54:34,400 --> 00:54:36,470
It just depends on what
you're trying to achieve.

1080
00:54:36,470 --> 00:54:39,830
If I wanna add multiple
people to one group,

1081
00:54:39,830 --> 00:54:43,150
it's easiest to edit the group right here,
like I'm doing, right.

1082
00:54:43,150 --> 00:54:48,900
If I wanna add one person to more than
one group, it's easier to edit the user.

1083
00:54:48,900 --> 00:54:52,930
So I could go to Users,
I can take somebody like Nick Menza, and

1084
00:54:52,930 --> 00:54:54,260
I'll see the Groups that he's in.

1085
00:54:54,260 --> 00:54:57,880
And I can hit plus, and I can start
adding him to more Groups right here,

1086
00:54:57,880 --> 00:55:00,420
all the Groups that I want, right.

1087
00:55:00,420 --> 00:55:03,060
So, handling that Group
membership is pretty easy.

1088
00:55:04,160 --> 00:55:08,460
Once they're in the group, now I can
give permissions to that group and

1089
00:55:08,460 --> 00:55:09,630
they'll get access.

1090
00:55:09,630 --> 00:55:14,080
So, if I have a folder,
here I'll jump into My Documents,

1091
00:55:14,080 --> 00:55:16,600
and I'll make a new folder in here.

1092
00:55:18,500 --> 00:55:22,380
And maybe this is my Accounting documents,
right?

1093
00:55:22,380 --> 00:55:25,780
And so, I want The Band, to have
access to the Accounting documents.

1094
00:55:25,780 --> 00:55:28,670
Well, if I pull up the information for

1095
00:55:28,670 --> 00:55:34,250
that folder, down here at the bottom,
I've got Sharing & Permissions.

1096
00:55:34,250 --> 00:55:37,190
And I'll see who has
access to it right now.

1097
00:55:37,190 --> 00:55:43,540
Now in the standard Unix format, we end
up with a user, a group, and an other.

1098
00:55:43,540 --> 00:55:46,310
The user is me, Help Desk,
that's who I'm logged in as right now.

1099
00:55:46,310 --> 00:55:48,600
So I'm the owner, and
I get read and write.

1100
00:55:48,600 --> 00:55:50,550
The Group is Staff.

1101
00:55:50,550 --> 00:55:54,050
Staff is all of my other user accounts,
and they get read-only.

1102
00:55:54,050 --> 00:55:57,247
And then, Everyone,
well that's everybody else, and

1103
00:55:57,247 --> 00:55:59,256
I can see they get read-only also.

1104
00:55:59,256 --> 00:56:01,903
I could change the group of that folder.

1105
00:56:01,903 --> 00:56:05,164
From staff to the band and
now they would have access to it, but

1106
00:56:05,164 --> 00:56:09,494
I'm gonna have a little bit of a problem
there cuz it's an open directory group and

1107
00:56:09,494 --> 00:56:10,750
not a local group.

1108
00:56:10,750 --> 00:56:14,600
It'll work, you can do it, but it's better
to leave that alone as a local one.

1109
00:56:14,600 --> 00:56:16,740
We could remove that access
if we didn't want it.

1110
00:56:16,740 --> 00:56:19,470
But we can use
Apple's Access Control List,

1111
00:56:19,470 --> 00:56:22,610
their ACL functionality to add to this.

1112
00:56:22,610 --> 00:56:27,300
And I can add more groups, so
I can add another group, and here,

1113
00:56:27,300 --> 00:56:29,520
you'll see where I can pick
from my local users and

1114
00:56:29,520 --> 00:56:33,440
groups, and my network users,
and my network group.

1115
00:56:33,440 --> 00:56:37,550
And I can add the band, and so
I'm going to add the band, and

1116
00:56:37,550 --> 00:56:40,060
I'm going to give them read and write.

1117
00:56:40,060 --> 00:56:42,450
They'll have full access to that folder.

1118
00:56:42,450 --> 00:56:45,160
Now, anyone who's in that group,

1119
00:56:45,160 --> 00:56:48,190
anybody who's in the band,
will have access to that folder.

1120
00:56:48,190 --> 00:56:52,860
And so, when I fire my drummer and
I bring in a new drummer, well,

1121
00:56:52,860 --> 00:56:56,210
all I do is I take the old
drummer out of the group and,

1122
00:56:56,210 --> 00:57:00,460
then, I add the new drummer to the group
and they get access to that folder.

1123
00:57:00,460 --> 00:57:03,340
They get access through
their group membership.

1124
00:57:03,340 --> 00:57:07,360
So, groups make it really easy to
manage permissions and access.

1125
00:57:07,360 --> 00:57:10,110
When I add a new band member,
I just throw them in the group.

1126
00:57:10,110 --> 00:57:13,430
I don't have to go to all
the various folders and files and

1127
00:57:13,430 --> 00:57:16,190
places like that where I assign
permissions and add that new user.

1128
00:57:16,190 --> 00:57:18,070
I just add them to the group.

1129
00:57:18,070 --> 00:57:22,580
So the rule of thumb, is you should
never assign permissions to a user.

1130
00:57:22,580 --> 00:57:25,230
Unless you're using something
that absolutely requires it.

1131
00:57:25,230 --> 00:57:27,160
Like remote desktop settings.

1132
00:57:27,160 --> 00:57:31,120
But anytime that you can assign
it to a group, you should.

1133
00:57:31,120 --> 00:57:33,910
Because groups make life
a lot easier to manage.

1134
00:57:33,910 --> 00:57:36,690
Another neat thing about groups
is they can be nested, all right?

1135
00:57:36,690 --> 00:57:38,520
Let me show you an example of that.

1136
00:57:38,520 --> 00:57:43,150
Let's say that I have sales people,
sales people all over the world.

1137
00:57:43,150 --> 00:57:47,680
And so there's certain things that I want
every sales person to have access to.

1138
00:57:47,680 --> 00:57:51,654
So I go into my server manager,
into server app, and I go into groups and

1139
00:57:51,654 --> 00:57:56,111
I create a group called Sales People,
all right, so these are my sales people.

1140
00:57:59,760 --> 00:58:01,590
Okay, so now I've gotta do sales people.

1141
00:58:01,590 --> 00:58:04,705
And I want all of my sales people to
have access to this particular folder.

1142
00:58:05,875 --> 00:58:10,585
But then, I see that I've got some other
sales people that are in North America.

1143
00:58:10,585 --> 00:58:12,615
And I want them to have this other folder.

1144
00:58:12,615 --> 00:58:14,785
And I want the ones in South America
to have their own folder.

1145
00:58:14,785 --> 00:58:16,335
I want the ones in Europe
to have their own folder.

1146
00:58:16,335 --> 00:58:18,000
And Asia to have their own folder.

1147
00:58:18,000 --> 00:58:18,990
And then that way,

1148
00:58:18,990 --> 00:58:21,510
they're kind of separated and
they can't see each others stuff.

1149
00:58:22,550 --> 00:58:25,910
Well, if I have one big sales people
group, I can't really use that.

1150
00:58:25,910 --> 00:58:27,430
So I'm gonna need to create more groups.

1151
00:58:27,430 --> 00:58:33,530
I'm gonna need to create a,
like a North America sales and

1152
00:58:33,530 --> 00:58:39,300
maybe South American sales,
Europe sales and so on, right?

1153
00:58:39,300 --> 00:58:42,920
So these are all the different sales
groups that I'm gonna have for

1154
00:58:42,920 --> 00:58:43,570
my sales people.

1155
00:58:44,780 --> 00:58:49,760
Well, now,
what happens when I hire a new person?

1156
00:58:49,760 --> 00:58:53,430
When I hire a new person, I could say
okay you're working in North America so

1157
00:58:53,430 --> 00:58:58,180
let me put you in North America sales,
and I'll put you in sales people.

1158
00:58:58,180 --> 00:59:01,350
In fact, maybe I ditch that one and
rename it.

1159
00:59:01,350 --> 00:59:05,660
I might create one like all sales
people or I could just rename this one.

1160
00:59:05,660 --> 00:59:10,300
I'll call this one All Sales People,
there we go.

1161
00:59:10,300 --> 00:59:16,660
So I can put them in two groups,but it's
even easier if I just nest the groups.

1162
00:59:16,660 --> 00:59:18,900
You can put one group
inside another group.

1163
00:59:18,900 --> 00:59:24,450
I could take All sales People and
when I added that one in the membership,

1164
00:59:24,450 --> 00:59:30,015
I could add in North America sales,
South America sales,

1165
00:59:30,015 --> 00:59:34,130
and Europe sales, all right?

1166
00:59:34,130 --> 00:59:36,120
Now, I've got groups in a group.

1167
00:59:37,190 --> 00:59:41,600
If I put a user, in EU sales,
right, so if I go in here and

1168
00:59:41,600 --> 00:59:48,190
I'm going to add Chris, Chris is going
to be in European sales, all right.

1169
00:59:48,190 --> 00:59:54,810
Chris is in European sales and European
sales is in the All Sales People group.

1170
00:59:54,810 --> 00:59:58,880
So if I give permission to the all
sales people group, Chris will get it.

1171
00:59:58,880 --> 01:00:03,090
And if I give permissions to the EU sales,
he's gonna get that.

1172
01:00:03,090 --> 01:00:07,260
Because technically he's in both,
even though his user account is only in

1173
01:00:07,260 --> 01:00:12,250
EU sales,
EU sales itself is in All Sales People.

1174
01:00:12,250 --> 01:00:15,450
And that's how he gets his
access through nested groups.

1175
01:00:15,450 --> 01:00:17,560
And you can nest several
layers deep if you want.

1176
01:00:17,560 --> 01:00:19,800
