to get that in place.

1403
01:11:41,655 --> 01:11:44,015
Right now, somebody would've
had to have changed that.

1404
01:11:44,015 --> 01:11:46,475
So it's a pretty uncommon thing to happen,
but it is possible.

1405
01:11:49,717 --> 01:11:52,965
Al lright, now, those are pretty much
the different things that we look for

1406
01:11:52,965 --> 01:11:54,785
when we have problems with authentication.

1407
01:11:54,785 --> 01:11:57,937
Number one was DNS and
network connectivity.

1408
01:11:57,937 --> 01:11:59,688
Right?
Make sure you can connect to the server.

1409
01:11:59,688 --> 01:12:01,546
Number two was your clock.

1410
01:12:01,546 --> 01:12:03,404
Gotta make sure you're time is in sync.

1411
01:12:03,404 --> 01:12:05,820
Number three was to check the ACLs.

1412
01:12:05,820 --> 01:12:07,910
Do you have access to those services?

1413
01:12:07,910 --> 01:12:11,510
And then number four,
is Kerberos even on for that service?

1414
01:12:11,510 --> 01:12:13,270
Right, cuz that may be the problem too.

1415
01:12:13,270 --> 01:12:15,020
So those are kinda the four
things that we look for

1416
01:12:15,020 --> 01:12:17,210
when we're trying to
troubleshoot access like that.

1417
01:12:17,210 --> 01:12:20,070
The one we leave off though is
the common sense one which is,

1418
01:12:20,070 --> 01:12:21,570
does the user actually
know their password?

1419
01:12:21,570 --> 01:12:22,390
Are they locked out?

1420
01:12:22,390 --> 01:12:25,580
Maybe the user account has been disabled
because they exceeded our password policy

1421
01:12:25,580 --> 01:12:26,700
or something like that.

1422
01:12:26,700 --> 01:12:28,570
So, you might need to go and
re-enable them.

1423
01:12:28,570 --> 01:12:29,710
Those are all things
that we need to look at.

1424
01:12:31,240 --> 01:12:32,540
One last thing I wanna mention.

1425
01:12:32,540 --> 01:12:34,120
I don't know if this will
show up on the exam, but

1426
01:12:34,120 --> 01:12:36,030
in real life it's something that I use.

1427
01:12:36,030 --> 01:12:40,510
Whenever I'm troubleshooting a Kerberos
type problem, I mentioned in the,

1428
01:12:40,510 --> 01:12:43,420
I guess it was two episodes ago where
we talked about authentication.

1429
01:12:43,420 --> 01:12:45,970
I talked a little bit
about how Kerberos works.

1430
01:12:45,970 --> 01:12:48,830
About how we get that ticket granting
ticket and how we're able to

1431
01:12:48,830 --> 01:12:52,480
generate service tickets based off of
that to run different applications.

1432
01:12:52,480 --> 01:12:55,200
Well, there may come a time when
you boot up your machine and

1433
01:12:55,200 --> 01:12:59,680
you're having some issues, and you just
wanna know, do I have a valid ticket?

1434
01:12:59,680 --> 01:13:01,730
And which server gave me that ticket?

1435
01:13:01,730 --> 01:13:03,600
If I have more than one
Open Directory server,

1436
01:13:03,600 --> 01:13:05,060
which one did I authenticate off of?

1437
01:13:05,060 --> 01:13:06,890
Especially if you're doing locales.

1438
01:13:06,890 --> 01:13:08,560
Well, the end user doesn't see that.

1439
01:13:08,560 --> 01:13:09,360
That's not in the GUI.

1440
01:13:09,360 --> 01:13:14,860
But there's a super simple utility we can
use from the command line to view it.

1441
01:13:14,860 --> 01:13:19,460
If I jump over to my workstation here,
which is now gonna have time problems so

1442
01:13:19,460 --> 01:13:21,780
let me [LAUGH] revert my time.

1443
01:13:21,780 --> 01:13:23,150
We'll set that back to automatic.

1444
01:13:23,150 --> 01:13:23,810
There we go.

1445
01:13:23,810 --> 01:13:27,930
All right, so back here on my workstation,
if I'm logged into open directory and

1446
01:13:27,930 --> 01:13:32,590
I just wanna see information about my
ticket, you can open up a terminal window.

1447
01:13:34,000 --> 01:13:39,180
And in terminal you can run a very
simple command, it's klist, all right?

1448
01:13:39,180 --> 01:13:41,530
K is for Kerberos.

1449
01:13:41,530 --> 01:13:45,960
And you can run klist and it will show
you all of your Kerberos tickets.

1450
01:13:45,960 --> 01:13:47,490
Most of the time you're
only gonna have one,

1451
01:13:47,490 --> 01:13:50,180
but if you've done a lot of stuff you
might actually have more than one.

1452
01:13:50,180 --> 01:13:55,060
But you can see your ticket in here,
and get an idea of what server

1453
01:13:55,060 --> 01:13:59,420
you logged into, and
whether your ticket is actually valid.

1454
01:13:59,420 --> 01:14:02,080
So let me rerun that on a wider screen.

1455
01:14:02,080 --> 01:14:03,080
There we go.

1456
01:14:03,080 --> 01:14:07,250
So, I can see that I've got a credential
cache, and here's my principal.

1457
01:14:07,250 --> 01:14:09,150
I'm logged in as Don Pezet.

1458
01:14:09,150 --> 01:14:13,970
And I logged into the server,
OSX-SERVER1.LAB.ITPRO.TV, right?

1459
01:14:13,970 --> 01:14:15,450
That's the server I logged in on.

1460
01:14:15,450 --> 01:14:19,940
If I had more than one
Open Directory server in place,

1461
01:14:19,940 --> 01:14:21,960
then it would tell me
which one I was hitting.

1462
01:14:21,960 --> 01:14:26,170
And so I can see it was issued
March 16th at 11:36 AM.

1463
01:14:26,170 --> 01:14:30,123
And it expires March 16th at 21:36, right?

1464
01:14:30,123 --> 01:14:32,413
What is that, 9 PM?

1465
01:14:32,413 --> 01:14:34,970
So [LAUGH] I did my military time there.

1466
01:14:34,970 --> 01:14:39,140
So 9 PM, so
it's gonna expire later on this evening.

1467
01:14:39,140 --> 01:14:41,820
And then I can see the principal,
where it came from.

1468
01:14:41,820 --> 01:14:45,550
And that ticket granting
ticket right there,

1469
01:14:45,550 --> 01:14:49,700
that's how I'm identifying myself and
reaching out and running these services.

1470
01:14:49,700 --> 01:14:52,320
So you can get an idea of whether
you have a valid certificate.

1471
01:14:52,320 --> 01:14:56,060
If this comes back empty,
you're not logged into Open Directory.

1472
01:14:56,060 --> 01:14:58,790
Maybe you were logged in at some point,
but

1473
01:14:58,790 --> 01:15:01,810
now you've become disconnected from the
network and your ticket is expired, right?

1474
01:15:01,810 --> 01:15:05,850
And you're trying to access the network
now, but you haven't gotten a new ticket.

1475
01:15:05,850 --> 01:15:08,030
Maybe the domain is offline.

1476
01:15:08,030 --> 01:15:10,990
Whatever open directory server
is there is offline, and

1477
01:15:10,990 --> 01:15:12,635
your ticket's expired
you can't get a renewal.

1478
01:15:12,635 --> 01:15:14,080
Klist will show that.

1479
01:15:14,080 --> 01:15:17,120
You'll be able to see that you
don't have a valid certificate.

1480
01:15:17,120 --> 01:15:19,770
If this comes back empty,
you know you've got problems.

1481
01:15:19,770 --> 01:15:22,720
It should come back with a certificate,
at least one, or

1482
01:15:22,720 --> 01:15:28,050
a ticket granting ticket, and you should
currently be in between these two times.

1483
01:15:28,050 --> 01:15:30,260
Whatever the time is on your clock
should be between these two,

1484
01:15:30,260 --> 01:15:32,200
and you'll be a healthy system.

1485
01:15:33,310 --> 01:15:35,970
If you stay logged in past this time,

1486
01:15:35,970 --> 01:15:38,380
your system will automatically
get a new ticket.

1487
01:15:38,380 --> 01:15:39,500
In fact, if you're ever bored one day,

1488
01:15:39,500 --> 01:15:42,560
you can just sit here and re-run klist
over and over and over again, and

1489
01:15:42,560 --> 01:15:46,330
eventually you'll see this renew
even before you hit the end time.

1490
01:15:46,330 --> 01:15:48,030
It doesn't run the full
life of the certificate.

1491
01:15:48,030 --> 01:15:50,820
It'll actually renew early
to make sure that you have

1492
01:15:50,820 --> 01:15:52,180
a zero interruption connection.

1493
01:15:54,010 --> 01:15:57,470
All right, so the klist utility is
just another way that we can see that

1494
01:15:57,470 --> 01:15:58,430
right there in the command line.

1495
01:16:00,140 --> 01:16:05,050
All right well that pretty much wraps up
all I've got on user accounts and groups,

1496
01:16:05,050 --> 01:16:07,300
and basic Kerberos authentication.

1497
01:16:07,300 --> 01:16:10,860
It's a good way to see how to
actually use the stuff that we

1498
01:16:10,860 --> 01:16:12,610
set up in the other episodes.

1499
01:16:12,610 --> 01:16:15,180
Very powerful,
now I did a really small environment here,

1500
01:16:15,180 --> 01:16:18,130
in yours you might have hundreds or
thousands of users.

1501
01:16:18,130 --> 01:16:20,480
Gets to be really big,
well it'll scale to that.

1502
01:16:20,480 --> 01:16:23,090
Open Directory can scale very, very large.

1503
01:16:23,090 --> 01:16:26,900
Just keep in mind, you might need
more than one directory server,

1504
01:16:26,900 --> 01:16:28,680
because the servers do
start to get bogged down.

1505
01:16:28,680 --> 01:16:32,180
They get kind of busy handling all
these authentication requests.

1506
01:16:32,180 --> 01:16:37,410
So on average, a Open Directory server
can handle a few thousand users.

1507
01:16:37,410 --> 01:16:41,020
I usually try and
keep it around 2,500 users per replica.

1508
01:16:41,020 --> 01:16:43,490
And then you just add more
replicas as you need.

1509
01:16:43,490 --> 01:16:45,581
If you've got less than
2,500 users though,

1510
01:16:45,581 --> 01:16:48,260
then you probably only need
two directory servers.

1511
01:16:48,260 --> 01:16:50,240
You should always have two.

1512
01:16:50,240 --> 01:16:53,410
If one fails, you wanna have
a back up that's already running.

1513
01:16:53,410 --> 01:16:55,980
You don't want to go offline and
have to go and do a recovery.

1514
01:16:55,980 --> 01:16:58,440
You'd rather have two and be in business.

1515
01:16:58,440 --> 01:17:00,480
Pretty easy to create all this stuff so
you might as well do two.

1516
01:17:01,574 --> 01:17:05,530
All right, well about it for user
accounts, so let me just remind you guys,

1517
01:17:05,530 --> 01:17:09,930
if you have questions on anything
we've talked about, feel free to ask.

1518
01:17:09,930 --> 01:17:12,930
Live during the show you can
go to http://itpro.tv/live and

1519
01:17:12,930 --> 01:17:15,040
you'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

1520
01:17:15,040 --> 01:17:18,410
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1521
01:17:18,410 --> 01:17:21,700
If you have any questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1522
01:17:21,700 --> 01:17:25,282
At the top of every page on ITProTV
you'll see a link that says Q&A.

1523
01:17:25,282 --> 01:17:28,010
It'll take you to the forums,
you can post your questions there.

1524
01:17:28,010 --> 01:17:30,240
We monitor and answer after the show.

1525
01:17:30,240 --> 01:17:32,865
One way or another we'll get you
the answers to your questions because

1526
01:17:32,865 --> 01:17:34,080
that's what we're all about.

1527
01:17:34,080 --> 01:17:37,200
We want to make sure you guys have all
the information you need to be successful.

1528
01:17:38,500 --> 01:17:40,200
Well, that's all I've got for today.

1529
01:17:40,200 --> 01:17:44,790
So signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

1530
01:17:44,790 --> 01:17:54,790
[MUSIC]

1531
01:17:58,710 --> 01:17:59,210
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. He also shows some of the settings that can be configured.
episodes.title: Configuration Profiles
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[NOISE]

2
00:00:15,299 --> 00:00:25,299
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:33,551 --> 00:00:34,641
All right.
Good morning.

4
00:00:34,641 --> 00:00:35,181
Good afternoon.

5
00:00:35,181 --> 00:00:35,920
And good evening.

6
00:00:35,920 --> 00:00:37,440
And welcome back.

7
00:00:37,440 --> 00:00:38,830
To another episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:38,830 --> 00:00:40,860
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

9
00:00:40,860 --> 00:00:44,970
Back again with another episode of
Apple-Certified Technical Coordinator.

10
00:00:44,970 --> 00:00:47,060
We're going to be diving right
back into our Apple Technology.

11
00:00:47,060 --> 00:00:49,550
And today's is one of those neat ones.

12
00:00:49,550 --> 00:00:51,360
I know this is one that a lot of
viewers have been waiting for.

13
00:00:51,360 --> 00:00:54,650
We're going to be taking
a look at the Profile Manager.

14
00:00:54,650 --> 00:00:55,370
Now.

15
00:00:55,370 --> 00:00:56,820
What is the Profile Manager?

16
00:00:56,820 --> 00:01:00,910
Well, if you've got 1 Mac,
or 5 Macs for that matter.

17
00:01:00,910 --> 00:01:03,210
And you want to get them
set-up a particular way.

18
00:01:03,210 --> 00:01:06,180
You want them to have
certain Default Settings.

19
00:01:06,180 --> 00:01:07,170
Certain Wallpaper.

20
00:01:07,170 --> 00:01:08,860
Certain Permissions.

21
00:01:08,860 --> 00:01:10,440
Well, you just go and set that up.

22
00:01:10,440 --> 00:01:11,600
You've only got a couple of Macs.

23
00:01:11,600 --> 00:01:13,180
You just do it by hand.

24
00:01:13,180 --> 00:01:15,330
But what if you've got 500 macs?

25
00:01:15,330 --> 00:01:16,270
or 5,000 macs?

26
00:01:16,270 --> 00:01:20,080
And you want them all
configured the same way?

27
00:01:20,080 --> 00:01:22,320
Well, that becomes really challenging.

28
00:01:22,320 --> 00:01:23,510
You can't just sit there.

29
00:01:23,510 --> 00:01:24,010
And go through.

30
00:01:24,010 --> 00:01:25,480
And configure all those machines.

31
00:01:25,480 --> 00:01:28,240
Well, I guess if you were an hourly
employee then it would create

32
00:01:28,240 --> 00:01:29,080
some job security.

33
00:01:29,080 --> 00:01:29,670
You could just go and

34
00:01:29,670 --> 00:01:32,850
spend day after day after day doing
the same thing over and over again.

35
00:01:32,850 --> 00:01:38,070
But wouldn't it be nice to have
a way to implement that all at once.

36
00:01:38,070 --> 00:01:41,600
To have a Standard Configuration
we push out to our machines.

37
00:01:41,600 --> 00:01:44,610
The other thing is, if you work in
an environment where you have all

38
00:01:44,610 --> 00:01:47,450
highly trained IT Professionals
that are responsible.

39
00:01:47,450 --> 00:01:50,650
That have read your Security Policies and
followed them to the letter.

40
00:01:50,650 --> 00:01:52,842
Once that configuration is in place,
you're done.

41
00:01:52,842 --> 00:01:55,570
But I've never worked in that environment.

42
00:01:55,570 --> 00:01:59,470
I've never worked where I was surrounded
by highly trained IT Professionals.

43
00:01:59,470 --> 00:02:02,530
You're normally working
with some IT Professionals.

44
00:02:02,530 --> 00:02:06,390
But most of your company has
employees that aren't IT guys.

45
00:02:06,390 --> 00:02:08,450
They are accountants.

46
00:02:08,450 --> 00:02:13,300
And lawyers, receptionists,
mail clerks, whatever.

47
00:02:13,300 --> 00:02:14,780
IT is not their forte.

48
00:02:14,780 --> 00:02:18,970
And when a computer is set a certain way
for security reasons and it annoys them.

49
00:02:18,970 --> 00:02:21,790
They'll look for ways to bypass that,
just turn it off.

50
00:02:21,790 --> 00:02:26,690
So not only do we need a way to centrally
create a Standard Configuration for

51
00:02:26,690 --> 00:02:27,910
our machines.

52
00:02:27,910 --> 00:02:31,310
We need some way to make sure
the machines stay configured that way.

53
00:02:32,330 --> 00:02:35,220
If I set a machine to, let's just say for

54
00:02:35,220 --> 00:02:40,500
example, require a password
when the Screensaver kicks on.

55
00:02:40,500 --> 00:02:43,270
So if the Screensaver
kicks on the machine.

56
00:02:43,270 --> 00:02:45,500
And somebody tries to wake the machine up.

57
00:02:45,500 --> 00:02:46,950
It'll prompt for a password.

58
00:02:46,950 --> 00:02:48,310
That's a security measure.

59
00:02:48,310 --> 00:02:50,690
We do that to make sure that
somebody else doesn't come and

60
00:02:50,690 --> 00:02:52,450
use your computer while your gone.

61
00:02:52,450 --> 00:02:54,140
Now some users get annoyed with that.

62
00:02:54,140 --> 00:02:55,240
The screensaver came on.

63
00:02:55,240 --> 00:02:56,930
Now I gotta type my password.

64
00:02:56,930 --> 00:02:58,730
So they might want to turn that off.

65
00:02:58,730 --> 00:03:02,430
But if we have a security policy that
says, that setting needs to be in place.

66
00:03:02,430 --> 00:03:04,890
We need that to be enforced.

67
00:03:04,890 --> 00:03:07,590
I can use the Profile Manager to

68
00:03:07,590 --> 00:03:11,860
create a Standard Configuration that
requires that Screensaver Password.

69
00:03:11,860 --> 00:03:15,250
But a user can go and turn that
Screensaver Password off, couldn't they?

70
00:03:15,250 --> 00:03:17,020
They can, it's not hard to do.

71
00:03:17,020 --> 00:03:20,240
Well, using the Profile Manager.

72
00:03:20,240 --> 00:03:23,650
I can continue to push updates
out to that machine so

73
00:03:23,650 --> 00:03:25,590
that if somebody turns the setting off.

74
00:03:25,590 --> 00:03:27,860
We just turn it right back on again.

75
00:03:27,860 --> 00:03:29,650
Right?
That's how we can enforce that setting.

76
00:03:29,650 --> 00:03:32,620
Or we can make it where they can't
turn it off in the first place.

77
00:03:32,620 --> 00:03:34,610
The Profile Manager is very powerful for
that.

78
00:03:35,900 --> 00:03:37,170
It's a neat product.

79
00:03:37,170 --> 00:03:40,260
And it really does work well
with Mac desktops and laptops.

80
00:03:40,260 --> 00:03:41,930
Anything that's running OS10.

81
00:03:41,930 --> 00:03:43,620
But the funny part about it.

82
00:03:43,620 --> 00:03:45,950
It wasn't even designed for
that originally.

83
00:03:45,950 --> 00:03:50,450
The Profile Manager was originally
designed for managing mobile devices..

84
00:03:50,450 --> 00:03:55,310
It was part of the whole MDM movement,
the Mobile Device Management.

85
00:03:55,310 --> 00:04:00,000
The original versions were designed to
be able to control iPhones and iPads.

86
00:04:00,000 --> 00:04:02,610
To be able to manage what
applications are running on them.

87
00:04:02,610 --> 00:04:04,640
And in the event that they were lost.

88
00:04:04,640 --> 00:04:07,830
To be able to lock their screen to
prevent people from using them.

89
00:04:07,830 --> 00:04:11,310
And to erase the device
if you couldn't find it.

90
00:04:11,310 --> 00:04:13,370
So if I left my phone on a train.

91
00:04:13,370 --> 00:04:14,240
Or on a cab.

92
00:04:14,240 --> 00:04:15,050
Or whatever.

93
00:04:15,050 --> 00:04:16,940
That I don't know who
has my phone anymore.

94
00:04:16,940 --> 00:04:17,690
It's gone.

95
00:04:17,690 --> 00:04:20,900
It could just be somebody, innocent
who turns it into a lost and found.

96
00:04:20,900 --> 00:04:22,150
Or it could be somebody notorious.

97
00:04:22,150 --> 00:04:23,810
It's like digging through all the emails.

98
00:04:23,810 --> 00:04:25,820
And trying to find personal information.

99
00:04:25,820 --> 00:04:29,430
Well, with an MBM solution
like the Profile Manager.

100
00:04:29,430 --> 00:04:30,020
I can go in there.

101
00:04:30,020 --> 00:04:32,080
And I can say, you know what,
just erase my phone.

102
00:04:32,080 --> 00:04:33,030
Just erase it.

103
00:04:33,030 --> 00:04:34,650
And somebody else has got the phone.

104

00:07:28,450 --> 00:07:30,260

00:07:30,260 --> 00:07:32,910

00:07:32,910 --> 00:07:35,330

177
00:07:35,330 --> 00:07:39,940
The Configuration Profiles, we push
them out, can be kind of dangerous.

178
00:07:39,940 --> 00:07:42,810
Imagine if somebody
created a malicious file.

179
00:07:42,810 --> 00:07:45,670
A Configuration Profile that had all
sorts of really bad settings in it.

180
00:07:45,670 --> 00:07:46,990
That really weaken security.

181
00:07:46,990 --> 00:07:47,910
And then went out.

182
00:07:47,910 --> 00:07:49,960
And started pushing it to your machines.

183
00:07:49,960 --> 00:07:50,658
That'd be pretty bad.

184
00:07:50,658 --> 00:07:54,013
So when we get set-up
with a Profile Manager.

185
00:07:54,013 --> 00:07:57,924
One of the things that we have to
do is what's called an Enrollment.

186
00:07:57,924 --> 00:08:01,709
Clients aren't going to trust
your server by default.

187
00:08:01,709 --> 00:08:04,090
They don't know who you are.

188
00:08:04,090 --> 00:08:08,950
So we have to make our clients
recognize the server and trust it.

189
00:08:08,950 --> 00:08:12,490
We do that wath was called
an Enrollment Profile.

190
00:08:12,490 --> 00:08:15,160
Enrollment Profile is a lot
like an Configuration Profile.

191
00:08:15,160 --> 00:08:18,070
A Configuration Profile has all
the Configuration Settings.

192
00:08:18,070 --> 00:08:19,190
All the Security Settings.

193
00:08:19,190 --> 00:08:22,190
And just other General Settings
that we push with it.

194
00:08:22,190 --> 00:08:26,210
An Enrollment Profile though,
really just has 2 things.

195
00:08:26,210 --> 00:08:29,200
One.
It has a set of certificates in it.

196
00:08:29,200 --> 00:08:31,940
If you remember from
our certificate episode

197
00:08:31,940 --> 00:08:35,080
when we bring up a server in mac OS.

198
00:08:35,080 --> 00:08:37,250
And we make it like
an open director server.

199
00:08:37,250 --> 00:08:39,460
It becomes a certificate authority.

200
00:08:39,460 --> 00:08:42,500
But nobody is going to trust
the certificates we issue.

201
00:08:42,500 --> 00:08:46,430
Well the Enrollment Profile
contains our root certificate.

202
00:08:46,430 --> 00:08:49,060
So that other people will trust us.

203
00:08:49,060 --> 00:08:50,730
So that's the first
thing that it contains.

204
00:08:50,730 --> 00:08:53,490
Then the second thing
the Enrollment Profile contains

205
00:08:53,490 --> 00:08:54,870
is information about our server.

206
00:08:54,870 --> 00:08:55,390
Where it is.

207
00:08:55,390 --> 00:08:56,480
The name of the server.

208
00:08:56,480 --> 00:08:58,390
How to contact it.

209
00:08:58,390 --> 00:09:00,520
Sometimes you don't
have direct connection.

210
00:09:00,520 --> 00:09:03,650
I might be managing a laptop that's on
the other side of the world on a network

211
00:09:03,650 --> 00:09:05,260
that's just a public network.

212
00:09:05,260 --> 00:09:08,350
Meanwhile, my server's right
here in on my protected network.

213
00:09:08,350 --> 00:09:10,010
How do those 2 talk to each other?

214
00:09:10,010 --> 00:09:12,170
Well, the Enrollment Profile
contains that data too.

215
00:09:12,170 --> 00:09:14,430
And we'll talk about
that a little bit later.

216
00:09:14,430 --> 00:09:16,318
But that's what in the Enrollment Profile.

217
00:09:16,318 --> 00:09:20,968
So step 1 of getting this set-up is,
well, turning on the Profile Manager.

218
00:09:20,968 --> 00:09:22,970
Getting this set-up on the server.

219
00:09:22,970 --> 00:09:26,070
Step 2 is enrolling our clients.

220
00:09:26,070 --> 00:09:28,880
Getting our clients to trust our server.

221
00:09:28,880 --> 00:09:31,650
And only when that's done are we ready for
step 3.

222
00:09:31,650 --> 00:09:35,300
Which is pushing a Configuration Profile
out to our client.

223
00:09:35,300 --> 00:09:38,170
So you can't just jump right in and
start configuring the clients.

00:09:38,170 --> 00:09:40,670
You got some kind of pre-requisites
that you've gotta meet.

00:09:40,670 --> 00:09:43,990
Some stuff we've gotta do just in
the very beginning to get things ready.

00:09:45,610 --> 00:09:46,166
All right.

00:09:46,166 --> 00:09:50,080
So let's talk about those
prerequisites a little bit.

00:09:50,080 --> 00:09:52,460

00:09:52,460 --> 00:09:54,400
Technically, you can
fire-up the server app.

00:09:54,400 --> 00:09:55,630
And go to Profile Manager.

00:09:55,630 --> 00:09:57,640
And hit that little switch that says on.

00:09:57,640 --> 00:10:00,440
And its on.
But it's not going to work.

00:10:00,440 --> 00:10:02,820
We have this little saying around here.

00:10:02,820 --> 00:10:05,040
You can do that, it won't work,

00:10:06,150 --> 00:10:08,360
In this scenario we want it to work.

236
00:10:08,360 --> 00:10:10,440
So what are some of
the pre-requisites that we have?

237
00:10:10,440 --> 00:10:15,280
First off, we need to go ahead and
get an open directory in place.

238
00:10:15,280 --> 00:10:16,860
It doesn't have to be the same server.

239
00:10:16,860 --> 00:10:19,800
It doesn't have to be the server that's
running Profile Manager but it can be.

240
00:10:19,800 --> 00:10:21,570
It certainly makes things easier.

241
00:10:21,570 --> 00:10:24,510
When you bring up an open
directory server.

242
00:10:24,510 --> 00:10:27,630
That open directory server
is a Certificate Authority.

243
00:10:27,630 --> 00:10:30,110
And so
now it's able to issue out certificates.

244
00:10:30,110 --> 00:10:32,250
If it's also the Profile Manager.

245
00:10:33,280 --> 00:10:36,550
Now when somebody trusts that
route CA that you just created.

246
00:10:36,550 --> 00:10:38,240
They're also trusting the Profile Manager.

247
00:10:38,240 --> 00:10:40,470
And that makes life a lot more simple.

248
00:10:40,470 --> 00:10:44,180
But you can deploy it where you
have one server that's up as your

249
00:10:44,180 --> 00:10:47,720
Open Directory Server and a second server
that's up as your Profile Manager.

250
00:10:47,720 --> 00:10:48,720
You can do that.

251
00:10:48,720 --> 00:10:52,290
But the Profile Manager just has
to trust the Open Directory.

252
00:10:52,290 --> 00:10:55,780
And the easiest way to do that is
to bind it to the Open Directory.

253
00:10:55,780 --> 00:10:58,750
So, if your Profile Manager Server is not

254
00:10:58,750 --> 00:11:00,970
the same server that's
running open directory.

255
00:11:00,970 --> 00:11:03,000
You just need to make sure
that the Profile Manager is

256
00:11:03,000 --> 00:11:05,040
bound to the Open Directory.

257
00:11:05,040 --> 00:11:06,700
Same thing goes for your clients.

258
00:11:06,700 --> 00:11:08,950
The clients don't have to be
bound to the Open Directory.

259
00:11:08,950 --> 00:11:11,810
But it certainly makes things easier
because that will make them automatically

260
00:11:11,810 --> 00:11:13,070
trust that certificate.

261
00:11:13,070 --> 00:11:16,220
The certificate will be included in
the Enrollment Profile too, though, so if

262
00:11:16,220 --> 00:11:20,100
they're not bound to your Open Directory,
you'll still be able to deploy to it.

263
00:11:20,100 --> 00:11:25,070
It's just through an extra little step so
getting an Open Directory is in place.

00:11:25,070 --> 00:11:28,130
Remember a key thing of

00:11:28,130 --> 00:11:30,190

00:11:36,630 --> 00:11:37,960
And all that good stuff.

00:11:37,960 --> 00:11:40,350

And you wanna go.

00:12:05,210 --> 00:12:07,770
So, why am I saying do it ahead of time?

00:12:07,770 --> 00:12:09,850

00:12:09,850 --> 00:12:13,230

00:12:13,230 --> 00:12:15,730

00:12:15,730 --> 00:12:17,350
And when you're troubleshooting it.

287
00:12:17,350 --> 00:12:19,110
If it installed Profile Manager.

288
00:12:19,110 --> 00:12:20,070
And Open Directory.

289
00:12:20,070 --> 00:12:21,730
And DNS all at once.

00:12:21,730 --> 00:12:22,650
Where do you start?

00:12:22,650 --> 00:12:24,320
The problem can be in any one of those.

00:12:24,320 --> 00:12:28,050

00:12:28,050 --> 00:12:32,380
So I always recommend to people, don't

00:12:33,650 --> 00:12:35,040
Set-up DNS first.

00:12:35,040 --> 00:12:36,020

You can test DNS.

00:12:38,200 --> 00:12:39,690
You can do some look-ups against it.

300
00:12:39,690 --> 00:12:40,960
And make sure it's working.

301
00:12:40,960 --> 00:12:42,560
If you have problems now,

302
00:12:42,560 --> 00:12:46,010
you know it's DNS because that's
the only thing you've set-up.

303
00:12:46,010 --> 00:12:47,120
And when that's done.

00:12:47,120 --> 00:12:48,950
Then you set-up your Open Directory.

305
00:12:48,950 --> 00:12:50,060
Get that up and running.

306
00:12:50,060 --> 00:12:50,780
Test that out.

00:12:50,780 --> 00:12:53,760
Use your Directory Utility or
whatever to reach in and test that out.

308
00:12:53,760 --> 00:12:56,690
Find a client to it make
sure that's working.

309
00:12:56,690 --> 00:13:00,960
And if you have a problem here,
well, you already know DNS is good.

310
00:13:00,960 --> 00:13:03,080
So the problem is in Open Directory.

311
00:13:03,080 --> 00:13:04,540
You can solve the issue there.

312
00:13:04,540 --> 00:13:05,110
And get it nice.

313
00:13:05,110 --> 00:13:06,670
And stable.
Now that you've got

00:13:06,670 --> 00:13:08,740

00:13:08,740 --> 00:13:10,530
Then you install the Profile Manager.

00:13:10,530 --> 00:13:11,210
You get it set-up.

00:13:11,210 --> 00:13:14,540
And if you have a problem now,

00:13:14,540 --> 00:13:17,710
Makes it super easy to troubleshoot

00:13:17,710 --> 00:13:20,490

00:13:20,490 --> 00:13:23,340

00:13:23,340 --> 00:13:25,810

00:13:25,810 --> 00:13:26,840
That's why I recommend that.

All right.

Once that's done though.

00:58:05,028 --> 00:58:09,400

1235
00:58:09,400 --> 00:58:12,870
And really even more because I

1236
00:58:12,870 --> 00:58:16,420
So you could be getting configuration

1237
00:58:16,420 --> 00:58:17,880
Now, why is that important?

1238
00:58:17,880 --> 00:58:20,420
Well, the important thing here is that

1239
00:58:20,420 --> 00:58:24,400
you might not just have one policy

1240
00:58:24,400 --> 00:58:26,380
You could actually have 20 or

1241
00:58:26,380 --> 00:58:32,120
30 policies that combine together to
create the final policy that you need.

1242
00:58:32,120 --> 00:58:35,420
Where we have to be careful,
is where we duplicate settings.

1243
00:58:35,420 --> 00:58:38,840
You can have a conflict between
a setting at one level and

1244
00:58:38,840 --> 00:58:40,710
a setting at another level.

1245
00:58:40,710 --> 00:58:46,380
If I log in and in my Device settings,

1247
00:58:50,590 --> 00:58:53,240
But then in my Device Group,

1248
00:58:53,240 --> 00:58:57,220

should kick in in 20 minutes.

1249
00:58:57,220 --> 00:58:58,990
Well what happens?

1250
00:58:58,990 --> 00:59:03,560
Unfortunately, the answer is the system
tries its best to merge the settings

1251
00:59:03,560 --> 00:59:05,710
together to create the final policy.

1252
00:59:05,710 --> 00:59:09,370
But when there's a conflict, it often
comes down to which one was the last

1253
00:59:09,370 --> 00:59:11,670
one to apply, and
which one is that going to be?

1254
00:59:11,670 --> 00:59:12,940
You never really know.

1255
00:59:12,940 --> 00:59:16,800
It kind of applies them in pseudo
random order, depending on timing.

1256
00:59:16,800 --> 00:59:19,510
And so when it connects,
you can get erratic results.

1257
00:59:19,510 --> 00:59:21,210
So Apple's recommendation, really,

1258
00:59:21,210 --> 00:59:26,370
the thing you should do, is make sure you
don't duplicate settings between levels.

1259
00:59:26,370 --> 00:59:30,507
That I can set power settings
on Student-Desktops and

1260
00:59:30,507 --> 00:59:33,780
Student-iPads and
Student-Laptops because I would never have

1261
00:59:33,780 --> 00:59:36,240
one device that was gonna be in
more than one of those groups.

1262
00:59:37,240 --> 00:59:41,180
But I wouldn't want to set power
settings on Student-Desktops and

1263
00:59:41,180 --> 00:59:45,310
Student-Devices because now I'm gonna
get a conflict between the two.

1264
00:59:45,310 --> 00:59:47,640
And I won't necessarily know
what's gonna come out of that,

1265
00:59:47,640 --> 00:59:50,530
unless the value is the same,
then you know what will come out of it.

1266
00:59:50,530 --> 00:59:53,790
So if you're gonna be
overlapping settings like that,

1267
00:59:53,790 --> 00:59:56,530
you'll need to test it out really
thoroughly to make sure you

1268
00:59:56,530 --> 00:59:58,860

assuming they have proper credentials,

43
00:02:38,060 --> 00:02:40,410
can access that folder.

44
00:02:40,410 --> 00:02:43,230
Well, let's talk about those
credentials for a moment.

45
00:02:43,230 --> 00:02:47,160
In a normal network,
that doesn't have an open directory,

46
00:02:47,160 --> 00:02:50,550
those credentials are stored on each and
every machine individually.

47
00:02:50,550 --> 00:02:51,840
It's called a work group.

48
00:02:51,840 --> 00:02:55,320
So if somebody wants to browse across
the network and access my files and

49
00:02:55,320 --> 00:02:59,430
folders, they would have to have
a user account on my own machine.

50
00:02:59,430 --> 00:03:01,550
But, with an open directory,
we kinda, get around that.

51
00:03:01,550 --> 00:03:04,680
With an open directory, those user
accounts can be stored in that centralized

52
00:03:04,680 --> 00:03:07,820
database and we can have groups
that we assign permissions to.

53
00:03:07,820 --> 00:03:09,790
To again, make it easier for
people to access this.

54
00:03:09,790 --> 00:03:12,670
We get a lot of power by having
an open directory in place, so

55
00:03:12,670 --> 00:03:14,620
that's how we're normally
gonna see this deployed.

56
00:03:14,620 --> 00:03:18,090
Apple's built in several
different protocols into Mac OS.

57
00:03:18,090 --> 00:03:20,520
When we go to share a folder out,
we have to make a decision.

58
00:03:20,520 --> 00:03:22,410
Which ones to we want to support.

59
00:03:22,410 --> 00:03:23,970
They each have their pros and cons.

60
00:03:23,970 --> 00:03:25,480
Some are very popular.

61
00:03:25,480 --> 00:03:27,770
Some are very rarely used.

62
00:03:27,770 --> 00:03:28,620
You might need some.

63
00:03:28,620 --> 00:03:29,710
You might not need others.

64
00:03:29,710 --> 00:03:30,810
You can actually turn them all on.

65
00:03:30,810 --> 00:03:33,000
If you wanna go crazy,
you can activate them all.

66
00:03:33,000 --> 00:03:35,450
Not normally a good idea,
but you can do that.

67
00:03:35,450 --> 00:03:37,930
Well let's run through
the protocols that we're gonna see.

68
00:03:37,930 --> 00:03:40,460
And I wanna start with the three
that you're gonna see on the exam.

69
00:03:40,460 --> 00:03:41,980
There's really a good five or

70
00:03:41,980 --> 00:03:45,430
six of them, but there's only three
that truly make it on the exam.

71
00:03:45,430 --> 00:03:47,730
The first one is AFP.

72
00:03:47,730 --> 00:03:50,310
AFP is the Apple File protocol.

73
00:03:50,310 --> 00:03:53,210
It was developed by Apple for
use between Macs.

74
00:03:53,210 --> 00:03:57,380
When you had two Mac Pros or whatever and
you wanted to exchange files between it,

75
00:03:57,380 --> 00:04:00,280
they needed some kind of protocol
to handle that communication.

76
00:04:00,280 --> 00:04:02,090
And for that they created AFP.

77
00:04:02,090 --> 00:04:04,740
It's very reliable protocol,
very efficient.

78
00:04:04,740 --> 00:04:08,580
It builds on top of the bonjour protocol
which let's you do network discovery.

79
00:04:08,580 --> 00:04:11,650
That's how we can find the folders
that are out there on the network.

80
00:04:11,650 --> 00:04:13,830
If you have all Macs, AFP worked great.

81
00:04:13,830 --> 00:04:14,728
That's the one you want.

82
00:04:14,728 --> 00:04:19,330
But, AFP only works on Macs.

83
00:04:19,330 --> 00:04:23,210
Microsoft doesn't have an AFP client for
connecting to Apple shares.

84
00:04:23,210 --> 00:04:25,580
So if you're trying to blend Microsoft and

85
00:04:25,580 --> 00:04:28,510
Apple products together,
it doesn't work so well.

86
00:04:28,510 --> 00:04:32,500
If you've got all MacBooks, MacPros,
iPads, iPhones, AFP is great.

87
00:04:32,500 --> 00:04:36,380
If you start bringing in other
operating systems like Linux and

88
00:04:36,380 --> 00:04:37,900
Windows, it's not so great.

89
00:04:39,230 --> 00:04:43,530
The second protocol is kind
of the other way around.

90
00:04:43,530 --> 00:04:46,410
Instead of Apple having created it,
Microsoft created it.

91
00:04:46,410 --> 00:04:51,410
In the Microsoft world, we have something
called SMB, Server Message Block.

92
00:04:51,410 --> 00:04:53,550
SMB is a very, very old protocol.

93
00:04:53,550 --> 00:04:56,510
It was actually developed by Intel and
Microsoft for

94
00:04:56,510 --> 00:05:00,190
exchanging files between Windows and
DOS machines.

95
00:05:00,190 --> 00:05:03,630
It's been around a long time, and
it basically gives that quick and

96
00:05:03,630 --> 00:05:07,130
easy communications just like AFP does,
but for the Windows world.

97
00:05:08,330 --> 00:05:13,100
Now, SMB is not open source,
not everybody can just go and

98
00:05:13,100 --> 00:05:17,460
use SMB if they want, but Microsoft has
published a lot of the specifications for

99
00:05:17,460 --> 00:05:23,060
it that are out there, and so most
modern operating systems do support SMB.

100
00:05:23,060 --> 00:05:26,190
Windows does it,
Linux does it, and Mac does it.

101
00:05:26,190 --> 00:05:30,230
So if you wanna create a file share
that's available, that's easy for

102
00:05:30,230 --> 00:05:34,910
every operating system to get to,
SMB is normally the one you want.

103
00:05:34,910 --> 00:05:38,070
So even though you might
be a mostly Mac shop, you

104
00:05:38,070 --> 00:05:42,750
might still choose to go with SMB, because
of some of the extra support that you get.

105
00:05:42,750 --> 00:05:44,470
For other operating systems.

106
00:05:44,470 --> 00:05:48,350
Now a couple little caveats about
SMB that we should remember.

107
00:05:48,350 --> 00:05:51,735
Microsoft's office version of
Server Message Blockage is SMB version

108
00:05:51,735 --> 00:05:57,020
3.0 which they introduced with
Windows Server 2012 and Windows 8.

109
00:05:57,020 --> 00:05:58,970
That's SMB 3.0.

110
00:05:58,970 --> 00:06:02,660
Apple's implementation is SMB 2.0.

111
00:06:02,660 --> 00:06:05,610
And so there's certain advanced
features that Microsoft likes to brag

112
00:06:05,610 --> 00:06:08,170
about with SMB that aren't
supported by Apple.

113
00:06:08,170 --> 00:06:12,040
But as far as basic connectivity,
getting connected to a file, editing it,

114
00:06:12,040 --> 00:06:13,700
using permissions, that kind of stuff.

115
00:06:13,700 --> 00:06:15,490
Works just fine in SMB 2.0.

116
00:06:15,490 --> 00:06:19,260
In fact Windows 7 and earlier,
they all use SMB 2.0 anyway, so

117
00:06:19,260 --> 00:06:23,290
most Microsoft systems
still use SMB 2.0 also.

118
00:06:23,290 --> 00:06:27,610
On the Linux world, they build an SMB
through an extra software package called

119
00:06:27,610 --> 00:06:31,470
Samba, and Samba functions as SMB 2.0.

120
00:06:31,470 --> 00:06:36,150
So just because Apple's using SMB 2.0 and
not 3.0., it's not a big deal.

121
00:06:36,150 --> 00:06:38,940
There's just a few advanced features we
don't get which are features most people

122
00:06:38,940 --> 00:06:42,310
don't make use of anyway,
things like Multipath IO and

123
00:06:42,310 --> 00:06:45,260
stuff like that,
that we don't normally care about.

124
00:06:45,260 --> 00:06:48,340
All right, so SMB,
it's fully supported on the Apple devices.

125
00:06:48,340 --> 00:06:51,830
We can use that,
why wouldn't I want to use it?

126
00:06:51,830 --> 00:06:55,210
Well, there's one big reason why
we might not want to use SMB and

127
00:06:55,210 --> 00:06:58,580
use AFP instead, and that's Time Machine.

128
00:06:58,580 --> 00:07:03,570
With Time Machine, your Mac can keep
track of multiple revisions of a file.

129
00:07:03,570 --> 00:07:06,940
As you enter the file,
various copies of it are maintained.

130
00:07:07,950 --> 00:07:10,270
Well, AFP supports that.

131
00:07:10,270 --> 00:07:14,700
AFP can interact with the Mac OS
extended journal file system and

132
00:07:14,700 --> 00:07:16,900
keep track of those multiple versions.

133
00:07:16,900 --> 00:07:18,110
SMB can't.

134
00:07:18,110 --> 00:07:19,860
Microsoft doesn't support time machine.

135
00:07:19,860 --> 00:07:22,730
They don't know how that works,
or maybe they don't care.

136
00:07:22,730 --> 00:07:24,720
I don't know, but they don't support it.

137
00:07:24,720 --> 00:07:29,320
That means that if we use SMB shares,
we won't be able to do file revisions.

138
00:07:29,320 --> 00:07:33,830
You won't be able to the auto save
feature, and the feature where we can

139
00:07:33,830 --> 00:07:37,770
pull up multiple revisions of that text,
and go back several versions if we want.

140
00:07:37,770 --> 00:07:39,310
You lose that.

141
00:07:39,310 --> 00:07:41,450
So you really have to make a choice.

142
00:07:41,450 --> 00:07:44,290
If you want the best features,
you go with AFP.

143
00:07:44,290 --> 00:07:48,160
If you want the best compatibility,
you go with SMB.

144
00:07:48,160 --> 00:07:49,850
But that compatibility comes at a price.

145
00:07:49,850 --> 00:07:51,430
We give up some of those advance features.

146
00:07:53,100 --> 00:07:55,167
Fortunately, we can support both.

147
00:07:55,167 --> 00:07:59,510
You can do AFP and SMB at the same time,
on the same folder if you want.

148
00:07:59,510 --> 00:08:03,070
And that way your Macs can connect
using AFP and get file versioning.

149
00:08:03,070 --> 00:08:05,918
And then your Windows machines can connect
using SMB and not get file versioning.

150
00:08:05,918 --> 00:08:06,500
But who cares?

151
00:08:06,500 --> 00:08:08,469
That's fine,
at least they get that connectivity, and

152
00:08:08,469 --> 00:08:09,940
they're able to function.

153
00:08:09,940 --> 00:08:13,310
So, you can enable more than one
protocol to get that flexibility.

154
00:08:14,440 --> 00:08:17,660
When we create a share in the Server app,
which we'll do here in a little bit,

155
00:08:17,660 --> 00:08:23,070
when we do that, it actually
turns on AFP and SMB by default.

156
00:08:23,070 --> 00:08:25,020
It turns on both of them for that folder.

157
00:08:25,020 --> 00:08:27,660
So, that's kind of what
Apple expects you to do.

158
00:08:27,660 --> 00:08:31,980
Use AFP for your Macs, SMB for Windows,
and run them both at the same time.

159
00:08:31,980 --> 00:08:34,910
Now that can cause some little
problems every now and then.

160
00:08:34,910 --> 00:08:38,840
One thing to remember is,
just because you're running two protocols

161
00:08:38,840 --> 00:08:41,690
doesn't change the fact that
it's still a shared folder.

162
00:08:41,690 --> 00:08:45,430
And you have all the problems of
people coming into a shared folder and

163
00:08:45,430 --> 00:08:46,520
accessing the same data.

164
00:08:46,520 --> 00:08:51,610
For example, if I've got a file that's
open and I'm editing that file, and

165
00:08:51,610 --> 00:08:55,260
you come along and connect to that
same file and start to edit it.

166
00:08:55,260 --> 00:08:56,740
Well, what happens?

167
00:08:56,740 --> 00:09:00,470
We're both editing the same file,
we're now conflicting.

168
00:09:00,470 --> 00:09:02,330
If we're both doing it in SMB, or

169
00:09:02,330 --> 00:09:05,730
if we're both doing it in AFP,
the Mac will actually sort that out.

170
00:09:05,730 --> 00:09:07,270
It'll tell you the file's locked, or

171
00:09:07,270 --> 00:09:10,480
it will make it where the last
person who saves wins.

172
00:09:10,480 --> 00:09:11,970
But if I'm running AFP and

173
00:09:11,970 --> 00:09:15,890
you're running SMB,
now it has a harder time sorting that out.

174
00:09:15,890 --> 00:09:18,980
And so you can end up with some problems
there if you have multiple people editing

175
00:09:18,980 --> 00:09:20,140
the same data.

176
00:09:20,140 --> 00:09:21,648
Just be aware of that.

177
00:09:21,648 --> 00:09:24,810
AFP and SMB are enabled by default,
but you might want to cut it down to

178
00:09:24,810 --> 00:09:29,040
one protocol to try and alleviate some
of those issues like file locking.

179
00:09:29,040 --> 00:09:31,620
Case sensitivity is another one.

180
00:09:31,620 --> 00:09:36,380
AFP, the Apple File Protocol,
if it's running for a shared folder and

181
00:09:36,380 --> 00:09:41,530
that shared folder is on a MacOS Extended
case sensitive journal file system, right?

182
00:09:41,530 --> 00:09:46,550
Remember when we format a drive,
we can choose to make it case sensitive.

183
00:09:46,550 --> 00:09:49,060
If we do that, AFP recognizes it, right?

184
00:09:49,060 --> 00:09:52,790
But SMB doesn't, because in the Microsoft
world, things aren't case sensitive.

185
00:09:52,790 --> 00:09:54,600
And so they don't have that support.

186
00:09:54,600 --> 00:09:57,940
And now we can end up with some problems
where Microsoft might see two files

187
00:09:57,940 --> 00:10:01,510
that are separate files, but
they view it as the same.

188
00:10:01,510 --> 00:10:04,530
All right, that's a risk that
we have when we deal with SMB.

189
00:10:04,530 --> 00:10:05,960
All right,

190
00:10:05,960 --> 00:10:09,410
now that's two of the three protocols
that we're gonna see on the exam.

191
00:10:09,410 --> 00:10:11,960
The third one is WebDAV.

192
00:10:11,960 --> 00:10:15,520
And WebDAV is the least
used of these three.

193
00:10:15,520 --> 00:10:19,820
In fact, it's turned off by default when
we create a share point in the Server app.

194
00:10:19,820 --> 00:10:24,800
WebDAV stands for
Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning.

195
00:10:24,800 --> 00:10:29,680
It was designed to be an open source,
completely standard method for

196
00:10:29,680 --> 00:10:32,580
accessing files and
folders on a remote system.

197
00:10:32,580 --> 00:10:36,740
It originated back with early content
management systems, things like

198
00:10:36,740 --> 00:10:41,535
Microsoft SharePoint used it, early
versions of WordPress and Drupal used it.

199
00:10:41,535 --> 00:10:44,845
There's a lot of web-based calendars
that use it so you can go in and

200
00:10:44,845 --> 00:10:46,575
create calendar items, that kind of thing.

201
00:10:46,575 --> 00:10:49,897
So, this is part of WebDAV.

202
00:10:49,897 --> 00:10:53,125
The nice thing about WebDAV,
it's open standard, right?

203
00:10:53,125 --> 00:10:58,066
So everybody supports WebDAV, or
everybody can support WebDAV.

204
00:10:58,066 --> 00:10:59,232
It's not terribly popular so

205
00:10:59,232 --> 00:11:03,065
there's a lot of operating systems out
there that choose not to support it.

206
00:11:03,065 --> 00:11:04,640
Mac OS does support it.

207
00:11:04,640 --> 00:11:07,550
And a lot of the software that we
run on Mac OS supports it also.

208
00:11:08,600 --> 00:11:13,150
Other operating systems like Microsoft
Windows don't support it natively, but you

209
00:11:13,150 --> 00:11:16,540
can run software on them that does support
it and that provides you the connectivity.

210
00:11:16,540 --> 00:11:18,320
Linux has the support native.

211
00:11:18,320 --> 00:11:20,420
So, different OSs handle
it different ways.

212
00:11:21,500 --> 00:11:25,565
Now, when we enable WebDAV, we have to
make sure that whatever clients we're

213
00:11:25,565 --> 00:11:28,200
using to connect support WebDAV also.

214
00:11:28,200 --> 00:11:32,520
And just like with SMB, we get more
compatibility out of WebDAV because it's

215
00:11:32,520 --> 00:11:34,690
open, and we get less features.

216
00:11:34,690 --> 00:11:37,230
It's very, very feature-sparse.

217
00:11:37,230 --> 00:11:38,630
WebDAV is not very flexible,

218
00:11:38,630 --> 00:11:40,800
and that's part of the reason
why it's not very popular.

219
00:11:41,840 --> 00:11:43,092
But it is another option
that we could use.

220
00:11:43,092 --> 00:11:46,948
It's an open standard, you can leverage
it, connect up, access the system, and

221
00:11:46,948 --> 00:11:47,510
off you go.

222
00:11:49,150 --> 00:11:51,390
All right, so those are the three
we're gonna see on the exam.

223
00:11:51,390 --> 00:11:52,450
What about others?

224
00:11:52,450 --> 00:11:56,250
Well, Mac OS is built on top of BSD,
so there's a lot of

225
00:11:56,250 --> 00:12:00,180
other types of file sharing that you
can do just right in the native OS.

226
00:12:00,180 --> 00:12:05,450
Like NFS, the Network File System, that's
a traditional Unix file sharing protocol

227
00:12:05,450 --> 00:12:08,340
that Linux supports, Mac OS supports.

228
00:12:08,340 --> 00:12:12,210
Microsoft even has an NFS client for
Windows so you can get support there too.

229
00:12:12,210 --> 00:12:15,910
So if you need connectivity with
systems using NFS, you can.

230
00:12:17,000 --> 00:12:19,460
Also we have support for FTP,
the file transfer protocol.

231
00:12:19,460 --> 00:12:23,012
You can bring up a shared
folder that's connected to FTP,

232
00:12:23,012 --> 00:12:25,790
people can connect in and use that.

233
00:12:25,790 --> 00:12:29,800
The problem with FTP though,
it's not encrypted, it's not very secure.

234
00:12:29,800 --> 00:12:33,750
All the other protocols we've talked about
support encryption in one form or another.

235
00:12:34,780 --> 00:12:36,160
FDP doesn't.

236
00:12:36,160 --> 00:12:39,056
So instead we might choose to
use another protocol like SFTP.

237
00:12:39,056 --> 00:12:42,580
SFTP is secure file transfer protocol.

238
00:12:42,580 --> 00:12:46,190
It takes the FTP traffic and
it sticks it on top of an SSH tunnel.

239
00:12:46,190 --> 00:12:49,910
So now it's being encrypted using SSH,
and you can transfer your files.

240
00:12:49,910 --> 00:12:51,930
That's another one that's supported,
all right.

241
00:12:51,930 --> 00:12:53,790
These are all great methods for

242
00:12:53,790 --> 00:12:57,290
sharing out files, but
they're not supported in the Server app.

243
00:12:57,290 --> 00:13:00,410
When you go into the Server app,
you don't see a lot of that functionality.

244
00:13:00,410 --> 00:13:05,030
You do see FTP, but you don't see other
things like NFS, they don't show up there.

245
00:13:05,030 --> 00:13:09,010
So while your Mac does support it, it's
not intended to be your regular use thing.

246
00:13:09,010 --> 00:13:11,730
For that, we have AFP and SMB.

247
00:13:11,730 --> 00:13:15,460
Those are our two main
ones that we're gonna see.

248
00:13:15,460 --> 00:13:18,830
One quick comment about WebDAV
before I move on from that.

249
00:13:18,830 --> 00:13:24,300
WebDAV uses HTTP and
HTTPS for communication.

250
00:13:24,300 --> 00:13:28,740
If you connect to WebDAV using HTTP,
it's unencrypted.

251
00:13:28,740 --> 00:13:33,520
If you connect using HTTPS, it's using
SSL to encrypt your traffic, and

252
00:13:33,520 --> 00:13:35,220
you get secure communications.

253
00:13:35,220 --> 00:13:38,800
When you're transferring files, you
almost always want secure communications,

254
00:13:38,800 --> 00:13:40,200
that's kind of the goal.

255
00:13:40,200 --> 00:13:43,180
So you'll typically use
HTTPS with that one.

256
00:13:43,180 --> 00:13:46,280
With SMB and AFP we'll get a chance
to see those as we set them up and

257
00:13:46,280 --> 00:13:47,180
get connected to that.

258
00:13:48,200 --> 00:13:53,180
All right now, just be aware that when you
go to configure file sharing on a server

259
00:13:53,180 --> 00:13:55,380
there's two places you can do it from.

260
00:13:55,380 --> 00:14:00,050
You can do it from the Server app or you
can do it from what's built into Mac OS,

261
00:14:00,050 --> 00:14:03,540
go into System Preferences and Sharing.

262
00:14:03,540 --> 00:14:06,920
The two can conflict
a bit with each other.

263
00:14:06,920 --> 00:14:09,580
The Server app tries to read
the configuration from what you've done

264
00:14:09,580 --> 00:14:11,650
outside of the Server app and bring it in.

265
00:14:11,650 --> 00:14:15,010
But there's things that can be supported,
like NSF and SFTP,

266
00:14:15,010 --> 00:14:19,640
that the Server app doesn't necessarily
see, and that can create some issues.

267
00:14:19,640 --> 00:14:23,870
So the recommendation is, if you're gonna
be configuring file sharing on a machine

268
00:14:23,870 --> 00:14:28,700
running Server app, that you always do
it from the server, from Mac OS Server.

269
00:14:28,700 --> 00:14:31,490
Even setting file permissions,
which we know we can do file

270

00:52:43,900 --> 00:52:45,480

00:52:45,480 --> 00:52:51,390

00:52:51,390 --> 00:52:54,520

1053
00:52:59,720 --> 00:53:02,500
So it's time to look at

1054
00:53:02,500 --> 00:53:05,190
Well when it comes to changing
permissions for folders and

1055
00:53:05,190 --> 00:53:09,680
shares, there's a little bit of
confusion that gets created.

1056
00:53:09,680 --> 00:53:13,620
Because on a Mac, you actually have
two different types of permissions.

1057
00:53:13,620 --> 00:53:17,650
You have what are called
POSIX compliant permissions.

1058
00:53:17,650 --> 00:53:21,980
And POSIX is a very very old Unix
standard for applying permissions.

1059
00:53:21,980 --> 00:53:25,360
It's part of the BSD operating system and
it's under the hood of Mac OS, and

1060
00:53:25,360 --> 00:53:30,070
it's a very old traditional system
that just doesn't scale very well.

1061
00:53:30,070 --> 00:53:34,700
And then, there's the newer system which
uses ACLs or Access Control Lists.

1062
00:53:36,120 --> 00:53:40,510
You support both of them, when you
create a new folder like I did and

1063
00:53:40,510 --> 00:53:44,970
you share it, the only thing
you have are POSIX permission.

1064
00:53:44,970 --> 00:53:47,200
So let's talk about POSIX
permissions briefly.

1065
00:53:47,200 --> 00:53:50,080
If you've watched the Apple Certified
Support Professional shows,

1066
00:53:50,080 --> 00:53:51,330
you've already seen this in depth.

1067
00:53:51,330 --> 00:53:53,190
So I don't want to spend
too much time on it.

1068
00:53:53,190 --> 00:53:57,050
If you've never dealt with permission like
this before jump back to the ACSP show.

1069
00:53:57,050 --> 00:53:59,680
We actually did two episodes on
file permissions over there, so

1070
00:53:59,680 --> 00:54:01,100
definitely check those out.

1071
00:54:01,100 --> 00:54:07,040
But just to quickly summarize it,
in POSIX, you only have three permissions.

1072
00:54:07,040 --> 00:54:11,100
There's the owner, who ever owns the file,
what permissions do they get.

1073
00:54:12,160 --> 00:54:17,680
Then you get one group, just one group,
and what permissions do they get to it?

1074
00:54:17,680 --> 00:54:21,490
And then lastly you have everybody
else and what permissions they get.

1075
00:54:21,490 --> 00:54:25,350
Well, what if I wanna stay
the owner of this HelpDesk, but

1076
00:54:25,350 --> 00:54:28,260
I want Jane Doe specifically
to have access?

1077
00:54:28,260 --> 00:54:31,005
Well, you can't do that
with POSIX permissions.

1078
00:54:31,005 --> 00:54:32,920
POSIX permissions are fairly limited.

1079
00:54:32,920 --> 00:54:37,490
You get one owner, one group, and
then everybody else and that's it.

1080
00:54:38,710 --> 00:54:42,390
Now, if you can make that fit your needs,
then fine.

1081
00:54:42,390 --> 00:54:44,220
You don't need to do anything crazy.

1082
00:54:44,220 --> 00:54:46,280
But often times you need more.

1083
00:54:46,280 --> 00:54:50,110
You need more specific permissions
than what POSIX can do for you.

1084
00:54:50,110 --> 00:54:52,760
That's where access control lists come in.

1085
00:54:52,760 --> 00:54:57,680
ACLs let us add even more information
to this folder as far as who

1086
00:54:57,680 --> 00:54:59,040
has access to it.

1087
00:54:59,040 --> 00:55:00,250
If I take a look at this folder.

1088
00:55:00,250 --> 00:55:01,500
Let me just fire up my terminal.

1089
00:55:02,850 --> 00:55:05,900
And take a look at the Unix
permission that are on it.

1090
00:55:07,910 --> 00:55:12,930
Alright, so
I'm going to go into /volumes/,

1091
00:55:12,930 --> 00:55:14,300
or wait, where did I put that one.

1092
00:55:14,300 --> 00:55:17,108
Storage is I think that one is
actually in my home directory isn't?

1093
00:55:17,108 --> 00:55:22,310
[LAUGH] Now I have to remember
where I put these things.

1094
00:55:22,310 --> 00:55:26,400
Pretty sure that one's
in the help desk folder.

1095
00:55:29,130 --> 00:55:30,500
There it is.

1096
00:55:30,500 --> 00:55:31,160
Alright.

1097
00:55:31,160 --> 00:55:33,141
So if I do an ls -la.

1098
00:55:33,141 --> 00:55:37,470
ls is the list command, the la,
the a means show me all files and

1099
00:55:37,470 --> 00:55:40,160
l means give me the long output.

1100
00:55:40,160 --> 00:55:45,530
In the long output for storage, I can
see the permissions written right here.

1101
00:55:45,530 --> 00:55:48,790
They're written as nine characters.

1102
00:55:48,790 --> 00:55:52,750
The first set of three characters, I
guess there's ten characters technically.

1103
00:55:52,750 --> 00:55:55,250
This d here indicates
that it's a directory.

1104
00:55:55,250 --> 00:55:58,650
If you have a D, it's a directory
if you have a dash it's a file.

1105
00:55:58,650 --> 00:56:00,830
After that I have RWX.

1106
00:56:00,830 --> 00:56:02,480
That's the user.

1107
00:56:02,480 --> 00:56:03,680
Who owns this?

1108
00:56:03,680 --> 00:56:07,720
The person who owns it has read,
write, and execute.

1109
00:56:07,720 --> 00:56:10,770
Well, helpdesk, that's who owns it.

1110
00:56:10,770 --> 00:56:12,620
The next three characters are the group.

1111
00:56:12,620 --> 00:56:15,310
And I've got read and execute, not write.

1112
00:56:15,310 --> 00:56:17,330
They've got read only access.

1113
00:56:17,330 --> 00:56:18,550
And the group is staff.

1114
00:56:18,550 --> 00:56:22,980
And then lastly I have everyone else,
and everyone else has nothing.

1115
00:56:22,980 --> 00:56:24,560
They get no access.

1116
00:56:24,560 --> 00:56:27,170
They don't get in there and that's it.

1117
00:56:27,170 --> 00:56:28,800
These are POSIX permissions.

1118
00:56:28,800 --> 00:56:31,580
What I'm seeing right here
are the POSIX permissions.

1119
00:56:31,580 --> 00:56:34,330
But notice how there's a little
plus sign at the end of this?

1120
00:56:34,330 --> 00:56:37,000
That plus sign is letting
me know that there's

1121
00:56:37,000 --> 00:56:38,990
more to this file than
what I see on this screen.

1122
00:56:38,990 --> 00:56:39,980
It's like Transformers, right?

1123
00:56:39,980 --> 00:56:41,560
More than meets the eyes.

1124
00:56:41,560 --> 00:56:43,750
It's not just POSIX permissions here.

1125
00:56:43,750 --> 00:56:46,710
I must have an ACL on it also, all right.

1126
00:56:46,710 --> 00:56:50,934
Well, if I wanna see that,
you can run ls -le, and

1127
00:56:50,934 --> 00:56:55,865
that'll show you extended
information about the folder.

1128
00:56:55,865 --> 00:57:01,760
And I can see right here that I have
an access control entry, an ACE.

1129
00:57:01,760 --> 00:57:05,150
An access control list is
really just a list of entries.

1130
00:57:05,150 --> 00:57:09,990
And so here's one entry that
says spotlight is getting list,

1131
00:57:09,990 --> 00:57:12,210
search, file_inherit, directory_inherit.

1132
00:57:12,210 --> 00:57:14,950
It's getting a couple of extra
permissions on that folder.

1133
00:57:14,950 --> 00:57:18,860
I don't see that in POSIX,
I see it outside of POSIX, all right?

1134
00:57:18,860 --> 00:57:20,990
It's an ACL, it's separate.

1135
00:57:20,990 --> 00:57:24,169
So when I go back to that
folder here in the server app,

1136
00:57:24,169 --> 00:57:28,000
if I start adding something in,
like if I add Don Pezet, right?

1137
00:57:28,000 --> 00:57:31,550
I want me to have read and
write access to it.

1138
00:57:31,550 --> 00:57:33,130
Now I have two users.

1139
00:57:33,130 --> 00:57:36,390
POSIX doesn't support that,
this would blow POSIX's mind.

1140
00:57:36,390 --> 00:57:38,498
But ACLs do support it.

1141
00:57:38,498 --> 00:57:41,560
And I could add in John Doe and
Jane Doe and whoever I want.

1142
00:57:41,560 --> 00:57:44,790
Now I probably don't wanna
do that because managing

1143
00:57:44,790 --> 00:57:48,410

becomes a real challenge.

1144
00:57:48,410 --> 00:57:51,460
As I hire new employees,

1145
00:57:51,460 --> 00:57:53,930
It's better to manage them with groups.

1146
00:57:53,930 --> 00:57:57,060
So I might create a group
called Employees.

1147
00:57:57,060 --> 00:58:01,040
So I'm gonna come in here and

00:58:01,040 --> 00:58:03,750
And as I hire employees I

1149
00:58:03,750 --> 00:58:05,580
Or if it's gonna encompass

00:58:05,580 --> 00:58:08,590
then I might just use the Workgroup

1151
00:58:08,590 --> 00:58:10,450
We already have this one
here called Workgroup and

1152
00:58:10,450 --> 00:58:13,640
it contains all the users

1153
00:58:13,640 --> 00:58:17,490
But you might not want everybody,
you might want sales people.

1154
00:58:17,490 --> 00:58:19,050
So I might have a Sales People group.

1155
00:58:19,050 --> 00:58:22,150
And we talked about groups in another
episode, but I'll just go ahead and

1156
00:58:22,150 --> 00:58:23,600
whip this one up real quick.

1157
00:58:23,600 --> 00:58:25,790
So I might have Sales People, and

1158
00:58:25,790 --> 00:58:29,820
in Sales People I might add
in John Doe and Jane Doe.

1159
00:58:29,820 --> 00:58:31,200
So I want them to have access.

1160
00:58:32,540 --> 00:58:34,310
So they're my sales people.

1161
00:58:34,310 --> 00:58:37,540
We'll get them punched in and
they're gonna have access to it.

1162
00:58:37,540 --> 00:58:39,720
All right, so there they are,
they're in that group.

1163
00:58:39,720 --> 00:58:41,510
Now I can go back to that shared folder.

1164
00:58:41,510 --> 00:58:47,190
I go to my File Sharing and Edit Storage,
and I can add the group on here.

1165
00:58:47,190 --> 00:58:51,355
And just like we saw a moment ago,
POSIX only supported one user,

1166
00:58:51,355 --> 00:58:52,870
it only supported one group.

1167
00:58:52,870 --> 00:58:56,200
Now I've got more than one user and
I've got more than one group.

1168
00:58:56,200 --> 00:58:58,510
I'm going well beyond
what POSIX can support.

1169
00:59:00,820 --> 00:59:02,230
When I say OK, it's gonna apply that.

1170
00:59:02,230 --> 00:59:06,150
And if I look at that in my terminal,
let's see how that's changed, right?

1171
00:59:06,150 --> 00:59:07,840
If I do a list for

1172
00:59:07,840 --> 00:59:12,830
that storage folder, I can see that it
still has read, write, and execute for

1173
00:59:12,830 --> 00:59:17,710
helpdesk, read and execute for staff, and
nothing for the everyone group, right?

1174
00:59:17,710 --> 00:59:19,919
So those are still the same,
the POSIX permissions are unchanged.

1175
00:59:21,080 --> 00:59:26,830
But if I do an ls -le,
now I can see the access control entries.

1176
00:59:26,830 --> 00:59:31,680
And I have a new entry for donpezet that's
giving me all this additional access.

1177
00:59:31,680 --> 00:59:34,700
Read, and write, and
all of the control I gave it.

1178
00:59:34,700 --> 00:59:36,840
And then here's that group salespeople.

1179
00:59:36,840 --> 00:59:38,670
We're enhancing our permissions.

1180
00:59:39,800 --> 00:59:41,420
Now, here's the problem.

1181
00:59:41,420 --> 00:59:48,460

00:59:48,460 --> 00:59:51,770

00:59:57,360 --> 01:00:00,952

01:00:00,952 --> 01:00:04,510

01:00:04,510 --> 01:00:05,880

01:00:05,880 --> 01:00:10,390
Well, when there's a conflict

01:00:10,390 --> 01:00:13,530
So whatever permissions are in the ACL,
they apply.

1189
01:00:13,530 --> 01:00:17,060
So I might have no access in

01:00:17,060 --> 01:00:18,860
the ACL overrides that and
I get my access.

01:00:20,020 --> 01:00:24,250
If there's no ACL, or there's just no
match in the ACLs, like Don Pezet,

1192
01:00:24,250 --> 01:00:26,220
I'm not listed in the ACL anywhere.

01:00:26,220 --> 01:00:27,824
If there's no ACL or I'm not in it,

01:00:27,824 --> 01:00:30,610

01:00:30,610 --> 01:00:33,280

1202
01:00:55,780 --> 01:00:59,770

cached and your data doesn't get updated.

1203
01:00:59,770 --> 01:01:02,320

01:01:02,320 --> 01:01:05,250

01:01:05,250 --> 01:01:09,280

01:01:09,280 --> 01:01:11,020
Because your Kerberos ticket,

01:01:11,020 --> 01:01:15,130
your ticket granting ticket, it contains
a list of all the groups that you're in.

1208
01:01:15,130 --> 01:01:17,770
And it doesn't get updated until
you log back in the next time.

01:01:17,770 --> 01:01:19,750

1404
01:11:03,390 --> 01:11:05,330
It's because of those
different carriage returns.

1405
01:11:05,330 --> 01:11:10,180
So we can share a folder like this
between the different systems.

1406
01:11:10,180 --> 01:11:13,850
But, some file formats
don't play nice with that.

1407
01:11:13,850 --> 01:11:16,970
Word documents, binary formats,
those are all fine.

1408
01:11:16,970 --> 01:11:21,030
But raw text files can get mangled
a little bit when they go between them.

1409
01:11:21,030 --> 01:11:23,310
Now, the problem here is actually Notepad,

1410
01:11:23,310 --> 01:11:26,810
this program that I'm using in Windows,
isn't designed to support that.

1411
01:11:26,810 --> 01:11:30,070
If I were to open it in
another program like WordPad.

1412
01:11:30,070 --> 01:11:31,770
Fire up WordPad.

1413
01:11:31,770 --> 01:11:35,510
WordPad is smarter, and it recognizes,
oh this one's in a UNIX format, and

1414
01:11:35,510 --> 01:11:40,090
it puts the line feeds in
place like it's supposed to.

1415
01:11:40,090 --> 01:11:43,500
That's the difference between
the two applications, and

1416
01:11:43,500 --> 01:11:45,840
it's a problem you'll bump
into with Windows machines.

1417
01:11:45,840 --> 01:11:49,870
It's not a problem with SMB,
it's not a problem with the file share or

1418
01:11:49,870 --> 01:11:50,610
really the file itself.

1419
01:11:50,610 --> 01:11:52,790
It's a problem with the operating systems.

1420
01:11:52,790 --> 01:11:57,472
Mac OS and Windows just use a different
way for signalling the end of a line,

1421
01:11:57,472 --> 01:12:00,090
and It ends up causing some issues there.

1422
01:12:00,090 --> 01:12:03,962
But as far as being able to access
the same folder and work in the same data,

1423
01:12:03,962 --> 01:12:04,820
we can do that.

1424
01:12:04,820 --> 01:12:06,940
The Windows machine connected just fine.

1425
01:12:08,460 --> 01:12:13,130
Now, back in my server, if I wanna
know who's connected to my system and

1426
01:12:13,130 --> 01:12:15,840
whether there's actually people
in there able to use it.

1427
01:12:15,840 --> 01:12:17,120
You can see all that.

1428
01:12:17,120 --> 01:12:20,220
If you back down to
the file sharing service.

1429
01:12:20,220 --> 01:12:23,130
There's another tab up here,
where it says connected users.

1430
01:12:23,130 --> 01:12:27,160
You can see all the people connected
into your system right now.

1431
01:12:27,160 --> 01:12:29,430
You can see what protocol they're using.

1432
01:12:29,430 --> 01:12:31,910
These guys right here,
where it says Don Pezet.

1433
01:12:31,910 --> 01:12:33,951
These are connections from my Mac.

1434
01:12:33,951 --> 01:12:35,333
They're AFP.

1435
01:12:35,333 --> 01:12:39,900
This one right here, 10.211.55.202,
that's my Windows machine.

1436
01:12:39,900 --> 01:12:42,950
And I can see that I'm logged
in as this longer name.

1437
01:12:42,950 --> 01:12:45,960
Windows likes to put the computer
name before the user name.

1438
01:12:45,960 --> 01:12:48,610
And then I can see type SMB.

1439
01:12:48,610 --> 01:12:50,440
It's connected using Server Message Block.

1440
01:12:50,440 --> 01:12:53,890
You can see what protocol people
are using to connect to your system.

1441
01:12:53,890 --> 01:12:56,790
And ensure that they are getting in there.

1442
01:12:56,790 --> 01:12:59,150
If you're going to be
shutting this server down,

1443
01:12:59,150 --> 01:13:00,840
these are the people you need
to call on the phone and say,

1444
01:13:00,840 --> 01:13:04,440
hey I'm gonna be shutting down the server
you need to get out of the system.

1445
01:13:04,440 --> 01:13:08,230
And you can kick people out, I could take
like that one and just hit disconnect, and

1446
01:13:08,230 --> 01:13:12,280
it's gonna kick them out of the server,
and that'll stop that session.

1447
01:13:12,280 --> 01:13:17,500
If they have any open files at that point,
then they might lose their data and

1448
01:13:17,500 --> 01:13:20,210
some operating systems like Windows,
did you see what it did?

1449
01:13:20,210 --> 01:13:22,100
It just turned right around and reconnect.

1450
01:13:22,100 --> 01:13:25,320
It'll reconnect automatically cuz it
thinks a network outage happened, so

1451
01:13:25,320 --> 01:13:27,780
the disconnect button doesn't always work.

1452
01:13:27,780 --> 01:13:30,710
If you truly wanna get people
outta your system, you just

1453
01:13:30,710 --> 01:13:34,270
flip that old off switch right there and
they're out but they will lose data.

1454
01:13:34,270 --> 01:13:36,940
If they were working something, they
won't be able to save it to the network

1455
01:13:36,940 --> 01:13:39,290
share at that point and
that's gonna cause some problems.

1456
01:13:40,650 --> 01:13:42,210
It won't cause you any problems,
except for

1457
01:13:42,210 --> 01:13:44,350
the phone calls you get
from people who are angry.

1458
01:13:44,350 --> 01:13:47,760
It'll cause them a lot of problems,
all right.

1459
01:13:47,760 --> 01:13:53,010
Setting up a share point inside of Mac OS
server, whatever product we're using here.

1460
01:13:53,010 --> 01:13:55,200
Pretty straightforward.

1461
01:13:55,200 --> 01:13:56,350
Permissions are a big deal.

1462
01:13:56,350 --> 01:13:57,870
You gotta make sure you get those set.

1463
01:13:57,870 --> 01:14:00,810
And there's a lot of really
neat options in there.

1464
01:14:00,810 --> 01:14:02,160
To be able to tail those permissions.

1465
01:14:02,160 --> 01:14:05,090
Set up home directories and
get that data exchange.

1466
01:14:05,090 --> 01:14:07,580
The key thing to take away
from this section though,

1467
01:14:07,580 --> 01:14:10,650
is that we have multi-operating
systems support.

1468
01:14:10,650 --> 01:14:15,190
You can share folders and
files with systems other than MAC OS.

1469
01:14:15,190 --> 01:14:18,650
If you're working in a hybrid environment
with Linux boxes and Windows, and

1470
01:14:18,650 --> 01:14:21,500
MAC OS, they can all play nice together.

1471
01:14:21,500 --> 01:14:24,540
SMB is really the key to that one,
they all support it and

1472
01:14:24,540 --> 01:14:26,520
they can communicate and use it.

1473
01:14:26,520 --> 01:14:30,640
Just be aware of things like Time Machine
don't work so well on SMB, so

1474
01:14:30,640 --> 01:14:34,450
you lose some of the file versioning, but
the compatibility is normally worth it.

1475
01:14:34,450 --> 01:14:36,050
Being able to support those other systems.

1476
01:14:38,170 --> 01:14:39,980
At the end of the day though,
that's basically it.

1477
01:14:39,980 --> 01:14:43,540
We set up our file shares, we get them all
in place, and this is usually one of those

1478
01:14:43,540 --> 01:14:47,150
technologies that we set it and forget it
like the rotisserie chicken commercial.

1479
01:14:47,150 --> 01:14:49,660
We just put it in place,
and that's the end, so.

1480
01:14:49,660 --> 01:14:51,760
We'll probably wrap it up right there.

1481
01:14:51,760 --> 01:14:55,160
I do wanna remind you guys,
if you have questions on any of this,

1482
01:14:55,160 --> 01:14:56,490
please feel free to ask.

1483
01:14:56,490 --> 01:14:59,230
Live during the show you can
go to itpro.tv/live, and

1484
01:14:59,230 --> 01:15:02,855
you'll see the the chat box right beneath
the video, post your questions there.

1485
01:15:02,855 --> 01:15:04,655
We monitor and answer during the show.

1486
01:15:04,655 --> 01:15:08,595
If you have any questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1487
01:15:08,595 --> 01:15:12,289
At the top of every page on the ITProTV
site, you'll see a link that says Q&A.

1488
01:15:12,289 --> 01:15:13,671
It'll take you to the forums.

1489
01:15:13,671 --> 01:15:16,771
Post your question there,
we monitor and answer after the show.

1490
01:15:16,771 --> 01:15:20,056
They're all great places to go to get
the answers to the questions you have.

1491
01:15:20,056 --> 01:15:22,889
Take advantage of that
resource it's there for you.

1492
01:15:22,889 --> 01:15:25,270
Well, I hope you guys
enjoyed today's episode.

1493
01:15:25,270 --> 01:15:29,495
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
