episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,020 --> 00:00:10,020
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:14,938 --> 00:00:22,044
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,044 --> 00:00:32,924
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:32,924 --> 00:00:33,586
All right.

5
00:00:33,586 --> 00:00:35,284
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

6
00:00:35,284 --> 00:00:37,746
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:37,746 --> 00:00:39,258
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

8
00:00:39,258 --> 00:00:44,000
back again with another episode of
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

9
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:46,840
Today we're gonna be jumping into
a special topic,cuz this is one of

10
00:00:46,840 --> 00:00:50,620
the neater technologies, is a part
of the server system in Yosemite.

11
00:00:50,620 --> 00:00:52,660
And that is the caching server.

12
00:00:52,660 --> 00:00:55,870
The caching server is one of those
really neat functions because it's so

13
00:00:55,870 --> 00:00:56,830
easy to implement.

14
00:00:56,830 --> 00:00:59,110
Of all the technologies
we cover in this show,

15
00:00:59,110 --> 00:01:02,030
this one is dead simple
to get functioning.

16
00:01:02,030 --> 00:01:05,760
But before we jump into that,
what is the caching server?

17
00:01:05,760 --> 00:01:10,050
A lot of our computers reach out and
download content from the Internet.

18
00:01:10,050 --> 00:01:11,830
We download things from
the Internet every day.

19
00:01:11,830 --> 00:01:14,200
every time we install a new application,

20
00:01:14,200 --> 00:01:17,360
a software update comes out
we're downloading content.

21
00:01:17,360 --> 00:01:20,670
Well, if you just had a single
machine like my laptop right here.

22
00:01:20,670 --> 00:01:24,800
If a new update comes out from Apple and
it's 2 gigs in size,

23
00:01:24,800 --> 00:01:29,290
like the Yosemite 10.10.3
update just came out last week.

24
00:01:29,290 --> 00:01:32,880
So that update is 2 gigabytes in size.

25
00:01:32,880 --> 00:01:36,690
If I download on my laptop, 2 gig, so
it'll take a few minutes to download.

26
00:01:36,690 --> 00:01:38,820
And once it's done,
I install it and I'm done.

27
00:01:38,820 --> 00:01:39,400
Right?
No big deal.

28
00:01:40,410 --> 00:01:43,010
But what if I have a 100 laptops, or

29
00:01:43,010 --> 00:01:46,660
1000 laptops, or
I've got some desktops in mix too, right?

30
00:01:46,660 --> 00:01:48,650
We have some MAC pros or something.

31
00:01:48,650 --> 00:01:53,900
Well if you've got thousands of machines,
they're all going out to Apple,

32
00:01:53,900 --> 00:01:57,540
and they're all downloading
that 2 gigabyte update.

33
00:01:57,540 --> 00:02:00,020
So now you take that 2 gigs
that you're downloading and

34
00:02:00,020 --> 00:02:01,510
you multiply it by a hundred or
a thousand,

35
00:02:01,510 --> 00:02:04,520
and you're talking about terabytes
of data that you're downloading.

36
00:02:04,520 --> 00:02:05,640
It's a lot of bandwidth.

37
00:02:05,640 --> 00:02:08,260
All right.
It's a lot of resources on the network.

38
00:02:08,260 --> 00:02:09,640
And it's not just updates.

39
00:02:09,640 --> 00:02:12,190
It's things like App Store apps, right?

40
00:02:12,190 --> 00:02:15,520
Anything you pull out of
the App Store those, they add up.

41
00:02:15,520 --> 00:02:20,320
And if you're a school or an enterprise,
you can really hurt your bandwidth by

42
00:02:20,320 --> 00:02:24,070
doing repetitious downloads,
over and over and over again.

43
00:02:24,070 --> 00:02:27,170
So, what the cashing server
does is it helps with that.

44
00:02:27,170 --> 00:02:30,700
It allows us to set up a server,
just a machine running OS 10,

45
00:02:30,700 --> 00:02:32,770
that's running the cashing service.

46
00:02:32,770 --> 00:02:36,430
And, the first time
somebody gets an update,

47
00:02:36,430 --> 00:02:37,380
it's going to go out to the internet.

48
00:02:37,380 --> 00:02:39,490
It's going to go out to Apple and
download that update.

49
00:02:39,490 --> 00:02:43,170
But at the same time,
the cache server will grab a copy of it.

50
00:02:43,170 --> 00:02:45,390
It'll hold a copy of that data.

51
00:02:45,390 --> 00:02:49,560
And from then on if anybody else
goes out to get that same update,

52
00:02:49,560 --> 00:02:52,740
instead of going out to the Internet,
instead of going all the way out to Apple,

53
00:02:52,740 --> 00:02:56,850
they can get it right from your own
server, right there local on network.

54
00:02:56,850 --> 00:02:59,260
That has two big benefits, right.

55
00:02:59,260 --> 00:03:02,380
The biggest benefit for us as
Administrators is it saves band width.

56
00:03:02,380 --> 00:03:05,620
It says, hey if I got a hundred people,
don't let them all go onto the Internet.

57
00:03:05,620 --> 00:03:06,940
The first person goes to the Internet.

58
00:03:06,940 --> 00:03:09,720
The other 99 pull it from a local server.

59
00:03:09,720 --> 00:03:11,330
That frees up Internet band width, right.

60
00:03:11,330 --> 00:03:13,230
That's our number one benefit.

61
00:03:13,230 --> 00:03:16,040
But our number two benefit,
is it's faster for the end user.

62
00:03:17,190 --> 00:03:20,480
Your Internet connection is typically
slower than your local area network.

63
00:03:20,480 --> 00:03:24,090
So for example here in the studio,
we have an 80 megabit Internet connection.

64
00:03:24,090 --> 00:03:25,520
Now that's pretty fast.

65
00:03:25,520 --> 00:03:27,270
Al least for me that's fast.

66
00:03:27,270 --> 00:03:30,220
So 80 megabit,
I can download things pretty fast.

67
00:03:30,220 --> 00:03:33,160
Here on the local network,
we're on a gigabit network.

68
00:03:33,160 --> 00:03:36,300
So if the update is already stored on
a server right here I can get it at

69
00:03:36,300 --> 00:03:40,190
a gigabit speed, as opposed to the 80
megabits I get going out to the Internet,

70
00:03:40,190 --> 00:03:44,150
and probably even less than that going to
Apple, especially if it's a new update and

71
00:03:44,150 --> 00:03:46,200
their servers are getting hit really hard.

72
00:03:46,200 --> 00:03:50,760
So a caching server helps to
basically get us our updates faster,

73
00:03:50,760 --> 00:03:52,440
while at the same time saving bandwidth.

74
00:03:53,470 --> 00:03:55,920
Now, there are some limitations
to the caching server.

75
00:03:55,920 --> 00:03:57,320
It can't cache everything.

76
00:03:57,320 --> 00:03:58,080
And you don't want it to.

77
00:03:58,080 --> 00:04:01,210
There's a lot of people that
do caching of web pages, but

78
00:04:01,210 --> 00:04:03,600
most web pages these day are dynamic.

79
00:04:03,600 --> 00:04:04,440
They change.

80
00:04:04,440 --> 00:04:08,380
If you go to CNN now, or
whatever news site you go to,

81
00:04:08,380 --> 00:04:10,660
you're gonna see a set of current news.

82
00:04:10,660 --> 00:04:12,690
If you go five minutes later,
there might be new articles.

83
00:04:12,690 --> 00:04:13,640
You don't want to cache that.

84
00:04:13,640 --> 00:04:14,270
You want the latest.

85
00:04:14,270 --> 00:04:16,780
You want the newest news available.

86
00:04:16,780 --> 00:04:19,830
So the caching server
doesn't try to be everything.

87
00:04:19,830 --> 00:04:24,320
It just focuses on things that
Apple knows are okay to cache,

88
00:04:24,320 --> 00:04:27,360
that are things that you'll
want to be able to save.

89
00:04:27,360 --> 00:04:28,910
Let me show you the web page.

90
00:04:28,910 --> 00:04:31,770
Apple has some tech
documentation posted and

91
00:04:31,770 --> 00:04:34,640
I'll post the link to this to
the show after the episode.

92
00:04:34,640 --> 00:04:38,480
But they list out all the different
content that the caching server is capable

93
00:04:38,480 --> 00:04:39,440
of storing.

94
00:04:39,440 --> 00:04:42,480
And you'll see it's quite
a collection of things.

95
00:04:42,480 --> 00:04:46,380
I call up updates,
cuz those are usually the biggest things.

96
00:04:46,380 --> 00:04:49,850
That 10.10.3 right now,
it's 2 GB in size, and

97
00:04:49,850 --> 00:04:52,730
all of your machines are gonna
need that 2 gigabytes of data.

98
00:04:52,730 --> 00:04:54,800
That's a big chunk of data.

99
00:04:54,800 --> 00:04:59,230
But it caches other things,
like iTunes purchases and iBooks.

100
00:04:59,230 --> 00:05:03,970
So if you buy an iBook and it downloads,
you might be thinking well it's six MGs or

101
00:05:03,970 --> 00:05:04,560
something like that.

102
00:05:04,560 --> 00:05:06,550
It's not a big file, who cares.

103
00:05:06,550 --> 00:05:09,160
But if you're about to roll
out to 1000 students or

104
00:05:09,160 --> 00:05:11,980
1000 employees,
that 6 Megs starts to add up.

105
00:05:11,980 --> 00:05:14,030
So that purchase can be backed up.

106
00:05:14,030 --> 00:05:17,190
For colleges or universities,
high schools, elementary schools,

107
00:05:17,190 --> 00:05:19,830
that's a really beneficial thing to have.

108
00:05:19,830 --> 00:05:20,890
iTunes.

109
00:05:20,890 --> 00:05:24,950
This includes movies, so if you've
purchased a movie and it's gonna be

110
00:05:24,950 --> 00:05:28,240
available on multiple machines,
the caching server can help with that.

111
00:05:28,240 --> 00:05:32,370
So any kind of iOS app purchase,
any other bookstore content and

112
00:05:32,370 --> 00:05:34,080
so on, that's gonna be included in there.

113
00:05:34,080 --> 00:05:37,180
And notice that it's both iOS and
Mavericks.

114
00:05:37,180 --> 00:05:40,670
Remember the ACTC is really is
really centering around OS 10.

115
00:05:40,670 --> 00:05:41,920
We're supporting OS 10.

116
00:05:41,920 --> 00:05:45,140
But a lot of you guys are going
to have iPads and iPhones.

117
00:05:45,140 --> 00:05:48,860
Well, the iPads and
iPhones can use the caching server, also.

118
00:05:48,860 --> 00:05:51,250
So again,
going back to that school example.

119
00:05:51,250 --> 00:05:53,620
Maybe you've got a bunch of iPads for
your students and

120
00:05:53,620 --> 00:05:55,820
they're all pulling down some textbook.

121
00:05:55,820 --> 00:05:58,380
Well, they can leverage
that caching server, and

122
00:05:58,380 --> 00:06:01,590
it's the same caching server that
your OS X 10 machines are using.

123
00:06:01,590 --> 00:06:03,420
That makes it really flexible and
easy to deploy.

124
00:06:04,710 --> 00:06:08,250
On the OS X 10 side, we've got things
like the actual operating system updates,

125
00:06:08,250 --> 00:06:10,930
any kind of OS X 10 software
updates that come out.

126
00:06:10,930 --> 00:06:14,270
We've got our App Store and
the App Store purchases inside of it.

127
00:06:14,270 --> 00:06:16,920
Anything like Apple updates.

128
00:06:16,920 --> 00:06:20,630
So software like pages, and

129
00:06:20,630 --> 00:06:24,590
the other iWorks suite utilities,
those updates get cached.

130
00:06:24,590 --> 00:06:27,140
Your operating system updates get cached,
that kind of stuff.

131
00:06:27,140 --> 00:06:28,470
Which is really kinda nice to have.

132
00:06:30,170 --> 00:06:32,080
They do list a couple of things here, and

133
00:06:32,080 --> 00:06:35,280
this is the one that causes a lot of
confusion, especially on the exam.

134
00:06:35,280 --> 00:06:38,630
Third party applications and
updates via the Mac App Store.

135
00:06:38,630 --> 00:06:39,380
All right.

136
00:06:39,380 --> 00:06:43,030
That last little part right there,
via the Mac App Store, that's important.

137
00:06:44,150 --> 00:06:48,260
The caching server will not

So, my server, for example, if I go

00:20:52,159 --> 00:20:54,430
But what if you had more than one subnet?

00:20:56,390 --> 00:21:01,280
In the olden days, in previous versions of

00:21:01,280 --> 00:21:04,380
and you had to go and modify

00:21:04,380 --> 00:21:06,650
other subnets than the subnet

00:21:07,860 --> 00:21:10,260
But Apple's changed that now,

00:21:10,260 --> 00:21:11,900
In fact, it's really automatic.

00:21:20,610 --> 00:21:23,200
All of your clients are on one network.

00:21:23,200 --> 00:21:25,540
The caching server is

00:21:25,540 --> 00:21:27,580
They go through the same router

they all have the same public ID.

But now, what happens is when they go out,

00:21:39,020 --> 00:21:41,310

00:21:41,310 --> 00:21:45,390

00:21:46,830 --> 00:21:50,670

00:21:50,670 --> 00:21:54,470
They both go through switches to a router.

441
00:21:54,470 --> 00:21:57,150
And they both go out
with the same public IP.

442
00:21:57,150 --> 00:21:59,420
They got the same public IP.

443
00:21:59,420 --> 00:22:02,680
And because of that, as they go out
to Apple and the caching server.

444
00:22:02,680 --> 00:22:05,400
See, the caching server's
over on the 10.0.1 network.

445
00:22:05,400 --> 00:22:08,040
It goes out to Apple and registers itself.

446
00:22:08,040 --> 00:22:12,920
And so, now, clients in both subnets
because they have the same public IP,

447
00:22:12,920 --> 00:22:14,840
Apple knows they're in
the same physical location.

448
00:22:14,840 --> 00:22:15,650
And it says,

449
00:22:15,650 --> 00:22:19,820
if they're in the same physical location,
they can use the same caching server.

450
00:22:19,820 --> 00:22:24,500
What happened before in previous
versions is when these guys went out and

451
00:22:24,500 --> 00:22:28,510
registered with Apple, sure they had the
same public IP, but Apple would see that

452
00:22:28,510 --> 00:22:32,110
different subnet and it would assume they
were in a different geographic location.

453
00:22:32,110 --> 00:22:36,010
It would say, you know what,
yeah they got the same public IP, but

454
00:22:36,010 --> 00:22:39,460
there in a different subnet, so maybe
that's a branch office somewhere else.

455
00:22:39,460 --> 00:22:41,370
And we don't wanna use
a caching server for

456
00:22:41,370 --> 00:22:46,340
the branch office because they're probably
crossing the internet to get over here,

457
00:22:46,340 --> 00:22:49,480
and then from here,
going out to the internet.

458
00:22:49,480 --> 00:22:52,140
So, we don't wanna double
up that WAN consumption,

459
00:22:52,140 --> 00:22:54,400
having them jump the WAN to get
over to the other location.

460
00:22:54,400 --> 00:22:58,050
And then, jump the WAN again to
get out to the internet to Apple.

461
00:22:58,050 --> 00:23:00,438
Why do it twice, let's just let them
go straight out to the internet.

462
00:23:00,438 --> 00:23:04,510
And that was kind of the stance that
Apple took, and what they found was that

463
00:23:04,510 --> 00:23:08,250
overwhelmingly, that wasn't
the topology that most people had.

464
00:23:08,250 --> 00:23:11,160
That when you had a branch office and
it didn't have a caching server,

465
00:23:11,160 --> 00:23:13,770
when they went out to the internet,
they went out with a different public IP.

466
00:23:13,770 --> 00:23:15,950
People weren't routing internet access for

467
00:23:15,950 --> 00:23:19,260
their branches back to a core,
at least not very often.

468
00:23:19,260 --> 00:23:22,730
And so, Apple said, well we didn't handle
this the right way, let's change it.

469
00:23:22,730 --> 00:23:23,530
And they did.

470
00:23:23,530 --> 00:23:28,710
So, now, when you have multiple subnets,
if they go out with the same public IP,

471
00:23:28,710 --> 00:23:31,440
Apple will treat them as
the same physical location, and

472
00:23:31,440 --> 00:23:33,140
allow them to use that caching service.

473
00:23:33,140 --> 00:23:34,770
So, they'll hit this caching server.

474
00:23:34,770 --> 00:23:37,600
These clients over on this different
network will hit that one.

00:23:37,600 --> 00:23:42,400
And that's really beneficial because a lot

476
00:23:42,400 --> 00:23:45,740

their teachers and professors.

00:23:45,740 --> 00:23:48,522
And then, a separate network for
their students.

478
00:23:48,522 --> 00:23:50,870
And maybe, even a third network for
public access for

479
00:23:50,870 --> 00:23:52,870
people who are visiting the campus.

00:23:52,870 --> 00:23:54,678
Well, in the past,
you have to have a caching service for

481
00:23:54,678 --> 00:23:55,479
each of those networks.

Now, we can have one caching server and

00:23:58,739 --> 00:24:02,067
because Apple will treat them as all

to choose the logs for the caching server.

591
00:29:43,710 --> 00:29:47,140
And you'll see when clients check in or
when we register with Apple,

592
00:29:47,140 --> 00:29:49,580
it's all right there in the log files.

593
00:29:49,580 --> 00:29:52,050
So, I'm looking at my system
logs here by default, but

594
00:29:52,050 --> 00:29:56,780
let me switch over to my caching
server logs, right here.

595
00:29:56,780 --> 00:30:00,220
And what I expect to see is
me registering with Apple, so

596
00:30:00,220 --> 00:30:02,230
here's my caching server started.

597
00:30:02,230 --> 00:30:05,730
Registration succeeded,
that's me registering with Apple to say,

598
00:30:05,730 --> 00:30:07,170
I'm a caching server.

599
00:30:07,170 --> 00:30:10,760
And then right after that,
request my software update for.

600
00:30:10,760 --> 00:30:14,370
Here's somebody requesting an update.

601
00:30:14,370 --> 00:30:17,380
As I look down the list,
I see these request that are going on, and

602
00:30:17,380 --> 00:30:20,240
then right down here,
it's starting these downloads.

603
00:30:20,240 --> 00:30:22,880
It's downloading some of these
different little updates

604
00:30:22,880 --> 00:30:26,560
that are the ones that were all
created those GUID folders.

605
00:30:26,560 --> 00:30:28,710
So it's already cached some of that.

606
00:30:28,710 --> 00:30:32,477
It's not showing the big update,
the 2 gig update for 10.10.3 yet.

607
00:30:32,477 --> 00:30:36,010
It wont show up here until it's done,
until it's actually downloaded.

608
00:30:36,010 --> 00:30:37,790
So we have to wait for that to happen, but

609
00:30:37,790 --> 00:30:41,320
I can see that I am downloading
updates and it is now available.

610
00:30:41,320 --> 00:30:43,390
So, caching server?

611
00:30:43,390 --> 00:30:45,120
Super easy to configure,
you just turn it on.

612
00:30:46,120 --> 00:30:47,970
Works great, things to watch out for.

613
00:30:47,970 --> 00:30:49,130
Watch out for that hard drive space.

614
00:30:49,130 --> 00:30:52,170
You might need to set a limit to it,
definitely keep that in mind.

615
00:30:52,170 --> 00:30:55,360
There's actually a hidden command that's
useful for saving hard drive space.

616
00:30:55,360 --> 00:31:02,520
Let me cover that, I doubt it will show
up on the exam but it is possible.

617
00:31:02,520 --> 00:31:05,570
Let's see, what actually,
no, sorry nevermind.

618
00:31:05,570 --> 00:31:07,610
I'm thinking of something
slightly different,

619
00:31:07,610 --> 00:31:10,270
it's with the software update
server there's a hidden command.

620
00:31:10,270 --> 00:31:13,490
So for this one, really simple,
really straightforward.

621
00:31:13,490 --> 00:31:17,120
Not a big deal to get this one up and
going, definitely easy.

622
00:31:17,120 --> 00:31:20,430
Keep in mind if you're about to deploy
this in production, and you gotta weigh

623
00:31:20,430 --> 00:31:24,240
the benefits between the caching
server and the software update server.

624
00:31:24,240 --> 00:31:27,560
And this might not be the right one for
you, while it looks easy and great and

625
00:31:27,560 --> 00:31:29,010
you wanna go and deploy it.

626
00:31:29,010 --> 00:31:32,650
You might wanna look at software update
too, so if you haven't done it already,

627
00:31:32,650 --> 00:31:35,720
make sure you jump over and watch our
episode on the software update service.

628
00:31:35,720 --> 00:31:37,290
You might find,
that one's the better choice.

629
00:31:37,290 --> 00:31:39,950
You might find, that one gives you
more control than you care for.

630
00:31:39,950 --> 00:31:42,940
And in that case, the caching server
is the better option for you.

631
00:31:42,940 --> 00:31:46,570
So weight the two, decide which one is
right for you, and get it deployed.

632
00:31:46,570 --> 00:31:49,400
This one dead simple to deploy, definitely
something you wanna make use of.

633
00:31:51,040 --> 00:31:52,800
Well, that's about it for this episode.

634
00:31:52,800 --> 00:31:55,120
There's only so much we can talk
about on the caching server.

635
00:31:55,120 --> 00:31:57,140
So, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

636
00:31:57,140 --> 00:32:01,350
Keep in mind if you have any questions
on this always feel free to ask.

637
00:32:01,350 --> 00:32:04,150
Live during the show you
can go to ITPro.tv/live and

638
00:32:04,150 --> 00:32:06,280
you'll see the chatroom
right beneath the video.

639
00:32:06,280 --> 00:32:07,600
You can post your questions there.

640
00:32:07,600 --> 00:32:09,180
We monitor and answer during the show.

641
00:32:09,180 --> 00:32:12,790
If you have questions after the show,
like if you're watching this recorded,

642
00:32:12,790 --> 00:32:15,960
well you're not left in the lurch,
use our forums.

643
00:32:15,960 --> 00:32:19,330
At the top of every page on the ITProTV
site, you'll see a link that says Q & A.

644
00:32:19,330 --> 00:32:21,790
Click on it,
it will take you to the forums.

645
00:32:21,790 --> 00:32:23,250
You can post your question there.

646
00:32:23,250 --> 00:32:25,190
We monitor and answer after the show.

647
00:32:25,190 --> 00:32:28,030
It's a great resource,
make sure you take advantage of it.

648
00:32:28,030 --> 00:32:29,316
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed today's episode.

649
00:32:29,316 --> 00:32:33,199
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

650
00:32:33,199 --> 00:32:43,199

episodes.title: Software Update Service
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,585 --> 00:00:36,140
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening!

3
00:00:36,140 --> 00:00:40,505
Welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host Don Pezet.

4
00:00:40,505 --> 00:00:44,400
Back again with another episode of
Apple certified technical coordinator.

5
00:00:44,400 --> 00:00:48,450
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at the software update service.

6
00:00:48,450 --> 00:00:50,450
Now, this episode covers, well,

7
00:00:50,450 --> 00:00:54,220
the software update service,
I've already said that, but covers it.

8
00:00:54,220 --> 00:00:56,980
And it's important to understand that
you don't wanna watch just this episode

9
00:00:56,980 --> 00:00:57,870
by itself.

10
00:00:57,870 --> 00:01:02,390
It's a great idea to also watch
the caching service episode,

11
00:01:02,390 --> 00:01:05,530
because these two are mutually
exclusive technologies.

12
00:01:05,530 --> 00:01:07,200
You can use one or the other.

13
00:01:07,200 --> 00:01:10,140
So if you haven't watched the caching one,
you definitely wanna check that out.

14
00:01:10,140 --> 00:01:14,200
But setting that aside, let's dive into
the software update service, right?

15
00:01:14,200 --> 00:01:17,135
So, what the heck is
the software update service?

16
00:01:17,135 --> 00:01:21,065
Well, what it is is a really neat
system that's built into the OS 10

17
00:01:21,065 --> 00:01:24,765
server application that allows
us to take some control

18
00:01:24,765 --> 00:01:28,315
over the updates that
are available to our end users.

19
00:01:28,315 --> 00:01:29,855
When a new update comes out from Apple, so

20
00:01:29,855 --> 00:01:34,345
for example that the 10.10.3
update just came out last week.

21
00:01:34,345 --> 00:01:37,350
When a new update comes out
like that each of your Macs,

22
00:01:37,350 --> 00:01:40,430
by default,
are checking in with Apple every so often.

23
00:01:40,430 --> 00:01:44,250
And they'll see that update and
they'll prompt the end users to update.

24
00:01:44,250 --> 00:01:45,066
And it's up to them.

25
00:01:45,066 --> 00:01:46,159
They decide.

26
00:01:46,159 --> 00:01:47,540
Do they wanna do the update or not?

27
00:01:47,540 --> 00:01:48,980
Sometimes they won't.

28
00:01:48,980 --> 00:01:52,490
Sometimes they'll skip it and you've got
this machine that's outta date, right?

29
00:01:52,490 --> 00:01:54,770
Other times, they'll say yeah,
I wanna do it.

30
00:01:54,770 --> 00:01:58,300
And they do the update, and maybe you
have things like third party applications

31
00:01:58,300 --> 00:02:01,060
that aren't ready for that update yet
and things get broken.

32
00:02:01,060 --> 00:02:03,380
That really happens when
you have a major update.

33
00:02:03,380 --> 00:02:05,830
So maybe you've got machines
that are running Mavericks and

34
00:02:05,830 --> 00:02:08,670
Yosemite just came out and you wanna wait.

35
00:02:08,670 --> 00:02:09,436
You gotta test some software.

36
00:02:09,436 --> 00:02:10,830
You gotta make sure things are ready.

37
00:02:10,830 --> 00:02:12,170
And your end users have already done it.

38
00:02:12,170 --> 00:02:16,010
They've already jumped and installed
Yosemite and now some software is broken.

39
00:02:16,010 --> 00:02:18,170
And you gotta roll them
back with time machine or

40
00:02:18,170 --> 00:02:20,770
whatever it is that you need to do
to get them back and operational.

41
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:22,950
Well software update lets us control that.

42
00:02:22,950 --> 00:02:28,260
With software update service we can
download a list of updates from Apple,

43
00:02:28,260 --> 00:02:29,960
all the updates are available.

44
00:02:29,960 --> 00:02:31,410
And then we can go through and

45
00:02:31,410 --> 00:02:34,210
pick and choose whether
the updates are enabled or not.

46
00:02:34,210 --> 00:02:37,140
So just because 10.10.3
came out doesn't mean I

47
00:02:37,140 --> 00:02:39,600
want all my end users to have it just yet.

48
00:02:39,600 --> 00:02:42,340
So I can flag that update to download it.

49
00:02:42,340 --> 00:02:45,790
And then I can choose who gets
the update and who doesn't.

50
00:02:45,790 --> 00:02:48,710
I can choose whether it's enabled
in my network or not, right?

51
00:02:48,710 --> 00:02:52,970
And if something goes wrong, if I push
an update out and things start to break

52
00:02:52,970 --> 00:02:57,230
I can choose to remove the update and back
it off of the machines that are out there.

53
00:02:57,230 --> 00:03:00,530
It gives you the control
to manage those updates.

54
00:03:00,530 --> 00:03:05,380
Now if you've watched the caching episode,
this might sound a little bit familiar.

55
00:03:05,380 --> 00:03:07,990
In the caching episode we talked
about how the caching server

56
00:03:07,990 --> 00:03:10,610
can download copies of the updates.

57
00:03:10,610 --> 00:03:14,410
And when people go to install an update
they just get it from the caching server.

58
00:03:14,410 --> 00:03:16,202
Well the software update
sort of works the same way.

59
00:03:16,202 --> 00:03:17,119
It downloads the updates.

60
00:03:17,119 --> 00:03:18,581
It's sitting right there.

61
00:03:18,581 --> 00:03:20,115
And when somebody goes
out to get an update,

62
00:03:20,115 --> 00:03:22,030
they can get it right from
the software update server.

63
00:03:23,190 --> 00:03:25,740
The difference is control.

64
00:03:25,740 --> 00:03:28,670
The software update server
will automatically download

65
00:03:28,670 --> 00:03:31,920
updates as soon as they're available,
if you set it that way.

66
00:03:31,920 --> 00:03:34,150
And then it can make them
available to your clients.

67
00:03:34,150 --> 00:03:36,710
Or you can manually pick and
choose which updates get approved,

68
00:03:36,710 --> 00:03:37,940
you get that control.

69
00:03:37,940 --> 00:03:40,510
The caching server doesn't
give you that control.

70
00:03:40,510 --> 00:03:43,660
And that's why these two
are mutually exclusive.

71
00:03:43,660 --> 00:03:45,746
You're going to run one or the other.

72
00:03:45,746 --> 00:03:49,066
If you're running the caching server,
don't run software update services.

73
00:03:49,066 --> 00:03:50,756
If you're running
software update services,

74
00:03:50,756 --> 00:03:52,225
don't run the caching server, right?

75
00:03:52,225 --> 00:03:53,875
You gotta run one or the other.

76
00:03:53,875 --> 00:03:57,395
But if you're in an enterprise
environment, if you have mission critical

77
00:03:57,395 --> 00:04:00,695
systems, a software update
server can be really beneficial,

78
00:04:00,695 --> 00:04:05,640
because it's what's going to control
whether or not you push these updates out.

79
00:04:05,640 --> 00:04:07,860
These updates could
potentially break software.

80
00:04:07,860 --> 00:04:09,940
You need to keep your
employees productive.

81
00:04:09,940 --> 00:04:11,570
But, you need to keep your network secure.

82
00:04:11,570 --> 00:04:15,050
So, it's kind of like weighing
the benefits, the pros and cons.

83
00:04:15,050 --> 00:04:17,380
I can rapidly push out updates.

84
00:04:17,380 --> 00:04:20,320
But potentially I can break software,
now my employees can't work.

85
00:04:20,320 --> 00:04:23,780
Well, that's just as bad as if
their machine got compromised and

86
00:04:23,780 --> 00:04:26,600
taken offline,
like a denial of service attack.

87
00:04:26,600 --> 00:04:27,830
In which case they can't work.

88
00:04:27,830 --> 00:04:29,900
So you kind of lose out either way there.

89
00:04:29,900 --> 00:04:32,960
So being able to test your updates,
make sure they're good,

90
00:04:32,960 --> 00:04:34,870
then push them out, that's very valuable.

91
00:04:35,930 --> 00:04:38,410
The software update service
is pretty easy to configure.

92
00:04:38,410 --> 00:04:39,770
It's not as easy as the caching server.

93
00:04:39,770 --> 00:04:42,220
Caching server you just flip an on switch,
right?

94
00:04:42,220 --> 00:04:46,290
But with the software update server,
there's an on switch, so there's that.

95
00:04:46,290 --> 00:04:50,940
But we actually do have to tell the
clients to use our software update server.

96
00:04:50,940 --> 00:04:52,100
The clients don't know.

97
00:04:52,100 --> 00:04:55,190
They don't automatically find
an update server like they would with

98
00:04:55,190 --> 00:04:56,280
a caching server.

99
00:04:56,280 --> 00:04:59,100
So to get a set-up,
there's actually two parts.

100
00:04:59,100 --> 00:05:00,760
The first part is setting up a server.

101
00:05:00,760 --> 00:05:04,215
You need to get your software
update server set up.

102
00:05:04,215 --> 00:05:06,759
And then the second part
is you have to go and

103
00:05:06,759 --> 00:05:09,313
tell the clients to use the update server.

104
00:05:09,313 --> 00:05:14,530
All right, now,
you may need more than one update server.

105
00:05:14,530 --> 00:05:19,400
So for example, let's say that I want
to do, I always call it a canary group.

106
00:05:19,400 --> 00:05:21,107
When a new update comes out,

107
00:05:21,107 --> 00:05:25,670
I always immediately rolled the update
out to a select number of computers.

108
00:05:25,670 --> 00:05:28,745
These are computers that are gonna
be run by IT personnel or

109
00:05:28,745 --> 00:05:31,778
staff that's a little more
technically savvy, right?

110
00:05:31,778 --> 00:05:34,794
I want them to get the updates right
away because if there's a problem,

111
00:05:34,794 --> 00:05:35,910
they'll spot it.

112
00:05:35,910 --> 00:05:37,170
They'll spot it and they'll let me know.

113
00:05:37,170 --> 00:05:39,230
We can troubleshoot it and
find out what's wrong with that update or

114
00:05:39,230 --> 00:05:40,520
what we need to do to get it working.

115
00:05:40,520 --> 00:05:44,741
And only after I pass that period
of testing do I then say, okay,

116
00:05:44,741 --> 00:05:48,036
I'm gonna roll the update
out to everybody else.

117
00:05:48,036 --> 00:05:52,657
Well, in the software update service
you can only turn an update on or off.

118
00:05:52,657 --> 00:05:55,640
You can't really pick like,
I want this group to get this update.

119
00:05:55,640 --> 00:05:58,015
I want this other group
to not get that update.

120
00:05:58,015 --> 00:06:01,695
If you want that, you need more
than one software update server.

121
00:06:01,695 --> 00:06:05,355
So, you might have one software update
server, that's your Canary group,

122
00:06:05,355 --> 00:06:10,005
that's automatically proven every
update the moment it's released.

123
00:06:10,005 --> 00:06:12,615
And, then you have another
software update server,

124
00:06:12,615 --> 00:06:15,315
that services the rest of
the computers in your environment.

125
00:06:15,315 --> 00:06:17,460
And it is a lot more conservative.

126
00:06:17,460 --> 00:06:19,260
It requires manual approval.

127
00:06:19,260 --> 00:06:22,060
You go through and
approve when the updates roll out, and

128
00:06:22,060 --> 00:06:25,620
that way you get that granular control,
who get what updates, and

129
00:06:25,620 --> 00:06:26,961
now you've got a nice,
flexible environment, all right?

130
00:06:28,060 --> 00:06:31,780
But getting the software updates server
setup itself is pretty straightforward.

131
00:06:31,780 --> 00:06:34,970
The client side, getting the client
configured, that's that second part.

132
00:06:34,970 --> 00:06:37,200
That is a little more involved,
cuz there's two ways to do it.

133
00:06:37,200 --> 00:06:38,690
Neither way is particularly convenient,
but

134
00:06:38,690 --> 00:06:42,050
we'll get a chance to see both
of them here in this episode.

135
00:06:42,050 --> 00:06:44,200
But let's start with just getting
our server set up, right?

136
00:06:45,260 --> 00:06:47,640
Well, this is all built
into the server app, but

137
00:06:47,640 --> 00:06:49,430
it is one of the advanced services.

138
00:06:49,430 --> 00:06:54,100
So if I go into my server app here, and
if I kinda put this back to the default,

139
00:06:54,100 --> 00:06:56,660
the first time you want a server
app this is what you see, and

140
00:06:56,660 --> 00:06:59,020
things like the caching server,
it's right there.

141
00:06:59,020 --> 00:07:00,848
It's considered a standard service.

142
00:07:00,848 --> 00:07:04,865
But the software update service is
buried down here under Advanced.

143
00:07:04,865 --> 00:07:07,750
And if I go down under Advanced,
I'll find Software Update, and

144
00:07:07,750 --> 00:07:10,177
that's where my software
update service is, right?

145
00:07:11,290 --> 00:07:14,810
Now when I first get in here,
it's turned off.

146
00:07:14,810 --> 00:07:17,890
It's turned off and
I'm not seeing a lot of options, right?

147
00:07:17,890 --> 00:07:20,357
The only option I see is automatic or
manual, right?

148
00:07:21,550 --> 00:07:26,934
What that means is when an update
comes out from Apple, what do I do?

149
00:07:26,934 --> 00:07:31,333
Do I automatically download it and
immediately enable it for everybody, or

150
00:07:31,333 --> 00:07:32,994
do I do it manually, right?

151
00:07:32,994 --> 00:07:36,179
Now this automatic setting, the automatic
setting says the moment an update

152
00:07:36,179 --> 00:07:38,480
comes out from Apple,
go ahead and download it.

153
00:07:38,480 --> 00:07:40,500
Even if none of my clients
have requested it.

154
00:07:40,500 --> 00:07:42,140
That's a little different
than the caching server.

155
00:07:42,140 --> 00:07:43,750
But, just go out and get it.

156
00:07:43,750 --> 00:07:45,600
And then enable it right away.

157
00:07:45,600 --> 00:07:47,953
So, if any of my clients request it,
they'll that get that update.

158
00:07:47,953 --> 00:07:53,133
Well, that functionality is not really
any different than the caching server.

159
00:07:53,133 --> 00:07:57,568
And, so, I can honestly say that I
don't normally use the automatic mode.

160
00:07:57,568 --> 00:08:01,555
I use the automatic mode for my canary
group, for that group that I want to get

161
00:08:01,555 --> 00:08:04,500
the updates right away, but
then I can do my testing on.

162
00:08:04,500 --> 00:08:06,670
But, in that scenario for most people,

163
00:08:06,670 --> 00:08:09,550
they'll just use the caching server,
all right?

164
00:08:09,550 --> 00:08:11,660
What we normally want is manual.

165
00:08:11,660 --> 00:08:15,000
And manual means when
a new update comes out,

166
00:08:15,000 --> 00:08:18,040
let me figure out if I wanna download and
enable it.

167
00:08:18,040 --> 00:08:19,630
And push it out to my clients.

168
00:08:19,630 --> 00:08:21,820
Okay, so we've got that choice.

169
00:08:21,820 --> 00:08:22,900
But notice here,

well they are going to start
receiving these updates.

862
00:42:09,090 --> 00:42:11,060
If this is my production group,
everybody else,

863
00:42:11,060 --> 00:42:12,370
they'll start getting the updates too.

864
00:42:12,370 --> 00:42:15,580
But normally my canary group,
I would do an automatic server.

865
00:42:15,580 --> 00:42:16,720
It would already be approved.

866
00:42:16,720 --> 00:42:19,600
Here I'm greenlighting these rolling
it out on all the other computers.

867
00:42:19,600 --> 00:42:20,940
And so now when they start to check in,

868
00:42:20,940 --> 00:42:23,960
they'll see these updates,
and they'll update.

869
00:42:23,960 --> 00:42:25,303
Well, hopefully they'll update.

870
00:42:25,303 --> 00:42:26,838
[LAUGH] Unless there's some other issue.

871
00:42:26,838 --> 00:42:29,270
Remember the other benefit here is that
when they go to download the update,

872
00:42:29,270 --> 00:42:33,410
they're not gonna download it from Apple,
they're gonna download it from our server,

873
00:42:33,410 --> 00:42:35,590
because we did download it right here,
right?

874
00:42:35,590 --> 00:42:37,920
So it serves kind of like a caching
server for those updates.

875
00:42:39,290 --> 00:42:42,460
Definitely cool stuff, not a terribly
difficult thing to get configured,

876
00:42:42,460 --> 00:42:44,840
but a little more in depth
than the caching server.

877
00:42:44,840 --> 00:42:45,960
There's definitely a difference there.

878
00:42:47,440 --> 00:42:50,990
All right, well, in this episode, we got a
chance to see the software update service.

879
00:42:50,990 --> 00:42:51,860
It works pretty well.

880
00:42:51,860 --> 00:42:56,350
It does it's job and it's exciting and
thrilling as all of our technologies are.

881
00:42:56,350 --> 00:42:58,180
So I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

882
00:42:58,180 --> 00:43:00,990
Let me remind you if you have
questions on any of this.

883

Live during the show you
can go to ITPro.TV/live and

884
00:43:04,200 --> 00:43:06,490
you'll see the chatbox beneath the video.

885

Post your questions there.

886
00:43:07,390 --> 00:43:09,660
We monitor and answer during the show.

887
00:43:09,660 --> 00:43:13,280
If you have any questions after the show
like if you're watching this recorded,

888
00:43:13,280 --> 00:43:14,740
make use of our forums.

889
00:43:14,740 --> 00:43:18,850
You can click on the Q&A link on top
of every page on the ITProTV site.

890
00:43:18,850 --> 00:43:19,820
It'll take you to the forums.

00:43:19,820 --> 00:43:21,160
You can post your question there.

00:43:21,160 --> 00:43:23,200
We monitor and answer after the show.

893
00:43:23,200 --> 00:43:24,510
Take advantage of those resources.

894

They are there for you.

895
00:43:25,740 --> 00:43:26,950
All right.

896
00:43:26,950 --> 00:43:28,250
Well that's all I got for today.

897
00:43:28,250 --> 00:43:30,350
So signing off for ITPro TV.

899

episodes.title: Deployment with NetInstall
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,588 --> 00:00:10,588
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,402 --> 00:00:22,402
[NOISE]

3
00:00:22,402 --> 00:00:33,303
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,303 --> 00:00:36,364
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

5
00:00:36,364 --> 00:00:38,310
welcome back another episode of ItProTV.

6
00:00:38,310 --> 00:00:39,640
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:39,640 --> 00:00:43,790
back again with another episode of
Apple certified technical coordinator.

8
00:00:43,790 --> 00:00:46,630
Today we're gonna jump into the single

9
00:00:46,630 --> 00:00:51,500
coolest technology that we get to cover
in this whole exam, which is NetInstall.

10
00:00:51,500 --> 00:00:53,320
Net install is a really versatile tool.

11
00:00:53,320 --> 00:00:56,050
It's built into the OS10 server app.

12
00:00:56,050 --> 00:00:59,930
What it does, is allows you to quickly
provision work stations on your network.

13
00:00:59,930 --> 00:01:03,330
Now, that's a lot of buzz words to
take in this early in the morning.

14
00:01:03,330 --> 00:01:05,170
So what the heck am I talking about?

15
00:01:05,170 --> 00:01:08,700
Well, normally when you
buy a new Mac from Apple.

16
00:01:08,700 --> 00:01:13,520
Be it a Mac Book or a Mac Pro or whatever,
it's already got OS 10 installed on it.

17
00:01:13,520 --> 00:01:17,640
And it's got a configuration that Apple
feels is suitable for most people.

18
00:01:17,640 --> 00:01:20,100
But, it's not perfect for everyone.

19
00:01:20,100 --> 00:01:23,060
There might be things that you want to
change, software that you need to install,

20
00:01:23,060 --> 00:01:24,970
modifications that you need to make.

21
00:01:24,970 --> 00:01:28,230
And, that's fine, you make those
changes and you're done, right?

22
00:01:28,230 --> 00:01:31,137
But what if you just
bought a thousand Macs.

23
00:01:31,137 --> 00:01:35,820
You bought 1,000 Mac Book Pros to
give to students at a university, and

24
00:01:35,820 --> 00:01:37,870
you wanna get them all
set up the same way.

25
00:01:37,870 --> 00:01:41,950
Well, you don't have to go and
do those changes 1,000 different times.

26
00:01:41,950 --> 00:01:47,680
So what NetInstall does is it allows
us to build custom installations.

27
00:01:47,680 --> 00:01:49,800
Installations that can be
deployed not just once, but

28
00:01:49,800 --> 00:01:53,210
100 times, 1,000 times over and
over and over again.

29
00:01:53,210 --> 00:01:57,080
So that all of our machines
have a consistent environment.

30
00:01:57,080 --> 00:01:59,390
For a regular end user, for a home user,

31
00:01:59,390 --> 00:02:02,350
this is a pointless technology
they have no use for.

32
00:02:02,350 --> 00:02:05,900
For a small business we have four,
five, maybe even ten computers.

33
00:02:05,900 --> 00:02:07,910
Pointless technology, no need for it.

34
00:02:07,910 --> 00:02:11,320
But if you're a medium or large business,
if you're an enterprise or

35
00:02:11,320 --> 00:02:15,640
a university, this is something that is
really critical to your infrastructure.

36
00:02:15,640 --> 00:02:16,150
All right.

37
00:02:16,150 --> 00:02:17,840
There's two main uses for it, right?

38
00:02:17,840 --> 00:02:21,700
One uses quick deployment, like what I
mentioned, is you get new computers and

39
00:02:21,700 --> 00:02:23,240
you can provision them.

40
00:02:23,240 --> 00:02:26,560
Provision them, that means just getting
them ready to be used in your environment.

41
00:02:26,560 --> 00:02:29,620
And that might be configuration changes,
it might be custom software,

42
00:02:29,620 --> 00:02:30,880
it might be custom files.

43
00:02:30,880 --> 00:02:34,455
Whatever it is it takes to get that
machine ready, NetInstall makes that easy.

44
00:02:34,455 --> 00:02:35,550
Right.

45
00:02:35,550 --> 00:02:41,360
The other thing that NetInstall can
provide is quick recovery right?

46
00:02:41,360 --> 00:02:43,220
If you've ever worked tech support.

47
00:02:43,220 --> 00:02:46,500
I think a lot of our viewers have
been in the situation where,

48
00:02:46,500 --> 00:02:50,290
you answer the phone and the user on
the other end is describing some problem.

49
00:02:50,290 --> 00:02:52,920
Hey, I installed some software and
now things are broken.

50
00:02:52,920 --> 00:02:54,190
And I can't figure out what's going on.

51
00:02:54,190 --> 00:02:56,830
And I need to uninstall this or
reinstall that.

52
00:02:56,830 --> 00:02:59,380
Well, you can try and
work through that problem with them.

53
00:02:59,380 --> 00:03:02,190
But sometimes half an hour goes by,
an hour goes by and

54
00:03:02,190 --> 00:03:04,240
you're still trying to
troubleshoot the problem.

55
00:03:04,240 --> 00:03:07,780
With NetInstall you can say let's
just quickly wipe your machine and

56
00:03:07,780 --> 00:03:09,420
set it back to the way we had it.

57
00:03:09,420 --> 00:03:13,320
And you can redeploy that NetInstall image
and now their machine is back up and

58
00:03:13,320 --> 00:03:16,030
running and you didn't have to
spend an hour troubleshooting it.

59
00:03:16,030 --> 00:03:19,050
So you can quickly recover
machines with NetInstall.

60
00:03:19,050 --> 00:03:20,520
It's very very cool.

61
00:03:20,520 --> 00:03:23,070
Now when you configure NetInstall
there is actually three

62
00:03:23,070 --> 00:03:24,820
different modes it can run in.

63
00:03:24,820 --> 00:03:27,000
And they're really easy to confuse.

64
00:03:27,000 --> 00:03:30,250
And so for the exam you've got to make
sure you've got all three modes straight,

65
00:03:30,250 --> 00:03:33,370
like which mode is designed for
which purpose.

66
00:03:33,370 --> 00:03:36,690
So NetInstall is the main mode.

67
00:03:36,690 --> 00:03:42,130
In NetInstall, we create an image, an
installation image, and we can then roll

68
00:03:42,130 --> 00:03:46,532
that installation image out to one, 100,
1000, however many computers that we want.

69
00:03:46,532 --> 00:03:50,050
So NetInstall is all about installing

70
00:03:50,050 --> 00:03:54,260
a copy of OS 10 on a machine and
having it set up the way we want it.

71
00:03:54,260 --> 00:03:55,940
That's NetInstall.

72
00:03:55,940 --> 00:03:57,497
Then there's NetBoot.

73
00:03:57,497 --> 00:04:01,002
NetBoot is a variation of NetInstall.

74
00:04:01,002 --> 00:04:04,662
With NetInstall, we're installing the
operating system on the client machine.

75
00:04:04,662 --> 00:04:09,490
With NetBoot, we say let's just run
the operating system from the network.

76
00:04:09,490 --> 00:04:11,550
Don't even install it on the client.

77
00:04:11,550 --> 00:04:16,170
Now, somebody turns on a client computer
and it reaches out over the network, and

78
00:04:16,170 --> 00:04:20,050
it downloads that operating system and
it runs it.

79
00:04:20,050 --> 00:04:21,950
And then when you turn
the computer off it's all gone.

80
00:04:21,950 --> 00:04:26,330
And when you turn the computer back on,
it downloads it all over again.

81
00:04:26,330 --> 00:04:29,490
And it runs again based off
of this network install.

82
00:04:29,490 --> 00:04:31,950
Now, why would we want to do that?

83
00:04:31,950 --> 00:04:34,030
Well, there's two reasons, right?

84
00:04:34,030 --> 00:04:37,400
One reason is it allows us to have
what are called diskless clients.

85
00:04:37,400 --> 00:04:39,030
Clients that don't even have a hard drive.

86
00:04:39,030 --> 00:04:39,930
They boot up.

87
00:04:39,930 --> 00:04:41,990
They load their operating system and
their RAM, and

88
00:04:41,990 --> 00:04:44,360
they run with no hard
drive in their system.

89
00:04:44,360 --> 00:04:46,310
Right?
Now, there's not a lot of use for that,

90
00:04:46,310 --> 00:04:48,980
but some people do like
having that environment.

91
00:04:48,980 --> 00:04:51,380
Hard drive failures are pretty prevalent.

92
00:04:51,380 --> 00:04:53,910
It's one of the main areas where
we have failure on a system.

93
00:04:53,910 --> 00:04:56,540
So, you can get away from hard drives,
if you want.

94
00:04:56,540 --> 00:05:00,040
But the biggest advantage is that
every time you boot that computer up,

95
00:05:00,040 --> 00:05:01,900
it's fresh and clean.

96
00:05:01,900 --> 00:05:06,600
And if you've ever worked with children,
if you've ever set up a computer lab for

97
00:05:06,600 --> 00:05:10,760
an elementary school, those computers
get messed up pretty quick.

98
00:05:10,760 --> 00:05:14,610
It gets worse in junior high or
high school, where the kids start learning

99
00:05:14,610 --> 00:05:17,310
a little bit more about how to get into
the computer and really cause some damage.

100
00:05:17,310 --> 00:05:20,330
So, somebody fires up a computer and
they change the wallpaper,

101
00:05:20,330 --> 00:05:22,000
they delete some software,
and they add in a.

102
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:25,700
I don't even know,
a BitTorrent miner or Bitcoin miner.

103
00:05:25,700 --> 00:05:30,500
Whatever it is that the kids are running
these days, and it junks up the machine.

104
00:05:30,500 --> 00:05:32,790
Well you just reboot it,
and when it reboots,

105
00:05:32,790 --> 00:05:36,840
it downloads that operating system and
runs it live over the network again.

106
00:05:36,840 --> 00:05:38,720
That's NetBoot, all right?

107
00:05:38,720 --> 00:05:41,235
So NetBoot is a variation of NetInstall.

108
00:05:42,520 --> 00:05:45,985
And the last mode is NetRestore.

109
00:05:45,985 --> 00:05:48,440
NetRestore is designed for
recovering machines.

110
00:05:48,440 --> 00:05:53,570
Now, we've already talked in other
episodes about recovery mode in Mac OS and

111
00:05:53,570 --> 00:05:57,830
how we can boot up using the command
R keys and it takes us into recovery.

112
00:05:57,830 --> 00:06:01,580
And we can even reinstall Mac OS via

113
00:06:01,580 --> 00:06:04,530
net recovery right off of Apple
servers down to our machine.

114
00:06:04,530 --> 00:06:11,530
So, NetRestore is kind of going away,
but it's still here for a reason.

115
00:06:11,530 --> 00:06:15,040
First off, it lets you do exactly
what regular Internet Recovery does.

116
00:06:15,040 --> 00:06:17,750
You can boot a machine to the network.

117
00:06:17,750 --> 00:06:21,860
It'll load recovery basically
off of a NetInstall server.

118
00:06:21,860 --> 00:06:24,786
And allow you to reinstall your
operating system and recover it.

119
00:06:24,786 --> 00:06:30,170
But where NetRestore differs is when you
do Internet Recovery off of Apple servers.

120
00:06:30,170 --> 00:06:35,960
You're just getting a stock, plain old
copy of OS10, the factory default.

121
00:06:35,960 --> 00:06:38,960
But with NetRestore,
you can customize that image.

122
00:06:38,960 --> 00:06:42,190
So now, when it loads the image
down machine it can already

123
00:06:42,190 --> 00:06:44,660
have custom software and
other things in it.

124
00:06:44,660 --> 00:06:47,120
That's not going to happen
with Internet Recovery.

125
00:06:47,120 --> 00:06:48,940
A lot of people look at NetRestore and
say, "Well,

126
00:06:48,940 --> 00:06:50,820
I don't need that now because
Apple has Internet Recovery.

127
00:06:50,820 --> 00:06:54,280
I can just use that." But
if you want a customized image

128
00:06:54,280 --> 00:06:58,580
to be deployed down as that recovery,
that's where NetRestore comes in.

129
00:06:58,580 --> 00:07:01,080
So just to recap, and make sure
you keep it straight in your head,

130
00:07:01,080 --> 00:07:03,440
the three modes: NetInstall.

131
00:07:03,440 --> 00:07:05,460
Installs OS10 on a client.

132
00:07:06,555 --> 00:07:12,088
NetBoot runs OS10 from a network location,
doesn't actually install it on the client.

133
00:07:12,088 --> 00:07:12,827
And then,

134
00:07:12,827 --> 00:07:18,280
NetRestore allows us to recover OS10
to a client with customizations, right?

135
00:07:18,280 --> 00:07:21,910
So, those are our three modes, and it's
up to us to pick the ones that we want.

136
00:07:21,910 --> 00:07:23,840
And, you can mix and match them.

137
00:07:23,840 --> 00:07:28,642
When you bring up a NetInstall server,
you create NetInstall images,

138
00:07:28,642 --> 00:07:32,090
and it's the image that
determines the mode.

139
00:07:32,090 --> 00:07:34,720
So, I can have eight different
images on my server.

140
00:07:34,720 --> 00:07:37,140
And one image could be a NetBoot image.

141
00:07:37,140 --> 00:07:39,050
Two images might be NetInstall images,

142
00:07:39,050 --> 00:07:41,630
another three images might
be net restore images.

143
00:07:41,630 --> 00:07:43,110
You can mix and match,
so it's kind of neat.

144
00:07:43,110 --> 00:07:47,410
You've got all that flexibility to be able
to build all that into the system,right?

145
00:07:47,410 --> 00:07:49,550
Now, I said image.

146
00:07:49,550 --> 00:07:50,545
What is an image?

147
00:07:50,545 --> 00:07:53,645
Well, an image is really just
a snapshot of a hard drive.

148
00:07:53,645 --> 00:07:57,392
When you install OS ten to a hard drive
through your machine It copies a bunch of

149
00:07:57,392 --> 00:08:00,693
files to the hard drive, and
there's all that data sitting there.

150
00:08:00,693 --> 00:08:04,036
You guys have navigated around a hard
drive structure, you've seen those files.

151
00:08:04,036 --> 00:08:08,479
When you take an image, that's just
a giant archive file that includes

152
00:08:08,479 --> 00:08:11,560
everything that was on that hard drive.

153
00:08:11,560 --> 00:08:14,490
And we'll see when we make images
a little bit later, that it's really just

154
00:08:14,490 --> 00:08:17,230
a giant snapshot of all the files
that were found inside of that drive.

155
00:08:18,460 --> 00:08:21,440
So the images are kind of
the key piece to this.

156
00:08:21,440 --> 00:08:25,383
In fact it's so important, that we can't
even turn on the NetInstall service until

157
00:08:25,383 --> 00:08:29,047
we've created an image and so that's kind
of where we need to start the show but

158
00:08:29,047 --> 00:08:32,285
let me show you what I mean first
before I jump into creating an image.

159
00:08:32,285 --> 00:08:37,114
I've got my handy dandy server here,
and it's just Running OS/X Yosemite,

160
00:08:37,114 --> 00:08:41,502
I've got my server app fired up, and
right here in my list of services,

161
00:08:41,502 --> 00:08:45,690
if you kind of browse down,
you'll find NetInstall way down here.

162
00:08:45,690 --> 00:08:49,460
Now, NetInstall is under the advanced
services, it's not considered one of

163
00:08:49,460 --> 00:08:52,910
the normal ones, and remember that
the advanced menu is hidden by default.

164
00:08:52,910 --> 00:08:56,720
So you might have to show that to get
a list of the advanced services and

165
00:08:56,720 --> 00:08:58,610
then you will find that
install right down in there.

166
00:09:00,220 --> 00:09:01,190
And there it is.

167
00:09:01,190 --> 00:09:04,460
Now a lot of these services
the configuration is just a matter of

168
00:09:04,460 --> 00:09:05,850
flipping that on switch.

169
00:09:05,850 --> 00:09:08,580
But watch what happens when
I go hit that on switch.

170
00:09:08,580 --> 00:09:10,980
It went right back off again, okay?

171
00:09:10,980 --> 00:09:15,110
What happens is,
you cannot turn on the netinstall service

172
00:09:15,110 --> 00:09:18,200
until you have at least
one image on your server.

173
00:09:18,200 --> 00:09:20,220
So we gotta have an image available.

174
00:09:20,220 --> 00:09:23,560
And if you don't have an image,
well then, it's not gonna turn on.

175
00:09:23,560 --> 00:09:25,740
And if you ever forget
that's what's going on,

176
00:09:25,740 --> 00:09:28,160
you can always go in your server logs and
it shows that.

177
00:09:28,160 --> 00:09:34,580
If I pull up my server logs, I won't have
NetInstall logs, or actually I'm lying.

178
00:09:34,580 --> 00:09:36,308
I guess I will have NetInstall logs.

179
00:09:36,308 --> 00:09:39,400
Sometimes the NetInstall logs won't
show up until you've started the service

180
00:09:39,400 --> 00:09:40,460
at least once.

181
00:09:40,460 --> 00:09:42,520
But it my case it appears I do have one.

182
00:09:42,520 --> 00:09:44,190
But see how it doesn't
have any errors in it?

183
00:09:44,190 --> 00:09:45,480
This doesn't normally show up.

184
00:09:45,480 --> 00:09:48,300
Instead, if you go into your system log,

185
00:09:48,300 --> 00:09:51,040
you'll see where it tried
to turn on the service, and

186
00:09:51,040 --> 00:09:53,530
there will be an error there letting you
know that it didn't have any images.

187
00:09:53,530 --> 00:09:58,410
So if we root through here,
it will show where I tried to start it,

188
00:09:58,410 --> 00:10:02,780
and it didn't have any images, so,

189
00:10:02,780 --> 00:10:05,230
I'm not seeing the error message offhand,
but it'll be in here somewhere.

190

a slash system.

00:11:04,220 --> 00:11:07,340
All right, now when you fire
up the system image utility,

00:11:07,340 --> 00:11:10,210
the first thing it's gonna
do is it's gonna look.

00:11:10,210 --> 00:11:11,780
So that Yosemite installer file.

00:11:12,900 --> 00:11:16,040
When you go into the App Store and

00:11:16,040 --> 00:11:18,760

00:11:23,510 --> 00:11:27,130

00:11:47,850 --> 00:11:51,150

00:11:54,540 --> 00:11:58,220

Or a net restore image?

00:12:02,068 --> 00:12:02,700
Now the NetInstall,

00:12:02,700 --> 00:12:05,910
that's the default because that's

00:12:05,910 --> 00:12:09,370

00:12:09,370 --> 00:12:11,220
It wouldn't be very effective.

00:12:11,220 --> 00:12:14,160
People would turn on their computer, and

00:12:14,160 --> 00:12:16,160
They'd have to go through

00:12:16,160 --> 00:12:18,430
And when it's done, it's gonna reboot.

00:12:18,430 --> 00:12:22,310
And then they start all over again because

00:12:22,310 --> 00:12:24,090
you reboot and

00:12:24,090 --> 00:12:26,500
So that kind of defeats the purpose.

00:12:26,500 --> 00:12:29,300
So we really wouldn't want to make

00:12:29,300 --> 00:12:30,770
We'll talk about NetBoot

00:12:31,950 --> 00:12:33,910

So maybe you've got offices in Orlando,

00:13:35,810 --> 00:13:39,280

00:13:39,280 --> 00:13:42,990
Well, if a computer

00:13:42,990 --> 00:13:46,920
you don't want it to have to reach all the

00:13:46,920 --> 00:13:48,151
That could take a long time.

00:13:48,151 --> 00:13:53,090
So it would be nice to have more than

272
00:13:53,090 --> 00:13:56,870
So maybe I've got one in Paris,

273
00:13:56,870 --> 00:13:59,880
and one in Washington D.C.
here in the U.S.

00:13:59,880 --> 00:14:03,750
and I want computers in those countries

00:14:03,750 --> 00:14:06,920
The reality is the server typically

00:14:06,920 --> 00:14:07,500

00:14:07,500 --> 00:14:09,750
You don't usually want to go over

00:14:10,750 --> 00:14:13,660
But, you do want people

00:14:13,660 --> 00:14:15,440

00:14:15,440 --> 00:14:16,940
These images can be pretty large.

00:14:16,940 --> 00:14:18,810
They can 10, 15 gigs in size.

00:14:18,810 --> 00:14:21,540
It can be even larger if you

00:14:21,540 --> 00:14:23,920
So, if you're downloading that
over an internet connection,

284
00:14:23,920 --> 00:14:25,740
that's gonna take a long time.

285
00:14:25,740 --> 00:14:29,370
But if you're on a gigabit network,
it'll download pretty fast, right?

286
00:14:29,370 --> 00:14:31,709
So, that's how this is
normally intended to be used.

287
00:14:32,770 --> 00:14:37,760
Well, if I have more than one server, then

288
00:14:37,760 --> 00:14:40,350
image will be served from
more than one server.

00:14:40,350 --> 00:14:45,240
And now it knows that this image
might exist in more than one place.

290
00:14:45,240 --> 00:14:50,090
And the way it ties the images together,
is by that index number I mentioned.

291
00:14:50,090 --> 00:14:53,650
And so, when I create this image,
it's gonna have an index number, and

00:14:53,650 --> 00:14:58,550
I can then copy this image to as many

00:14:58,550 --> 00:15:03,010
I just need to make sure that index

00:15:03,010 --> 00:15:07,030
that way it will know, these aren't unique

295
00:15:07,030 --> 00:15:09,600
And that way when a client boots
up it can pick this one image and

296
00:15:09,600 --> 00:15:11,870
it'll just get it from the server

00:15:11,870 --> 00:15:14,480
So, that index number we'll see
that a little bit later, but

00:15:14,480 --> 00:15:17,810
that's what this is saying is basically
whether this image will be present on

299
00:15:17,810 --> 00:15:20,910
more than one NetInstall server,
or just one.

00:15:20,910 --> 00:15:23,680
I've only got one NetInstall server so

Now you do have to accept the licensing

00:15:45,755 --> 00:15:47,791
So what it's doing is it's taking, well,

let me give it my administrator

00:15:50,831 --> 00:15:57,032
It's taking that DMG, that disk image

It's taking it, and

The file that you download from the app

00:16:06,422 --> 00:16:10,218
if we looked at that file where it said,
Install Yosemite, or

Install OS X Yosemite,
it's actually Install OS X Yosemite.app.

00:16:14,454 --> 00:16:15,991
So it's an application folder.

00:16:17,130 --> 00:16:21,320
What it's doing now is, its converting
it into a DMG, into a disk image, and

00:16:21,320 --> 00:16:25,520
it's making it bootable, so that, we'll be
able to boot off of it via the network.

00:16:25,520 --> 00:16:26,507
So it has to convert that.

00:16:26,507 --> 00:16:30,126
It doesn't take terribly long to do, so

And that folder is special.

Notice the folder,

that's the name I gave it, .nbi.

NBI stands for NetBoot Image.

Now I'm doing NetInstall, but it always

00:16:57,390 --> 00:17:02,690

So you need to leave them all together,

00:17:38,415 --> 00:17:41,725
and treat this folder as

Always move everything

00:17:51,925 --> 00:17:54,850
If I go to my server, and

00:17:54,850 --> 00:17:57,690
So I'm gonna go, and take my NetInstall,

00:17:57,690 --> 00:18:00,330

The reason is,

It's got to be in a particular place for

So if I look in /Library,, and I'm just

00:18:43,440 --> 00:18:46,700
So I need to let it know,

00:18:46,700 --> 00:18:48,700
Now, the default is

00:18:48,700 --> 00:18:51,760
but as you can imagine these image files,

00:18:51,760 --> 00:18:54,420
So they can be ten gigs, or however big.

00:18:54,420 --> 00:18:58,110
And actually,
how big was that one that I just made?

00:18:58,110 --> 00:19:00,500
We'll find another, the one I just

00:19:00,500 --> 00:19:05,050
It's really just a straight up
Yosemite Install, nothing too fancy there.

00:19:05,050 --> 00:19:08,940
And it ended up being

372
00:19:08,940 --> 00:19:13,240
So, if you have a bunch of these images,

373
00:19:13,240 --> 00:19:17,390
So it's a good idea to have an extra hard
drive available to store your images on.

374
00:19:17,390 --> 00:19:19,060
And you'll see in my background,

00:19:19,060 --> 00:19:23,840
I actually do have an extra hard drive,

00:19:23,840 --> 00:19:25,610
And so I've got a one
terabyte hard drive attached,

00:19:25,610 --> 00:19:27,840
where I can store my image files,

00:19:28,950 --> 00:19:31,470
Well, you can't just go
throwing the images around.

00:19:31,470 --> 00:19:34,830
You actually have to have them
in a particular folder, and

00:19:34,830 --> 00:19:38,670
when we go to turn on storage,

00:19:38,670 --> 00:19:43,180
Now, right here in my server app, down at

And if I go into Edit Storage Settings,

00:19:51,937 --> 00:19:55,380
Images is the other hard drive,

00:19:55,380 --> 00:19:58,810
If I take Macintosh HD I can

00:19:58,810 --> 00:20:02,370
I can choose what kind of
data I want to store there.

388
00:20:02,370 --> 00:20:04,360
Now, there's two types of data.

389
00:20:04,360 --> 00:20:09,050
Images, which is really what I wanna
store right now for NetInstall.

390
00:20:09,050 --> 00:20:12,140
But if you're going to do NetBoot,
if you're gonna do NetBoot there's

391
00:20:12,140 --> 00:20:14,680
actually a second set of data
that needs to be stored.

392
00:20:14,680 --> 00:20:15,750
When somebody does NetBoot,

393
00:20:15,750 --> 00:20:18,820
they're booting the operating
system from your NetInstall server.

394
00:20:18,820 --> 00:20:21,580
So you'll have an image,
that they're booting up.

395
00:20:21,580 --> 00:20:23,820
But once it gets to running,

396
00:20:23,820 --> 00:20:27,250
they've got to be able to
store temporary session data.

397
00:20:27,250 --> 00:20:29,200
As they launch their applications,

398
00:20:29,200 --> 00:20:32,320
and working with things
temporary data is generated.

399
00:20:32,320 --> 00:20:35,440
Now, the temporary data is gonna
get wiped out, when they reboot.

400
00:20:35,440 --> 00:20:38,140
But the temporary data still
has to exist somewhere.

401
00:20:38,140 --> 00:20:41,750
And it can't all stay in RAM because most
computers don't have enough RAM for that.

402
00:20:41,750 --> 00:20:44,590
So, they need to store data somewhere.

403
00:20:44,590 --> 00:20:47,880
Now the default,
is to store data on the Client.

404
00:20:47,880 --> 00:20:51,850
So if they're on a MacBook,
or a Mac Pro, or whatever,

405
00:20:51,850 --> 00:20:55,290
it's gonna use that internal hard drive
to store their temporary session data.

406
00:20:55,290 --> 00:20:56,540
It'll wipe it out when they reboot,

407
00:20:56,540 --> 00:20:59,040
but it'll store that session data
right there on their own hard drive.

408
00:21:00,300 --> 00:21:01,930
But, what if they're disk-less?

409
00:21:01,930 --> 00:21:03,300
What if they have no hard drive?

410
00:21:03,300 --> 00:21:06,510
If they have no hard drive, then they need
to store their session data somewhere

411
00:21:06,510 --> 00:21:11,670
else, and that's my other option here
is Images only, Client data only,

412
00:21:11,670 --> 00:21:14,240
or both Images, and Client data.

413
00:21:14,240 --> 00:21:17,200
That Client data,

00:42:11,040 --> 00:42:13,510
