00:43:58,718 --> 00:44:02,030
You might wanna add a help desk account,
or something else to this machine, so

862
00:44:02,030 --> 00:44:03,330
that you'll be able to manage it.

863
00:44:03,330 --> 00:44:04,920
You need to have at
least one user account.

864
00:44:06,330 --> 00:44:07,350
So we can punch that in here.

865
00:44:07,350 --> 00:44:08,750
I'll create an account called Help Desk.

866
00:44:09,940 --> 00:44:12,060
And you give it a short name,
and a password,

867
00:44:12,060 --> 00:44:13,600
the things that you need to know.

868
00:44:13,600 --> 00:44:16,220
And then you can specify, whether
you want it to log in automatically,

869
00:44:16,220 --> 00:44:17,730
which is probably a bad idea.

870
00:44:17,730 --> 00:44:20,990
Or allow the user to be an administrator,
which is a good idea in this case.

871
00:44:22,440 --> 00:44:26,160
And then Create Image, so
what kind of image are you making, and

872
00:44:26,160 --> 00:44:28,390
where is it going to be stored.

873
00:44:28,390 --> 00:44:30,840
So it knows that I wanna do a NetRestore.

874
00:44:30,840 --> 00:44:32,450
It's gonna include a recovery partition,
and

875
00:44:32,450 --> 00:44:34,650
that's useful cuz sometimes
you deploy images, and

876
00:44:34,650 --> 00:44:37,250
they don't have a recovery partition,
and you have to use Internet recovery.

877
00:44:38,450 --> 00:44:40,952
You can pick which volume,
you want it to install.

878
00:44:40,952 --> 00:44:43,350
And it'll just default to
NetInstall in this case, and

879
00:44:43,350 --> 00:44:44,470
where you want it to save to.

880
00:44:44,470 --> 00:44:48,642
Now this little dropdown box, which
mine doesn't seem to want to dropdown,

881
00:44:48,642 --> 00:44:50,837
it can be a little confusing sometimes.

882
00:44:50,837 --> 00:44:53,774
Because if both of your folder
have been called NetBoot SP0,

883
00:44:53,774 --> 00:44:56,264
you don't know which one to pick,
it's all right.

884
00:44:56,264 --> 00:44:59,110
You can always move the image afterwards,
it's not a big deal.

885
00:45:00,150 --> 00:45:04,796
And then it just has the name, and
the index number like we've seen before.

886
00:45:04,796 --> 00:45:07,920
Now, if I fill this out, and
I hit Run at the bottom,

887
00:45:07,920 --> 00:45:10,269
it's still not a truly generic image.

888
00:45:10,269 --> 00:45:13,689
There's a few other things that
we probably wanna tweak in here,

889
00:45:13,689 --> 00:45:17,030
just to make sure that everything is nice,
and smooth.

890
00:45:17,030 --> 00:45:19,780
So one of the things is gonna be
that computer name, and as you look

891
00:45:19,780 --> 00:45:23,200
across the left side here, you'll see a
number of different things you can tweak.

892
00:45:23,200 --> 00:45:27,810
I like to jump over to most used, because
on most used, that's where it's gonna have

893
00:45:27,810 --> 00:45:32,517
all the individual items that we typically
need to make the system generic.

894
00:45:32,517 --> 00:45:34,710
So some of the key things
that I'm looking for here,

895
00:45:34,710 --> 00:45:38,690
are things like renaming the computer,
binding to an Open Directory.

896
00:45:38,690 --> 00:45:41,320
These are things that we need to make
the system a little more unique,

897
00:45:41,320 --> 00:45:43,820
and make sure that we're not
butting heads with other computers.

898
00:45:43,820 --> 00:45:48,800
So right here under most used, we can
see Create Image, Define Image Source,

899
00:45:48,800 --> 00:45:49,800
Define User Account.

900
00:45:49,800 --> 00:45:52,210
Those are the ones that
were already in the list.

901
00:45:52,210 --> 00:45:53,747
Those are the key ones.

902
00:45:53,747 --> 00:45:58,134
But if we go back under our Library,
you can see other things in here,

903
00:45:58,134 --> 00:46:00,416
like Add Configuration Profiles.

904
00:46:00,416 --> 00:46:03,462
Now, Add Configuration Profiles,
that would be great if we were using

905
00:46:03,462 --> 00:46:06,770
Profile Manager, and we had profiles
that we wanted to send in there.

906
00:46:06,770 --> 00:46:12,270
You'll see a few other ones in here,
like Apply System Configuration Settings.

907
00:46:12,270 --> 00:46:14,770
That's a good one because that's
the one that has the Open Directory.

908
00:46:14,770 --> 00:46:19,097
And notice, as you look down the list,
you won't really see any in here that say,

909
00:46:19,097 --> 00:46:20,600
like Open Directory.

910
00:46:20,600 --> 00:46:23,080
So that's one that I'm gonna
need to grab to throw in there.

911
00:46:23,080 --> 00:46:26,910
So I'll just grab that one,
and add it to my list.

912
00:46:26,910 --> 00:46:29,572
And you can edit,
pretty much anywhere here in the list.

913
00:46:29,572 --> 00:46:33,001
It does need to be above the Create Image,
so

914
00:46:33,001 --> 00:46:37,834
that last little workflow item
needs to be that Create Image.

915
00:46:37,834 --> 00:46:41,087
But up above, we can stick to
the Apply System Configuration Settings,

916
00:46:41,087 --> 00:46:43,340
in there pretty much wherever we want.

917
00:46:43,340 --> 00:46:47,970
So, I've got it in here, and you'll see,
Connect computer to a directory server.

918
00:46:47,970 --> 00:46:51,850
So I could come in, and I could
configure a directory server to bind to,

919
00:46:51,850 --> 00:46:57,780
if I've got, well, it's showing 127.00.1
cuz I'm on a directory server right now.

920
00:46:57,780 --> 00:47:01,300
So it sees itself, and
so we can punch that in.

921
00:47:01,300 --> 00:47:05,390
Apply computer name, and
local host name setting from a file.

922
00:47:05,390 --> 00:47:09,560
You can have a CSV file that lists
a bunch of computer names, and

923
00:47:09,560 --> 00:47:13,410
it can pull from those as it deploys it
out to have a unique names for each one.

924
00:47:13,410 --> 00:47:16,142
Or easier,
you can generate unique nicknames.

925
00:47:16,142 --> 00:47:19,690
And it'll say generate a unique
name starting with, and so

926
00:47:19,690 --> 00:47:23,400
I might call out like
itproworkstation- like that, and

927
00:47:23,400 --> 00:47:27,302
then look at the little sample over here,
the example.

928
00:47:27,302 --> 00:47:31,570
It's gonna stick a random string of
letters, and numbers at the end.

929
00:47:31,570 --> 00:47:34,580
So now I can deploy this work station,
and everyone will have a unique name.

930
00:47:34,580 --> 00:47:37,870
They're not the most friendly of names,
but at least they've got something.

931
00:47:39,240 --> 00:47:43,300
So a few options there,
we can tweak those, and adjust them,

932
00:47:43,300 --> 00:47:46,450
set them however we need,
and then save that in there.

933
00:47:46,450 --> 00:47:47,940
You'll see other things that are in here.

934
00:47:47,940 --> 00:47:51,385
Things like Creating an Image, which is
already in here for what we're doing.

935
00:47:51,385 --> 00:47:54,540
Multi-Volume NetRestore,
just some advanced stuff in here.

936
00:47:54,540 --> 00:47:58,837
You can filter clients by MAC address,
so you can restrict who this can go to.

937
00:47:58,837 --> 00:48:01,763
We've seen that in the server app itself.

938
00:48:01,763 --> 00:48:02,599
All right.

939
00:48:02,599 --> 00:48:04,097
And there's even advanced
disk partitioning.

940
00:48:04,097 --> 00:48:07,960
If you wanna partition out the disk and
set aside a partition, you can do that.

941
00:48:07,960 --> 00:48:09,420
So basically whatever you want to do.

942
00:48:09,420 --> 00:48:11,170
You're customizing that deployment.

943
00:48:11,170 --> 00:48:14,600
But at a minimum, change in the computer
name, binding to a directory,

944
00:48:14,600 --> 00:48:18,280
these are things that are pretty useful
to get this image the way we want.

945
00:48:18,280 --> 00:48:22,510
And then when you hit run,
it's gonna woops, I clicked it twice.

946
00:48:22,510 --> 00:48:24,650
If you click it twice,
you hit stop by accident.

947
00:48:24,650 --> 00:48:27,080
So I'm gonna hit run, and
it's gonna go and try and build it.

948
00:48:27,080 --> 00:48:31,250
Now, mine's gonna fail, because I'm
pointing at that installation image,

949
00:48:31,250 --> 00:48:33,320
that Yosemite installer.

950
00:48:33,320 --> 00:48:36,010
You really do need to have
a machine that's in target mode.

951
00:48:36,010 --> 00:48:37,230
And the main reason is,

952
00:48:37,230 --> 00:48:39,660
there's some little issues with
how the partitions are set up.

953
00:48:39,660 --> 00:48:41,210
It's expecting one thing, and

954
00:48:41,210 --> 00:48:43,990
the installation image,
it contains something else.

955
00:48:43,990 --> 00:48:47,400
But that'll build up that
installation image for us.

956
00:48:47,400 --> 00:48:52,358
And once it's built it in place,
now, it goes into our

957
00:48:52,358 --> 00:48:57,630
net sp folder, our folder where we've got
all of our net boot installation images.

958
00:48:57,630 --> 00:48:59,350
And it becomes available to clients.

959
00:48:59,350 --> 00:49:01,880
And when they boot up,
they can pick that image, and

960
00:49:01,880 --> 00:49:03,880
it'll deploy it right
down to their machine.

961
00:49:03,880 --> 00:49:06,390
Or if it's a net boot, it'll actually
run from the network, right?

962
00:49:06,390 --> 00:49:10,840
It all comes down to whether you
chose NetBoot or NetInstall, right?

963
00:49:10,840 --> 00:49:13,160
So that's gonna be that
big difference there.

964
00:49:13,160 --> 00:49:15,910
I'm sorry, NetBoot or
NetRestore is gonna be the big difference.

965
00:49:15,910 --> 00:49:18,760
So the functionality there is pretty neat.

966
00:49:18,760 --> 00:49:21,270
Again, I think you guys can see where
this really wouldn't be useful for

967
00:49:21,270 --> 00:49:24,150
a small business, or somebody at home.

968
00:49:24,150 --> 00:49:28,080
But in an enterprise, where you've got
thousands of machines that are out there,

969
00:49:28,080 --> 00:49:30,910
it's nice to have a good consistent
image across those machines that

970
00:49:30,910 --> 00:49:33,070
are all configured the same way.

971
00:49:33,070 --> 00:49:36,030
And if something goes wrong on a machine,
just redeploy the image.

972
00:49:36,030 --> 00:49:38,820
You boot it up while holding down the N
key and you just redeploy the image.

973
00:49:38,820 --> 00:49:40,950
The machine is reset, and off you go.

974
00:49:40,950 --> 00:49:43,640
You really can minimize
the amount of support.

975
00:49:43,640 --> 00:49:48,580
A couple of things to remember
especially if you're doing the NetBoot.

976
00:49:48,580 --> 00:49:52,790
With NetBoot, you're running your
operating system from the network and so

977
00:49:52,790 --> 00:49:54,310
none of your changes are saved.

978
00:49:54,310 --> 00:49:56,570
If you reboot that machine
everything goes away.

979
00:49:56,570 --> 00:49:59,750
So it's really important
that your users know

980
00:49:59,750 --> 00:50:04,050
not to save data on their boot volume
because their boot volume gets wiped out.

981
00:50:04,050 --> 00:50:07,320
The way it works is with
the use of a shadow file.

982
00:50:07,320 --> 00:50:10,110
When you do NetBoot,
there's an image on the server, and

983
00:50:10,110 --> 00:50:11,680
that's what you're running.

984
00:50:11,680 --> 00:50:15,670
But you make changes, and those changes,
that's called your state, your user state.

985
00:50:15,670 --> 00:50:18,750
So your temporary files that are created
when you browse the Internet, or

986
00:50:18,750 --> 00:50:19,960
just your session data.

987
00:50:19,960 --> 00:50:23,910
All of that's stored in state, and
that state is stored in a shadow file.

988
00:50:23,910 --> 00:50:27,780
By default that shadow file was stored
on the local hard drive of the client

989
00:50:27,780 --> 00:50:29,160
if they have a hard drive.

990
00:50:29,160 --> 00:50:30,570
If you choose the disk-less option though,

991
00:50:30,570 --> 00:50:34,900
then it saves it to the server in
the client's folder we saw earlier.

992
00:50:34,900 --> 00:50:38,480
And that's wiped out
every time they reboot.

993
00:50:38,480 --> 00:50:42,340
So when they boot up on NetBoot, and
they save something to Macintosh HD,

994
00:50:42,340 --> 00:50:46,025
to the regular hard drive, it's going into
that state folder, into that shadow file.

995
00:50:46,025 --> 00:50:48,730
And when they reboot,
it gets wiped out and they lose it.

996
00:50:48,730 --> 00:50:52,040
So it's really important,
doubly important if you're doing NetBoot,

997
00:50:52,040 --> 00:50:54,500
they need to have
a network home directory.

998
00:50:54,500 --> 00:50:58,240
If you remember from the directory
services episode, when you create a user

999
00:50:58,240 --> 00:51:02,930
account in the open directory, you can
specify a network home directory for them.

1000
00:51:02,930 --> 00:51:04,470
They need to save their data there.

1001
00:51:04,470 --> 00:51:07,960
Or at least have a file share somewhere,
and use Apple file protocol, and

1002
00:51:07,960 --> 00:51:09,690
they can connect and
save their data there.

1003
00:51:09,690 --> 00:51:12,480
But they need to save their data to
a network, because when they reboot,

1004
00:51:12,480 --> 00:51:15,060
everything on their individual
machine will be wiped out.

1005
00:51:15,060 --> 00:51:18,140
So be aware of that,
definitely get some angry

1006
00:51:18,140 --> 00:51:21,330
end users if they aren't trained
properly to handle that.

1007
00:51:21,330 --> 00:51:25,480
But otherwise, as far as use in a lab or
whatever, it really is a great thing,

1008
00:51:25,480 --> 00:51:26,210
it works out really well.

1009
00:51:28,100 --> 00:51:32,390
All right, well that's about all I've got
on NetInstall and NetBoot, and NetRestore

1010
00:51:32,390 --> 00:51:36,330
for that matter, so we'll probably
go ahead and wrap it up right here.

1011
00:51:36,330 --> 00:51:39,400
Let me remind you guys,
if you have questions on any of this,

1012
00:51:39,400 --> 00:51:43,590
because it is a pretty neat thing to mess
around with, definitely feel free to ask.

1013
00:51:43,590 --> 00:51:46,770
Live during the show you're always
welcome to go to itpro.tv/live and

1014
00:51:46,770 --> 00:51:48,920
you'll see the chatroom beneath the video.

1015
00:51:48,920 --> 00:51:49,840
Post your questions there.

1016
00:51:49,840 --> 00:51:52,110
We monitor and answer during the show.

1017
00:51:52,110 --> 00:51:53,770
But if you have questions after the show,

1018
00:51:53,770 --> 00:51:56,390
like if you're watching this recorded,
you're not out of luck.

1019
00:51:56,390 --> 00:51:57,620
You can still ask us.

1020
00:51:57,620 --> 00:51:59,280
Make use of our Q and A forums.

1021
00:51:59,280 --> 00:52:02,735
At the top of every page on the ITProTV
site, you'll see a link that says Q&A.

1022
00:52:02,735 --> 00:52:04,325
Click on it.

1023
00:52:04,325 --> 00:52:05,305
It'll take you to the forums.

1024
00:52:05,305 --> 00:52:06,855
You can post your questions there.

1025
00:52:06,855 --> 00:52:08,565
We monitor and answer after the show.

1026
00:52:08,565 --> 00:52:10,125
Take advantage of that resource.

1027
00:52:10,125 --> 00:52:11,295
It is there for you.

1028
00:52:11,295 --> 00:52:14,185
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

1029
00:52:14,185 --> 00:52:18,051
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2

[SOUND]

3
00:00:23,786 --> 00:00:33,445
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,445 --> 00:00:36,371
All right good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

5
00:00:36,371 --> 00:00:39,745
welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host Don Pezet,

6
00:00:39,745 --> 00:00:43,910
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

7
00:00:43,910 --> 00:00:47,570
Today we're gonna be jumping into
Time Machine which is a lot of fun.

8
00:00:47,570 --> 00:00:51,140
Let me clarify, this isn't just your
regular old Time Machine running on a work

9
00:00:51,140 --> 00:00:52,180
station or laptop.

10
00:00:52,180 --> 00:00:56,170
We're talking about the Time Machine
service inside of the server app.

11
00:00:56,170 --> 00:00:59,773
Now, you might ask yourself, why do
we need a Time Machine service in our

12
00:00:59,773 --> 00:01:03,516
server app when Time Machine just works
right here on my laptop or desktop?

13
00:01:03,516 --> 00:01:05,530
Do I really need something on the server?

14
00:01:05,530 --> 00:01:08,580
And the reason we have it
is kind of a neat one.

15
00:01:08,580 --> 00:01:10,350
It's not a problem everybody has.

16
00:01:10,350 --> 00:01:13,540
If you're a small business or whatever,
this might not pertain to you.

17
00:01:13,540 --> 00:01:14,480
You might not care.

18
00:01:14,480 --> 00:01:16,820
But if you're a larger organization,

19
00:01:16,820 --> 00:01:20,240
there's a real need to
have centralized backups.

20
00:01:20,240 --> 00:01:20,740
All right.

21
00:01:20,740 --> 00:01:23,580
Let me explain the problem that we
have with traditional Time Machine.

22
00:01:23,580 --> 00:01:26,480
So I've got a work station here
that is set up with Time Machine.

23
00:01:26,480 --> 00:01:28,010
Let's take a look at it real quick.

24
00:01:28,010 --> 00:01:32,550
So this is just a regular, Yosemite
laptop, it's got Time Machine set up.

25
00:01:32,550 --> 00:01:35,910
I've got it added on my
little menu bar up here.

26
00:01:35,910 --> 00:01:39,170
But even if I didn't, you can jump
into your system preferences and

27
00:01:39,170 --> 00:01:40,690
jump into Time Machine.

28
00:01:40,690 --> 00:01:45,580
And when we set up a Time Machine
back up on an individual machine,

29
00:01:45,580 --> 00:01:51,400
the expectation is that we have either
a second hard drive in the same machine.

30
00:01:51,400 --> 00:01:55,730
Or a removable hard drive of some sort
that we are plugging in to the desktop or

31
00:01:55,730 --> 00:01:57,290
laptop to backup.

32
00:01:57,290 --> 00:02:00,700
Now, that removable drive
poses a few little problems.

33
00:02:00,700 --> 00:02:01,240
All right.

34
00:02:01,240 --> 00:02:03,950
The big problem is what happens
if you lose that drive?

35
00:02:03,950 --> 00:02:06,810
If you lose that drive,
it has all of your data on it and so,

36
00:02:06,810 --> 00:02:10,030
somebody could take that drive and
now they have access to your information.

37
00:02:10,030 --> 00:02:13,780
Well fortunately time machine can encrypt
your backup, so that solves that problem.

38
00:02:13,780 --> 00:02:15,420
You lose the hard drive,
somebody gets it but

39
00:02:15,420 --> 00:02:18,550
it's encrypted,
no big sweat there, All right.

40
00:02:18,550 --> 00:02:22,540
But the bigger problem in my opinion, is
that if you have a removable hard drive,

41
00:02:22,540 --> 00:02:25,640
in order for the backup to work,
you gotta plug it in.

42
00:02:25,640 --> 00:02:29,810
And, while it sounds simple,
your N-users forget to do that.

43
00:02:29,810 --> 00:02:30,860
I forget to do that.

44
00:02:30,860 --> 00:02:34,260
I have for my laptop right
here that I use for this show,

45
00:02:34,260 --> 00:02:37,870
I have a removable drive that I stick on
it that I do Time Machine backups to.

46
00:02:37,870 --> 00:02:42,595
And when I first got it, I was pretty good
about hooking it up maybe one once a week.

47
00:02:42,595 --> 00:02:45,525
Then I had a period of time where
I went two or three weeks and

48
00:02:45,525 --> 00:02:48,015
I never hooked it up and I kind of forgot.

49
00:02:48,015 --> 00:02:48,595
And that's a risk.

50
00:02:48,595 --> 00:02:51,205
If my drive had failed I
could have lost some data.

51
00:02:51,205 --> 00:02:53,825
So I ended up switching to
something like a docking station so

52
00:02:53,825 --> 00:02:57,600
that it would always plug-in when I put
my laptop in, that's how I remember.

53
00:02:57,600 --> 00:02:59,440
Well, I'm one person.

54
00:02:59,440 --> 00:03:01,369

00:03:01,369 --> 00:03:05,640
That's a thousand removable hard

00:03:05,640 --> 00:03:08,890
How do you know that users are plugging
these guys in, in the first place?

00:03:08,890 --> 00:03:11,000
The answer is a lot of times you don't.

58
00:03:11,000 --> 00:03:13,020
And even if they are,

59
00:03:13,020 --> 00:03:16,500
how do you know as an administrator

60
00:03:16,500 --> 00:03:19,280
How do I know if that person
hasn't backed up in a week versus

61
00:03:19,280 --> 00:03:22,035
another person who's backed
up just an hour ago.

62
00:03:22,035 --> 00:03:23,360
Right.
You don't have a good way to tell,

00:03:23,360 --> 00:03:25,480
because Time Machine is
managed individually for

00:03:25,480 --> 00:03:27,250

65
00:03:27,250 --> 00:03:32,010
So in the server app we have
the function to create a centralized

00:03:32,010 --> 00:03:36,080

00:03:36,080 --> 00:03:39,640
And it's not a drive that they have to

68
00:03:39,640 --> 00:03:42,810
So if they're on a laptop, when they

00:03:42,810 --> 00:03:46,300

00:03:46,300 --> 00:03:50,440

00:03:50,440 --> 00:03:53,240

the next time they come back it will.

72
00:03:53,240 --> 00:03:55,910
If they're on a desktop one

73
00:03:55,910 --> 00:03:59,800
Then it's reliably backing up every

74
00:03:59,800 --> 00:04:02,540
you got a nice centralized
repository of back ups.

75
00:04:02,540 --> 00:04:05,780
And that's a great thing to have

76
00:04:05,780 --> 00:04:09,700
because it does insulate you from users
forgetting to plug in their drive.

77
00:04:09,700 --> 00:04:11,240
Users losing their drive.

78
00:04:11,240 --> 00:04:13,570
It's all right here in

79
00:04:13,570 --> 00:04:14,560
Now, when this first came out,

00:04:14,560 --> 00:04:18,830

00:04:18,830 --> 00:04:20,560
Right.

00:04:20,560 --> 00:04:22,260

00:04:25,770 --> 00:04:27,340
with some hard drives in it.

00:04:27,340 --> 00:04:30,870
And the time capsule serves

00:04:30,870 --> 00:04:33,530
And it was really successful,
it worked great if you,

00:04:33,530 --> 00:04:36,590
you wanted to use one at home,

00:04:36,590 --> 00:04:38,660
They are Apple only which

00:04:38,660 --> 00:04:41,470

00:04:41,470 --> 00:04:45,780
So, for homes where all MAC environments,

00:04:45,780 --> 00:04:48,480
But if you've got a thousand laptops

00:04:48,480 --> 00:04:51,350

00:04:51,350 --> 00:04:55,900
So if you set up a server, a machine

00:04:55,900 --> 00:05:00,430

00:05:00,430 --> 00:05:04,350

00:05:04,350 --> 00:05:05,840

97
00:05:05,840 --> 00:05:10,040
Now, you might be thinking to yourself

00:05:10,040 --> 00:05:14,190

00:05:14,190 --> 00:05:16,340
Over the network it's gonna be slow.

00:05:16,340 --> 00:05:17,970
Right, maybe we have a gigabit network.

00:05:17,970 --> 00:05:20,330
Maybe we're on wireless and

00:05:20,330 --> 00:05:24,250
It could take forever to backup

00:05:24,250 --> 00:05:28,750

00:05:28,750 --> 00:05:30,540
Remember how Time Machine works.

00:05:30,540 --> 00:05:34,180
The very first Time Machine backup

106
00:05:34,180 --> 00:05:38,320
and it will take a while, not so

00:05:38,320 --> 00:05:40,850
a USB 3 drive, but

108
00:05:41,870 --> 00:05:45,670
But after that,
Time Machine runs once an hour.

00:05:45,670 --> 00:05:49,140
And every hour it just

00:05:49,140 --> 00:05:51,120
How many changes do your

00:05:51,120 --> 00:05:53,320
Not usually that much.

00:05:53,320 --> 00:05:57,620
And so that really cuts down on the amount

00:05:57,620 --> 00:06:01,290
backups and it makes it where backing

114
00:06:01,290 --> 00:06:03,800
So as long as we set it up early

00:06:03,800 --> 00:06:06,670

00:06:06,670 --> 00:06:08,790
that first backup happens, it's long.

00:06:08,790 --> 00:06:11,330

00:06:13,790 --> 00:06:16,399
It really does work out pretty well.

00:06:16,399 --> 00:06:20,224
All right, the other thing to remember,

00:06:22,060 --> 00:06:23,410
It's not like you have to make a choice.

00:06:23,410 --> 00:06:27,411
Do I back up to a removable drive,

00:06:27,411 --> 00:06:29,780
It's really an and, you can do both.

00:06:29,780 --> 00:06:31,880
I can backup to the removable drive and

00:06:31,880 --> 00:06:34,210

00:06:34,210 --> 00:06:37,400
The way Time Machine works,

00:06:37,400 --> 00:06:39,850
whatever backup media is available.

00:06:39,850 --> 00:06:43,120
And if there's more than one available,

00:06:43,120 --> 00:06:47,000
And that's really nice because the users
can still use the removable drives they're

131
00:06:47,000 --> 00:06:48,410
used to if they want.

00:06:48,410 --> 00:06:52,140
But you got that safety net of

00:06:52,140 --> 00:06:54,030
That way if their laptop bag gets stolen,

00:06:54,030 --> 00:06:58,030

00:06:58,030 --> 00:07:00,710

their back up drive.

00:07:00,710 --> 00:07:02,130
So how do we restore the data?

Well, it's on the server.

00:07:03,420 --> 00:07:05,250
I've got that backup,

00:07:05,250 --> 00:07:07,569
It's kind of nice to have that safety net.

00:07:07,569 --> 00:07:09,790

But you'll see other options in here

As the end user I still want to

00:09:40,670 --> 00:09:43,570

00:09:43,570 --> 00:09:46,720

Time Machine is saying if the USB

00:10:19,355 --> 00:10:22,255

00:10:22,255 --> 00:10:26,205

00:10:26,205 --> 00:10:28,275

00:10:32,195 --> 00:10:36,900
See how in that mobile back ups folder,

00:10:38,240 --> 00:10:42,070
Well, here inside of my

00:10:46,850 --> 00:10:50,220

00:10:50,220 --> 00:10:54,080

00:11:03,190 --> 00:11:06,020

00:11:06,020 --> 00:11:08,730

00:11:08,730 --> 00:11:10,140

00:11:10,140 --> 00:11:12,701

00:11:12,701 --> 00:11:17,390

00:11:17,390 --> 00:11:21,300

00:11:21,300 --> 00:11:24,180

00:11:24,180 --> 00:11:25,930
But this one we can turn on and

00:11:25,930 --> 00:11:29,020

00:11:29,020 --> 00:11:31,470

00:11:31,470 --> 00:11:33,670
They have to store their

00:11:33,670 --> 00:11:35,540

If I go up to my server and

00:11:39,390 --> 00:11:42,130

00:11:45,420 --> 00:11:48,640
The Time Machine service, it'll actually

00:11:48,640 --> 00:11:52,000
the backups themselves,

00:11:52,000 --> 00:11:53,930
hey, these backups can be big.

00:11:57,010 --> 00:11:59,700

00:12:06,760 --> 00:12:08,010

00:12:09,430 --> 00:12:11,830
So if I were to turn it on right

00:12:11,830 --> 00:12:13,850

00:12:13,850 --> 00:12:17,090

00:12:40,380 --> 00:12:43,950
And so, you may need to add more

00:12:43,950 --> 00:12:46,310

00:24:28,420 --> 00:24:31,940
we don't necessarily know who has access
to it, you wanna encrypt the backups.

505
00:24:31,940 --> 00:24:34,570
And that way they won't even
be able to mount this drive,

506
00:24:34,570 --> 00:24:36,900
without having the encryption key.

507
00:24:36,900 --> 00:24:38,663
You can still mount it
if you have the key, and

508
00:24:38,663 --> 00:24:41,743
then you can open up browsers inside of
it, but without the key It's useless.

509
00:24:44,762 --> 00:24:47,810
So once that's done,
what do we do for maintenance?

510
00:24:47,810 --> 00:24:50,510
Well, there's not really much
you have to do to maintain it.

511
00:24:50,510 --> 00:24:53,700
The key thing is to make sure
your users are getting backed up.

512
00:24:53,700 --> 00:24:56,390
They'll only backup when they're
on the same network as the server,

513
00:24:56,390 --> 00:24:57,370
and they see you.

514
00:24:57,370 --> 00:24:59,320
Otherwise they can't backup to the server.

515
00:24:59,320 --> 00:25:01,480
So, you wanna come in and
check this from time-to-time.

516
00:25:01,480 --> 00:25:05,380
Sort by latest backup, and just look for
people that have gone too long.

517
00:25:05,380 --> 00:25:08,930
If they're on the network,
you should see time less than an hour.

518
00:25:08,930 --> 00:25:11,000
Because Time Machine runs every hour.

519
00:25:11,000 --> 00:25:13,570
But, if they travel, if they're out
of the office, it could be days or

520
00:25:13,570 --> 00:25:14,630
it could be weeks.

521
00:25:14,630 --> 00:25:17,260
But the longer that interval is,

522
00:25:17,260 --> 00:25:21,320
the more data you're gonna lose if that
laptop gets damaged, the hard drive fails,

523
00:25:21,320 --> 00:25:24,420
device gets destroyed whatever
that's the amount of data you lose.

524
00:25:24,420 --> 00:25:27,910
If I've got a back up two weeks ago,
well, if I have a failure today,

525
00:25:27,910 --> 00:25:29,250
I just lost two weeks of data.

526
00:25:29,250 --> 00:25:32,840
That's bad so,
we can come in and check that.

527
00:25:32,840 --> 00:25:36,050
On the logging side, there's not
really much to log for Time Machine.

528
00:25:36,050 --> 00:25:39,140
Because Time Machine,
isn't truly a service in and of itself.

529
00:25:39,140 --> 00:25:40,630
It's really just a shared folder.

530
00:25:40,630 --> 00:25:43,700
It's a shared folder that is advertised
a little differently than the other ones.

531
00:25:43,700 --> 00:25:47,480
So, if you go up to logs, and
you pull up your system logs.

532
00:25:48,610 --> 00:25:50,850
A lot of services will look in here,
and they will have their own entry, but

533
00:25:50,850 --> 00:25:52,530
notice that Time Machine doesn't.

534
00:25:52,530 --> 00:25:53,860
They don't have their own entry.

535
00:25:53,860 --> 00:25:56,120
And that's because it's
really just AFP file access.

536
00:25:56,120 --> 00:25:59,285
So, I can come up here to file sharing and
I can go to the access.

537
00:25:59,285 --> 00:26:00,385
Log or the Error Log.

538
00:26:00,385 --> 00:26:02,495
And we'll see entries in here.

539
00:26:02,495 --> 00:26:04,855
And notice all these
10.211.55.201 connections.

540
00:26:04,855 --> 00:26:08,675
That's the laptop that I just backed up.

541
00:26:08,675 --> 00:26:13,285
And I can see here it's doing CreateFile,
and OpenFork commands.

542
00:26:13,285 --> 00:26:15,975
CreateFile means it copied
something up to the server.

543
00:26:15,975 --> 00:26:19,405
And CreateFork, that means it
turned on the File Versioning.

544
00:26:19,405 --> 00:26:22,185
Time Machine uses file versioning
to track changes to the file,

545
00:26:22,185 --> 00:26:23,680
to allow us to restore back.

546
00:26:23,680 --> 00:26:27,280
That's why the Time Machine hard drives
have to be formatted with that MAC OS

547
00:26:27,280 --> 00:26:31,190
extended journal, that's what allows us to
do forking, which Time Machine requires.

548
00:26:31,190 --> 00:26:34,010
So, I can see that's all going on,
and these aren't errors,

549
00:26:34,010 --> 00:26:37,210
these are logs, it's just letting me
know that it was doing a backup, and

550
00:26:37,210 --> 00:26:38,990
I should see a ton of entries in here,

551
00:26:38,990 --> 00:26:43,000
which I'm as I scroll back, because
it backed up that whole hard drive.

552
00:26:43,000 --> 00:26:46,940
But in the future, when the backup runs,
it's only gonna backup the changes.

553
00:26:46,940 --> 00:26:51,130
So, it'll be a much smaller amount of data
that's being written to the system and

554
00:26:51,130 --> 00:26:52,990
it'll happen a lot more quickly.

555
00:26:52,990 --> 00:26:55,580
The backup that,
I ran over here took about ten minutes.

556
00:26:55,580 --> 00:26:58,350
That was because I had to
backup the whole hard drive.

557
00:26:58,350 --> 00:27:02,090
But if I tell it to backup now,
it's gonna run a backup.

558
00:27:03,380 --> 00:27:05,740
And if I jump in here,
I can see the backup preferences.

559
00:27:05,740 --> 00:27:08,660
And instead of having to back
up the whole 10 gig hard drive,

560
00:27:08,660 --> 00:27:11,070
it only has to back up the changes.

561
00:27:11,070 --> 00:27:15,420
And I've been up here talking this whole
time, so there haven't been any changes.

562
00:27:15,420 --> 00:27:20,110
So, I just ran a back up, and see how
it already says, backup at 10:33 AM.

563
00:27:20,110 --> 00:27:21,890
It just did that backup local.

564
00:27:21,890 --> 00:27:25,890
And it's gonna back up to the network
next, it will be very quick and fast.

565
00:27:25,890 --> 00:27:29,730
So, you'll just get that rapid entry onto
the server, the changes are logged in and

566
00:27:29,730 --> 00:27:31,180
that's the end of it.

567
00:27:31,180 --> 00:27:35,450
Then again, the cool part is these backups
are stored right here, on the server now.

568
00:27:35,450 --> 00:27:38,170
If that laptop gets completely lost,
it's gone,

569
00:27:38,170 --> 00:27:41,260
and they lost their backup
hard drive with it.

570
00:27:41,260 --> 00:27:43,220
I've got the backup right
here on the server.

571
00:27:43,220 --> 00:27:45,280
We can come and retrieve that and
we can use that to restore.

572
00:27:46,400 --> 00:27:48,610
When it comes time to restore well,

573
00:27:48,610 --> 00:27:51,010
you can actually restore
from the network location.

574
00:27:51,010 --> 00:27:52,330
You get a brand new MAC.

575
00:27:52,330 --> 00:27:54,130
I'm assuming you lost yours.

576
00:27:54,130 --> 00:27:57,160
It might be a replaced hard drive, or
whatever, but you boot your MAC up and

577
00:27:57,160 --> 00:27:58,540
you boot it into recovery.

578
00:27:58,540 --> 00:28:00,710
And when you go into recovery, or
you can do it from recovery or

579
00:28:00,710 --> 00:28:05,160
you can do it from the installation media,
if you've got a USB install media.

580
00:28:05,160 --> 00:28:08,290
You might have to do that if you
have a blank hard drive or whatever.

581
00:28:08,290 --> 00:28:10,810
But once you get into recovery
you can choose to restore from

582
00:28:10,810 --> 00:28:11,530
a Time Machine backup.

583
00:28:11,530 --> 00:28:14,430
And when you go to restore
from the Time Machine backup,

584
00:28:14,430 --> 00:28:17,790
you can pick from a local drive if
you still have it or the server.

585
00:28:17,790 --> 00:28:20,390
It will see the server and
you can restore the backup,

586
00:28:20,390 --> 00:28:23,150
right from there to an all new machine and
your back up in business.

587
00:28:23,150 --> 00:28:25,780
It's a great system and
it gives those centralized backups.

588
00:28:28,080 --> 00:28:33,300
Well that's about it, the only other thing
that I even have to mention here is that.

589
00:28:33,300 --> 00:28:37,510
If somebody's consuming too much space or
you wanna change the restrictions on

590
00:28:37,510 --> 00:28:40,640
people, you might wanna go and
purge back ups out of the system.

591
00:28:40,640 --> 00:28:43,920
And you can, when you see that list
of backups here, you can choose one.

592
00:28:43,920 --> 00:28:46,710
And you got the little minus button
down there, so you can delete them out.

593
00:28:46,710 --> 00:28:48,520
You can remove the backup from the system.

594
00:28:48,520 --> 00:28:52,560
And you've got your pencil icon,
where you can normally pencils to edit.

595
00:28:52,560 --> 00:28:56,160
Here it just shows you the details,
so I can see information about it.

596
00:28:56,160 --> 00:28:59,490
But, we can go in here and hit that Minus,
and it will let us delete that backup.

597
00:28:59,490 --> 00:29:01,770
And it deletes it from
the server freeing up space.

598
00:29:01,770 --> 00:29:02,520
The backup's gone.

599
00:29:02,520 --> 00:29:05,530
You can't recover it and that's it.

600
00:29:05,530 --> 00:29:09,450
Now, that workstation is still
set up to backup to the server.

601
00:29:09,450 --> 00:29:11,950
So, sometime in the next hour
it's going to run a back up and

602
00:29:11,950 --> 00:29:13,480
go put itself back again.

603
00:29:13,480 --> 00:29:15,830
So, if I really want to stop that
I need to go to the client and

604
00:29:15,830 --> 00:29:18,980
remove the back up there too,
to say stop backing up to the server.

605
00:29:18,980 --> 00:29:21,640
And then that's gone, but,

606
00:29:21,640 --> 00:29:24,490
that's basically the Time Machine
service in a nutshell.

607
00:29:24,490 --> 00:29:27,390
It gives you that centralized back up,
right there in the server.

608
00:29:27,390 --> 00:29:28,770
Gives us centralized monitoring.

609
00:29:28,770 --> 00:29:29,740
It's a great system to have,

610
00:29:29,740 --> 00:29:33,400
especially if you're trying to back
up a large quantity of devices.

611
00:29:33,400 --> 00:29:38,150
Now, in extremely large environments where
you've got tens of thousands of machines,

612
00:29:38,150 --> 00:29:41,430
it's not realistic to maintain
backups of every single machine.

613
00:29:41,430 --> 00:29:46,490
And in that case you'll probably wanna
use something like a net boot or

614
00:29:46,490 --> 00:29:48,000
net install solution.

615
00:29:48,000 --> 00:29:50,850
And that's where you have an image of
a machine that's like a base image,

616
00:29:50,850 --> 00:29:55,340
and if somebody loses their computer
you can just redeploy that image.

617
00:29:55,340 --> 00:29:57,500
One image for all of your computers.

618
00:29:57,500 --> 00:30:00,560
So, if you're interested in learning about
the solution like that, make sure to catch

619
00:30:00,560 --> 00:30:04,520
our net installation episode, it will
be called rthe Net Boot Episodes so

620
00:30:04,520 --> 00:30:06,570
you can jump over and
check those out and see it.

621
00:30:06,570 --> 00:30:09,750
For normal system backups
Time Machine can't be beat.

622
00:30:09,750 --> 00:30:13,520
Super easy, works really well, and
runs in the background invisible to you,

623
00:30:13,520 --> 00:30:14,250
it's a great system.

624
00:30:15,890 --> 00:30:17,940
Well, that's all I've got for
this episode, so

625
00:30:17,940 --> 00:30:19,720
this is a great spot to wrap it up.

626
00:30:19,720 --> 00:30:24,160
Let me remind you guys, if you have any
questions on this feel free to ask.

Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live,

and you'll see the chatroom
beneath the video.

629

You post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

You have questions after the show,

At the top of every page on the itpro.tv

Click on it.

It'll take you to the forums.

You can post your questions there.

We're going to make sure you guys

Right, that's how you,

[LAUGH] So,

00:30:54,740 --> 00:30:56,094
They are there for you.

Well, I hope you guys,
