episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,289 --> 00:00:07,742
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,742 --> 00:00:15,942
Good morning,

3
00:00:15,942 --> 00:00:25,403
good afternoon,

4
00:00:25,403 --> 00:00:29,818
and good

5
00:00:29,818 --> 00:00:35,501
evening.

6
00:00:35,501 --> 00:00:38,250
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:38,250 --> 00:00:40,200
I'm your host Don Pezet,

8
00:00:40,200 --> 00:00:43,930
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

9
00:00:43,930 --> 00:00:47,460
In this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at the DHCP or

10
00:00:47,460 --> 00:00:50,265
dynamic host configuration
protocol [LAUGH] server.

11
00:00:50,265 --> 00:00:52,565
It's a part of server apps,
but quite a mouth full.

12
00:00:52,565 --> 00:00:55,425
Well, it's actually [LAUGH] not
that bad of a technology to use.

13
00:00:55,425 --> 00:00:58,695
It's one that almost everybody uses,
so let's start with some real basics,

14
00:00:58,695 --> 00:01:00,595
just with what DHCP is, and

15
00:01:00,595 --> 00:01:03,987
then we'll get into how we can set
that up as part of the server app.

16
00:01:03,987 --> 00:01:05,687
Well, most of our networks today,

17
00:01:05,687 --> 00:01:09,677
center around a protocol called IP,
or Internet Protocol.

18
00:01:09,677 --> 00:01:14,037
IP version 4 is the most common networking
protocol used in the world, and

19
00:01:14,037 --> 00:01:17,193
it's the primary protocol to the Internet.

20
00:01:17,193 --> 00:01:20,613
In order for
a computer to talk on an IP based network,

21
00:01:20,613 --> 00:01:22,443
it has to have an IP address.

22
00:01:22,443 --> 00:01:25,853
An IP address is their numbers,
you guys have seen them before I'm sure,

23
00:01:25,853 --> 00:01:29,171
things like 192.168.0.1, or 10.1.230.50.

24
00:01:29,171 --> 00:01:31,901
Those are IP addresses, and

25
00:01:31,901 --> 00:01:36,361
they help computers to recognize
each other on the network, and

26
00:01:36,361 --> 00:01:40,001
to figure out whether computers are on
different networks and how to get to them.

27
00:01:40,001 --> 00:01:41,651
It's kind of a key piece.

28
00:01:41,651 --> 00:01:45,001
When you browse across the Internet,
your computer has to know how to go,

29
00:01:45,001 --> 00:01:46,471
how to cross that network,

30
00:01:46,471 --> 00:01:50,291
how to get from point a to point b,
and IP addresses are what direct that.

31
00:01:51,320 --> 00:01:55,770
Well, if you've got an IP based
network you have to make a choice.

32
00:01:55,770 --> 00:02:00,820
One, you could go to every computer in
your network, and manually give them an IP

33
00:02:00,820 --> 00:02:03,310
address, you could type in
the ip address on each machine.

34
00:02:04,755 --> 00:02:09,004
Or two, you could have them automatically,
[SOUND] get an IP address.

35
00:02:09,004 --> 00:02:10,800
Sorry, I smashed my hand on the table.

36
00:02:10,800 --> 00:02:12,860
He gets [LAUGH] an automatic address.

37
00:02:12,860 --> 00:02:16,390
Now, an automatic address
has some pros and cons,

38
00:02:16,390 --> 00:02:17,940
and a manual address has pros and cons.

39
00:02:17,940 --> 00:02:19,930
So, let's talk about each of those.

40
00:02:19,930 --> 00:02:24,040
On the manual addressing side, if I'm
manually typing an IP address on each

41
00:02:24,040 --> 00:02:27,870
computer, first off,
I have to know what address to put in.

42
00:02:27,870 --> 00:02:31,895
So, I'm gonna need to keep a spreadsheet,
or a notebook, or something that says,

43
00:02:31,895 --> 00:02:34,841
I gave this IP to computer one,
I gave this IP to computer two,

44
00:02:34,841 --> 00:02:36,860
this IP computer four, and so on.

45
00:02:36,860 --> 00:02:38,980
So I remember, whose got what IPs, and

46
00:02:38,980 --> 00:02:43,180
so that I don't issue the same
IP to more than one computer.

47
00:02:43,180 --> 00:02:45,350
You can't two computers
with the same IP address,

48
00:02:45,350 --> 00:02:48,910
it creates a conflict, and they wont work,
so you've gotta keep track of that.

49
00:02:50,130 --> 00:02:54,000
The other thing is, we have to make
sure we don't make type errors.

50
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:56,360
As you're typing in an address,
as a human being,

51
00:02:56,360 --> 00:02:59,280
it's very easy to type in the wrong data,
and now you've got a problem.

52
00:03:00,970 --> 00:03:04,735
The other issue with manual addressing
is that when you type in an IP address,

53
00:03:04,735 --> 00:03:08,555
you don't normally just type in an IP,
you also type in an address for

54
00:03:08,555 --> 00:03:12,625
a router to use, as well as DNS
servers to use for name look-ups.

55
00:03:12,625 --> 00:03:14,705
What if you decide one day
you wanna change that?

56
00:03:14,705 --> 00:03:18,625
Maybe your DNS servers are getting kinda
old, and you decide it's time to replace

57
00:03:18,625 --> 00:03:22,000
them, and you got 1,000
computers all with manual IPs.

58
00:03:22,000 --> 00:03:24,680
Now, you've got to go to all
thousand of those computers, and

59
00:03:24,680 --> 00:03:28,670
change their DNS values, or router or
whatever it is you're trying to modify.

60
00:03:28,670 --> 00:03:32,940
It's kind of a burden, so
those are negatives with a manual setting.

61
00:03:32,940 --> 00:03:35,705
The positive side on manual your
setting is, you'll type in the address.

62
00:03:35,705 --> 00:03:39,905
Now, that computer has it, it will have
that address, and you know what it i, but

63
00:03:39,905 --> 00:03:41,445
there's just so many negatives to it.

64
00:03:41,445 --> 00:03:45,276
With the record keeping, and
the administrative effort,

65
00:03:45,276 --> 00:03:48,425
of having to go in and
update all those machines.

66
00:03:48,425 --> 00:03:52,846
So, DHCP, the dynamic host configuration
protocol, is designed to fix that,

67
00:03:52,846 --> 00:03:56,941
and what it does is it says, don't
worry about configuring your clients,

68
00:03:56,941 --> 00:03:59,490
leave all of your clients
set to go automatic.

69
00:03:59,490 --> 00:04:02,454
And when those clients
start up on the network,

70
00:04:02,454 --> 00:04:06,541
they'll reach out to the network,
they'll send out a message.

71
00:04:06,541 --> 00:04:08,252
So they'll say, hey, I'm a new computer, I
need an IP address, can somebody help me?

72
00:04:08,252 --> 00:04:12,256
And a DHCP server will respond,
and say, hey, I'm a DHCP server,

73
00:04:12,256 --> 00:04:16,170
here's an address you can use,
if you would like it.

74
00:04:16,170 --> 00:04:19,640
And the client can take that address and
say, all right, sweet, I got an address.

75
00:04:19,640 --> 00:04:21,230
And now it can work on the network.

76
00:04:21,230 --> 00:04:22,840
It automatically configures itself.

77
00:04:23,920 --> 00:04:26,700
On a positive side,
we don't have to do record keeping.

78
00:04:26,700 --> 00:04:31,200
The DHCP server does it for us, it keeps
track of what addresses are issued out and

79
00:04:31,200 --> 00:04:32,620
what ones aren't.

80
00:04:32,620 --> 00:04:34,890
And if we wanna change something,
like change our router,

81
00:04:34,890 --> 00:04:39,450
change DNS, well, we can go and
modify it on the DHCP server.

82
00:04:39,450 --> 00:04:41,960
And the next time a client connects,
they'll get the new router, or

83
00:04:41,960 --> 00:04:45,210
they'll get the new DNS setting
automatically from the server.

84
00:04:45,210 --> 00:04:50,450
We never have to go to our clients to set
something up, that's really convenient.

85
00:04:50,450 --> 00:04:54,500
On a negative thought,
what happens if our DHCP server fails?

86
00:04:54,500 --> 00:04:55,110
If if goes offline?

87
00:04:56,260 --> 00:04:58,860
Well, now clients can't get addresses,
and they can't function.

88
00:04:58,860 --> 00:05:03,305
So You're trading off a lot of
administrative effort and other work in

89
00:05:03,305 --> 00:05:07,676
exchange for having centralized
IP management that's kinda nice,

90
00:05:07,676 --> 00:05:11,840
but you do have some risk in that
you get a single point of failure.

91
00:05:11,840 --> 00:05:14,240
Well, there's ways to make
DHCP servers redundant.

92
00:05:14,240 --> 00:05:15,980
We'll talk about that later, but

93
00:05:15,980 --> 00:05:18,860
the reward is usually worth more
than the risk, in this case.

94
00:05:18,860 --> 00:05:23,750
Most organizations,
even home networks, use DHCP servers.

95
00:05:23,750 --> 00:05:24,970
You might not know about it.

96
00:05:24,970 --> 00:05:26,540
It's build into your router.

97
00:05:26,540 --> 00:05:28,030
A lot of people buy wireless access point,

98
00:05:28,030 --> 00:05:32,010
like an Apple AirPort, and
it can be a DHCP server.

99
00:05:32,010 --> 00:05:34,730
It can issue addresses
to all of your clients.

100
00:05:34,730 --> 00:05:37,990
Well, an OS 10 server can also.

101
00:05:37,990 --> 00:05:42,820
As part of the OS 10, or
OS X Server App, you have a DHCP server.

102
00:05:42,820 --> 00:05:45,580
You can make where your server
is what's issuing out those

103
00:05:45,580 --> 00:05:46,440
addresses to your clients.

104
00:05:46,440 --> 00:05:48,403
It's pretty easy to get set up.

105
00:05:48,403 --> 00:05:50,222
So, let me show you how that works.

106
00:05:50,222 --> 00:05:54,800
I'm gonna start not on the server,
but on a client.

107
00:05:54,800 --> 00:05:58,140
So, here's a client, I've got
a client that's up and running, and

108
00:05:58,140 --> 00:06:02,270
if I go into my
System Preferences > Network,

109
00:06:03,780 --> 00:06:07,350
I can see right here that my IP4
address right now is manual.

110
00:06:07,350 --> 00:06:12,321
I've manually assigned it this address
of 10.211.55.201, I typed that in,

111
00:06:12,321 --> 00:06:16,800
I could have made a typo, that IP could
have already been used somewhere else.

112
00:06:16,800 --> 00:06:19,790
But I know what address it is,
I typed it in, and it's always set.

113
00:06:21,180 --> 00:06:24,960
We set a Subnet Mask, which tells
us where the network id ends, and

114
00:06:24,960 --> 00:06:26,570
where the host id starts.

115
00:06:26,570 --> 00:06:29,326
So, my network is 10.211.55, and

116
00:06:29,326 --> 00:06:34,120
my host is .201, right, that's
separation that a Subnet Mask creates.

117
00:06:34,120 --> 00:06:37,009
And then,
the router if I wanna get to the Internet,

118
00:06:37,009 --> 00:06:41,162
I need to go to 10.201.55.1,
that's the address I wanna use.

119
00:06:41,162 --> 00:06:46,160
And if I go under Advanced,
I'm manually typed in DNS settings.

120
00:06:46,160 --> 00:06:49,805
If I go to the DNS tab,
I typed in what server to use,

121
00:06:49,805 --> 00:06:54,790
10.201.55.200, and
I typed in a search domain.

122
00:06:54,790 --> 00:06:56,490
And the search domain just means,

123
00:06:56,490 --> 00:06:59,820
if I try to do something like
access a server with a single name.

124
00:06:59,820 --> 00:07:02,610
So, I try and go to OS X-server1,
and that's it.

125
00:07:02,610 --> 00:07:07,702
It will automatically add this to the end,
and it'll say, alright, I wanna go

126
00:07:07,702 --> 00:07:13,570
to OSX-server1.lab.ITproductTV, so
now it knows the full name of that system.

127
00:07:13,570 --> 00:07:17,850
And you can add in more than one Search
Domain if you wanted, that one is my open

128
00:07:17,850 --> 00:07:22,510
directory domain, so that's why I put that
one in there, but I did all this by hand.

129
00:07:22,510 --> 00:07:24,220
I put all this information in here.

130
00:07:25,950 --> 00:07:28,600
I could have,
instead of manually putting this in here.

131
00:07:28,600 --> 00:07:32,040
If I go in here and remove this stuff,
so I'm just going to go through and

132
00:07:32,040 --> 00:07:32,930
get all those out of there.

133
00:07:35,370 --> 00:07:41,530
And then back here, on configure IPV4,
I could have switched to Using DHCP.

134
00:07:41,530 --> 00:07:43,580
And that's telling it to go automatic.

135
00:07:43,580 --> 00:07:46,665
Now, when the computer connects,
it's gonna reach out to the network,

136
00:07:46,665 --> 00:07:50,245
and just say, hey, is there somebody out
there that can give me an address, please,

137
00:07:50,245 --> 00:07:51,720
I can't talk without an address.

138
00:07:51,720 --> 00:07:55,909
And a DHCP server on the network
will give us those values.

139
00:07:55,909 --> 00:07:58,079
Well, I don't have a DHCP
server on this network,

140
00:07:58,079 --> 00:08:00,808
that's kind of why I put manual
ones on there it the first place.

141
00:08:00,808 --> 00:08:04,894
So, it's gonna sit here, and
after a while, it's gonna give up.

142
00:08:04,894 --> 00:08:09,734
And you can always recognize when it's
given up because an address will show up,

143
00:08:09,734 --> 00:08:11,890
but it's not complete.

144
00:08:11,890 --> 00:08:13,150
Notice how I have no router?

145
00:08:13,150 --> 00:08:14,830
I have no DNS servers?

146
00:08:14,830 --> 00:08:18,830
I don't have any other information,
I just have an IP and

147
00:08:18,830 --> 00:08:23,160
a subnet mask, and
the IP starts with 169.254.

148
00:08:23,160 --> 00:08:27,180
If you ever see 169.254 at
the beginning of an address,

149
00:08:27,180 --> 00:08:29,920
what you have is what's
called an APIPA address.

150
00:08:31,080 --> 00:08:38,080
APIPA is the Automatic Private IP
Addressing address, A-P-I-P-A.

151
00:08:38,080 --> 00:08:41,330
And it just means the machine
couldn't find a server, and

152
00:08:41,330 --> 00:08:43,140
so it made up its own address.

153
00:08:43,140 --> 00:08:48,410
It made one up that started with 169.254
and ended with two random numbers.

154
00:08:48,410 --> 00:08:49,412
Mine picked 205.19.

155
00:08:49,412 --> 00:08:52,000
Yours might pick something
completely different, but

156
00:08:52,000 --> 00:08:54,070
it'll always start with 169.254.

157
00:08:54,070 --> 00:08:55,800
And the idea is,

158
00:08:55,800 --> 00:08:59,600
if other computers all do the same thing,
they'll at least be on the same network.

159
00:08:59,600 --> 00:09:00,960
They can all see each other.

160
00:09:00,960 --> 00:09:02,360
But they wont be able
to get to the internet.

161
00:09:02,360 --> 00:09:04,070
It's not gonna function.

162
00:09:04,070 --> 00:09:07,300
So when you're troubleshooting DHCP,
this is something to look out for.

163
00:09:07,300 --> 00:09:09,360
If you're seeing 169.254
addresses on your clients,

164
00:09:09,360 --> 00:09:13,010
that means they're not
finding the DHCP server.

165
00:09:13,010 --> 00:09:16,282
Maybe the DHCP server's off,
maybe it's not configured properly,

166
00:09:16,282 --> 00:09:18,760
maybe it's on a different network.

167
00:09:18,760 --> 00:09:20,700
DHCP uses broadcasts.

168
00:09:20,700 --> 00:09:22,448
We send a broadcasts
message out to clients,

169
00:09:22,448 --> 00:09:25,890
sends a message out the world saying,
hey somebody give me an address.

170
00:09:25,890 --> 00:09:28,958
Well, routers don't forward
those broadcasters.

171
00:09:28,958 --> 00:09:33,160
So the DHCP server needs to be on
the same network as their client.

172
00:09:33,160 --> 00:09:36,510
If it's not, if the DHCP server
is on a separate network,

173
00:09:36,510 --> 00:09:40,770
the router won't forward the broadcast and
the DHCP server will never hear it.

174
00:09:40,770 --> 00:09:44,180
It will never see that message and
it won't know to respond.

175
00:09:44,180 --> 00:09:47,473
Now there are technologies out there that
fix that, you're not going to see them

176
00:09:47,473 --> 00:09:50,090
on the exam, but if you're dealing
with this in real life land,

177
00:09:50,090 --> 00:09:52,430
you can use things like there's
different names for it.

178
00:09:52,430 --> 00:09:57,044
Some people call it a DHCP proxy,
other people call it an IP helper address,

179
00:09:57,044 --> 00:10:00,880
some people call it a DHCP relay agent,
that's the real name.

180
00:10:00,880 --> 00:10:06,193
And what a relay agent does is it listens
on one network for those DHCP request, and

181
00:10:06,193 --> 00:10:11,830
then it forwards them to another network
where the server is to get a response.

182
00:10:11,830 --> 00:10:15,850
So you can have one DHCP server
that handles addresses for

183
00:10:15,850 --> 00:10:17,520
more than one subnet.

184
00:10:17,520 --> 00:10:18,320
That's kinda nice,

185
00:10:18,320 --> 00:10:21,570
if you have a bunch of different networks
you can consolidate that into one.

186
00:10:21,570 --> 00:10:24,059
Won't show up on the exam but in real
life land you might bump into that.

187
00:10:25,320 --> 00:10:28,040
The relay agents, or proxies,
they're normally your routers.

188
00:10:28,040 --> 00:10:29,450
And that's why it's not on the exam.

189
00:10:29,450 --> 00:10:33,964
You'd normally go to your Cisco router, or
Three Com, or Linksys or whatever it is

190
00:10:33,964 --> 00:10:38,040
that you're using and on there you'd
specify where that DHCP server was.

191
00:10:40,660 --> 00:10:42,410
But I wanna have DHCP server.

192
00:10:42,410 --> 00:10:45,170
I want this client to be able to
automatically get an address and

193
00:10:45,170 --> 00:10:47,260
not have to make one up like this.

194
00:10:47,260 --> 00:10:48,470
So that's where my server comes in.

195
00:10:48,470 --> 00:10:51,350
I'm gonna jump back over to my server.

196
00:10:51,350 --> 00:10:55,810
And if I look, the DHCP server is
not in the standard service list,

197
00:10:55,810 --> 00:10:57,750
I have to go down under advanced.

198
00:10:57,750 --> 00:10:59,370
And under advanced I'll find DHCP.

199
00:10:59,370 --> 00:11:02,800
Now if this is a service
that almost everybody uses,

200
00:11:02,800 --> 00:11:05,330
why would Apple tuck it away like that?

201
00:11:05,330 --> 00:11:08,660
Well the reason is,
everybody uses DHCP, but

202
00:11:08,660 --> 00:11:11,330
they typically use their
router as the DHCP server.

203
00:11:11,330 --> 00:11:13,960
Most organizations use their router,
all right?

204
00:11:13,960 --> 00:11:16,500
But if we wanna use our server we can,
we just have to turn it on.

205
00:11:16,500 --> 00:11:19,360
And so that's why it's tucked
away down here, all right?

206
00:11:19,360 --> 00:11:22,000
Now if I take a look at my DHCP server,

207
00:11:22,000 --> 00:11:24,100
there's not a whole lot
of options in here.

208
00:11:24,100 --> 00:11:28,580
I can turn it on and off, and
I can set up what are called my networks.

209
00:11:28,580 --> 00:11:30,840
A network is what's really
called a DHCP pool.

210
00:11:30,840 --> 00:11:33,370
It's a collection of addresses
that I'm ready to hand out.

211
00:11:33,370 --> 00:11:38,700
And you'll see on mine, it's already got
a pool here for this 10.10.1 network.

212
00:11:38,700 --> 00:11:41,690
Well, I'm not on the 10.10.1 network.

213
00:11:41,690 --> 00:11:43,455
I'm on the 10.211.55 network.

214
00:11:43,455 --> 00:11:46,470
So this doesn't match what I need.

215
00:11:46,470 --> 00:11:48,320
I'm just gonna delete that out of there.

216
00:11:49,620 --> 00:11:51,060
So I'll delete that one.

217
00:11:51,060 --> 00:11:52,810
And there we go, now I've got no networks.

218
00:11:52,810 --> 00:11:55,950
When you first configure a DHCP server
you'll likely see this screen right

219
00:11:55,950 --> 00:11:57,740
here, add networks.

220
00:11:57,740 --> 00:12:01,070
And we're adding pools of addresses
that can be available for our clients.

221
00:12:02,430 --> 00:12:04,970
So I'll hit the plus sign down here at
the bottom to create my first pool,

222
00:12:04,970 --> 00:12:06,550
and I'll give it a name.

223
00:12:06,550 --> 00:12:10,080
I'll call this one ITProTV studio.

224
00:12:10,080 --> 00:12:11,540
So this is the ITProTV studio.

225
00:12:11,540 --> 00:12:13,910
I'm gonna give out addresses to
machines that are right here

226
00:12:13,910 --> 00:12:14,510
in the network with me.

227
00:12:15,710 --> 00:12:17,520
I can then set a lease duration.

228
00:12:17,520 --> 00:12:18,340
Now this is important.

229
00:12:19,550 --> 00:12:23,540
When somebody gets an address
from the server, what if

230
00:12:23,540 --> 00:12:29,070
they have a machine that they're only
gonna be on my network for a little while?

231
00:12:29,070 --> 00:12:31,770
They come into the network, they get
an address, maybe they're here for

232
00:12:31,770 --> 00:12:33,230
45 minutes, and then they go home.

233
00:12:34,780 --> 00:12:39,880
Well, when we manually assign an IP
address, they've got that IP all the time.

234
00:12:39,880 --> 00:12:42,610
Whether they're here or not we've given
it to them and that's it, it's gone, and

235
00:12:42,610 --> 00:12:45,020
nobody else can use it because
we've run the risk of a conflict.

236
00:12:46,220 --> 00:12:49,940
But with DHCP, if they're gone,
if they're not here in the building,

237
00:12:49,940 --> 00:12:52,820
I could give their address to
somebody else, they're not using it.

238
00:12:52,820 --> 00:12:56,860
So I need to set a time that they're
allowed to have that address.

239
00:12:56,860 --> 00:12:58,790
And think of this as
a like a library book.

240
00:12:58,790 --> 00:13:02,100
When you come into the network,
you check out that library book.

241
00:13:02,100 --> 00:13:03,490
And you get it for
a certain period of time.

242
00:13:03,490 --> 00:13:04,480
The default here is one hour.

243
00:13:05,540 --> 00:13:09,710
After an hour, if I still need it,
I can renew it.

244
00:13:09,710 --> 00:13:10,550
I can check it out again.

245
00:13:10,550 --> 00:13:12,990
I can hold onto that address for
as long as I need it.

246
00:13:12,990 --> 00:13:17,100
But if I leave, I'm not here to
check it back in to renew it.

247
00:13:17,100 --> 00:13:20,321
And so if I leave at the end of that hour,
the address goes back into the pool and

248
00:13:20,321 --> 00:13:22,770
it can be shared with somebody else.

249
00:13:22,770 --> 00:13:24,730
Now, if your network has mostly desktops.

250
00:13:24,730 --> 00:13:26,730
If you've got a bunch of Mac Pros and

251
00:13:26,730 --> 00:13:30,490
that's it, then you might choose
to do a really long lease time.

252
00:13:30,490 --> 00:13:34,470
My computer aren't going anywhere, so
I might wanna bump that up and go 30 days.

253
00:13:34,470 --> 00:13:37,640
So once a month,
the computer has to check in.

254
00:13:37,640 --> 00:13:41,090
And if I decommission a computer and get
rid of it, sometime in the next 30 days,

255
00:13:41,090 --> 00:13:42,430
its IP address will
become available again.

256
00:13:43,630 --> 00:13:47,470
But if you're working at Starbucks, and
you've got thousands of customers bringing

257
00:13:47,470 --> 00:13:51,790
laptops into your coffee bar, or
whatever the heck they call it.

258
00:13:51,790 --> 00:13:54,200
They're bringing it in there and they're
only staying for 15 minutes at a time.

259
00:13:54,200 --> 00:13:57,900
You don't want them to hold that address
for 30 days, you've got thousands of more

260
00:13:57,900 --> 00:14:01,690
customers that are coming in, so
you might wanna set something much lower.

261
00:14:01,690 --> 00:14:04,330
One hour, one day,
seven days, it's up to you.

262
00:14:04,330 --> 00:14:06,620
I'm gonna go ahead and pick one day.

263
00:14:06,620 --> 00:14:08,960
I'm gonna pick 24 hours for mine.

264
00:14:08,960 --> 00:14:12,480
If somebody comes in the studio, they
can have that address for the whole day.

265
00:14:12,480 --> 00:14:15,040
But if they leave, by that time tomorrow,
it will be available for

266
00:14:15,040 --> 00:14:18,070
someone else to take.

267
00:14:18,070 --> 00:14:22,042
Then, I specify the range of IPs
that I want to give out, and

268
00:14:22,042 --> 00:14:24,995
see how it figured out
what network I was on?

269
00:14:24,995 --> 00:14:25,800
10.211.55.

270
00:14:25,800 --> 00:14:29,680
So, it knows what network the server's on,
it assumes that's what I wanna hand out.

271
00:14:29,680 --> 00:14:31,580
But there might be other networks.

272
00:14:31,580 --> 00:14:35,410
I could specify addresses for the other
networks, and if I have more than one

273
00:14:35,410 --> 00:14:38,710
network card in the server,
that may be something I need to deal with.

274
00:14:38,710 --> 00:14:40,690
Notice I've got network interface here.

275
00:14:40,690 --> 00:14:43,370
I could pick,
If I had three different network cards,

276
00:14:43,370 --> 00:14:46,400
I could create three different pools,
one for each card.

277
00:14:46,400 --> 00:14:48,680
Or if I have a relay agent I
could do it all off of one card.

278
00:14:48,680 --> 00:14:51,180
You don't have to have more than one card.

279
00:14:51,180 --> 00:14:57,080
But I'm gonna create a pool and
I'll set this one to run from 100 to 150.

280
00:14:57,080 --> 00:15:02,020
So if a client connects to my network,
I'll start giving 10.211.55.100 and

281
00:15:02,020 --> 00:15:06,730
then the next client will get 101 and
102 all the way up to 150.

282
00:15:06,730 --> 00:15:09,810
If I run out of addresses,
I just stop issuing.

283
00:15:09,810 --> 00:15:11,870
I don't answer anybody's request anymore.

284
00:15:11,870 --> 00:15:15,080
But, as long as I've got an address
available in the pool, I'll give it out.

285
00:15:16,610 --> 00:15:19,830
I can set my subnet mask and
my router right here.

286
00:15:19,830 --> 00:15:23,630
And those value are correct,
I'll leave them the way they are.

287
00:15:23,630 --> 00:15:26,800
Then, I can set the DNS data if I choose.

288
00:15:26,800 --> 00:15:30,920
If I go into Edit, I can specify
what DNS server I want to use and

289
00:15:30,920 --> 00:15:33,440
any other search domains
I want to specify.

290
00:15:33,440 --> 00:15:34,860
And so, I can put those in here,

291
00:15:34,860 --> 00:15:37,890
maybe for DNS I wanna provide
more than one DNS server.

292
00:15:37,890 --> 00:15:41,520
So, maybe I wanna set some backups
of like Google's DNS servers.

293
00:15:41,520 --> 00:15:43,110
So I can come in and I can punch those in.

294
00:15:45,050 --> 00:15:47,550
Just as backups in case my server is down.

295
00:15:47,550 --> 00:15:49,490
People can jump over and use one of those.

296
00:15:49,490 --> 00:15:52,849
While I might have other search
domains like itpro.tv or whatever,

297
00:15:52,849 --> 00:15:55,430
so I can punch each of those in.

298
00:15:55,430 --> 00:15:57,134
So I'm just gonna add those
values as appropriate.

299
00:15:57,134 --> 00:15:59,131
Now, it already had some data in there.

300
00:15:59,131 --> 00:16:00,687
Where did that data come from?

301
00:16:00,687 --> 00:16:01,894
It came from my server.

302
00:16:01,894 --> 00:16:04,007
It looks at what your server is using.

303
00:16:04,007 --> 00:16:06,733
And it prepopulates these to
save you a little bit of time.

304
00:16:06,733 --> 00:16:09,301
But I could have removed those values,
and put in whatever I wanted to.

305
00:16:09,301 --> 00:16:11,072
You have a complete control of that.

306
00:16:13,649 --> 00:16:16,482
So now I've got all that set,
I'll go ahead, and hit Create.

307
00:16:16,482 --> 00:16:18,444
And there's my first pool.

308
00:16:18,444 --> 00:16:20,836
If I have more than one network
card I could then go, and

309
00:16:20,836 --> 00:16:23,010
add pools for the other network cards.

310
00:16:23,010 --> 00:16:26,520
Or if I was using relay agents from
other networks, I would create pools for

311
00:16:26,520 --> 00:16:27,970
those other networks too.

312
00:16:27,970 --> 00:16:30,370
So you might have more than one pool,
if you need it.

313
00:16:30,370 --> 00:16:34,450
But I've created one, it's in place,
and now we're in business.

314
00:16:34,450 --> 00:16:37,330
I'm now issuing out addresses
to people that ask for them.

315
00:16:37,330 --> 00:16:41,770
If somebody asks for an address, I'll
give them one from the side of this pool.

316
00:16:41,770 --> 00:16:43,270
Now if my server fails, or

317
00:16:43,270 --> 00:16:47,120
if my server runs out of addresses,
it's not gonna answer people's requests.

318
00:16:47,120 --> 00:16:49,208
So it's kind of a central
point of failure.

319
00:16:49,208 --> 00:16:53,908
What I could do,
is I could bring up a second DHCP server.

320
00:16:53,908 --> 00:16:57,160
And on that other DHCP server,
I could create a pool there also.

321
00:16:57,160 --> 00:16:58,260
Now, I've got redundancy.

322
00:16:58,260 --> 00:17:00,340
If one fails, the other one's still there.

323
00:17:00,340 --> 00:17:04,757
But the key thing to remember,
is this pool should not overlap.

324
00:17:04,757 --> 00:17:08,170
You don't want two servers that are able
to issue out the same addresses.

325
00:17:08,170 --> 00:17:09,553
Cuz they don't talk to each other.

326
00:17:09,553 --> 00:17:12,999
They don't exchange information about
the leases, that they've issues.

327
00:17:12,999 --> 00:17:14,115
They're independent.

328
00:17:14,115 --> 00:17:18,312
So if I put the 100 to 150
pool on a second server,

329
00:17:18,312 --> 00:17:20,975
I get a lot of duplicate IP errors.

330
00:17:20,975 --> 00:17:25,542
So instead, what I would do is go to that
second server, and I would set it up for

331
00:17:25,542 --> 00:17:27,012
151 through 200.

332
00:17:27,012 --> 00:17:28,300
So the next little block.

333
00:17:28,300 --> 00:17:29,940
That way there's no overlapping.

334
00:17:29,940 --> 00:17:32,550
And if one server goes down,
the other server's still up,

335
00:17:32,550 --> 00:17:34,100
still issuing addresses.

336
00:17:34,100 --> 00:17:36,100
That's how we create redundancy in DHCP.

337
00:17:36,100 --> 00:17:38,700
Now, whenever somebody asks for
an address on the network.

338
00:17:38,700 --> 00:17:41,770
So a laptop bootsup, and
says hey, I need an address.

339
00:17:41,770 --> 00:17:43,560
Both servers would respond.

340
00:17:43,560 --> 00:17:45,340
They would get two responses.

341
00:17:45,340 --> 00:17:49,000
And the laptop is gonna pick
the first one that comes in.

342
00:17:49,000 --> 00:17:50,760
First one that comes in,
that's what it's gonna take.

343
00:17:50,760 --> 00:17:53,820
The second one comes in, and
the laptop will just ignore it.

344
00:17:53,820 --> 00:17:57,080
And so, that server will sit there for
a moment, and then it will say, well,

345
00:17:57,080 --> 00:17:58,590
fine, I didn't wanna give
you that address anyway.

346
00:17:58,590 --> 00:18:01,580
And it will put it back into the pool,
and now it's available for somebody else.

347
00:18:02,660 --> 00:18:04,000
But they will both respond.

348
00:18:04,000 --> 00:18:06,470
The clients will receive double responses.

349
00:18:06,470 --> 00:18:08,161
They don't get two IPs though.

350
00:18:08,161 --> 00:18:09,809
They pick one, and that's all they use.

351
00:18:11,725 --> 00:18:14,090
So, I've got this pool in place.

352
00:18:14,090 --> 00:18:15,580
It's active.

353
00:18:15,580 --> 00:18:16,270
Let's see it work.

354
00:18:17,420 --> 00:18:19,900
Well, if I jump back over to my client,

355
00:18:19,900 --> 00:18:24,268
I've still got that 169.254
address kind of sitting there.

356
00:18:24,268 --> 00:18:28,124
That automatic private IP address,
or APIPA address.

357
00:18:28,124 --> 00:18:30,200
So, I know that's not quite working right.

358
00:18:30,200 --> 00:18:33,490
If we go under Advanced, do you know I can
go in here, and kind of tweak these, and

359
00:18:33,490 --> 00:18:34,580
manually set it.

360
00:18:34,580 --> 00:18:39,513
The reason I'm coming into Advanced, is
that right here where is says using DHCP,

361
00:18:39,513 --> 00:18:41,850
is a button that says Renew DHCP Lease.

362
00:18:42,880 --> 00:18:46,920
If I hit that, it says hey, you didn't get
an address before, but let's try again.

363
00:18:46,920 --> 00:18:48,250
Let's try, and get out there,
and renew that lease.

364
00:18:48,250 --> 00:18:50,370
So let's get a new address, if we can.

365
00:18:50,370 --> 00:18:54,840
So I'm gonna hit that, and it's gonna
reach out, looking for a DHCP server.

366
00:18:54,840 --> 00:18:57,732
And in my case,
I can see it still didn't get one.

367
00:18:57,732 --> 00:18:59,891
Well, I kind of forgot
something important.

368
00:18:59,891 --> 00:19:02,344
And I know at least one of you is
out there screaming at your monitor,

369
00:19:02,344 --> 00:19:03,970
cuz that was pretty obvious.

370
00:19:03,970 --> 00:19:05,280
Well, not obvious enough for me to do it.

371
00:19:05,280 --> 00:19:09,568
But if I go back over to my server, I kind
of forgot to hit the ON button up here.

372
00:19:09,568 --> 00:19:13,810
So the DHCP service oddly enough
doesn't work, unless you turn it on.

373
00:19:13,810 --> 00:19:19,130
So I'm gonna turn it on, and now I'm
leasing, and issuing stuff on the server.

374
00:19:19,130 --> 00:19:21,250
Kind of an important piece.

375
00:19:21,250 --> 00:19:24,112
So it's on, I'll just back over to
my client, and I'll go ahead, and

376
00:19:24,112 --> 00:19:25,250
try that again.

377
00:19:25,250 --> 00:19:29,024
And now, it's reaching out to the network,
and there we go.

378
00:19:29,024 --> 00:19:31,903
I've been worried for
a second [LAUGH] that 169 appeared again.

379
00:19:31,903 --> 00:19:36,362
And now, I can see I got 10.211.55.100.

380
00:19:36,362 --> 00:19:39,868
And that .100,
that was the first address in the pool.

381
00:19:39,868 --> 00:19:41,505
It came right out of that pool.

382
00:19:41,505 --> 00:19:44,710
And now I've got the address,
and there we go.

383
00:19:44,710 --> 00:19:47,930
Not only did I get the address,
I got the subnet mask, and the router.

384
00:19:47,930 --> 00:19:53,540
And if I go to DNS, there's the DNS
servers, and the search domains.

385
00:19:53,540 --> 00:19:59,020
The cool part here, is that address
that I got, I've got it on lease.

386
00:19:59,020 --> 00:20:01,272
And that lease time, is 24 hours.

387
00:20:01,272 --> 00:20:03,060
I picked one day.

388
00:20:03,060 --> 00:20:06,900
So, every 24 hours we renew that lease.

389
00:20:06,900 --> 00:20:11,570
And if I'm ever gone for more than 24
hours, I give up the .100 address, and

390
00:20:11,570 --> 00:20:12,600
somebody else can have it.

391
00:20:12,600 --> 00:20:13,793
Somebody else can use it.

392
00:20:13,793 --> 00:20:15,731
And when I come back,
I'll just get a different address.

393
00:20:15,731 --> 00:20:18,230
Our address could change if
the address is already in use.

394
00:20:19,540 --> 00:20:21,780
The other cool thing,
is if I wanna change something.

395
00:20:21,780 --> 00:20:25,690
Maybe I decide one day, well,
I'm pushing out those Google DNS servers.

396
00:20:25,690 --> 00:20:26,780
But that's causing a problem.

397
00:20:26,780 --> 00:20:28,570
So maybe, I wanna get rid of those.

398
00:20:28,570 --> 00:20:31,227
I can go back here, and
I can edit my pool.

399
00:20:31,227 --> 00:20:34,907
And if I edit that pool I can go in,
and change those values, and

400
00:20:34,907 --> 00:20:37,485
I'll just get rid of those Google servers.

401
00:20:37,485 --> 00:20:41,691
And maybe I've added a new DNS server
on my network, so I'll come in,

402
00:20:41,691 --> 00:20:43,770
and punch in some other servers.

403
00:20:43,770 --> 00:20:46,818
I've got two DNS servers right here.

404
00:20:46,818 --> 00:20:50,913
if I was doing manual addresses, I would
have to go to all of my computers, and

405
00:20:50,913 --> 00:20:52,238
update those settings.

406
00:20:52,238 --> 00:20:56,266
But because I'm using DHCP,
I can just set that value, and

407
00:20:56,266 --> 00:21:01,676
the next time those clients check in,
the next time they come to get an address.

408
00:21:01,676 --> 00:21:07,470
They'll get those updated values, and
normally this is where I would show you.

409
00:21:07,470 --> 00:21:09,652
My system seems to have locked up.

410
00:21:09,652 --> 00:21:12,410
But [LAUGH] I'll change that,
and it will update there.

411
00:21:12,410 --> 00:21:16,809
The next time this lease goes to renew,
you'll get that updated address.

412
00:21:16,809 --> 00:21:20,030
Let's see if my change happened
before it kind of locked up.

413
00:21:21,390 --> 00:21:22,050
There we go.

414
00:21:22,050 --> 00:21:22,810
So, I've renewed.

415
00:21:22,810 --> 00:21:23,600
I got my address.

416
00:21:23,600 --> 00:21:25,860
And if I look under DNS,
the change hasn't taken effect yet.

417
00:21:25,860 --> 00:21:28,990
So I've got to wait for that, but
these machines will automatically update.

418
00:21:28,990 --> 00:21:30,980
Now if you're in a hurry,
that doesn't help.

419
00:21:30,980 --> 00:21:32,260
It's a 24-hour release.

420
00:21:32,260 --> 00:21:35,160
That means it could take up to 24 hours,
before clients got the change.

421
00:21:36,250 --> 00:21:39,310
But if you've got a thousand computers,
you can wait 24 hours.

422
00:21:39,310 --> 00:21:42,480
Would it take you more than 24 hours
to go to all thousand computers, and

423
00:21:42,480 --> 00:21:43,530
update that value?

424
00:21:43,530 --> 00:21:44,590
Absolutely.

425
00:21:44,590 --> 00:21:45,860
So, you wait.

426
00:21:45,860 --> 00:21:47,450
But if you've got a long lease,

427
00:21:47,450 --> 00:21:52,220
like a 30-day lease, it's either gonna
be 30 days worse case scenari for

428
00:21:52,220 --> 00:21:54,990
somebody to get the new settings,
or the next time they reboot.

429
00:21:54,990 --> 00:21:58,460
When they reboot they'll automatically
refresh, and get those new settings.

430
00:21:58,460 --> 00:22:00,140
So, there's a few ways to get around that.

431
00:22:00,140 --> 00:22:02,680
You could just have people reboot,
and that'll solve it too.

432
00:22:02,680 --> 00:22:05,490
Or unplug their network cable,
and plug it back in.

433
00:22:05,490 --> 00:22:06,942
That causes a network hard reset.

434
00:22:06,942 --> 00:22:08,509
That'll get the new values too.

435
00:22:10,819 --> 00:22:13,336
So on the DHCP side,
getting the pool setup,

436
00:22:13,336 --> 00:22:17,260
getting that available,
not a very challenging thing.

437
00:22:17,260 --> 00:22:18,890
There is one thing, though.

438
00:22:18,890 --> 00:22:22,642
I mentioned how when I get an address,
if I leave for

439
00:22:22,642 --> 00:22:26,870
a longer than my lease time,
somebody else could use my address.

440
00:22:26,870 --> 00:22:30,810
And when I come back I might get a new
address, and that can be problematic.

441
00:22:30,810 --> 00:22:32,730
If you've got something
like a print server.

442
00:22:32,730 --> 00:22:34,350
Or a server in general.

443
00:22:34,350 --> 00:22:36,980
You want it to always
have the same address.

444
00:22:36,980 --> 00:22:40,540
So on servers,
we'll typically do a manual IP.

445
00:22:40,540 --> 00:22:43,760
Manual IPs on a server,
dynamic on clients.

446
00:22:43,760 --> 00:22:46,690
I don't care if my laptop gets
a different IP, it doesn't matter to me.

447
00:22:46,690 --> 00:22:49,180
Or my desktop,
if it gets a different IP, who cares.

448
00:22:49,180 --> 00:22:50,255
Those don't matter.

449
00:22:50,255 --> 00:22:52,763
But on a server, a network printer.

450
00:22:52,763 --> 00:22:54,028
Something like that, we may care.

451
00:22:54,028 --> 00:22:56,180
An IP phone, we might care.

452
00:22:56,180 --> 00:23:01,050
And so, if we always want people to have
the same address, we can't use DHCP.

453
00:23:01,050 --> 00:23:02,210
Well, not necessarily.

454
00:23:02,210 --> 00:23:03,800
You certainly, can use a manual address.

455
00:23:03,800 --> 00:23:04,790
That does work.

456
00:23:04,790 --> 00:23:08,060
So if we wanna configure
a DHCP reservation,

457
00:23:08,060 --> 00:23:10,290
we just need to jump onto
this Client's tab up here.

458
00:23:10,290 --> 00:23:12,750
We've been under the Settings
tab on our server.

459
00:23:12,750 --> 00:23:14,150
If I switch over to client's,

460
00:23:14,150 --> 00:23:18,280
I'll see all of the various devices that
requested an address from my server.

461
00:23:18,280 --> 00:23:22,594
And so, I can see OS X Client1, that's
the client I was using a moment ago,

462
00:23:22,594 --> 00:23:23,954
has a Dynamic address.

463
00:23:23,954 --> 00:23:26,997
So Dynamic means, it's just gonna
get whatever address is available.

464
00:23:26,997 --> 00:23:32,200
It got 10.211.55.100, and
it's on that network, ITProTV Studio.

465
00:23:32,200 --> 00:23:33,910
That's the network that it's on.

466
00:23:33,910 --> 00:23:36,650
Well, it's got this address now.

467
00:23:36,650 --> 00:23:39,500
If it leaves for 24 hours,
somebody else can have it, and

468
00:23:39,500 --> 00:23:41,390
when it comes on,
it'll have a new address.

469
00:23:41,390 --> 00:23:45,460
If I wanted to always get the same
address, I can just highlight that entry,

470
00:23:46,670 --> 00:23:51,390
and down here if I hit my gear,
you can choose Create Static Address.

471
00:23:51,390 --> 00:23:54,650
And when you choose Create Static Address,
it's gonna create a mapping.

472
00:23:54,650 --> 00:24:00,023
It's gonna map that IP to the MAC address
of the network card of that client.

473
00:24:00,023 --> 00:24:05,044
Now, MAC address is not Mac as in
Macintosh, it's media access control.

474
00:24:05,044 --> 00:24:06,252
Every Network Adapter.

475
00:24:06,252 --> 00:24:09,015
Be it a Physical Network Adapter or
a Wireless Network Adapter.

476
00:24:09,015 --> 00:24:12,338
They all have a Media Access Control ID.

477
00:24:12,338 --> 00:24:15,290
It's a 48-bit hexadecimal number and

478
00:24:15,290 --> 00:24:18,260
it looks like, well,
like this one right here on the screen.

479
00:24:18,260 --> 00:24:19,910
And so it's mapping to that.

480
00:24:19,910 --> 00:24:22,870
So if any computer sends out a request and

481
00:24:22,870 --> 00:24:27,840
it's got that Mac address,
it will give it this particular IP.

482
00:24:27,840 --> 00:24:29,380
And so I can hit create.

483
00:24:29,380 --> 00:24:30,440
And it's gonna create that.

484
00:24:30,440 --> 00:24:34,330
And now instead of saying Dynamic,
it says Static.

485
00:24:34,330 --> 00:24:36,790
Now, that address is reserved.

486
00:24:36,790 --> 00:24:37,610
It's a reservation.

487
00:24:37,610 --> 00:24:41,730
It's held in reserve just for that client.

488
00:24:41,730 --> 00:24:43,160
No one else will get that address.

489
00:24:43,160 --> 00:24:45,080
I can leave for weeks or months on end.

490
00:24:45,080 --> 00:24:47,290
And when I come back,
I'll get those same address.

491
00:24:48,480 --> 00:24:50,990
Now you might ask yourself,
what's the point in doing that?

492
00:24:50,990 --> 00:24:55,080
Well if you've got a server,
a print server, IP phones and

493
00:24:55,080 --> 00:24:58,110
you always want them to have
the same address but you don't want

494
00:24:58,110 --> 00:25:02,370
to do a manual configuration on
the devices, this is a great way to do it.

495
00:25:02,370 --> 00:25:04,690
I now know that client will
always get the same address.

496
00:25:06,330 --> 00:25:09,670
In my case, the device was already
connected so that made life sort of easy.

497
00:25:09,670 --> 00:25:13,200
But if the device isn't here yet,
maybe you've ordered it and

498
00:25:13,200 --> 00:25:15,060
you know what the MAC
address is ahead of time.

499
00:25:15,060 --> 00:25:16,130
You can actually add them in.

500
00:25:16,130 --> 00:25:21,910
You can go down here to the plus sign, so
maybe I've got a new server coming in.

501
00:25:21,910 --> 00:25:25,850
It's going to be OSX Server 2 and
I can give it an address.

502
00:25:26,880 --> 00:25:30,670
And I can punch in what that
MAC address is going to be.

503
00:25:30,670 --> 00:25:35,058
I can punch in that

504
00:25:35,058 --> 00:25:39,749
value and create it.

505
00:25:39,749 --> 00:25:44,470
And now I've got a static entry ready.

506
00:25:44,470 --> 00:25:45,980
And waiting for that server.

507
00:25:45,980 --> 00:25:48,320
If somebody walks into this
building with a server and

508
00:25:48,320 --> 00:25:53,050
the MAC address matches what I just
typed in, they will get the 150 IP.

509
00:25:53,050 --> 00:25:55,420
And every time it comes up,
they'll get that address.

510
00:25:55,420 --> 00:26:00,120
Saves you a lot of time from having to go
and configure that on the client's side.

511
00:26:00,120 --> 00:26:01,400
All right.

512
00:26:01,400 --> 00:26:04,110
After that, that's about it for GACP.

513
00:26:04,110 --> 00:26:07,610
It's not a terribly complex protocol
in the general scheme of things.

514
00:26:07,610 --> 00:26:10,760
You create your pools and
you set your addresses.

515
00:26:10,760 --> 00:26:12,060
And then off it goes.

516
00:26:12,060 --> 00:26:14,220
Now the troubleshooting side,
the biggest problems.

517
00:26:14,220 --> 00:26:16,428
Well the silly problems is
I forgot to turn it on.

518
00:26:16,428 --> 00:26:21,980
There are types you can make in your
pool configuration like setting a wrong.

519
00:26:21,980 --> 00:26:25,900
But one of the most common problems
is simply running out of addresses.

520
00:26:25,900 --> 00:26:29,460
There's some devices and iPads are pretty
guilty of this, where they can get

521
00:26:29,460 --> 00:26:33,590
a little aggressive with re-using
IPs after the lease is expired.

522
00:26:33,590 --> 00:26:36,880
You don't see that here on this screen
though, you'll see it in the logs.

523
00:26:36,880 --> 00:26:39,980
If you jump up to your logs,
there's a DHCP log.

524
00:26:39,980 --> 00:26:42,360
And if there's any conflicts,
you'll see them in there.

525
00:26:42,360 --> 00:26:47,000
So here's my DHCP service log and if there
were any conflicts I would see them.

526
00:26:47,000 --> 00:26:50,350
I can see where OSX Server 1 fired up.

527
00:26:50,350 --> 00:26:53,350
And then here's a DHCP
discover message that came in.

528
00:26:53,350 --> 00:26:56,250
That was my client asking for an address.

529
00:26:56,250 --> 00:26:57,680
And we responded back to it.

530
00:26:57,680 --> 00:26:58,790
And gave it an address.

531
00:26:58,790 --> 00:27:01,750
And so here's that
acknowledgement to OSX client 1.

532
00:27:01,750 --> 00:27:05,170
And it got 10.211.55.100.

533
00:27:05,170 --> 00:27:08,580
I can see that successful
negotiation happen right there.

534
00:27:08,580 --> 00:27:14,275
If I were out of addresses, I would
see a discover come in but no offer.

535
00:27:14,275 --> 00:27:17,235
I wouldn't be able to offer another
address because I'm out of addresses.

536
00:27:17,235 --> 00:27:19,175
The pool is full, and that's it.

537
00:27:19,175 --> 00:27:21,615
So, that's the kind of problem
that we can end up with.

538
00:27:21,615 --> 00:27:23,355
Your logs are the best place to go in and
see that.

539
00:27:24,685 --> 00:27:26,605
But other than that,
that's about it for DHCP.

540
00:27:27,785 --> 00:27:30,305
OSX does a great job as a DHCP Server.

541
00:27:30,305 --> 00:27:31,375
You might be asking yourself,

542
00:27:31,375 --> 00:27:36,460
well I use my router now, why would I
use MAC OS instead of using my router?

543
00:27:36,460 --> 00:27:39,980
One of the big reason for
me, I like to use Mac OS or

544
00:27:39,980 --> 00:27:41,830
whatever server it is
as opposed to a router.

545
00:27:42,910 --> 00:27:45,890
The problem with a router is
if you're using your router or

546
00:27:45,890 --> 00:27:51,130
firewall as a DHCP server, they usually
store the DHCP database in RAM.

547
00:27:51,130 --> 00:27:56,130
So that whole table of what IPs
are assigned to what MACs, it's in RAM.

548
00:27:56,130 --> 00:27:59,270
If you ever reboot that router or
reboot that file log,

549
00:27:59,270 --> 00:28:02,770
that's when RAM gets wiped out and
they lose all those mappings.

550
00:28:02,770 --> 00:28:06,810
And for the next few hours you end-up
with a lot of duplicate IP issues.

551
00:28:06,810 --> 00:28:11,750
On a Mac, though, the DHCP tables
are saved to the hard drive and

552
00:28:11,750 --> 00:28:15,800
so if I reboot this Mac, it remembers
all the leases that it issued out.

553
00:28:15,800 --> 00:28:18,870
And that minimizes the chance
of me getting duplicate IPs.

554
00:28:18,870 --> 00:28:21,250
So, having it on a server
can be kind of nice and

555
00:28:21,250 --> 00:28:22,570
it's a little easier to administer.

556
00:28:22,570 --> 00:28:25,810
It's just right here inside of
the Server App that you work with anyway.

557
00:28:25,810 --> 00:28:26,880
Pros and cons.

558
00:28:26,880 --> 00:28:29,730
A lot of people feel that the routers
are a lot more reliable cuz they're just

559
00:28:29,730 --> 00:28:31,230
dedicated hardware.

560
00:28:31,230 --> 00:28:35,125
But there's pros to having
it over on the server also.

561
00:28:35,125 --> 00:28:36,990
So, that decisions kind of up to you.

562
00:28:36,990 --> 00:28:39,580
Apple doesn't really care whether
you want to run it on your router or

563
00:28:39,580 --> 00:28:43,000
whether you want to run it on the server,
they're not pressuring you either way.

564
00:28:43,000 --> 00:28:45,790
If you want to run it on the server,
here's all the tools for you.

565
00:28:45,790 --> 00:28:47,180
You are more than welcome to do it.

566
00:28:47,180 --> 00:28:50,100
If you want to run it on your router,
well, Apple plays with those too.

567
00:28:50,100 --> 00:28:52,370
So that works fine and
that'll work out too.

568
00:28:52,370 --> 00:28:54,932
So just keep that in mind as
you go to set all this up.

569
00:28:54,932 --> 00:28:56,580
All right.

570
00:28:56,580 --> 00:28:57,720
That's it for DHCP.

571
00:28:57,720 --> 00:28:59,740
So we'll go ahead and
wrap this episode up here.

572
00:28:59,740 --> 00:29:01,160
I do want to remind you guys.

573
00:29:01,160 --> 00:29:04,700
If you have questions on any of this,
feel free to ask.

you can go to ITProTV/live.

Post your questions there.

579
00:29:16,250 --> 00:29:20,460
At the top of every page on the ITProTV
site, you'll see a link that says Q&A.

580
00:29:20,460 --> 00:29:22,490
Click on it,
it'll take you right into our forums.

581
00:29:22,490 --> 00:29:23,860
You can post your question there.

582
00:29:23,860 --> 00:29:25,605
We monitor and answer after the show.

583
00:29:25,605 --> 00:29:29,135
Take advantage of that resource,

584
00:29:29,135 --> 00:29:31,095
All right, well I hope you

episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,335 --> 00:00:22,406
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,406 --> 00:00:32,406
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,458 --> 00:00:34,608
All right.

5
00:00:34,608 --> 00:00:36,745
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening, and

6
00:00:36,745 --> 00:00:38,561
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:38,561 --> 00:00:39,831
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

8
00:00:39,831 --> 00:00:45,110
Back again with another episode of ACTC,
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

9
00:00:45,110 --> 00:00:48,660
In this episode, we're gonna be
diving into virtual private networks,

10
00:00:48,660 --> 00:00:52,320
or VPNs, and
these are an incredibly useful technology.

11
00:00:52,320 --> 00:00:54,490
So it's something we definitely
want to be familiar with and

12
00:00:54,490 --> 00:00:56,870
be ready to implement in
our workplace environment.

13
00:00:56,870 --> 00:01:00,560
Now, let's start with some basics
real quick with what is a VPN?

14
00:01:00,560 --> 00:01:04,830
Well, a VPN, like the name implies,
a virtual private network.

15
00:01:04,830 --> 00:01:09,770
It takes a network that isn't normally
private and makes it private.

16
00:01:09,770 --> 00:01:11,290
All right, now what does that mean?

17
00:01:11,290 --> 00:01:14,080
Well, think about if
you're at your office.

18
00:01:14,080 --> 00:01:15,460
You've got your computer and

19
00:01:15,460 --> 00:01:18,750
you've got a server right there in your
office doing your transferring files and

20
00:01:18,750 --> 00:01:21,930
data between your machine,
your laptop, and your server.

21
00:01:21,930 --> 00:01:26,640
Well, those files are transmitting over
a network that you own and you control, or

22
00:01:26,640 --> 00:01:28,380
your company owns and controls.

23
00:01:28,380 --> 00:01:30,480
So it's a network that we consider safe.

24
00:01:30,480 --> 00:01:31,270
It's private.

25
00:01:31,270 --> 00:01:36,080
It's your private network, but
then you take your laptop and you go home.

26
00:01:36,080 --> 00:01:40,410
You go home and you plug into your network
and you connect your wireless at home and

27
00:01:40,410 --> 00:01:43,240
you're on a cable or DSL line.

28
00:01:43,240 --> 00:01:45,610
Now you're reaching out to the internet.

29
00:01:45,610 --> 00:01:46,650
And your work.

30
00:01:46,650 --> 00:01:49,270
Your work might be connected
to the internet also.

31
00:01:49,270 --> 00:01:52,040
Youd think if youre connected
to the internet at home and

32
00:01:52,040 --> 00:01:54,900
your office is connected to the internet,
that you can talk to each other and

33
00:01:54,900 --> 00:01:57,050
access those files and
the reality is you can.

34
00:01:57,050 --> 00:01:58,640
You can do that.

35
00:01:58,640 --> 00:02:01,260
But the internet is not a private network.

36
00:02:01,260 --> 00:02:02,890
Its a public network.

37
00:02:02,890 --> 00:02:06,580
There are millions upon millions
of people that are out there and

38
00:02:06,580 --> 00:02:09,530
your crossing networks
that you dont control.

39
00:02:09,530 --> 00:02:12,550
That you don't own, that you don't
even know who necessarily runs.

40
00:02:12,550 --> 00:02:15,130
These are networks that are kind of
invisible to you, but they're there.

41
00:02:15,130 --> 00:02:18,080
When you're crossing networks
controlled by other people, and

42
00:02:18,080 --> 00:02:20,090
when you use the internet, you trust them.

43
00:02:20,090 --> 00:02:22,540
You're saying, well,
I guess I trust those people.

44
00:02:22,540 --> 00:02:25,630
But as we all know, you can't
trust the people on the internet.

45
00:02:25,630 --> 00:02:27,880
So, what a VPN does,
is it says, all right,

46
00:02:27,880 --> 00:02:32,390
let me take my data and
I'm going to encrypt it.

47
00:02:32,390 --> 00:02:33,220
Encrypt it and

48
00:02:33,220 --> 00:02:36,730
make it where other people can't read
it unless they have a special key.

49
00:02:36,730 --> 00:02:41,430
And that special key, I'm going to put
that on the computer at the office.

50
00:02:41,430 --> 00:02:46,720
And my computer at home can now send
encrypted data to the office, and

51
00:02:46,720 --> 00:02:47,660
the office has the key.

52
00:02:47,660 --> 00:02:50,150
So, they'll be able to open it and
look at the data and it will work.

53
00:02:50,150 --> 00:02:53,780
But, anybody on the internet who
sees that data, well it's encrypted,

54
00:02:53,780 --> 00:02:56,300
they can't get to it to read and
see what it is.

55
00:02:56,300 --> 00:02:58,910
The information is protected,right?

56
00:02:58,910 --> 00:03:00,930
That's what a virtual
private network does.

57
00:03:00,930 --> 00:03:05,260
A VPN,
it's primary purpose is data security.

58
00:03:05,260 --> 00:03:08,790
And there's really, I don't wanna go too
crazy security level on this stuff, but

59
00:03:08,790 --> 00:03:11,840
there's really two
things that it performs.

60
00:03:11,840 --> 00:03:16,120
There's what's called we
have confidentiality and

61
00:03:16,120 --> 00:03:17,960
integrity are the official terms.

62
00:03:17,960 --> 00:03:21,550
So confidentiality means
we encrypt the data.

63
00:03:21,550 --> 00:03:25,560
So that only the people that we
want to see it, are able to see it.

64
00:03:25,560 --> 00:03:28,200
And anybody unauthorized tries to get it,
they can't, right?

65
00:03:28,200 --> 00:03:29,970
The data's confidential.

66
00:03:29,970 --> 00:03:34,100
And in integrity,
says the data has been tampered with.

67
00:03:34,100 --> 00:03:37,270
That if the data crosses the network and
somebody intercepts it,

68
00:03:37,270 --> 00:03:42,230
they could modify it, change that data and
send it somewhere else, right?

69
00:03:42,230 --> 00:03:45,120
An example might be,
maybe I'm doing a bank transfer.

70
00:03:45,120 --> 00:03:48,460
I'm transferring $1,000 from a checking
account to a savings account.

71
00:03:48,460 --> 00:03:51,830
Well, somebody intercepts that traffic and
modifies it so

72
00:03:51,830 --> 00:03:55,020
the destination account is their
account instead of mine, right?

73
00:03:55,020 --> 00:03:56,140
They modify it.

74
00:03:56,140 --> 00:03:59,120
Well a VPN would pick
up on that right away.

75
00:03:59,120 --> 00:04:02,440
It does a digital signature on every
packet that's sent and if it gets tampered

76
00:04:02,440 --> 00:04:06,780
with it knows that and it throws
the packet out and invalidates it.

77
00:04:06,780 --> 00:04:08,640
So that's integrity.

78
00:04:08,640 --> 00:04:11,720
Confidentiality and integrity,
that's what a VPN provides.

79
00:04:11,720 --> 00:04:14,100
Now it all sounds kinda complex, right?

80
00:04:14,100 --> 00:04:16,800
It's a complex thing, securing this data.

81
00:04:16,800 --> 00:04:18,750
But it's really not
that hard to implement.

82
00:04:18,750 --> 00:04:22,040
Getting it implemented inside of OS 10,
or in the OS X server app,

83
00:04:22,040 --> 00:04:23,460
is really pretty easy.

84
00:04:23,460 --> 00:04:27,570
There's a VPN server built in,
we can flip a switch to get it turned on.

85
00:04:27,570 --> 00:04:29,610
There's a little bit of
configuration we have to do.

86
00:04:29,610 --> 00:04:31,250
And we have to get our clients set up,
too.

87
00:04:31,250 --> 00:04:32,820
So there's a bit of work there.

88
00:04:32,820 --> 00:04:36,030
But for the most part,
it's a pretty simple thing to get going.

89
00:04:36,030 --> 00:04:38,230
Now I do want to clarify
one thing real quick,

90
00:04:38,230 --> 00:04:43,210
which is on the exam, they only
focus on the server side of things.

91
00:04:43,210 --> 00:04:48,540
They don't focus on the router and
firewall side, but in

92
00:04:48,540 --> 00:04:51,480
real life the router and firewall side is
something you're gonna have to deal with.

93
00:04:51,480 --> 00:04:54,110
So I will want to show that to
you guys a little bit later.

94
00:04:54,110 --> 00:04:54,800
It's not on the exam.

95
00:04:54,800 --> 00:04:57,790
I just want sure though that you guys
have an understanding of how that works.

96
00:04:57,790 --> 00:04:59,700
Cuz otherwise if you go to
implement it in the real world,

97
00:04:59,700 --> 00:05:00,790
it might not work as expected.

98
00:05:02,370 --> 00:05:05,080
All right.
Now inside of the OSX server,

99
00:05:05,080 --> 00:05:07,010
let's jump in here and
take a look at it real quick.

100
00:05:07,010 --> 00:05:11,160
So I've got a server fired up here and
I've got this OSX server one.

101
00:05:11,160 --> 00:05:12,010
This is my machine.

102
00:05:12,010 --> 00:05:13,280
It's up and it's running and

103
00:05:13,280 --> 00:05:16,780
when you look down the list of
services you'll see VPN right there.

104
00:05:16,780 --> 00:05:18,430
We've got that VPN service and

105
00:05:18,430 --> 00:05:22,000
there's not a whole heck of a lot
that we have to configure here.

106
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:25,920
So we're gonna go in and get that
configured get it put in place and

107
00:05:25,920 --> 00:05:27,540
see how we can secure that data.

108
00:05:27,540 --> 00:05:30,960
And I'm gonna show you a neat tool that
we can use to monitor the network and

109
00:05:30,960 --> 00:05:33,632
actually see whether the data
is being encrypted or not.

110
00:05:33,632 --> 00:05:37,000
All right now,
when we wanna turn the VPM service on.

111
00:05:37,000 --> 00:05:39,500
There's a few decisions
that we have to make, and

112
00:05:39,500 --> 00:05:44,570
the first decision is a pretty important
one, and it's this guy right here.

113
00:05:44,570 --> 00:05:48,390
The VPM server inside of OS10
supports two different protocols.

114
00:05:48,390 --> 00:05:52,430
If you drop that box down you'll see L2TP,
and PPTP.

115
00:05:52,430 --> 00:05:57,610
It's the layer two tunneling protocol and
the point to point tunneling protocol.

116
00:05:57,610 --> 00:05:59,950
Now, we have to make a choice.

117
00:05:59,950 --> 00:06:02,920
Notice how L2TP is gonna
be turned on either way.

118
00:06:02,920 --> 00:06:08,530
We're just choosing whether
we also support PPTP or not.

119
00:06:08,530 --> 00:06:10,090
There's pros and cons to both, right?

120
00:06:10,090 --> 00:06:11,970
Let's talk about PPTP first.

121
00:06:11,970 --> 00:06:15,970
On the positive side,
everybody supports PPTP.

122
00:06:15,970 --> 00:06:19,040
It's the most compatible
VPN protocol out there.

123
00:06:19,040 --> 00:06:24,020
So if you've got iOS phones and
iPads, you've got Android phones,

124
00:06:24,020 --> 00:06:26,840
you've got Windows computers,
Linux computers.

125
00:06:26,840 --> 00:06:30,900
And you want all of these different
operating systems to be able to VPN in,

126
00:06:30,900 --> 00:06:32,830
PPTP will work on all of them.

127
00:06:32,830 --> 00:06:34,470
It's the most compatible.

128
00:06:34,470 --> 00:06:37,130
So, you might say to yourself well
that sounds like a winner right there.

129
00:06:37,130 --> 00:06:38,250
I'll go with that one.

130
00:06:38,250 --> 00:06:42,030
The problem with PPTP is
it uses weak encryption.

131
00:06:42,030 --> 00:06:45,580
It was developed and released during the
days when the US had really tight export

132
00:06:45,580 --> 00:06:47,200
restrictions on encryption.

133
00:06:47,200 --> 00:06:49,520
And so it uses a protocol called MPPE and

134
00:06:49,520 --> 00:06:53,380
it's 40 bits by default
which is not very strong.

135
00:06:53,380 --> 00:06:55,240
PPTP can be broken.

136
00:06:55,240 --> 00:07:00,440
So if you're using that as your encryption
protocol, well, people can decipher it.

137
00:07:00,440 --> 00:07:01,500
People can break into that and

138
00:07:01,500 --> 00:07:05,500
give it that data and that kind of
negates the whole purpose of a VPN.

139
00:07:05,500 --> 00:07:08,370
It'll stop your basic level attackers,

140
00:07:08,370 --> 00:07:10,140
but it won't stop anybody
who's really advanced.

141
00:07:10,140 --> 00:07:11,420
They'll be able to get it back.

142
00:07:11,420 --> 00:07:15,690
So we typically don't want to use
PPTP unless we absolutely have to.

143
00:07:15,690 --> 00:07:19,070
If you have a device
that just supports that.

144
00:07:19,070 --> 00:07:19,960
L2TP on the other hand,

145
00:07:19,960 --> 00:07:24,800
layer two tunneling protocol, this one
is not supported by everybody, right?

146
00:07:24,800 --> 00:07:28,080
Every Mac supports it and
every Windows machine supports it, but

147
00:07:28,080 --> 00:07:29,890
most Android phones don't.

148
00:07:29,890 --> 00:07:31,880
A lot of Linux boxes don't.

149
00:07:31,880 --> 00:07:34,120
It's not as widespread as PPTP.

150
00:07:35,210 --> 00:07:37,540
But, it's a lot more secure.

151
00:07:37,540 --> 00:07:41,120
It throws away that MPEE encryption and
instead it uses IP sic.

152
00:07:41,120 --> 00:07:42,460
The IP sic framework and

153
00:07:42,460 --> 00:07:46,720
that lets it have some of the best
encryption possible on the network.

154
00:07:46,720 --> 00:07:49,930
That makes it very secure and
it is the one that you want.

155
00:07:49,930 --> 00:07:52,359
And that's why Apple
makes you turn on L2TD.

156
00:07:52,359 --> 00:07:55,450
And it leaves it where PPTP
is kind of optional, right?

157
00:07:55,450 --> 00:07:57,650
Its that kind of secondary choice there.

158
00:07:57,650 --> 00:08:02,449
So usually, we just want L2TP and
that's what I'm gonna do here on the show.

159
00:08:02,449 --> 00:08:06,400
If you choose both, the configuration and
setup, it's all the same.

160
00:08:06,400 --> 00:08:07,980
Right?
It doesn't really change anything.

161
00:08:07,980 --> 00:08:10,145
It just makes that second
protocol available and

162
00:08:10,145 --> 00:08:11,685
makes things a little bit weaker.

163
00:08:13,351 --> 00:08:15,350
All right, next we have the VPN host name.

164
00:08:15,350 --> 00:08:20,380
Now, it's gonna automatically fill in the
name of your server but be aware of this.

165
00:08:20,380 --> 00:08:25,090
Your server is not really gonna be
servicing people on the local network and

166
00:08:25,090 --> 00:08:29,180
this name that it's given mine in
this example is my local name.

167
00:08:29,180 --> 00:08:30,400
When I want somebody to VPNN,

168
00:08:30,400 --> 00:08:33,930
I want them to VPNN because they're
not here on the network with me.

169
00:08:33,930 --> 00:08:37,750
But they're out there at home or
at a hotel or at a conference center and

170
00:08:37,750 --> 00:08:39,700
I want them to have
a secure connection back.

171
00:08:39,700 --> 00:08:46,268
So the name that we provide here this name
actually needs to be our public name.

172
00:08:46,268 --> 00:08:50,620
The name that people can use out there on
the Internet to find their way back to

173
00:08:50,620 --> 00:08:54,904
the server so we need to punch in whatever
that is maybe I've given my server

174
00:08:54,904 --> 00:08:59,680
the name vpn.itpro.tv so I would punch
that in here and make it available.

175
00:08:59,680 --> 00:09:03,780
Or in my case, I can leave it to this
cuz this is actually in one of our

176
00:09:03,780 --> 00:09:05,910
main domains I don't have this
pushed out to the Internet.

177
00:09:05,910 --> 00:09:10,040
But you wanna put a name in here
that is publicly accessible so

178
00:09:10,040 --> 00:09:11,570
