00:44:17,306 --> 00:44:19,940
It'll take you to the forums,
you can post your questions there.

854
00:44:19,940 --> 00:44:22,210
We monitor and answer after the show.

855
00:44:22,210 --> 00:44:23,510
Take advantage of that resource.

856
00:44:23,510 --> 00:44:25,600
It is there for you.

857
00:44:25,600 --> 00:44:27,860
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

858
00:44:27,860 --> 00:44:30,193
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

859
00:44:30,193 --> 00:44:32,056
And I'll see you next time.

860
00:44:32,056 --> 00:44:42,056
[MUSIC]

861
00:44:46,056 --> 00:44:52,730
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Web Server
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,091 --> 00:00:10,091
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,321 --> 00:00:36,253
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:36,253 --> 00:00:38,218
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,218 --> 00:00:39,478
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:39,478 --> 00:00:43,760
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

6
00:00:43,760 --> 00:00:47,040
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at the web server built into

7
00:00:47,040 --> 00:00:49,350
the server app in Mac OS X.

8
00:00:49,350 --> 00:00:54,005
Now, a web server is probably one of
the most commonly brought up servers,

9
00:00:54,005 --> 00:00:56,875
right after file and
print servers for most networks.

10
00:00:56,875 --> 00:00:58,415
Just about everybody has a website.

11
00:00:58,415 --> 00:01:02,825
You might have public websites, or
internal websites that are intranets,

12
00:01:02,825 --> 00:01:04,105
just for your own employees.

13
00:01:04,105 --> 00:01:06,295
But just about everybody
has web servers these days.

14
00:01:06,295 --> 00:01:08,025
So this is a real common thing.

15
00:01:08,025 --> 00:01:12,645
Well, Apple provides us with the ability
to host websites right inside a Mac OS via

16
00:01:12,645 --> 00:01:13,580
the server app.

17
00:01:13,580 --> 00:01:14,610
And it's kind of nice.

18
00:01:14,610 --> 00:01:18,210
It's actually really nice because
it's built on top of Apache.

19
00:01:18,210 --> 00:01:22,440
Apache is one of the most common
web servers in the entire planet.

20
00:01:22,440 --> 00:01:25,760
When you go to websites, well, like ours,

21
00:01:25,760 --> 00:01:29,345
if you go to the ITProTV site, it's
hosted on top of the Apache web server.

22
00:01:29,345 --> 00:01:30,935
I forget the exact statistics but

23
00:01:30,935 --> 00:01:35,295
it's something like over 60% of websites
in the world are hosted on top of Apache.

24
00:01:35,295 --> 00:01:38,445
So when Apple decided to deploy
a web server inside of their system,

25
00:01:38,445 --> 00:01:40,555
they didn't have to reinvent the wheel.

26
00:01:40,555 --> 00:01:44,235
They leveraged an already proven
web server in Apache Version 2.0.

27
00:01:44,235 --> 00:01:46,285
And so that's what we find under the hood.

28
00:01:46,285 --> 00:01:51,217
And remember when you run Mac OS, the user
interface, all the easy to use stuff,

29
00:01:51,217 --> 00:01:54,310
the simple utilities and things,
that's all developed by Apple.

30
00:01:54,310 --> 00:01:58,452
But under the hood is the BSD
operating system, which bases on Unix.

31
00:01:58,452 --> 00:02:01,616
And most of the web servers that are out
there in the world are running Linux or

32
00:02:01,616 --> 00:02:02,667
another units variant.

33
00:02:02,667 --> 00:02:06,068
So Apple didn't have to go very
far to find a good web server.

34
00:02:06,068 --> 00:02:10,440
The big challenge with Apache though,
is that it's not very user friendly.

35
00:02:10,440 --> 00:02:12,950
It's all handled through these text
based configuration files, and so

36
00:02:12,950 --> 00:02:16,350
what Apple really did is they just
made the technology easier to use.

37
00:02:16,350 --> 00:02:19,330
They gave us a nice little GUI
inside of a server app that lets us

38
00:02:19,330 --> 00:02:21,680
control this web server and
get it up and running.

39
00:02:21,680 --> 00:02:23,190
And it's really easy.

40
00:02:23,190 --> 00:02:26,860
If you just need a basic web server,
it's just a matter of turning it on,

41
00:02:26,860 --> 00:02:28,330
and that's it.

42
00:02:28,330 --> 00:02:31,500
But if you need something more advanced,
it's got that functionality too.

43
00:02:31,500 --> 00:02:34,060
And we'll get a chance to see that in
this episode as we run through and

44
00:02:34,060 --> 00:02:37,560
set up the different components inside of
the web server, and get it up and running.

45
00:02:38,710 --> 00:02:42,050
Well, let's jump in here and
take a look at that.

46
00:02:42,050 --> 00:02:43,680
Now, when we look at our server app,

47
00:02:43,680 --> 00:02:45,860
we'll see all the different
services that are available.

48
00:02:45,860 --> 00:02:48,131
And the web server's
actually listed as websites.

49
00:02:48,131 --> 00:02:51,700
So, if we look at the server app, here,
you'll see it down on the left side.

50
00:02:51,700 --> 00:02:56,280
If I go down to Services,
you'll find Websites right there, okay.

51
00:02:56,280 --> 00:02:58,880
And I've already turned mine on,
let me just turn that off.

52
00:02:58,880 --> 00:03:00,780
What you'll normally see is
it'll look just like this.

53
00:03:00,780 --> 00:03:03,160
I haven't changed any settings or
anything.

54
00:03:03,160 --> 00:03:05,740
But when you come in,
the service will look like like this,

55
00:03:05,740 --> 00:03:10,250
it says Websites, and this is
the Apache web server under the hood.

56
00:03:10,250 --> 00:03:13,740
Now when you turn it on,
you become a web server.

57
00:03:13,740 --> 00:03:18,350
But the reality is you probably are
already a web server from other services.

58
00:03:18,350 --> 00:03:21,340
There's many services that
use a website to manage them.

59
00:03:21,340 --> 00:03:23,230
For example, the Profile Manager.

60
00:03:23,230 --> 00:03:26,940
If you configure the Profile Manager,
it has a user portal and

61
00:03:26,940 --> 00:03:29,860
it has an admin portal
which are both web pages.

62
00:03:29,860 --> 00:03:33,830
People browse to get to them, and
it uses the Apache web server for that.

63
00:03:33,830 --> 00:03:37,950
If you configure the Software Update
service, down here, that guy.

64
00:03:37,950 --> 00:03:41,990
That one uses web pages to provide
the catalog files for all of the updates.

65
00:03:41,990 --> 00:03:47,090
It uses Apache, so the odds are you're
already running Apache on your server.

66
00:03:47,090 --> 00:03:50,430
You're running it as a support service for
something else.

67
00:03:50,430 --> 00:03:53,340
So when we go to websites,
what we're really turning on

68
00:03:53,340 --> 00:03:56,710
is just the basic website functionality,
the basic webpage.

69
00:03:56,710 --> 00:03:59,690
The server itself is probably
already running on your system.

70
00:03:59,690 --> 00:04:00,400
It might not be, though.

71
00:04:00,400 --> 00:04:03,800
This might be a fresh and clean server
that we've just installed the server app.

72
00:04:03,800 --> 00:04:07,740
We're not running any other services, and
in that case, Apache might not be running.

73
00:04:07,740 --> 00:04:12,650
But either way, we come in here, and
we just flip that on switch and now it is.

74
00:04:12,650 --> 00:04:14,970
Now we're running the web server,
and we're up and

75
00:04:14,970 --> 00:04:17,250
available to provide those pages.

76
00:04:17,250 --> 00:04:24,550
Now a standard web page is usually an HTML
file, a HyperText Markup Language file.

77
00:04:24,550 --> 00:04:28,870
And when you turn this on,
the settings that are there by default.

78
00:04:28,870 --> 00:04:33,021
These are the default setting right here,
where I've got everything on check,

79
00:04:33,021 --> 00:04:35,601
is that the server will
serve up those HTML files.

80
00:04:35,601 --> 00:04:39,001
You can take an HTML file,
make it available, and get to it.

81
00:04:39,001 --> 00:04:43,370
But other files, things that are more
advanced, those are disabled.

82
00:04:43,370 --> 00:04:46,780
Apple takes the approach of giving
you basic functionality, and

83
00:04:46,780 --> 00:04:50,230
then saying you can turn on whatever
you need to get more advanced.

84
00:04:50,230 --> 00:04:53,710
They don't want to turn all the advanced
stuff on by default because web servers

85
00:04:53,710 --> 00:04:57,280
are a high level target for
attackers that are out there.

86
00:04:57,280 --> 00:05:00,840
If you're a hacker and you want to attack
a company, usually you'll look for

87
00:05:00,840 --> 00:05:02,930
their services that
are exposed to the Internet.

88
00:05:02,930 --> 00:05:04,950
And websites are exposed to the Internet.

89
00:05:04,950 --> 00:05:08,080
Websites also allow anonymous
connections because you wanna allow

90
00:05:08,080 --> 00:05:09,770
anybody to get to your website.

91
00:05:09,770 --> 00:05:15,240
If I'm going to CNN.com, they don't
know who I am or where I'm coming from,

92
00:05:15,240 --> 00:05:18,040
they want to allow me to get to that page,
that's how they make their money.

93
00:05:18,040 --> 00:05:19,340
You gotta get to the page.

94
00:05:19,340 --> 00:05:22,000
So attackers, that helps them.

95
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:24,640
They know they can access that server and
if they can break into it,

96
00:05:24,640 --> 00:05:26,420
they can get into the rest of the network.

97
00:05:26,420 --> 00:05:28,820
So web servers
are constantly under attack.

98
00:05:28,820 --> 00:05:29,950
So Apple says,

99
00:05:29,950 --> 00:05:33,280
let's just turn on the basic stuff
because the basic stuff is pretty safe.

100
00:05:33,280 --> 00:05:37,690
It's hard for an attacker to break into a
server that's only serving up html files.

101
00:05:37,690 --> 00:05:40,890
But as we start to turn on more advanced
features, we increase our risk.

102
00:05:40,890 --> 00:05:44,930
Now Apple does a great job of patching and
tuning and keeping this stuff up-to-date,

103
00:05:44,930 --> 00:05:48,180
but hackers do a great job of keeping
their skills up-to-date, too.

104
00:05:48,180 --> 00:05:51,300
So they constantly find different
ways to get in and wreak havoc.

105
00:05:51,300 --> 00:05:53,790
So that stuff's off right now.

106
00:05:53,790 --> 00:05:55,730
I just have a basic web server.

107
00:05:55,730 --> 00:06:00,060
Now when you turn on a basic web server,
it comes up like we've got here, and

108
00:06:00,060 --> 00:06:01,250
it's actually already working.

109
00:06:01,250 --> 00:06:06,710
It's kind of hard to tell here, but if I
fire up Safari and I browse to my server,

110
00:06:06,710 --> 00:06:12,430
so if I browse to http://osx-server1,

111
00:06:12,430 --> 00:06:15,960
when I browse to it I
should get a webpage.

112
00:06:15,960 --> 00:06:20,550
Now I'm getting a message here saying that
it can't verify the identify of my server.

113
00:06:20,550 --> 00:06:24,670
What that means is that my server has a
certificate on it to identify it, and for

114
00:06:24,670 --> 00:06:27,910
some reason the certificate isn't
matching the name of the server.

115
00:06:27,910 --> 00:06:30,540
And if I hit Show Certificate, I can see
that it's because the certificate was

116
00:06:30,540 --> 00:06:34,380
actually issued to osx-server1.local and

117
00:06:34,380 --> 00:06:36,180
that's not what I typed
in the address bar.

118
00:06:36,180 --> 00:06:38,048
So the names don't match,
that's what it's complaining about.

119
00:06:38,048 --> 00:06:41,120
That's a self-signed certificate
that was built into the system

120
00:06:41,120 --> 00:06:43,170
when we did the install of the server app.

121
00:06:43,170 --> 00:06:47,460
Or actually, that one was probably created
when I made this an open directory server.

122
00:06:47,460 --> 00:06:50,100
But that's just a little
name not matching.

123
00:06:50,100 --> 00:06:51,670
But when I go to the server.

124
00:06:51,670 --> 00:06:52,440
Here it is.

125
00:06:52,440 --> 00:06:53,200
I get a web page.

126
00:06:53,200 --> 00:06:56,770
This is the default web page that
Apple includes to let me know the web

127
00:06:56,770 --> 00:06:57,890
server is working.

128
00:06:59,270 --> 00:07:03,360
Now it highlights, right here, some of the
other services that use the web server.

129
00:07:03,360 --> 00:07:05,450
I mentioned the Profile Manager already.

130
00:07:05,450 --> 00:07:08,950
If you are using the Profile Manager,
you're already running Apache.

131
00:07:08,950 --> 00:07:12,120
I also mention the software update
service which isn't on this screen.

132
00:07:12,120 --> 00:07:14,760
The wiki which we'll talk
about in another episode,

133
00:07:14,760 --> 00:07:19,218
that's a web page that users can
actually edit with a WYSIWYG editor.

134
00:07:19,218 --> 00:07:22,880
We've got Xcode the development
environment that uses web pages.

135
00:07:22,880 --> 00:07:25,300
And then we just have our
general setting for the server,

136
00:07:25,300 --> 00:07:27,300
which is what we're gonna get into here,
in just a minute.

137
00:07:29,560 --> 00:07:32,240
All right, but
that's just a basic web page.

138
00:07:32,240 --> 00:07:35,510
And now I've got this basic website up,
and

139
00:07:35,510 --> 00:07:39,630
I can start to customize how this
server works, how it responds to users.

140
00:07:39,630 --> 00:07:42,930
And I can even customize the content
that's inside of it, all right?

141
00:07:42,930 --> 00:07:44,330
So let's take a look at those settings.

142
00:07:44,330 --> 00:07:46,440
I'm just going to go ahead and
just get out of this,

143
00:07:46,440 --> 00:07:48,080
and I'll go back to my system here.

144
00:07:48,080 --> 00:07:50,586
Now, when my website was activated,

145
00:07:50,586 --> 00:07:53,886
it actually activated it
on two different ports.

146
00:07:53,886 --> 00:07:54,884
So I can see it right here.

147
00:07:54,884 --> 00:07:57,705
Server website and server website SSL.

148
00:07:57,705 --> 00:07:58,472
What's that all about?

149
00:07:58,472 --> 00:08:03,391
Well, Server website is a standard,
unencrypted webpage.

150
00:08:03,391 --> 00:08:05,254
We're gonna connect to it anonymously, and

151
00:08:05,254 --> 00:08:07,490
the web page is gonna be
transmitted in plaintext.

152
00:08:07,490 --> 00:08:12,010
That's how HTTP, the Hypertext
Transfer Protocol, works by default.

153
00:08:12,010 --> 00:08:15,685
It works over TCP port 80,
and I see that right here.

154
00:08:15,685 --> 00:08:18,455
Notice how it says all IP addresses?

155
00:08:18,455 --> 00:08:21,465
If I have more than one
network card in my server

156
00:08:21,465 --> 00:08:24,025
this web page is being served up
in all of those network cards.

157
00:08:24,025 --> 00:08:28,105
So users can come in any network interface
and get to this web page on port 80.

158
00:08:28,105 --> 00:08:33,970
If they want to secure connection,
well then it needs to switch to SSL.

159
00:08:33,970 --> 00:08:38,630
SSL is Secure Socket Layer,
and it's gonna use HTTPS,

160
00:08:38,630 --> 00:08:40,750
which is done over TCP port 443.

161
00:08:40,750 --> 00:08:44,640
And so, it set up the same web page
on port 443 for secure connections.

162
00:08:46,090 --> 00:08:48,210
This is actually the same webpage,

163
00:08:48,210 --> 00:08:52,200
just being provided over two different
protocols, secure and unsecure.

164
00:08:52,200 --> 00:08:53,920
That's how most webpages are.

165
00:08:53,920 --> 00:08:57,440
Maybe you just want secure, or
maybe you just want unsecure, so

166
00:08:57,440 --> 00:09:00,890
you could actually remove one of
the these or customize it, change it, and

167
00:09:00,890 --> 00:09:02,180
set things the way that you need it.

168
00:09:02,180 --> 00:09:03,490
Most people want both, right?

169
00:09:03,490 --> 00:09:04,680
You want unsecure and secure.

170
00:09:05,940 --> 00:09:08,400
So before we jump into configuring
all these individual settings,

171
00:09:08,400 --> 00:09:11,380
let me just verify that my site is
actually presenting on these two

172
00:09:11,380 --> 00:09:13,000
ports like we described, right?

173
00:09:13,000 --> 00:09:15,390
So I'm gonna fire Safari back up.

174
00:09:15,390 --> 00:09:19,660
And I'm gonna start by actually
typing in the full address.

175
00:09:19,660 --> 00:09:23,950
And when I browse through
the server I can say, http://, so

176
00:09:23,950 --> 00:09:25,840
I'm telling it I don't
want a secure connection.

177
00:09:25,840 --> 00:09:30,120
And then, I'll point it to OSX-server one,
that's the name of my server.

178
00:09:30,120 --> 00:09:31,960
I can also do this by IP address.

179
00:09:31,960 --> 00:09:36,790
I can punch in an IP address of my network
adapter, or the loop back address,

180
00:09:36,790 --> 00:09:39,100
127.00.1, I could point to that.

181
00:09:39,100 --> 00:09:40,310
Whatever it is that I want.

182
00:09:40,310 --> 00:09:44,061
But I can browse, and there I'm getting
the webpage, and it's a non-secure

183
00:09:44,061 --> 00:09:47,720
connection cuz I don't see a little
lock up here in my address bar.

184
00:09:47,720 --> 00:09:52,990
And if I open up another tab and
I put in https://,

185
00:09:52,990 --> 00:09:56,680
and I'm going to add .local
to the end of that name, so

186
00:09:56,680 --> 00:10:00,400
it'll be https:// osx-server1.local.

187
00:10:00,400 --> 00:10:01,710
By typing in that name,

188
00:10:01,710 --> 00:10:06,210
it'll make it not complain about
that certificate, and there we go.

189
00:10:06,210 --> 00:10:08,760
So I've connected to it,
I didn't get any certificate complaints.

190
00:10:08,760 --> 00:10:12,660
And if I click on my address bar,
I can see that I did connect with HTTPS.

191
00:10:12,660 --> 00:10:16,140
My little lock isn't appearing,
which is a little odd.

192
00:10:16,140 --> 00:10:19,810
Yeah, see what happened there?

193
00:10:19,810 --> 00:10:24,620
But it is connecting securely, but
I'm not getting the little lock

194
00:10:24,620 --> 00:10:27,565
icon which means I'm probably still not
trusting my root certificate on this one.

195
00:10:27,565 --> 00:10:30,020
Self-signed certificates
are always a problem.

196
00:10:30,020 --> 00:10:32,850
What you really want to do, if you're
gonna be exposing this to the internet,

197
00:10:32,850 --> 00:10:35,360
is to go to a certificate
authority on the internet.

198
00:10:35,360 --> 00:10:37,320
Somebody like Digicert or

199
00:10:37,320 --> 00:10:41,320
Verisign, and purchase a trusted
certificate to attach to your server.

200
00:10:41,320 --> 00:10:44,372
That's when you get the nice little green
lock up here, or if you do extended

201
00:10:44,372 --> 00:10:47,152
verification you get the nice big
block that says your company name.

202
00:10:47,152 --> 00:10:51,780
That kinda stuff, that's important for
a lot of people for security.

203
00:10:51,780 --> 00:10:53,210
But my server is responding.

204
00:10:53,210 --> 00:10:58,212
I got a response here on HTTPS and I got
a response here on just regular HTTP.

205
00:10:58,212 --> 00:10:58,813
Actually, you know what?

206
00:10:58,813 --> 00:11:01,690
It says it flipped over to HTTPS,
didn't it?

207
00:11:01,690 --> 00:11:03,630
I'm gonna just do this by IP,

208
00:11:03,630 --> 00:11:09,220
if I do like 127.0.0.1 that's a local
connection right to the server.

209
00:11:09,220 --> 00:11:11,968
So I'm getting responses on all
of these different connections.

210
00:11:11,968 --> 00:11:16,378
Now why does the server care
what IP I'm coming in on or

211
00:11:16,378 --> 00:11:18,740
what name I'm coming in on.

212
00:11:18,740 --> 00:11:24,142
And the answer is you might want to host
more than one website on the same server.

213
00:11:24,142 --> 00:11:27,081
Well, if you've got more than
one website on the same server,

214
00:11:27,081 --> 00:11:29,810
how does it know which
site to present to users?

215
00:11:29,810 --> 00:11:33,370
So, when we create a website, there are
really three things that identify it, and

216
00:11:33,370 --> 00:11:35,820
you sorta see that here in the server app.

217
00:11:35,820 --> 00:11:40,650
When we look at it, it says the name of

Let me remind you guys,
if you have any questions on this,

753
00:38:02,660 --> 00:38:05,240
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

754
00:38:05,240 --> 00:38:08,150
You'll see the chatroom
right beneath the video.

755
00:38:08,150 --> 00:38:09,090
Post your questions there.

756
00:38:09,090 --> 00:38:11,220
We monitor and answer during the show.

757
00:38:11,220 --> 00:38:14,710
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

758
00:38:14,710 --> 00:38:16,530
On any page on the ITProTV website,

759
00:38:16,530 --> 00:38:19,270
you'll see a link that says Q&A
up at the top of the screen.

760
00:38:19,270 --> 00:38:20,000
Click on it.

761
00:38:20,000 --> 00:38:22,470
It'll take you to the forums,
you can post your questions there.

762
00:38:22,470 --> 00:38:24,020
We monitor and answer after the show.

763
00:38:24,020 --> 00:38:25,810
Take advantage of those resources.

764
00:38:25,810 --> 00:38:27,700
They are there for you.

765
00:38:27,700 --> 00:38:29,680
I hope you guys enjoyed today's episode.

766
00:38:29,680 --> 00:38:33,733
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Wikis
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,265 --> 00:00:22,509
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,509 --> 00:00:33,409
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,409 --> 00:00:36,487
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

5
00:00:36,487 --> 00:00:38,549
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,549 --> 00:00:41,254
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with another episode of

7
00:00:41,254 --> 00:00:43,790
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

8
00:00:43,790 --> 00:00:46,670
In this episode we're gonna be
taking at the Wiki service that's

9
00:00:46,670 --> 00:00:50,360
included with the Server
app in Mac OS X Yosemite.

10
00:00:50,360 --> 00:00:54,890
Now the Wiki service is very closely
related to the website service.

11
00:00:54,890 --> 00:00:57,130
In the website service,
if you've watched those episodes,

12
00:00:57,130 --> 00:01:00,100
we saw how you can bring up
a web server and host web pages.

13
00:01:00,100 --> 00:01:01,070
That's cool.

14
00:01:01,070 --> 00:01:04,590
But typically what most companies
do is they have web developers or

15
00:01:04,590 --> 00:01:07,150
staff that creates those pages and
puts them on there.

16
00:01:07,150 --> 00:01:12,350
Wouldn't it be nice if we could have
pages,that anybody could contribute to and

17
00:01:12,350 --> 00:01:14,720
that's where wikis came about.

18
00:01:14,720 --> 00:01:16,850
Wikis are very common on the Internet.

19
00:01:16,850 --> 00:01:21,060
If you've never used one, I find that hard
to believe, but maybe some people haven't.

20
00:01:21,060 --> 00:01:25,030
The biggest example would be Wikipedia,
the online encyclopedia.

21
00:01:25,030 --> 00:01:28,580
Anybody can go to that website, you
sign up for an account, and then you can

22
00:01:28,580 --> 00:01:32,270
edit pages and add your own content or
remove content or have some fun.

23
00:01:32,270 --> 00:01:35,970
Well, that's what Wikipedia is all about,
and that's what wikis in general are.

24
00:01:35,970 --> 00:01:38,900
They're a great way to
do group collaboration.

25
00:01:38,900 --> 00:01:41,920
Well, inside of the wiki service
inside of the Server app,

26
00:01:41,920 --> 00:01:44,530
it actually has two different
methods of function.

27
00:01:44,530 --> 00:01:46,460
The Primary function is that is a Wiki.

28
00:01:46,460 --> 00:01:50,160
So you can have all of your employees, or
you can set permissions, you can limit it

29
00:01:50,160 --> 00:01:54,870
to a particular group, can access
the Wiki, read the content, edit it,

30
00:01:54,870 --> 00:01:59,310
add more content and build out webpages,
without having it have access to the file

31
00:01:59,310 --> 00:02:03,295
system underneath, without having to know
how to write html or anything like that.

32
00:02:03,295 --> 00:02:05,820
They can just use a WYSI WYG wig editor,

33
00:02:05,820 --> 00:02:10,380
a what you see is what you get editor and
modify the content.

34
00:02:10,380 --> 00:02:12,170
And get some really good stuff in place.

35
00:02:12,170 --> 00:02:14,980
So, wikis are really
popular from that aspect.

36
00:02:14,980 --> 00:02:19,690
The second method that a wiki can
function in the Server app, is as a blog.

37
00:02:19,690 --> 00:02:21,530
And blogs are a little different.

38
00:02:21,530 --> 00:02:27,560
The blog, the idea is that somebody,
usually a person, but it could be a group.

39
00:02:27,560 --> 00:02:31,150
Is posting information they
want other people to see.

40
00:02:31,150 --> 00:02:35,330
And they post maybe once a day,
once a week, however often,

41
00:02:35,330 --> 00:02:37,320
those posts kinda accumulate.

42
00:02:37,320 --> 00:02:39,360
And instead of browsing to a site and

43
00:02:39,360 --> 00:02:42,710
having navigation trees,
you move through the various pages,

44
00:02:42,710 --> 00:02:47,990
with a blog, you just see post after post
after post in a chronological order.

45
00:02:47,990 --> 00:02:50,770
So normally you see the newest post first,
then the next post, and

46
00:02:50,770 --> 00:02:52,380
the next post, and so on.

47
00:02:52,380 --> 00:02:54,450
It's how a number of
different websites work.

48
00:02:54,450 --> 00:02:58,560
I know every single day I go to a website
called Slashdot, and that's what they do.

49
00:02:58,560 --> 00:03:01,780
They post news stories, and
you see them, it's effectively a blog.

50
00:03:01,780 --> 00:03:04,400
Somebody's Facebook feed,
that's effectively a blog, right?

51
00:03:04,400 --> 00:03:07,290
They post little messages, and
they show up in their feed.

52
00:03:07,290 --> 00:03:12,180
Well the Wiki service inside of the Server
app can function as a blog too.

53
00:03:12,180 --> 00:03:16,170
The thing is, with a blog you
normally have one person or

54
00:03:16,170 --> 00:03:20,180
a particular group that's posting to it,
versus a Wiki that is oftentimes open for

55
00:03:20,180 --> 00:03:21,940
everybody to post to it.

56
00:03:21,940 --> 00:03:24,650
So it works a little bit different,
and I want to show you guys both

57
00:03:24,650 --> 00:03:27,880
configurations so that you're aware of it,
not just because it's on the exam, but

58
00:03:27,880 --> 00:03:30,510
also because you may
use this in real life.

59
00:03:30,510 --> 00:03:33,240
All right, so,
the first thing I want to comment on.

60
00:03:33,240 --> 00:03:36,440
If we want to turn on the Wiki service,
it's really easy.

61
00:03:36,440 --> 00:03:39,910
We just go down to Wiki, and
we flip the On button, right.

62
00:03:39,910 --> 00:03:41,000
Pow.
We're a Wiki server.

63
00:03:41,000 --> 00:03:43,310
And most of these Server
apps are just like that.

64
00:03:43,310 --> 00:03:45,570
But there is something
that's a little confusing.

65
00:03:45,570 --> 00:03:52,300
The Wiki service is up and running,
and it's running in the /Wiki folder,

66
00:03:52,300 --> 00:03:57,270
see how it says available at, my server
is called osx-server1.lab.itpro.tv,

67
00:03:57,270 --> 00:04:02,000
and it's saying that it can
get there at Server/Wiki.

68
00:04:02,000 --> 00:04:06,490
Well, the Wiki is a webpage, so
a lot of people think that you

69
00:04:06,490 --> 00:04:11,660
have to be running the website's server
also in order for the Wiki to work.

70
00:04:11,660 --> 00:04:12,990
And that's actually not true.

71
00:04:12,990 --> 00:04:16,100
You don't have to run the website
service if you don't want to.

72
00:04:16,100 --> 00:04:20,980
The website service and the Wiki service
are both running Apache in the background,

73
00:04:20,980 --> 00:04:23,670
but they are two separate entities, so

74
00:04:23,670 --> 00:04:26,810
one can be disabled without
affecting the other, all right?

75
00:04:26,810 --> 00:04:27,710
Let me show you what I mean.

76
00:04:27,710 --> 00:04:30,160
If I take this default website here.

77
00:04:30,160 --> 00:04:34,300
And I go over to a client machine.

78
00:04:35,350 --> 00:04:43,130
I can browse to
http://osx-server1.lab.itpro.tv.

79
00:04:43,130 --> 00:04:47,390
And if I browse to that,
I'm hitting my websites service.

80
00:04:48,550 --> 00:04:54,510
But if I add /wiki to the end of it
now I'm hitting the Wiki service.

81
00:04:54,510 --> 00:04:57,490
Alright, two different services,
and I can see that more

82
00:04:57,490 --> 00:05:00,000
clearly if I go back over to
the Server and turn one of them off.

83
00:05:00,000 --> 00:05:01,750
I'm gonna turn the website service off.

84
00:05:03,150 --> 00:05:07,700
So now, if I give it a second, it takes
a moment to stop, but once it stops,

85
00:05:07,700 --> 00:05:11,850
the website service will be stopped,
and the Wiki service is still running.

86
00:05:11,850 --> 00:05:15,240
If I go back over to that same client, and

87
00:05:15,240 --> 00:05:19,200
fire up a new Safari window and
try to browse to that server.

88
00:05:19,200 --> 00:05:24,350
All right so I'm just going to
browse right to the server.

89
00:05:24,350 --> 00:05:25,730
Well, I've cached the page.

90
00:05:25,730 --> 00:05:26,750
Shoot.

91
00:05:26,750 --> 00:05:28,330
I've cached it, so
it's gonna bring that up.

92
00:05:28,330 --> 00:05:31,260
But what we'll normally get is
that it can't access the server,

93
00:05:31,260 --> 00:05:32,760
the server is off.

94
00:05:32,760 --> 00:05:35,450
But then if we add /wiki,

95
00:05:35,450 --> 00:05:39,210
we can still get to that wiki even
though the web sites service is down.

96
00:05:39,210 --> 00:05:42,520
And the wiki one, it doesn't get cached,
because it's gotta refresh,

97
00:05:42,520 --> 00:05:45,340
just show if it's got new content so
I know I'm seeing that live page.

98
00:05:46,510 --> 00:05:49,370
Now, when you browse to the Wiki server,
you see this screen right here.

99
00:05:49,370 --> 00:05:50,690
A simple welcome, and

100
00:05:50,690 --> 00:05:54,240
it's introducing you to the idea
of how to create wikis, and so on.

101
00:05:54,240 --> 00:05:58,850
I've turned on the Wiki service but
I actually don't have any Wikis yet.

102
00:05:58,850 --> 00:06:00,130
So we need to make one.

103
00:06:00,130 --> 00:06:03,610
And before we can make one,
we need to log in.

104
00:06:03,610 --> 00:06:07,140
When you create a Wiki,
it's going to be tied to a user account.

105
00:06:07,140 --> 00:06:10,820
Whoever created it is
the Administrator for that Wiki.

106
00:06:10,820 --> 00:06:14,490
And the Administrator can then
determine who's allowed to edit it.

107
00:06:14,490 --> 00:06:17,720
You might have one that you want
everybody to be able to comment on.

108
00:06:17,720 --> 00:06:21,150
You might have one that you might want to
be a little bit more Strictive to, and

109
00:06:21,150 --> 00:06:22,756
it's up to that
administrator to define it.

110
00:06:22,756 --> 00:06:27,690
So I'm gonna log in, and
when i go to log in,

111
00:06:27,690 --> 00:06:30,880
you can see it's remembering my password
that I've used on the server before, so

112
00:06:30,880 --> 00:06:34,670
I can fill that in or I can type in
a different account if I wanted to.

113
00:06:34,670 --> 00:06:37,040
But I'll go ahead and get logged in here.

114
00:06:37,040 --> 00:06:40,750
And I'm just logged in as a regular user,
I'm not an Administrator.

115
00:06:40,750 --> 00:06:43,910
Anybody can create a Wiki by default.

116
00:06:43,910 --> 00:06:49,190
When I turned on the Wiki service,
I just hit the Onswitch, that's all I did.

117
00:06:49,190 --> 00:06:52,400
But right beneath it,
you'll see Permissions.

118
00:06:52,400 --> 00:06:56,130
And it says all users can create Wikis.

119
00:06:56,130 --> 00:07:00,810
That is why I can log in as John Doe, as
a regular user, and start to make Wikis.

120
00:07:00,810 --> 00:07:03,520
If you don't want all of your
users to be able to do that,

121
00:07:03,520 --> 00:07:07,110
you'll want to edit that permission and
from there, you can limit it down.

122
00:07:07,110 --> 00:07:10,490
And you can say only these users
are allowed to create a Wiki.

123
00:07:10,490 --> 00:07:13,330
Maybe you create a Wiki group,
like a Wiki admins, and

124
00:07:13,330 --> 00:07:15,520
those are the people who are allowed
to go in and create Wikis.

125
00:07:15,520 --> 00:07:17,110
So that gives you that control.

126
00:07:17,110 --> 00:07:21,800
But for my case I want all my users
to be able to create their own Wikis.

127
00:07:21,800 --> 00:07:24,620
The only other option on this
screen is right here Enable WebDAV

128
00:07:24,620 --> 00:07:26,440
access to the wiki files.

129
00:07:26,440 --> 00:07:30,690
WebDAV is Web Distributed Authoring and
Versioning.

130
00:07:30,690 --> 00:07:35,360
And it's a open standards protocol
that allows editing of webpages from

131
00:07:35,360 --> 00:07:36,890
third party applications.

132
00:07:36,890 --> 00:07:37,780
The only real use for

133
00:07:37,780 --> 00:07:41,870
it here is if you want to allow iOS users,
people who are on an iPad or iPhone.

134
00:07:41,870 --> 00:07:43,780
If you want to allow them
to be able to go in and

135
00:07:43,780 --> 00:07:47,250
edit these web pages you'll
need to turn on WebDAV access.

136
00:07:47,250 --> 00:07:49,902
But if you're not gonna support that
you can turn it off and that's it.

137
00:07:49,902 --> 00:07:56,171
You just basically jump in and
you edit it via a regular web browser.

138
00:07:56,171 --> 00:07:56,984
But I'll leave that on.

139
00:07:56,984 --> 00:07:59,608
It's on by default.

140
00:07:59,608 --> 00:08:04,100
All right, so log in as John Doe here,
I can create my first Wiki.

141
00:08:04,100 --> 00:08:06,830
You've got a little plus icon
up at the top of the page.

142
00:08:06,830 --> 00:08:07,710
And I can click that.

143
00:08:07,710 --> 00:08:11,830
And you'll see where I can add new pages,
if I just want to create a web page.

144
00:08:11,830 --> 00:08:14,120
Or I can create a new Wiki.

145
00:08:14,120 --> 00:08:19,110
If I create a web page, that's a page
that I'm allowed to edit and update, and

146
00:08:19,110 --> 00:08:20,690
nobody else can mess with it.

147
00:08:20,690 --> 00:08:23,040
They can read it, but
they can't change it.

148
00:08:23,040 --> 00:08:25,700
A Wiki on the other hand,
gives us a lot more flexibility.

149
00:08:28,130 --> 00:08:29,700
All right.
We had a question in the chat room about

150
00:08:29,700 --> 00:08:31,880
whether or not Windows has a Wiki service.

151
00:08:31,880 --> 00:08:33,280
They don't have one built in.

152
00:08:33,280 --> 00:08:36,720
Microsoft has a product called SharePoint,
and SharePoint is what they push for Wiki,

153
00:08:36,720 --> 00:08:38,250
is it's pretty heavy handed.

154
00:08:38,250 --> 00:08:43,670
What I just did here in OS-10, I flicked
an on switch and we had the Wiki.

155
00:08:43,670 --> 00:08:45,490
Windows is a lot more involved.

156
00:08:45,490 --> 00:08:48,550
You gotta install the share point server,
set up a database and all that.

157
00:08:48,550 --> 00:08:50,650
It's a bit of a bear.

158
00:08:50,650 --> 00:08:51,800
But that's their solution.

159
00:08:51,800 --> 00:08:56,210
So I'm gonna create this Wiki,
and I'll just give it a name.

160
00:08:56,210 --> 00:09:02,830
This is my corporate bulletin board,
right?

161
00:09:02,830 --> 00:09:05,990
So this is gonna be a Wiki that
everybody in the company can post to and

162
00:09:05,990 --> 00:09:09,330
share their ideas and
information, and I'll create it.

163
00:09:09,330 --> 00:09:13,660
Now I am automatically the administrator,
cuz I'm the one who made it.

164
00:09:13,660 --> 00:09:16,340
But now I can set permissions for
other people.

165
00:09:16,340 --> 00:09:19,600
I might wanna say that
if anybody is logged in,

166
00:09:19,600 --> 00:09:21,900
they are allowed to read and write.

167
00:09:21,900 --> 00:09:24,950
I want everybody to be able to
come in here and modify this.

168
00:09:25,990 --> 00:09:29,650
But if you're not authenticated, if
you're not logged in, you can only read.

169
00:09:29,650 --> 00:09:32,195
You can read this page,
but you can't modify it.

170
00:09:32,195 --> 00:09:33,925
I can also add in specific people.

171
00:09:33,925 --> 00:09:37,875
So maybe I have a coworker like Jane Doe,
and

172
00:09:37,875 --> 00:09:39,817
I want Jane to help me
out as an administrator.

173
00:09:39,817 --> 00:09:43,115
I wanna give here read and write or even
owner privileges so she can do whatever

174
00:09:43,115 --> 00:09:47,280
she wants to this blog, the difference
between read and write and owner.

175
00:09:47,280 --> 00:09:50,200
Read and write can change or
modify anything they want, but

176
00:09:50,200 --> 00:09:52,890
if you're the owner,
you can also change these permissions.

177
00:09:52,890 --> 00:09:54,630
You can come and
change the settings on the blog itself.

178
00:09:54,630 --> 00:09:56,260
So it's a little more than just read and
write.

179
00:09:59,150 --> 00:10:01,110
On the next page I pick my Wiki icon,

180
00:10:01,110 --> 00:10:03,220
if I want it to have a different
icon then the pencils.

181
00:10:03,220 --> 00:10:06,290
You can upload your own and
I can pick a color them for it.

182
00:10:06,290 --> 00:10:08,110
I maybe I want this one to
have a green color theme.

183
00:10:10,050 --> 00:10:14,090
And I'll create it, and
now I've got a corporate bulletin board.

184
00:10:14,090 --> 00:10:15,790
And this is a Wiki.

185
00:10:15,790 --> 00:10:19,830
Anybody in the company, because I gave all
authenticated users the ability to edit,

186
00:10:19,830 --> 00:10:25,460
anybody can come to this page, log in,
and start to add data to it, all right?

187
00:10:25,460 --> 00:10:28,720
This page right here is the only
page that is created by default,

188
00:10:28,720 --> 00:10:33,480
and people typically use this as an index
page, an index of all the different.

189
00:10:33,480 --> 00:10:35,330
Stuff that they've got out there.

190
00:10:35,330 --> 00:10:39,060
And we can then start to add
additional pages for what we want.

191
00:10:39,060 --> 00:10:40,090
As a user,

192
00:10:40,090 --> 00:10:43,820
when I go up to the plus sign up here,
I can choose to create a new Wiki.

193
00:10:43,820 --> 00:10:47,530
But see how it's got New Page
in Corporate Bulletin Board.

194
00:10:47,530 --> 00:10:50,040
Or Upload File to
Corporate Bulletin Board,

195
00:10:50,040 --> 00:10:51,470
I can start to create new web pages.

196
00:10:51,470 --> 00:10:53,560
Or I can upload my own files, PDFs.

197
00:10:53,560 --> 00:10:54,480
Things like that.

198
00:10:54,480 --> 00:10:56,170
And throw them here into the Wiki and

199
00:10:56,170 --> 00:10:58,630
now everybody will have access to those,
right?

200
00:10:58,630 --> 00:11:01,870
Great way to collaborate and
share that information.

201
00:11:01,870 --> 00:11:03,730
This home page just has sample data on it.

202
00:11:03,730 --> 00:11:08,170
I can come in and edit that, and this is
the WYSIWYG editor I was talking about.

203
00:11:08,170 --> 00:11:10,380
I just hit the pencil icon
at the top of the page.

204
00:11:10,380 --> 00:11:12,170
That puts us into edit mode.

205
00:11:12,170 --> 00:11:14,980
And now I can come in, and I can start
to wipe a lot of this stuff out.

206
00:11:14,980 --> 00:11:18,330
And so, I'll just empty that out,
and now I'll start to type in,

207
00:11:18,330 --> 00:11:23,380
Welcome to the Corporate Bulletin Board.

208
00:11:26,225 --> 00:11:30,895
And, I'll say this is
available to all employees.

209
00:11:30,895 --> 00:11:31,655
All right.

00:22:58,930 --> 00:23:00,280
I need to get back to my server.

440
00:23:00,280 --> 00:23:06,000
On the server,
if I go to /Library/Server/Wiki.

441
00:23:06,000 --> 00:23:08,270
That'll make a difference.

442
00:23:08,270 --> 00:23:11,010
There we go.
That's where the Wiki files are stored.

443
00:23:11,010 --> 00:23:14,190
But don't expect to see a bunch
of individual files or posts.

444
00:23:14,190 --> 00:23:17,630
You're going to see config,
you'll see file data and so on.

445
00:23:17,630 --> 00:23:20,724
But notice this file right here,
PostgressSocket,

446
00:23:20,724 --> 00:23:23,190
right, the Wiki uses PostgreSQL.

447
00:23:23,190 --> 00:23:29,790
It's a SQL-type database that runs in
the background, that stores all the pages.

448
00:23:29,790 --> 00:23:31,130
And so they aren't actually here.

449
00:23:31,130 --> 00:23:36,660
This database.xpg file, if you look at the
file itself, it's actually a directory.

450
00:23:36,660 --> 00:23:40,950
And if we change into that folder,
well, I have to be an admin to do it.

451
00:23:40,950 --> 00:23:42,560
But we'll cheat around that a little bit.

452
00:23:45,410 --> 00:23:46,720
So let me just elevate my privileges.

453
00:23:46,720 --> 00:23:47,510
There we go.

454
00:23:47,510 --> 00:23:50,920
Inside of that, you'll see this
Clustert.pg and a backup file.

455
00:23:50,920 --> 00:23:53,490
And the Wikiposts
are actually being stored

456
00:23:53,490 --> 00:23:56,750
inside of that database file
already inside of there.

457
00:23:56,750 --> 00:23:58,091
And that's what the information is.

458
00:23:58,091 --> 00:23:59,972
So, we don't see them as raw files.

459
00:23:59,972 --> 00:24:02,608
And the idea is,
that these can quickly be queried and

460
00:24:02,608 --> 00:24:04,314
pulled right out of the database.

461
00:24:04,314 --> 00:24:07,133
And people aren't supposed to
be editing the files anyway,

462
00:24:07,133 --> 00:24:09,710
they're using that WYSIWYG
editor on the page.

463
00:24:09,710 --> 00:24:14,280
So, if it comes up on the exam,
that's what you've got.

464
00:24:14,280 --> 00:24:18,470
As far as logging, there's not really
much to deal with on the Wiki side.

465
00:24:18,470 --> 00:24:21,860
If I go back to my server app and
I jump up to Logs,

466
00:24:21,860 --> 00:24:26,600
when we look inside of the log services,
if we pull up that big list and

467
00:24:26,600 --> 00:24:30,160
kinda look around, you'll notice
Wiki does have several entries.

468
00:24:30,160 --> 00:24:32,830
And that's because they've divided up,
not just things like errors,

469
00:24:32,830 --> 00:24:36,720
which actually come under the Apache logs,
under the website logs.

470
00:24:36,720 --> 00:24:39,620
But they come under these other ones for
Collaboration,

471
00:24:39,620 --> 00:24:42,950
Notification, Preview Generator and
Wiki Admin.

472
00:24:42,950 --> 00:24:45,380
These are all the different
activities people take.

473
00:24:45,380 --> 00:24:49,610
When you post content, that's your
collaboration demon firing off.

474
00:24:49,610 --> 00:24:52,594
And so, here we can see where we
started to post some of those things.

475
00:24:52,594 --> 00:24:58,200
We got that long timer right there,
that's when that save stalled out on me.

476
00:24:58,200 --> 00:25:00,210
But you'll see that information in here.

477
00:25:00,210 --> 00:25:01,800
It's useful for troubleshooting.

478
00:25:01,800 --> 00:25:04,640
You've also got this
preview generator log.

479
00:25:04,640 --> 00:25:07,880
If somebody uploads files into the Wiki,
when you

480
00:25:07,880 --> 00:25:10,650
click on it you can actually see a preview
of the file without downloading it.

481
00:25:10,650 --> 00:25:14,725
So we'll see an information right in
there and you get a chance to see it and

482
00:25:14,725 --> 00:25:17,700
just kinda verify that those
previews are working properly.

483
00:25:17,700 --> 00:25:20,060
And then, we've got our notifications.

484
00:25:20,060 --> 00:25:21,930
So here we just got posting notifications.

485
00:25:21,930 --> 00:25:26,640
It's various information that's useful for
troubleshooting.

486
00:25:26,640 --> 00:25:29,790
All right but that's basically it for
the Wiki service, it's not very complex,

487
00:25:29,790 --> 00:25:32,720
it's kinda neat compared to
other services out there.

488
00:25:32,720 --> 00:25:36,170
I know I mentioned SharePoint earlier,
this Wiki service is

489
00:25:36,170 --> 00:25:39,850
far easier to get running than
trying to deal with one of those.

490
00:25:39,850 --> 00:25:41,120
If you're doing blogging,

491
00:25:41,120 --> 00:25:44,390
the Wiki service is not really
the greatest blogging platform out there.

492
00:25:44,390 --> 00:25:47,220
I know a lot of people that will
use the websites functionality and

493
00:25:47,220 --> 00:25:48,680
deploy WordPress in it.

494
00:25:48,680 --> 00:25:51,540
And so you could use WordPress for
your blogging platform instead.

495
00:25:51,540 --> 00:25:52,640
That's fine.

496
00:25:52,640 --> 00:25:54,240
But you're not gonna see
WordPress on the exam.

497
00:25:54,240 --> 00:25:56,350
So they do want you to know this one and
be aware of it.

498
00:25:57,510 --> 00:26:00,190
All right, well that's a good point for
us to wrap this episode up.

499
00:26:00,190 --> 00:26:04,530
Let me remind you guys, if you have any
questions on this always feel free to ask.

500
00:26:04,530 --> 00:26:07,510
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live and

501
00:26:07,510 --> 00:26:09,550
you'll see the chat
room beneath the video.

502
00:26:09,550 --> 00:26:12,860
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

503
00:26:12,860 --> 00:26:15,295
If you have questions after the show,
use our forums.

504
00:26:15,295 --> 00:26:19,410
Hit that Q and A link found on
every page on the itprotv site.

505
00:26:19,410 --> 00:26:22,260
It'll take you to the forums, you can
post your questions there, we monitor and

506
00:26:22,260 --> 00:26:23,300
answer after the show.

507
00:26:23,300 --> 00:26:26,180
Take advantage of those resources,
they are there for you.

508
00:26:26,180 --> 00:26:30,654
All right, well I hope you guys enjoyed
today's episode, signing off for ITProTV,

509
00:26:30,654 --> 00:26:33,029
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

510
00:26:33,029 --> 00:26:43,029

episodes.title: Mail
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,207 --> 00:00:23,125
[NOISE]

3
00:00:23,125 --> 00:00:33,271
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,271 --> 00:00:35,881
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

5
00:00:35,881 --> 00:00:38,070
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,070 --> 00:00:39,480
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

7
00:00:39,480 --> 00:00:43,740
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Technician Coordinator.

8
00:00:43,740 --> 00:00:46,710
Today we're gonna be
jumping into a neat topic,

9
00:00:46,710 --> 00:00:50,980
which is setting up the mail server
on top of the server app in OS10.

10
00:00:50,980 --> 00:00:53,260
Now, I say this one's neat.

11
00:00:53,260 --> 00:00:54,510
You've watched some of our episodes.

12
00:00:54,510 --> 00:00:57,270
You've seen where most of the services
in the server app are really just

13
00:00:57,270 --> 00:00:58,790
switching that on switch, and that's it.

14
00:00:58,790 --> 00:01:01,050
And it turns on a single service.

15
00:01:01,050 --> 00:01:03,330
Well, in the mail service,

16
00:01:03,330 --> 00:01:08,070
when you turn on that mail server, it's
actually launching quite a few different

17
00:01:08,070 --> 00:01:13,010
little services that each provide
individual components of an email server.

18
00:01:13,010 --> 00:01:16,120
And all combined,
you get a pretty robust mail server.

19
00:01:16,120 --> 00:01:19,860
Now, it's not the be-all end-all with mail
servers, there are higher end products

20
00:01:19,860 --> 00:01:22,640
that are out there, but for
most companies, especially small and

21
00:01:22,640 --> 00:01:27,030
medium businesses, the mail server
built into the OS X Server app, it's

22
00:01:27,030 --> 00:01:30,620
actually pretty adequate and it knocks
out most of people's' needs, all right?

23
00:01:30,620 --> 00:01:33,680
Now, I say it's pretty adequate which
is kinda a bad things to say, but

24
00:01:33,680 --> 00:01:36,890
there's little things that are missing
from it, things like web based email,

25
00:01:36,890 --> 00:01:40,920
a lot of people expect to have that and
the OS X Server app doesn't give you that.

26
00:01:40,920 --> 00:01:43,860
But it does give you
a ton of other features.

27
00:01:43,860 --> 00:01:47,650
It gives you things like POP3 and
IMAP4 access.

28
00:01:47,650 --> 00:01:50,970
It gives us anti-spam, anti-virus.

29
00:01:50,970 --> 00:01:53,310
It gives us forwarding capabilities.

30
00:01:53,310 --> 00:01:56,590
It gives us all sorts of neat and
interesting functions.

31
00:01:56,590 --> 00:01:59,620
And it does that by combining
a number of different products.

32
00:01:59,620 --> 00:02:02,230
So let's talk about each one of
those before we actually dive in and

33
00:02:02,230 --> 00:02:03,580
get this service up and running.

34
00:02:03,580 --> 00:02:06,330
So when we turn on a mail server,

35
00:02:06,330 --> 00:02:09,120
there's some basic functions
that we've got to have.

36
00:02:09,120 --> 00:02:11,650
We've gotta have the ability
to send email, right,

37
00:02:11,650 --> 00:02:13,980
to get our outgoing email
to go to other people.

38
00:02:13,980 --> 00:02:16,530
And we have to have
the ability to receive email.

39
00:02:16,530 --> 00:02:18,090
To get that email in.

40
00:02:18,090 --> 00:02:23,160
And email has become such a critical
function, that we need this to be stable.

41
00:02:23,160 --> 00:02:25,300
Now, a lot of people look at it and
they say,

42
00:02:25,300 --> 00:02:27,440
you know what,
I'm just gonna use a cloud service.

43
00:02:27,440 --> 00:02:29,410
I don't want to deal
with my own mail server.

44
00:02:29,410 --> 00:02:34,180
It's actually what we did with ITPRO TV
is when we started this company we said,

45
00:02:34,180 --> 00:02:37,110
we can run our own mail server,
but we're kind of busy,

46
00:02:37,110 --> 00:02:39,730
and don't have a lot of time to deal
with maintaining our own equipment.

47
00:02:39,730 --> 00:02:42,810
So why don't we just use Google apps for
work.

48
00:02:42,810 --> 00:02:44,672
Or you might say,
why don't we just iCloud or

49
00:02:44,672 --> 00:02:46,390
any whatever other service is out there.

50
00:02:46,390 --> 00:02:47,230
And you can certainly do that.

51
00:02:47,230 --> 00:02:48,690
A lot of people opt for it.

52
00:02:48,690 --> 00:02:52,590
But there's still plenty of reasons for
running your own mail server.

53
00:02:52,590 --> 00:02:54,570
One of the biggest reasons?

54
00:02:54,570 --> 00:02:55,720
Security.

55
00:02:55,720 --> 00:02:57,890
When you outsource your email hosting,

56
00:02:57,890 --> 00:03:02,360
when you trust it to iCloud, or trust it
to Google apps or somebody else like that,

57
00:03:02,360 --> 00:03:05,750
you're trusting that they're putting
the proper security measures in.

58
00:03:05,750 --> 00:03:10,330
That they're keeping your data private and
taking backups and

59
00:03:10,330 --> 00:03:12,780
providing redundant hardware to keep
the systems available and online.

60
00:03:12,780 --> 00:03:14,750
And for the most part, they do.

61
00:03:14,750 --> 00:03:16,220
But you're trusting that.

62
00:03:16,220 --> 00:03:19,730
And unfortunately, in some industries,
you can't afford that trust, right.

63
00:03:19,730 --> 00:03:22,350
If you're in the financial industry,
or the medical industry if you're

64
00:03:22,350 --> 00:03:26,360
transmitting patient records, you can't
trust a third party to host your email.

65
00:03:26,360 --> 00:03:28,190
So, you need to host your own, right.

66
00:03:28,190 --> 00:03:30,870
So, the first reason is security.

67
00:03:30,870 --> 00:03:32,840
The second reason is control.

68
00:03:32,840 --> 00:03:36,440
If you wanna be able to control every
aspect of that server like setting mailbox

69
00:03:36,440 --> 00:03:37,300
size limits and so

70
00:03:37,300 --> 00:03:40,980
on, a lot of that you can't do when
you send it out to a third party.

71
00:03:40,980 --> 00:03:42,650
You're letting them control it.

72
00:03:42,650 --> 00:03:44,680
So if you need control of
your mail environment.

73
00:03:44,680 --> 00:03:45,880
Well, you'll want to host your own server.

74
00:03:45,880 --> 00:03:50,370
And then the last reason is
if you've got low bandwidth.

75
00:03:50,370 --> 00:03:52,900
There's a lot of
organizations out there that

76
00:03:52,900 --> 00:03:55,350
don't have a ton of
bandwidth in their company.

77
00:03:55,350 --> 00:03:58,370
So, if you've got 100 employees and
they're all backed

78
00:03:58,370 --> 00:04:02,390
behind a single DSL line, if you're using
hosted email on the internet, they're

79
00:04:02,390 --> 00:04:05,940
all going out to the internet to get their
email and that effects your bandwidth.

80
00:04:05,940 --> 00:04:08,300
Versus if you had a server
right there in house,

81
00:04:08,300 --> 00:04:11,020
everybody would just be hitting that
server, and the only time they'd be using

82
00:04:11,020 --> 00:04:13,520
your bandwidth is when they receive or
send an email.

83
00:04:13,520 --> 00:04:16,910
All the other things,
the internal email, all stays internal.

84
00:04:16,910 --> 00:04:20,250
So those are three reasons why you might
choose to run your own mail server.

85
00:04:20,250 --> 00:04:21,990
And if you're gonna run
your own mail server,

86
00:04:21,990 --> 00:04:26,180
there's a lot of choices out there, but
Apple's kind of made it easy for us.

87
00:04:26,180 --> 00:04:29,740
If you've ever set up a mail server on
a Linux environment, it's a lot of work

88
00:04:29,740 --> 00:04:32,760
getting all the different components
together, Apple's already done that.

89
00:04:33,940 --> 00:04:39,610
The first component that they use is
a software package called Postfix,

90
00:04:39,610 --> 00:04:42,190
and Postfix is an SMTP server.

91
00:04:42,190 --> 00:04:46,160
Now SMTP, that's
the Simple Mail Transport Protocol, and

92
00:04:46,160 --> 00:04:49,580
it's designed to move
e-mail between servers.

93
00:04:49,580 --> 00:04:53,480
SMTP is the protocol we
used when we send email.

94
00:04:53,480 --> 00:04:55,820
So when you write an email and
you click that send button,

95
00:04:55,820 --> 00:05:00,830
you transmit that email to your local
server, and your server then uses SMTP

96
00:05:00,830 --> 00:05:05,235
to reach out and get to that destination
server and send the email along.

97
00:05:05,235 --> 00:05:07,960
Postfix is what provides that, right?

98
00:05:07,960 --> 00:05:09,300
But what about our clients?

99
00:05:09,300 --> 00:05:11,050
Our clients need to get email.

100
00:05:11,050 --> 00:05:15,010
So they're running the Apple mail client
or they're running Thunderbird or

101
00:05:15,010 --> 00:05:17,520
they're running Microsoft Outlook or
whatever it is they're using and

102
00:05:17,520 --> 00:05:19,040
they wanna access their email.

103
00:05:19,040 --> 00:05:22,570
Well SMTP is not designed for
client access.

104
00:05:22,570 --> 00:05:25,010
For client access we use
two different protocols.

105
00:05:25,010 --> 00:05:29,130
POP3, which is the Post Office Protocol
version three, and IMAP4,

106
00:05:29,130 --> 00:05:31,290
I always forget this one here.

107
00:05:31,290 --> 00:05:33,540
It's the internet Messaging,
I've got it in my show notes here so

108
00:05:33,540 --> 00:05:37,490
I don't have remember,
Internet Message Access Protocol.

109
00:05:37,490 --> 00:05:38,910
There we go.

110
00:05:38,910 --> 00:05:42,450
So I'm at four and property,
those are the two main client protocols.

111
00:05:42,450 --> 00:05:46,750
And so to provide that function,
Apple leverages something called Dovecote.

112
00:05:46,750 --> 00:05:51,320
Dovecote is an open source pop server.

113
00:05:51,320 --> 00:05:54,600
You can run that in
combination with Postfix, and

114
00:05:54,600 --> 00:05:57,650
now you've got the ability to send email,
as well as the ability for

115
00:05:57,650 --> 00:06:00,720
clients to access and receive their email,
who get that full functionality.

116
00:06:02,080 --> 00:06:06,270
Now, in addition to sending and receiving
email, we need some basic security, right.

117
00:06:06,270 --> 00:06:09,330
We need the ability to make sure that
we don't have viruses in our email, and

118
00:06:09,330 --> 00:06:10,880
that we're not getting a ton of spam.

119
00:06:10,880 --> 00:06:13,710
And so,
Apple packages in two more products.

120
00:06:13,710 --> 00:06:16,405
They package in ClamAV for
doing the anti-virus.

121
00:06:16,405 --> 00:06:19,080
That's an open-source anti-virus
product that's out there.

122
00:06:19,080 --> 00:06:21,560
And, they package in SpamAssassin.

123
00:06:21,560 --> 00:06:24,300
Now, it's a silly name, but
SpamAssassin is the most

124
00:06:24,300 --> 00:06:29,440
widely used anti-spam service in the world
and it's another open source package.

125
00:06:29,440 --> 00:06:32,750
They have combined that and
pre-configured it for us.

126
00:06:32,750 --> 00:06:34,710
Again, if you've ever tried
to configure spam assessment,

127
00:06:34,710 --> 00:06:39,580
it's not the easiest thing in the world,
Apple's done that for us.

128
00:06:39,580 --> 00:06:41,460
Now I've listed four
main components there.

129
00:06:41,460 --> 00:06:43,290
There's actually about
12 components in total.

130
00:06:43,290 --> 00:06:46,750
There's all sorts of little tiny pieces
that get thrown into the picture, too.

131
00:06:46,750 --> 00:06:48,140
But those are the four big ones.

132
00:06:48,140 --> 00:06:49,750
Those are the ones that
might show up on the exam.

133
00:06:49,750 --> 00:06:52,620
So you need to be aware of what those
components are in the background that's

134
00:06:52,620 --> 00:06:53,830
actually powering this.

135
00:06:53,830 --> 00:06:55,860
Because at the end of the day,
when we go to configure it,

136
00:06:55,860 --> 00:06:58,380
we just hit the on switch,
and now we're a mail server.

137
00:06:58,380 --> 00:07:01,300
We don't realize these four components are
running in the background, but they are,

138
00:07:01,300 --> 00:07:04,200
and they're doing that work, and
they're making that server function.

139
00:07:05,970 --> 00:07:07,520
All right, now I mentioned Pop3 and

140
00:07:07,520 --> 00:07:10,460
iMac, and
how they're both client access protocols.

141
00:07:10,460 --> 00:07:14,020
Clients can use that to get connected
to the server and access their email.

142
00:07:14,020 --> 00:07:16,170
Well, why two protocols?

143
00:07:16,170 --> 00:07:19,880
Well, each one functions a little
bit different, and it's up to your

144
00:07:19,880 --> 00:07:23,390
end users or if you use an administrator,
to determine which one you prefer.

145
00:07:23,390 --> 00:07:23,950
All right?
So

146
00:07:23,950 --> 00:07:26,000
let's kind of recap
the difference between the two,

147
00:07:26,000 --> 00:07:28,220
cuz it is important to know for the exam.

148
00:07:28,220 --> 00:07:29,950
POP3, the Post Office Protocol.

149
00:07:29,950 --> 00:07:32,200
That's the older of the two protocols, and

150
00:07:32,200 --> 00:07:35,800
it's really the original client
access protocol that most of us use.

151
00:07:35,800 --> 00:07:40,320
With POP3 your email client,
we'll just assume your running Apple Mail.

152
00:07:40,320 --> 00:07:44,430
Apple Mail will reach out to the mail
server and it'll go to your inbox,

153
00:07:44,430 --> 00:07:45,330
your mailbox.

154
00:07:45,330 --> 00:07:49,403
And it'll look for any new email in
the mailbox and if there's email in there,

155
00:07:49,403 --> 00:07:53,308
it will download the mail to your client
and then delete it from the server.

156
00:07:53,308 --> 00:07:57,163
And so email is downloaded and
now it's gone from the server and

157
00:07:57,163 --> 00:08:00,378
You just have it locally and
that's it, all right?

158
00:08:00,378 --> 00:08:06,510
On a positive side, POP gives us
a very fast and optimized server.

159
00:08:06,510 --> 00:08:08,290
That's why this was the original protocol.

160
00:08:08,290 --> 00:08:12,290
If your server is storing everybody's
email forever, those mailboxes get bigger

161
00:08:12,290 --> 00:08:16,230
and bigger and bigger and the server
gets slower and slower and slower and

162
00:08:16,230 --> 00:08:20,820
that was a real problem in the 1980's and
even somewhat in the early 1990's.

163
00:08:20,820 --> 00:08:24,790
But as time has gone on, servers,
they aren't slow like that anymore and

164
00:08:24,790 --> 00:08:27,120
they can handle massive email databases.

165
00:08:27,120 --> 00:08:29,460
So it's not such a big deal.

166
00:08:29,460 --> 00:08:33,520
One of the negatives of downloading
the email and deleting it from the server,

167
00:08:33,520 --> 00:08:36,210
is if I download the email right
here on my laptop, also, and

168
00:08:36,210 --> 00:08:39,790
I have a desktop also,
the desktop never gets the email.

169
00:08:39,790 --> 00:08:40,990
Right?
It's been deleted from the server.

170
00:08:40,990 --> 00:08:42,430
The desktop doesn't know about it.

171
00:08:42,430 --> 00:08:45,180
And so as I move from machine, to machine,
to machine I've got a problem.

172
00:08:45,180 --> 00:08:47,200
And if I lose my laptop and

173
00:08:47,200 --> 00:08:49,890
I don't have a good backup,
the email's not on the server anymore.

174
00:08:49,890 --> 00:08:51,660
I just lost all my email.

175
00:08:51,660 --> 00:08:54,310
So that's where IMAP comes in.

176
00:08:54,310 --> 00:08:56,130
IMAP is a lot more advanced.

177
00:08:56,130 --> 00:08:59,990
With IMAP, you don't just download
the email to your local machine, but

178
00:08:59,990 --> 00:09:01,760
you leave a copy on the server.

179
00:09:01,760 --> 00:09:03,430
In fact, when a new email comes in,

180
00:09:03,430 --> 00:09:05,830
most IMAP clients will
just download the header.

181
00:09:05,830 --> 00:09:08,370
You get the subject line and
who it's from and who it's to and

182
00:09:08,370 --> 00:09:12,150
it's not until you open the email that it
actually downloads it from the server.

183
00:09:12,150 --> 00:09:15,270
Even then, it leaves a copy on the server.

184
00:09:15,270 --> 00:09:18,950
If you mark it red in your mail client,
it's now marked red on the server, too.

185
00:09:18,950 --> 00:09:24,030
If you go to another desktop and
log in, the email's already marked red.

186
00:09:24,030 --> 00:09:25,340
IMAP's a lot more powerful.

187
00:09:25,340 --> 00:09:26,770
But it leaves the emails on the server,

188
00:09:26,770 --> 00:09:29,140
which means the servers
database is gonna get bigger.

189
00:09:29,140 --> 00:09:33,100
That was bad in the 1980's and 1990's,
but we're talking about 20 years ago.

190
00:09:33,100 --> 00:09:36,070
So, in today's world,
that's normally the standard.

191
00:09:36,070 --> 00:09:40,080
So, if your gonna be setting up
a mail server, count on using IMAP.

192
00:09:40,080 --> 00:09:42,570
Another big advantage you get
with IMAP is you can create

193
00:09:42,570 --> 00:09:44,750
folders inside of your mailboxes.

194
00:09:44,750 --> 00:09:46,960
I use the heck out of
folders in my mailboxes.

195
00:09:46,960 --> 00:09:48,260
I've got tons of folders.

196
00:09:48,260 --> 00:09:51,870
And the really important to me, I would
have a hard time getting away from that.

197
00:09:51,870 --> 00:09:55,960
With POP, all of your email is lumped
into one big folder, and that's it.

198
00:09:55,960 --> 00:09:59,370
In IMAP you can create all sorts of
different folders, and you can categorize

199
00:09:59,370 --> 00:10:02,880
your emails and sort them and it really
helps you keep that mailbox under control.

200
00:10:02,880 --> 00:10:05,860
So, IMAP has a lot more
to offer than POP and so

201
00:10:05,860 --> 00:10:06,990
that's usually what we're going to use.

202
00:10:06,990 --> 00:10:08,430
We're usually going to use IMAP.

203
00:10:08,430 --> 00:10:09,650
But the POP support is there.

204
00:10:09,650 --> 00:10:10,540
That kind of gives us both.

205
00:10:12,020 --> 00:10:15,430
All right, so
when I go to setup a mail server,

I need to understand the different

then we have some little configurations

00:10:25,590 --> 00:10:29,615
And then I have to figure out whether I
want my clients to connect via POP or

00:10:29,615 --> 00:10:30,850
IMAP.

00:10:30,850 --> 00:10:35,200
Once I've got those decisions made,

00:10:35,740 --> 00:10:39,430
Now, one of the interesting things about

an internal server for internal use only,

00:10:43,350 --> 00:10:46,770

00:10:46,770 --> 00:10:50,030

basically recreate that environment

00:11:03,510 --> 00:11:09,260

00:11:09,260 --> 00:11:09,840

00:11:09,840 --> 00:11:12,730

00:11:15,600 --> 00:11:20,290

00:11:20,290 --> 00:11:21,710
It may be your own mail server.

00:11:21,710 --> 00:11:25,550
It might be an ISP's mail server, but

00:11:25,550 --> 00:11:29,680

00:11:29,680 --> 00:11:34,515
I'm sending this email,
it's from me, bob@aol.com, and

00:11:34,515 --> 00:11:37,550
it's to don@itpro.tv.

00:11:37,550 --> 00:11:40,290
So the mail server gets
a copy of that email, and

233
00:11:40,290 --> 00:11:43,140
now the mail server says all right,
well I've got to deliver this to Don.

00:11:43,140 --> 00:11:44,900
How do I get to Don?

00:11:44,900 --> 00:11:46,320
How do I find that?

00:11:46,320 --> 00:11:48,340
Well, it uses DNS.

00:11:48,340 --> 00:11:50,070
And specifically inside of DNS,

00:11:50,070 --> 00:11:54,190
it uses what's called a MX record,

239
00:11:54,190 --> 00:11:57,270
In order for
your mail server to work on the Internet,

240
00:11:57,270 --> 00:11:59,730
you're going to have to have
a mail exchange record.

00:11:59,730 --> 00:12:02,120
Let me show you what would happen

00:12:02,120 --> 00:12:03,390
Let me fire up my terminal here.

00:12:04,690 --> 00:12:05,910

So if you're gonna browse through our

If you try and send an email to that web

It doesn't care about that.

00:13:02,390 --> 00:13:04,840
And that's because your normal web lookup,
or

00:13:04,840 --> 00:13:07,850
your normal DNS lookup is just looking for

00:13:07,850 --> 00:13:10,230
It's not really paying

00:13:10,230 --> 00:13:15,460
But if it's email we can tell it, hey,

00:13:48,830 --> 00:13:49,390

When you send an email to me,

It does the MX record lookup, and

00:14:06,000 --> 00:14:08,650
So you're a mail server that's sitting
there with an email trying to figure out

00:14:08,650 --> 00:14:09,150
how to deliver it.

285
00:14:09,150 --> 00:14:13,500
It knows that it can send the email
to any of these five servers, and

00:14:13,500 --> 00:14:14,000
it'll get to me.

00:14:14,000 --> 00:14:15,350
All right.

00:14:15,350 --> 00:14:16,070
And then it will.

00:14:16,070 --> 00:14:18,480
It'll go over to Google and
then when I check my email next,

00:14:18,480 --> 00:14:20,860
I'll have that email sitting right there,

291
00:14:20,860 --> 00:14:23,500
Now, that MX record is

292
00:14:23,500 --> 00:14:27,460
So if you bring up a mail server, and
you don't define an MX record to let

00:14:27,460 --> 00:14:31,190

you're only gonna have internal email.

294
00:14:31,190 --> 00:14:34,870
And likely, your outgoing email will work,

00:14:34,870 --> 00:14:36,950
People won't be able to send you email.

00:14:36,950 --> 00:14:40,130
So setting up an MX record
is really important,

00:14:40,130 --> 00:14:41,730
now, you'll see where

00:14:41,730 --> 00:14:42,890
Why do we have five?

00:14:42,890 --> 00:14:47,820
Well, usually it's either for
low balancing or redundancy.

00:14:47,820 --> 00:14:51,040
When you create a mail exchanger

00:14:51,040 --> 00:14:53,400
that's this number right here, a priority.

00:14:53,400 --> 00:14:57,190
And the priority is defining

00:14:57,190 --> 00:15:01,240
The lower the number,

00:15:01,240 --> 00:15:03,730
So, while I've got five servers listed,

00:15:03,730 --> 00:15:07,740

00:15:15,970 --> 00:15:19,720
If you can't get to that, though,

00:15:30,620 --> 00:15:32,340

00:15:32,340 --> 00:15:36,020

00:15:36,020 --> 00:15:39,720
It's gonna rotate those records back and
forth as people do the queries, and

00:15:39,720 --> 00:15:43,640

00:15:43,640 --> 00:15:46,823
It creates like a,

00:15:49,975 --> 00:15:52,055
see where that had a priority of 30, and

00:15:52,055 --> 00:15:55,753
there's two of those two and

00:15:55,753 --> 00:15:58,029
Now for most people you're not going

Right.

and you can end up with tons of data on
your drive, and you might not want that.

1057
00:52:27,260 --> 00:52:29,370
Users don't delete e-mail by default.

1058
00:52:29,370 --> 00:52:31,310
It's just not what they do in their minds.

1059
00:52:31,310 --> 00:52:35,690
So, if you wanna force them to have
mailboxes that are small, you set a limit.

1060
00:52:35,690 --> 00:52:37,810
Now you might ask yourself,
why would I wanna set a limit?

1061
00:52:38,830 --> 00:52:40,830
Hard drive space is cheap these days, so

1062
00:52:40,830 --> 00:52:43,720
most people don't really care
about how big your mailbox is.

1063
00:52:43,720 --> 00:52:48,200
But from an administrative standpoint,
the bigger the mailboxes are,

1064
00:52:48,200 --> 00:52:49,710
the longer it takes to back them up.

1065
00:52:49,710 --> 00:52:53,570
And if you have a failure,
the longer it takes to restore them.

1066
00:52:53,570 --> 00:52:57,150
So if you're trying to keep a short backup
window, and you're trying to keep a short

1067
00:52:57,150 --> 00:53:01,280
restore window, then you need
those mailboxes to be smaller.

1068
00:53:01,280 --> 00:53:05,450
And so you can set a limit; maybe
I set it to 500 megabytes, or

1069
00:53:05,450 --> 00:53:07,030
I can set it to a gigabyte,
1000 megabytes.

1070
00:53:08,360 --> 00:53:11,590
Now, if a user's mailbox
grows to that size,

1071
00:53:11,590 --> 00:53:13,500
they'll stop being able to receive e-mail.

1072
00:53:13,500 --> 00:53:17,870
On a positive side, they've capped their
mailbox, they'll get warning messages, so

1073
00:53:17,870 --> 00:53:18,510
they'll know about it.

1074
00:53:18,510 --> 00:53:20,190
They can go in and delete stuff.

1075
00:53:20,190 --> 00:53:23,860
But on a negative side, if I'm a business,
I might be losing orders,

1076
00:53:23,860 --> 00:53:26,150
I might be losing
important communications.

1077
00:53:26,150 --> 00:53:28,920
So a lot of people don't like to
implement these limits, because of that.

1078
00:53:28,920 --> 00:53:31,210
You know, it's more important
that they get the e-mail,

1079
00:53:31,210 --> 00:53:32,960
then maintain a slim server.

1080
00:53:32,960 --> 00:53:35,810
And what you can do, is you can watch the
files on the hard drive to see who's got

1081
00:53:35,810 --> 00:53:38,720
a really big mailbox, and reach out,
and talk to them specifically.

1082
00:53:38,720 --> 00:53:43,150
But the big culprit is people use e-mail,
as a way of exchanging files.

1083
00:53:43,150 --> 00:53:46,030
So they do file attachments,
and your mailbox ends up huge.

1084
00:53:46,030 --> 00:53:48,150
If people were just to put
text in their e-mails, and

1085
00:53:48,150 --> 00:53:51,870
that's it,
nobody's mailbox should be over 200 megs.

1086
00:53:51,870 --> 00:53:56,500
One, I think it was the, I read a long
time ago, that if you took the entire

1087
00:53:56,500 --> 00:54:01,370
Encyclopedia Britannica, the whole thing,
and you wrote out just the text into

1088
00:54:01,370 --> 00:54:05,940
a file from those encyclopedias, it would
fit in about one and a half megabytes.

1089
00:54:05,940 --> 00:54:07,100
A fairly small amount of space.

1090
00:54:07,100 --> 00:54:10,690
So how many e-mails would that take to
equal out the Encyclopedia Britannica?

1091
00:54:10,690 --> 00:54:12,000
It'd take a lot.

1092
00:54:12,000 --> 00:54:17,320
But people attach images, they do HTML
e-mails, they do file attachments, PDFs.

1093
00:54:17,320 --> 00:54:18,130
Things like that.

1094
00:54:18,130 --> 00:54:20,430
And then,
mailboxes really start to get pretty big.

1095
00:54:20,430 --> 00:54:23,420
So this is where we can set that limit,
and cap it.

1096
00:54:23,420 --> 00:54:25,970
Just be aware if you set a limit,
and a user hits it,

1097
00:54:25,970 --> 00:54:27,990
they won't be able to receive email.

1098
00:54:27,990 --> 00:54:29,700
And they might lose
stuff that's important.

1099
00:54:29,700 --> 00:54:30,710
So we've gotta be careful with that.

1100
00:54:32,170 --> 00:54:37,290
Now, if any of you guys are old
school Server app users,

1101
00:54:37,290 --> 00:54:40,010
you might remember some screens
from previous versions of Mac OS,

1102
00:54:40,010 --> 00:54:41,810
where there was some advanced
functionality in here,

1103
00:54:41,810 --> 00:54:45,760
you could set different users, could have
different quotas, Apple's removed that.

1104
00:54:45,760 --> 00:54:48,970
And the main reason,
was not very many people used it.

1105
00:54:48,970 --> 00:54:52,710
So if that's a feature you rely on,
this doesn't work out so well.

1106
00:54:52,710 --> 00:54:56,080
You can still achieve that from the files
system, you can go, and set quotas there.

1107
00:54:56,080 --> 00:54:58,000
It's a lot harder to do now.

1108
00:54:58,000 --> 00:54:59,590
Apple just deprecated that feature, so

1109
00:54:59,590 --> 00:55:01,770
if you're wondering where that went,
that's what happened.

1110
00:55:01,770 --> 00:55:02,530
It's gone in.

1111
00:55:02,530 --> 00:55:07,680
Alright, but that's pretty much it for
the mail server.

1112
00:55:07,680 --> 00:55:10,980
Do I have anything else
that I want to mention?

1113
00:55:12,180 --> 00:55:16,180
Oh, the only other thing I do want to
mention, I talked about the virus scanner.

1114
00:55:16,180 --> 00:55:19,080
What happens if an e-mail has a virus?

1115
00:55:19,080 --> 00:55:22,220
Well, if it has a virus,
it actually gets quarantined, and

1116
00:55:22,220 --> 00:55:23,580
stuck in a special folder.

1117
00:55:23,580 --> 00:55:26,850
Let me show you guys that folder,
and then, we'll wrap up from there.

1118
00:55:26,850 --> 00:55:32,630
So right now,
I'm in /library/server/mail/data/mail.

1119
00:55:32,630 --> 00:55:35,400
Well, inside of that data folder,

1120
00:55:35,400 --> 00:55:40,230
there's another folder called Scanner,
and that's the virus scanner.

1121
00:55:40,230 --> 00:55:41,800
And if we go into scanner,

1122
00:55:41,800 --> 00:55:44,900
which is probably not gonna let me,
no, nobody let me in there.

1123
00:55:44,900 --> 00:55:48,730
Inside a scanner, that's where I can see,
there's ClamAV, there's SpamAssassin,

1124
00:55:48,730 --> 00:55:52,290
and the folder I'm looking for,
is this guy right here, virusmails.

1125
00:55:52,290 --> 00:55:58,260
Any email that gets flagged as a virus,
will actually get stuck here,

1126
00:55:58,260 --> 00:56:01,660
and it will sit in there for
a certain amount of time.

1127
00:56:01,660 --> 00:56:03,260
And I forget what the interval is.

1128
00:56:03,260 --> 00:56:05,550
But it'll sit in there, and
then eventually it'll get deleted.

1129
00:56:05,550 --> 00:56:08,940
But if you ever want to see, if emails
get flagged as spam, I mean not spam,

1130
00:56:08,940 --> 00:56:11,810
if they get flagged as having a virus,
you can look right in here, and

1131
00:56:11,810 --> 00:56:15,800
you'll see the email stored as files,
and it'll purge them out eventually.

1132
00:56:15,800 --> 00:56:19,470
But that's basically a quarantine area,
where those get stored.

1133
00:56:19,470 --> 00:56:21,850
I don't have any right now, so
there's nothing too exciting in there.

1134
00:56:23,340 --> 00:56:27,690
All right, key take aways here, especially
for the exam, is that the mail server,

1135
00:56:27,690 --> 00:56:32,760
is actually made up of numerous
components, Postfix, Dovecot, ClamAV,

1136
00:56:32,760 --> 00:56:35,600
Spamassassin, all preconfigured,
and ready to go.

1137
00:56:35,600 --> 00:56:37,270
We just flip an on switch.

1138
00:56:37,270 --> 00:56:40,620
Our users can connect via POP or
IMAP to get to the server, and

1139
00:56:40,620 --> 00:56:41,610
access their e-mail.

1140
00:56:41,610 --> 00:56:43,250
They send email with SMTP.

1141
00:56:43,250 --> 00:56:45,556
If you wanna receive
e-mail from the Internet,

1142
00:56:45,556 --> 00:56:47,250
you've gotta have that MX record.

1143
00:56:47,250 --> 00:56:49,300
Otherwise, Internet people
won't be able to find you.

1144
00:56:49,300 --> 00:56:54,380
And then lastly, you've got to back up
your server, people's e-mail is here.

1145
00:56:54,380 --> 00:56:55,780
You gotta make sure,
you got a good back up for that.

1146
00:56:55,780 --> 00:56:58,340
You don't want people to lose email.

1147
00:56:58,340 --> 00:56:58,980
All right.

1148
00:56:58,980 --> 00:57:01,140
And then lastly, we've got some of
those other advanced features things,

1149
00:57:01,140 --> 00:57:02,770
like the quota we just saw, and

1150
00:57:02,770 --> 00:57:06,520
the spam lists that we can configure,
the junk mail that we can tweak.

1151
00:57:06,520 --> 00:57:08,750
But all in all,
it's a pretty easy service to get going.

1152
00:57:08,750 --> 00:57:12,820
All right, well that's a pretty good
spot for me to wrap up this episode.

1153
00:57:12,820 --> 00:57:14,270
So let me just remind you guys,

1154
00:57:14,270 --> 00:57:18,900
if you have questions on this, live during
the show, you can go to itpro.tv/live,

1155
00:57:18,900 --> 00:57:22,210
you will see a chat box right beneath
the video, post your questions there.

1156
00:57:22,210 --> 00:57:23,870
We monitor and answer during the show.

1157
00:57:23,870 --> 00:57:28,470
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q and A forms at the top of

1158
00:57:28,470 --> 00:57:32,510
every page, on the itpro.tv site, you will
see a link that says Q and A, click on it.

1159
00:57:32,510 --> 00:57:34,440
It'll take you to the forums,
you can post your questions there.

1160
00:57:34,440 --> 00:57:36,980
We monitor and
answer after the show, all right?

1161
00:57:36,980 --> 00:57:39,040
It's a great way to get help,
even when we're not live.

1162
00:57:39,040 --> 00:57:40,680
Take advantage of that resource.

1163
00:57:40,680 --> 00:57:41,480
It is there for you.

1164
00:57:41,480 --> 00:57:44,450
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

1165
00:57:44,450 --> 00:57:46,633
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1166
00:57:46,633 --> 00:57:48,734
And I'll see you next time.

1167
00:57:48,734 --> 00:57:58,734
