4
00:00:33,341 --> 00:00:36,353
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening and

5
00:00:36,353 --> 00:00:38,449
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,449 --> 00:00:41,440
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with another episode of

7
00:00:41,440 --> 00:00:44,140
Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

8
00:00:44,140 --> 00:00:48,450
Today we're gonna be jumping into
the calendar service which actually

9
00:00:48,450 --> 00:00:52,210
is one of the more popular services
inside of the serve app on OS10.

10
00:00:52,210 --> 00:00:55,700
The calendar service lets us
host centralized calendars.

11
00:00:55,700 --> 00:00:57,260
And I know what you're thinking,

12
00:00:57,260 --> 00:01:01,780
I've already got calendars,
like iCloud or Google Apps, or whatever.

13
00:01:01,780 --> 00:01:06,030
And that's true, that works, but
what you'll see is the Calendar app here,

14
00:01:06,030 --> 00:01:10,170
the calendar service here, has some neat
features that make it really useful for

15
00:01:10,170 --> 00:01:11,100
businesses.

16
00:01:11,100 --> 00:01:14,230
Now as a regular end user or home user,
you probably don't care about it,

17
00:01:14,230 --> 00:01:15,530
this isn't one you're gonna use.

18
00:01:15,530 --> 00:01:18,890
But in the business environment,
centralized counters can be used for

19
00:01:18,890 --> 00:01:21,730
a lot more than just posting
which day is Memorial Day.

20
00:01:21,730 --> 00:01:22,260
Right?

21
00:01:22,260 --> 00:01:26,200
For example we can do things
like resource tracking.

22
00:01:26,200 --> 00:01:28,950
If your company has a couple
of conference rooms,

23
00:01:28,950 --> 00:01:30,620
how do you handle booking
a conference room?

24
00:01:30,620 --> 00:01:34,400
Saying, I need that conference on Tuesday,
2 PM.

25
00:01:34,400 --> 00:01:37,600
And avoiding somebody else trying
to book the same conference room.

26
00:01:37,600 --> 00:01:39,750
Well the calendar service can do that.

27
00:01:39,750 --> 00:01:43,020
So sure it gives us your basic calendar
where you see the days of the month, and

28
00:01:43,020 --> 00:01:44,530
you can put events on there.

29
00:01:44,530 --> 00:01:48,550
But it also gives you the ability to do
resource tracking, and share calendars.

30
00:01:48,550 --> 00:01:51,740
Calendars that multiple users
have access to and can work with.

31
00:01:51,740 --> 00:01:53,420
So really neat stuff.

32
00:01:53,420 --> 00:01:56,800
The availability tracker is
really kind of the shining gem.

33
00:01:56,800 --> 00:01:58,000
So, it's a neat service.

34
00:01:58,000 --> 00:01:59,890
One that you definitely
wanna take advantage of, and

35
00:01:59,890 --> 00:02:01,390
it's not that hard to get going.

36
00:02:01,390 --> 00:02:04,580
So let's take a look at that calendar
service and see what we can do with it.

37
00:02:04,580 --> 00:02:08,480
So I'm here in my server app right now,
and down here under services,

38
00:02:08,480 --> 00:02:11,220
you'll see calendar just listed
right here along with the main ones.

39
00:02:11,220 --> 00:02:12,950
And there's not a ton of options.

40
00:02:12,950 --> 00:02:16,810
In fact, there's really only
two things to configure here.

41
00:02:16,810 --> 00:02:18,910
We can turn the server on and

42
00:02:18,910 --> 00:02:21,710
we can set up whether we want
to allow invitations by email.

43
00:02:21,710 --> 00:02:24,600
Now, what is an invitation by email?

44
00:02:24,600 --> 00:02:28,190
If I create a meeting in the calendar,
it'll show up as

45
00:02:28,190 --> 00:02:31,270
an invitation on the other people's
calendar, they'll know it exists, but

46
00:02:31,270 --> 00:02:33,730
what if they're not checking
their calendar very often.

47
00:02:33,730 --> 00:02:37,080
Instead, If I invite someone to
a meeting it sends them an e-mail.

48
00:02:37,080 --> 00:02:40,490
Now, they get an e-mail
notification about that.

49
00:02:40,490 --> 00:02:43,930
That's a nice feature to have,
but in order to do that

50
00:02:43,930 --> 00:02:48,230
the calendar is going to need an e-mail
account to send these invitations from.

51
00:02:48,230 --> 00:02:51,680
So you need to create a centralized
account to generate that.

52
00:02:51,680 --> 00:02:55,320
You can create your own account, or
Apple's actually already created one for

53
00:02:55,320 --> 00:02:58,640
you, so you can use the one that's
built into the system if you want, or

54
00:02:58,640 --> 00:03:00,130
you can make your own, all right?

55
00:03:00,130 --> 00:03:03,670
If you want to make your own, you just
jump over to your user accounts here and

56
00:03:03,670 --> 00:03:07,210
set up an account that has email,
all right?

57
00:03:07,210 --> 00:03:09,970
If we're gonna use the built in one,
we're actually ready to start.

58
00:03:09,970 --> 00:03:14,020
I'm gonna go ahead and choose that,
enable invitations by email, and

59
00:03:14,020 --> 00:03:17,130
it's gonna check and see if I've
got the email server running I do.

60
00:03:17,130 --> 00:03:19,360
The account doesn't actually
have to reside on the server,

61
00:03:19,360 --> 00:03:22,500
I could have a separate mail server,
a separate service altogether, but

62
00:03:22,500 --> 00:03:26,760
at a minimum,
it's gonna check to see if it runs here.

63
00:03:26,760 --> 00:03:28,885
And then here's the account
that it's already created.

64
00:03:28,885 --> 00:03:33,560
com.apple.calendarserver@ whatever
your server name is,

65
00:03:33,560 --> 00:03:36,870
mine's osx-server1.lab.itpro.tv.

66
00:03:36,870 --> 00:03:44,220
Now that email address is not necessarily
the most user understandable, right.

67
00:03:44,220 --> 00:03:46,330
When they look at that they
don't necessarily see it.

68
00:03:46,330 --> 00:03:49,470
And so this is an area where you
might want to create your own, right.

69
00:03:49,470 --> 00:03:53,410
Create your own account, like a calendar
account, and you would punch that in here.

70
00:03:53,410 --> 00:03:57,490
So I might have
calendar@osx-server1.lab.itprotv.

71
00:03:57,490 --> 00:03:59,200
Right?
You put in whatever you need.

72
00:03:59,200 --> 00:04:02,210
On the next screen,
is where we set the credentials for it.

73
00:04:02,210 --> 00:04:06,080
So is the calendar going
to receive calendar items?

74
00:04:06,080 --> 00:04:08,420
Usually.
And so you'll specify that IMAP server.

75
00:04:08,420 --> 00:04:10,950
And you'll punch in the server name and
the password.

76
00:04:10,950 --> 00:04:13,250
If you're using the built-in account,
it goes ahead and

77
00:04:13,250 --> 00:04:14,730
autopopulates this stuff for us.

78
00:04:14,730 --> 00:04:16,870
So it's already got everything
filled in that I need.

79
00:04:16,870 --> 00:04:19,190
If you're using your own account,
you'd need to fill this data out.

80
00:04:21,270 --> 00:04:21,990
All right?

81
00:04:21,990 --> 00:04:23,800
And then the outgoing.

82
00:04:23,800 --> 00:04:24,520
This is the important one.

83
00:04:24,520 --> 00:04:27,190
If you're gonna send invites,
you need to be able send email,

84
00:04:27,190 --> 00:04:28,710
you need an SMTP server.

85
00:04:28,710 --> 00:04:31,870
And again, it'll auto populate it
if you're using the built in one.

86
00:04:31,870 --> 00:04:34,210
If you create your own,
you just fill this out, all right?

87
00:04:34,210 --> 00:04:37,540
When you send an invite,
it goes out via SMTP.

88
00:04:37,540 --> 00:04:41,490
And then as people accept the invitations,
we've got to see those invites come back

89
00:04:41,490 --> 00:04:44,030
in and that's where it uses
IMAP on the previous screen.

90
00:04:44,030 --> 00:04:46,550
So the two are basically used to
handle that invitation process.

91
00:04:48,230 --> 00:04:51,180
When that's done I can hit finish and
now I'm able to send and

92
00:04:51,180 --> 00:04:53,210
receive meeting invites via email.

93
00:04:55,340 --> 00:04:59,070
I can also set up push notifications so
when there's a new Calendar item or

94
00:04:59,070 --> 00:05:00,380
a reminder.

95
00:05:00,380 --> 00:05:04,550
I can push that out to the clients, and it
uses the Apple push notification service.

96
00:05:04,550 --> 00:05:06,160
We've seen that in other episodes.

97
00:05:06,160 --> 00:05:07,910
If you want to use that,
you just hit Edit.

98
00:05:07,910 --> 00:05:09,420
It will ask for an Apple ID.

99
00:05:09,420 --> 00:05:13,300
And it will reach out and register with
Apple, and download a certificate to use.

100
00:05:13,300 --> 00:05:17,610
Because the push notifications go through
Apple's servers, so you have to have that.

101
00:05:17,610 --> 00:05:20,140
It just requires an Apple ID,
and it doesn't cost any money.

102
00:05:20,140 --> 00:05:21,360
So it's a nice service to have.

103
00:05:23,460 --> 00:05:27,370
The rest of the screen is
dedicated to resource management.

104
00:05:27,370 --> 00:05:31,680
If I just want calendars, I can stop
right here, I can hit my on switch, and

105
00:05:31,680 --> 00:05:32,830
now I'm a calendar server.

106
00:05:32,830 --> 00:05:33,630
Done.

107
00:05:33,630 --> 00:05:34,730
Right.

108
00:05:34,730 --> 00:05:39,750
But if I want to manage resources,
things like conference rooms or

109
00:05:39,750 --> 00:05:43,900
projectors or other devices,
I'm going to need to add those resources.

110
00:05:43,900 --> 00:05:46,600
And the resources really do, they fall
under two different categories, right.

00:05:46,600 --> 00:05:48,840
Locations, these are physical places.

112
00:05:48,840 --> 00:05:50,810
Usually meeting rooms,
buildings, whatever.

113
00:05:50,810 --> 00:05:53,470
It's a physical place where you're
going to have a meeting or an event.

114
00:05:54,500 --> 00:05:59,280
A resource is typically an item,
a laptop, a projector, a white board.

115
00:05:59,280 --> 00:06:02,000
So some kind of resource that
you also need to book that you

116
00:06:02,000 --> 00:06:02,970
have limited supply of.

117
00:06:02,970 --> 00:06:04,280
All right.

118
00:06:04,280 --> 00:06:06,980
If you have a construction company,
these might be things like dump trucks and

119
00:06:06,980 --> 00:06:10,540
pay loaders If you're just an IT
company it's usually laptops,

120
00:06:10,540 --> 00:06:11,420
projectors, things like that.

121
00:06:12,670 --> 00:06:13,880
So what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna come in here and

122
00:06:13,880 --> 00:06:15,520
just add a few of these resources.

00:06:15,520 --> 00:06:17,270
I'm gonna start with some locations.

124
00:06:17,270 --> 00:06:22,260
So maybe I've got like meeting room A, and
I could punch in the physical address for

00:06:22,260 --> 00:06:26,170
that if I wanted I can delegate

00:06:26,170 --> 00:06:27,480
Now, what does that mean?

00:06:27,480 --> 00:06:30,740
Well, what it's actually
gonna do on the back end,

00:06:30,740 --> 00:06:32,530
it's gonna create a user

00:06:32,530 --> 00:06:33,330
We're not gonna see that.

00:06:33,330 --> 00:06:36,590
It's hidden from us, but there will be

00:06:36,590 --> 00:06:39,450

00:06:39,450 --> 00:06:40,730

00:06:40,730 --> 00:06:44,790

00:06:44,790 --> 00:06:48,770
see what all is booked, you'd need to

00:06:48,770 --> 00:06:52,560
And then, they would be a delegate, they

00:06:52,560 --> 00:06:55,290
So I might put myself in or somebody else.

00:06:55,290 --> 00:06:57,120
I'll just add myself as a delegate.

00:06:57,120 --> 00:06:59,470
I'm an administrator so

00:06:59,470 --> 00:07:02,219
But if I wasn't an administrator,
that's what would grant me the access.

140
00:07:03,900 --> 00:07:06,430
Then we can see how we
want to handle scheduling.

141
00:07:06,430 --> 00:07:07,760
This is important.

142
00:07:07,760 --> 00:07:10,550
when you have a meeting room or
a projector or

143
00:07:10,550 --> 00:07:14,350
something, somebody's going to invite

144
00:07:14,350 --> 00:07:16,830
I'm going to invite meeting
room A to my meeting.

145
00:07:16,830 --> 00:07:20,080
If meeting room A is available,
what happens?

146
00:07:20,080 --> 00:07:22,660
And we can say, accept all invitations.

147
00:07:22,660 --> 00:07:24,830
So if somebody invites us, just accept it.

148
00:07:24,830 --> 00:07:28,360
But that can cause problems, because if
two people are invited for the same time,

149
00:07:28,360 --> 00:07:30,020
it'll accept both of them.

150
00:07:30,020 --> 00:07:32,910
If you choose accept all invitations,
you may get duplicate bookings.

151
00:07:34,070 --> 00:07:36,600
We've also got accept invitations if free.

152
00:07:37,640 --> 00:07:40,630
If I've got free time go ahead and
accept it.

153
00:07:40,630 --> 00:07:41,580
And we'll let it book.

154
00:07:41,580 --> 00:07:44,450
Right?
That's pretty attractive for most people.

155
00:07:44,450 --> 00:07:46,650

156
00:07:46,650 --> 00:07:49,420
If we're busy,
it just ignores the invitation.

157
00:07:49,420 --> 00:07:51,570
And that's where the third
option comes in.

158
00:07:51,570 --> 00:07:54,735

159
00:07:54,735 --> 00:07:57,579
If we're busy,
don't just ignore the invitation.

160
00:07:57,579 --> 00:07:58,717
Actually decline it.

161
00:07:58,717 --> 00:08:00,818
Respond back so the other person knows.

162
00:08:00,818 --> 00:08:03,523
You can't use Meeting Room A,
you need to find a different meeting room.

163
00:08:03,523 --> 00:08:05,640
That's the default, and
that's usually the best option.

164
00:08:06,650 --> 00:08:08,630
But there's one other problem, all right?

165
00:08:08,630 --> 00:08:12,910
What if I work in the mailroom, right?

166
00:08:12,910 --> 00:08:16,620
I'm a mail clerk at the company, and I
book Meeting Room A for some kind of phone

167
00:08:16,620 --> 00:08:21,480

the company needs that meeting room.

168
00:08:21,480 --> 00:08:26,050
Well if I booked it first I've got it,
and it shows as busy for the CEO.

169
00:08:26,050 --> 00:08:28,370
So, there's no way for
the CEO to override that,

170
00:08:28,370 --> 00:08:30,910
they'd have to go to whoever
the delegate of that calendar is.

171
00:08:30,910 --> 00:08:35,480
So instead, we might want to
require delegate approval.

172
00:08:35,480 --> 00:08:37,560
And that would, say if somebody
tries to book Meeting Room A,

173
00:08:38,700 --> 00:08:41,470
whoever's the delegate would
have to open this calendar and

174
00:08:41,470 --> 00:08:43,160
accept the invitation or decline it.

175
00:08:43,160 --> 00:08:47,020
And that allows them to set priorities and
say, well, the CEO's invitation is more

176
00:08:47,020 --> 00:08:51,710

177
00:08:51,710 --> 00:08:54,980
We've also got declines,
Decline Invitations If Busy,

178
00:08:54,980 --> 00:08:56,280
Decline All Invitations.

179
00:08:56,280 --> 00:09:01,270
Decline All Invitations means we will
only do manual booking of this resource.

180
00:09:01,270 --> 00:09:05,640
Decline Invitations If Busy means if we're
busy, we just reject it out of hand.

181
00:09:05,640 --> 00:09:09,800
If we are not busy, the invitation
comes in and sits there and waits for

182
00:09:09,800 --> 00:09:13,730

similar to Require Delegate Approval.

183
00:09:13,730 --> 00:09:14,743
The differences is,

184
00:09:14,743 --> 00:09:18,760
Require Delegate Approval doesn't
decline invites if it's busy, right?

185
00:09:18,760 --> 00:09:22,700
So, the two options that
are the most common, Accept If Free,

186
00:09:22,700 --> 00:09:26,180
Decline If Busy,
that's a fully automated method.

187
00:09:26,180 --> 00:09:30,560
Or, Decline Invitations If Busy,
that's like a moderated method.

188
00:09:30,560 --> 00:09:33,710
You can still accept manually, and
it'll automatically decline if busy.

00:09:36,890 --> 00:09:40,060
Then we can specify the Accept Group.

Who is allowed to accept invitations?

The delegate up here,

00:09:44,070 --> 00:09:47,670
they're an administrator that can view the

00:09:47,670 --> 00:09:51,240
people to view the calendar,we just need

00:09:51,240 --> 00:09:55,330
And so we can specify down here, who it

00:09:55,330 --> 00:09:58,500
Administrators can do it by default,

I want them to be able to

I'll just put Administrators in.

And I can start to create

I can have Meeting Room B, and C, and

so on, we start specifying all of those,

They've got a little check mark by them.

00:17:13,650 --> 00:17:14,940
So I'm good there.

337
00:17:14,940 --> 00:17:18,410
And I can add the laptop right there.

338
00:17:18,410 --> 00:17:20,910
We invite resources just
like we invite people,

339
00:17:20,910 --> 00:17:24,850
because really at the end of the day they
are just user accounts on the back-end.

340
00:17:24,850 --> 00:17:26,770
I've got check marks all down the line.

341
00:17:26,770 --> 00:17:28,070
I know the meeting room is available.

342
00:17:28,070 --> 00:17:30,860
I know the projector's available,
the laptop's available.

343
00:17:30,860 --> 00:17:33,486
I'm good to go next Wednesday at 9 AM.

344
00:17:33,486 --> 00:17:36,320
And I'll go ahead and hit send.

345
00:17:36,320 --> 00:17:41,460
That's gonna create the meeting item,
and the invitations are gonna go out.

346
00:17:41,460 --> 00:17:44,400
John Doe is getting
an invitation right now.

347
00:17:44,400 --> 00:17:47,910
The projector, and the conference room,
and the laptop are getting invitations.

348
00:17:47,910 --> 00:17:52,320
They're going to accept them so they'll
now show up as busy during that time.

349
00:17:52,320 --> 00:17:52,960
Okay.

350
00:17:52,960 --> 00:17:55,510
Now, how do I know that worked?

351
00:17:55,510 --> 00:17:57,490
There's a few things we could do.

352
00:17:57,490 --> 00:18:00,810
For example, we could try and
schedule another meeting.

353
00:18:00,810 --> 00:18:05,420
I'm going to schedule another meeting at
that same time, right, April 29th at 9 AM.

354
00:18:05,420 --> 00:18:08,410
So this is just a,
I'll call it a test meeting and for

355
00:18:08,410 --> 00:18:12,130
location, if I start typing meeting room,
there's my meetings.

356
00:18:12,130 --> 00:18:15,630
And it's probably hard to see in the
video, but right next to Meeting Room A,

357
00:18:15,630 --> 00:18:17,700
I can see it has an X now.

358
00:18:17,700 --> 00:18:20,260
That X lets me know it's busy.

359
00:18:20,260 --> 00:18:22,400
It's already booked for that time.

360
00:18:22,400 --> 00:18:23,200
I can still pick it.

361
00:18:23,200 --> 00:18:27,550
I can still try and invite it because
if it's a moderated connection,

362
00:18:27,550 --> 00:18:29,570
where somebody is actually checking it,
they might go in and

363
00:18:29,570 --> 00:18:32,270
override it for me and make mine win out.

364
00:18:32,270 --> 00:18:34,200
But I can see that it's busy.

365
00:18:34,200 --> 00:18:36,920
Same thing goes with my invitees.

366
00:18:36,920 --> 00:18:42,200
If I invite John Doe, for example,
I can see he's got a check mark,

367
00:18:42,200 --> 00:18:45,090
because he hasn't accepted the invite yet.

368
00:18:45,090 --> 00:18:47,090
Users don't automatically accept invites,
so

369
00:18:47,090 --> 00:18:51,230
John still shows a check mark because he
hasn't booked anything during that time.

370
00:18:51,230 --> 00:18:55,460
But if I type Projector 1,
Projector 1 has an x.

371
00:18:55,460 --> 00:18:58,730
Because I told that resource to
automatically accept the other invite,

372
00:18:58,730 --> 00:19:00,680
it shows as busy.

373
00:19:00,680 --> 00:19:01,390
All right?

374
00:19:01,390 --> 00:19:04,230
Now there's some neat stuff you can
do if you've got a problem with

375
00:19:04,230 --> 00:19:05,020
a meeting like this.

376
00:19:05,020 --> 00:19:07,870
Where I've got a lot of resources
that are already booked.

377
00:19:07,870 --> 00:19:08,420
Right?

378
00:19:08,420 --> 00:19:10,390
So this meeting has some issues.

379
00:19:10,390 --> 00:19:15,960
Well, you can actually move the data or
change it, kind of bump it around,

380
00:19:15,960 --> 00:19:21,660
and try and see if you can't find a better
time for that calendar event to occur.

381
00:19:21,660 --> 00:19:25,450
So when I look at this meeting I
can see that it is fairly booked.

382
00:19:25,450 --> 00:19:29,063
Jane Doe is shown as accepting,
cuz I'm the one who created it and

383
00:19:29,063 --> 00:19:31,770
John Doe has a check mark but
it's not green yet.

384
00:19:31,770 --> 00:19:34,520
He hasn't accepted the invitation yet.

385
00:19:34,520 --> 00:19:39,260
But projector one and Meeting Room A,
those guys, they're booked.

386
00:19:39,260 --> 00:19:43,080
I can't use them as this time
cuz it's already booked.

387
00:19:43,080 --> 00:19:44,010
So I've got a bit of a problem.

388
00:19:47,550 --> 00:19:48,220
All right.

389
00:19:48,220 --> 00:19:52,490
So instead what I can do is I can go and
try to find a better time, right.

390
00:19:52,490 --> 00:19:56,230
I can try and move this meeting
forward an hour or two and

391
00:19:56,230 --> 00:19:58,560
see if I can find a spot
that will get me in there.

392
00:19:58,560 --> 00:20:00,980
There's actually a,
let me see if I can find it,

393
00:20:00,980 --> 00:20:06,540
there's a availability checker
which is buried in here somewhere.

394
00:20:06,540 --> 00:20:07,400
Let's see, where is that?

395
00:20:07,400 --> 00:20:11,190
I'm gonna try and remember where that is.

396
00:20:11,190 --> 00:20:12,370
So somewhere here in the calendar,

397
00:20:12,370 --> 00:20:16,350
we've got a little availability checker
where you can kinda see a timeline.

398
00:20:16,350 --> 00:20:19,180
It's actually a function of the calendar
app, so I doubt it'll be on the exam.

399
00:20:19,180 --> 00:20:21,580
But it would be nice to
show it to you guys.

400
00:20:21,580 --> 00:20:23,040
Somewhere in here.

401
00:20:24,100 --> 00:20:28,189
We can pull it up and Jane might not
have the permissions for everything,

402
00:20:28,189 --> 00:20:32,098
but.

403
00:20:32,098 --> 00:20:33,760
Or I might be thinking
of a different program.

404
00:20:33,760 --> 00:20:36,160
I actually use a different
calendar program, myself, so

405
00:20:36,160 --> 00:20:37,310
I might be thinking of mine.

406
00:20:37,310 --> 00:20:41,940
But somewhere buried in here, there
is a way to see that availability for

407
00:20:41,940 --> 00:20:45,370
people to pick that next best
time that's available and find

408
00:20:45,370 --> 00:20:49,030
that one that'll work out a little bit
better for us for scheduling that meeting.

409
00:20:49,030 --> 00:20:51,570
In my case,
my meeting is scheduled at a bad time.

410
00:20:53,180 --> 00:20:58,352
All right, so if I take that meeting and
I move it forward, I'll just come in here

411
00:20:58,352 --> 00:21:03,320
and say instead of 9 AM let's bump that
up, and I'll bump that up to 10 AM.

412
00:21:05,758 --> 00:21:09,010
Whoops, there we go, 10 AM.

413
00:21:09,010 --> 00:21:10,550
Put it to 1 AM, that'll be a fun meeting.

414
00:21:10,550 --> 00:21:15,770
So I'll bump that forward to 10 AM, and
and just kind of accept those changes,

415
00:21:15,770 --> 00:21:18,730
so now it's bumped forward and
when I take a look at it,

416
00:21:18,730 --> 00:21:22,300
see how Meeting Room A automatically
switched to a check mark and John Doe and

417
00:21:22,300 --> 00:21:25,060
Projector 1, they've got check marks so
they're good to go now.

418
00:21:25,060 --> 00:21:28,512
I picked a better time for that so you can
start to kind of navigate and find that.

419
00:21:28,512 --> 00:21:33,210
All right, that's all being
powered by the calendar server.

420
00:21:33,210 --> 00:21:37,010
With the calendar server that lets
you see somebody's availability, but

421
00:21:37,010 --> 00:21:39,640
it doesn't let you see
their calendar itself.

422
00:21:39,640 --> 00:21:45,020
So I know that Meeting Room A was booked
at 9 AM, but I don't know who booked it,

423
00:21:45,020 --> 00:21:47,650
or what meeting it is,
I just know that it's booked.

424
00:21:47,650 --> 00:21:52,360
So it still maintains data privacy, while
making sure that you don't double book.

425
00:21:52,360 --> 00:21:55,320
So that's kind of a nice function that it
has, it's a good little feature there.

426
00:21:57,030 --> 00:21:59,900
All right, but that, in a nutshell,
is the calendar service.

427
00:21:59,900 --> 00:22:04,130
If I jump back over here, the calendar
server, really just not much to it,

428
00:22:04,130 --> 00:22:05,720
just basic settings on it.

429
00:22:05,720 --> 00:22:08,560
It's does maintain a little database on
the back end where it's keeping track of

430
00:22:08,560 --> 00:22:12,340
all these calendar events, and then
Caldav is the protocol to connect to it.

431
00:22:12,340 --> 00:22:13,990
But if you need a centralized calendar,

432
00:22:13,990 --> 00:22:17,250
or shared calendars inside your company,
is a quick and easy way to do it,

433
00:22:17,250 --> 00:22:19,720
and it's fairly feature rich so
it's a nice thing to have.

434
00:22:21,060 --> 00:22:23,740
All right, well that's about all I've
got on the calendar service here

435
00:22:23,740 --> 00:22:26,000
inside of the OS ten server app.

436
00:22:26,000 --> 00:22:29,790
If you have any questions on what we've
talked about, remember you can always ask.

437
00:22:29,790 --> 00:22:32,832
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live and

438
00:22:32,832 --> 00:22:35,340
you'll see the chatroom beneath the video.

439
00:22:35,340 --> 00:22:36,180
Post your questions there.

440
00:22:36,180 --> 00:22:38,130
We monitor and answer during the show.

441
00:22:38,130 --> 00:22:40,680
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q and A forms.

442
00:22:40,680 --> 00:22:43,830
At the top of every page is
a link that says Q and A.

443
00:22:43,830 --> 00:22:45,700
Click on that,
it'll take you into the forums.

444
00:22:45,700 --> 00:22:49,270
You can post your questions there and
we monitor and answer after the show.

445
00:22:49,270 --> 00:22:50,470
Take advantage of that resource.

446
00:22:50,470 --> 00:22:52,490
It is there for you.

447
00:22:52,490 --> 00:22:53,840
All right.
That's all I've got today.

448
00:22:53,840 --> 00:22:55,510
Hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

449
00:22:55,510 --> 00:22:56,700
Signing off for IT Pro Tv.

450
00:22:56,700 --> 00:22:59,418
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

451
00:22:59,418 --> 00:23:09,418
[MUSIC]

452
00:23:13,360 --> 00:23:15,983
[SOUND] All right, during the show,

453
00:23:15,983 --> 00:23:20,181
I couldn't find that stupid
scheduling advisor, and so

454
00:23:20,181 --> 00:23:25,427
I just wanted to throw a little segment
here onto the end of the episode,

455
00:23:25,427 --> 00:23:29,556
a little after the credit roll
thing to kind of show you.

456
00:23:29,556 --> 00:23:30,478
It's not on the exam but

457
00:23:30,478 --> 00:23:33,500
it's a pretty neat function, so
I wanted you guys to see it.

458
00:23:33,500 --> 00:23:36,140
If you go to schedule a meeting,
and it's already booked for

459
00:23:36,140 --> 00:23:39,600
a particular time, you can just try and
guess other times, but

460
00:23:39,600 --> 00:23:42,210
that can get really frustrating
if people have busy calendars.

461
00:23:42,210 --> 00:23:44,830
So the scheduling advisor helps with that.

462
00:23:44,830 --> 00:23:46,350
It's up here under my Window menu.

463
00:23:46,350 --> 00:23:50,730
If you go under Window, you'll see
the scheduling advisor show up, sorry,

464
00:23:50,730 --> 00:23:52,910
not scheduling advisor,
the Availability Panel.

465
00:23:52,910 --> 00:23:54,070
That's what it's called.

466
00:23:54,070 --> 00:23:58,390
So under Window and Availability Panel,
you can bring that panel up.

467
00:23:58,390 --> 00:24:03,100
And now, whenever you click a meeting
if it's double booked or whatever,

468
00:24:03,100 --> 00:24:04,680
it'll show up here, and

469
00:24:04,680 --> 00:24:10,570
you can start to move that meeting and
you can see whether things are booked.

470
00:24:10,570 --> 00:24:12,440
So if I try and
double book these meetings,

471
00:24:12,440 --> 00:24:16,180
see how John Doe is showing he's
available, everybody else is showing gray.

472
00:24:16,180 --> 00:24:18,830
That means these other people
are already booked and

473
00:24:18,830 --> 00:24:21,410
I can see the other times
that are available.

474
00:24:21,410 --> 00:24:25,580
And I know if I move that meeting
to one of these other times,

475
00:24:25,580 --> 00:24:27,940
now everybody is available.

476
00:24:27,940 --> 00:24:31,850
Be careful with this, cuz every time I
move it I'm clicking that Send button,

477
00:24:31,850 --> 00:24:34,150
and that means I'm re-sending my invites.

478
00:24:34,150 --> 00:24:37,770
That won't bother the camera,
the resources and

479
00:24:37,770 --> 00:24:40,770
meeting rooms I've added, but it'll annoy
the hell out of John Doe right there.

480
00:24:40,770 --> 00:24:42,420
He's getting emails for all of this.

481
00:24:42,420 --> 00:24:46,840
So you wanna make sure that you kind of
just move it once before hitting Send, or

482
00:24:46,840 --> 00:24:51,000
revert it back between each move that you
try, but it's nice because you can just

483
00:24:51,000 --> 00:24:57,450
quickly and visually see all the invitees
and whether or not they're available.

484
00:24:57,450 --> 00:25:01,660
And then you can schedule that meeting,
and now everybody's able to attend and

485
00:25:01,660 --> 00:25:02,530
you've kind of gotten around that.

486
00:25:02,530 --> 00:25:06,450
So this is all coming from the server,
all this availability data.

487
00:25:06,450 --> 00:25:08,190
It's a function inside of Caldav, and

488
00:25:08,190 --> 00:25:11,440
it's a great way to get those meetings
scheduled and not have duplicates.

489
00:25:11,440 --> 00:25:13,675
So sorry I didn't get that in the show but
it's right here.

490
00:25:13,675 --> 00:25:16,675
Hopefully, you benefited
[LAUGH] benefited from that and

491
00:25:16,675 --> 00:25:18,743
you're able to speak better than I am.

492
00:25:18,743 --> 00:25:20,082
So, hope you guys enjoyed it.

493
00:25:20,082 --> 00:25:21,220
I'll see you next time.

494
00:25:21,220 --> 00:25:27,180
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Contacts
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,347 --> 00:00:20,304
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,964 --> 00:00:33,396
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,396 --> 00:00:35,860
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:35,860 --> 00:00:38,270
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTv.

6
00:00:38,270 --> 00:00:39,110
I'm your host,

7
00:00:39,110 --> 00:00:43,920
Don Pezet, back again with another episode
of Apple-certified technical coordinator.

8
00:00:43,920 --> 00:00:47,020
In this episode, we're going to be
diving into the contact service,

9
00:00:47,020 --> 00:00:51,460
which, admittedly, is probably one of
the least used services in the server app.

10
00:00:51,460 --> 00:00:55,480
But it does serve a purpose, it is
usable for certain use case scenarios.

11
00:00:55,480 --> 00:00:57,940
And more importantly, it's on the exam so
we need to be familiar with it.

12
00:00:57,940 --> 00:01:00,490
Fortunately, it's not that
difficult to want to configure.

13
00:01:00,490 --> 00:01:05,640
The contact service is designed to provide
you with a centralized data where you can

14
00:01:05,640 --> 00:01:10,980
store your contacts that can be used in
all sorts of programs, like in Apple mail,

15
00:01:10,980 --> 00:01:15,070
messages, in well,
the contacts application obviously.

16
00:01:15,070 --> 00:01:17,350
But it can be used in all these
different applications and

17
00:01:17,350 --> 00:01:19,710
ties right back into this
centralized database.

18
00:01:19,710 --> 00:01:23,790
Now, you might ask yourself, well Don,
I kind of already have a contacts app.

19
00:01:23,790 --> 00:01:25,310
I can kind of already do that.

20
00:01:25,310 --> 00:01:27,490
Why would I care if it's on the server or
not?

21
00:01:27,490 --> 00:01:28,950
And there's two reasons.

22
00:01:28,950 --> 00:01:30,490
First off, you're exactly right.

23
00:01:30,490 --> 00:01:33,440
Most people aren't going to use this
because you can manage contacts

24
00:01:33,440 --> 00:01:34,820
just fine without it.

25
00:01:34,820 --> 00:01:38,130
But, what if you used
more than one computer?

26
00:01:38,130 --> 00:01:39,510
I have this problem, right.

27
00:01:39,510 --> 00:01:42,020
I have my laptop and I have a desktop.

28
00:01:42,020 --> 00:01:45,000
And, when I'm on my laptop,
if I fire up the contacts app,

29
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:48,840
I can create contacts in there and
they're right there on my laptop.

30
00:01:48,840 --> 00:01:52,730
But then when I go to my desktop,
the contacts aren't there, all right?

31
00:01:52,730 --> 00:01:57,010
So I need some kind of way to synchronize
contacts between the two machines.

32
00:01:57,010 --> 00:01:58,890
Well, today, we have iCloud.

33
00:01:58,890 --> 00:02:01,470
If you have your iCloud account,
you sign in,

34
00:02:01,470 --> 00:02:05,170
now your contacts synced between
the machines, and you're done, right.

35
00:02:05,170 --> 00:02:07,380
But we didn't always have iCloud.

36
00:02:07,380 --> 00:02:11,040
And so before there was an iCloud, the way
we would synchronize contacts between

37
00:02:11,040 --> 00:02:14,480
computers was with the contact
server in the server app.

38
00:02:14,480 --> 00:02:16,420
So that's why we have this solution.

39
00:02:16,420 --> 00:02:19,530
And while it's not really relevant
to people doing new deployments,

40
00:02:19,530 --> 00:02:23,450
it is still relevant because it can
be used not only for people who had

41
00:02:23,450 --> 00:02:27,170
the contact service before, but for
people who don't want to use iCloud.

42
00:02:27,170 --> 00:02:29,960
Not everybody wants to sync
their contacts up to Apple,

43
00:02:29,960 --> 00:02:32,260
because you gotta trust their servers.

44
00:02:32,260 --> 00:02:35,550
If you want to have your own
system that you trust, well,

45
00:02:35,550 --> 00:02:38,330
you can deploy the contact
service in the server app.

46
00:02:38,330 --> 00:02:39,390
That's one scenario.

47
00:02:39,390 --> 00:02:42,240
The other scenario where
the contact service is really nice

48
00:02:42,240 --> 00:02:44,440
is if you have an open directory.

49
00:02:44,440 --> 00:02:48,050
When you have an open directory,
anybody can go into there contacts app and

50
00:02:48,050 --> 00:02:49,460
they can add the open directory.

51
00:02:49,460 --> 00:02:52,860
In fact, if they're bound to the active
directory, then it's already in there, or

52
00:02:52,860 --> 00:02:54,680
open directory,
then it's already in there.

53
00:02:54,680 --> 00:02:56,393
Well, active directory too, that works.

54
00:02:56,393 --> 00:02:57,440
[LAUGH] Either one.

55
00:02:57,440 --> 00:03:00,280
So, it's automatically added to
contacts if you're bound to it.

56
00:03:00,280 --> 00:03:03,590
But, what if you don't want to
bind to the open directory?

57
00:03:03,590 --> 00:03:05,620
You don't want your work
station bound to it.

58
00:03:05,620 --> 00:03:07,320
You want to log in with
a local account and

59
00:03:07,320 --> 00:03:11,450
you just want to be able to search for
contacts throughout the open directory.

60
00:03:11,450 --> 00:03:14,690
Well, it doesn't really let you do that,
you pretty much need to bind.

61
00:03:14,690 --> 00:03:17,660
I mean you can add it in and
put your credentials in but if you connect

62
00:03:17,660 --> 00:03:22,030
to a centralized contact server and
that server is bond to the open directory.

63
00:03:22,030 --> 00:03:25,070
You can now search and
find contacts in the open directory too.

64
00:03:25,070 --> 00:03:29,660
So by connecting a client to the contact
service, you get centralized storage

65
00:03:29,660 --> 00:03:33,740
of your contacts that can be synchronized
between multiple machines and

66
00:03:33,740 --> 00:03:36,440
you get the ability to search through
the open directory for contacts.

67
00:03:36,440 --> 00:03:38,010
Those are the two benefits.

68
00:03:38,010 --> 00:03:40,860
If you're using iCloud you might
not need either of those and

69
00:03:40,860 --> 00:03:42,580
the contact service is not for you.

70
00:03:42,580 --> 00:03:44,680
But it is still relevant
in certain use cases.

71
00:03:44,680 --> 00:03:46,730
That's why we've got it and
that's why it's still on the exam.

72
00:03:46,730 --> 00:03:47,850
All right.

73
00:03:47,850 --> 00:03:51,290
Let's take a look at this thing
in action and see how it works.

74
00:03:51,290 --> 00:03:53,710
All right.
Inside of my server app,

75
00:03:53,710 --> 00:03:56,730
I can go right down here under services,
and you'll find contacts.

76
00:03:56,730 --> 00:03:57,490
There it is.

77
00:03:57,490 --> 00:04:00,620
There's not a whole ton of
options in here, right.

78
00:04:00,620 --> 00:04:03,980
First off, we've got our standard on
off button, so we can turn it on.

79
00:04:03,980 --> 00:04:06,530
You can define your permissions,
who's allowed to connect to it.

80
00:04:06,530 --> 00:04:10,275
By default, all users so
you do have to have a valid user account,

81
00:04:10,275 --> 00:04:13,660
it's not just anonymous people and
all networks.

82
00:04:13,660 --> 00:04:17,700
That means the users can be on the same
network as the server or they can be

83
00:04:17,700 --> 00:04:20,990
remote as long as they have connectivity
to the server they can get to it.

84
00:04:20,990 --> 00:04:24,270
If you want external people to
be able to sync to the server,

85
00:04:24,270 --> 00:04:25,270
you'll want that setting.

86
00:04:26,540 --> 00:04:29,230
The other thing is Push Notifications.

87
00:04:29,230 --> 00:04:33,440
If somebody's remote, you can have
it where a contact gets modified and

88
00:04:33,440 --> 00:04:37,080
automatically gets pushed over to their
other system through Apple servers.

89
00:04:37,080 --> 00:04:39,140
And so you can go and turn that on.

90
00:04:39,140 --> 00:04:41,780
It does require a valid iCloud or

91
00:04:41,780 --> 00:04:45,670
an Apple ID to create the push
certificate that you use for that.

92
00:04:45,670 --> 00:04:48,400
If you watched the Profile Manager
episode we did it in there.

93
00:04:48,400 --> 00:04:50,870
But basically you have to have that
push notification certificate.

94
00:04:50,870 --> 00:04:55,800
And then the last option is allow
users to search the directory

95
00:04:55,800 --> 00:04:59,350
using the contacts application,
that's the feature I mentioned earlier.

96
00:04:59,350 --> 00:05:03,400
By default, the contact server just
gives you synchronization of your

97
00:05:03,400 --> 00:05:06,670
own contacts and that's it,
that's all you get by default.

98
00:05:06,670 --> 00:05:08,420
But if you turn this on,

99
00:05:08,420 --> 00:05:11,360
now they'll be able to search
against the open directory also.

100
00:05:11,360 --> 00:05:14,981
So it's like having two separate sets
of contacts all rolled into one.

101
00:05:16,677 --> 00:05:19,630
All right, so at this stage,
I'm really done on the server.

102
00:05:19,630 --> 00:05:23,110
That's all we do on the server,
there's not anything else we can do here.

103
00:05:23,110 --> 00:05:25,612
Everything else is done
on the client's side.

104
00:05:25,612 --> 00:05:27,430
All right, so
let's take a look at a client and

105
00:05:27,430 --> 00:05:29,490
how that gets connected and set up.

106
00:05:29,490 --> 00:05:33,060
So, over here I've got a client with a,
well, a bunch of junk here.

107
00:05:33,060 --> 00:05:35,180
There we go.
So, I've got a client and

108
00:05:35,180 --> 00:05:40,130
this client is bound to the directory,
so the client already has their own

109
00:05:40,130 --> 00:05:43,210
contacts that they've created and
they can search the open directory.

110
00:05:43,210 --> 00:05:45,780
But let's just assume that
it wasn't I can go and

111
00:05:45,780 --> 00:05:48,700
connect that contact server and
then I'll be able to have that access.

112
00:05:48,700 --> 00:05:51,450
Now there is something
that I forgot to mention.

113
00:05:51,450 --> 00:05:54,120
I mentioned that a user can
connect from the outside.

114
00:05:54,120 --> 00:05:55,710
So if somebody's out
there on the internet and

115
00:05:55,710 --> 00:05:58,240
they want to connect
in they can get to it.

116
00:05:58,240 --> 00:06:01,420
The contact server uses
some non-standard ports, so

117
00:06:01,420 --> 00:06:04,570
if you have a firewall in between you and
the Internet,

118
00:06:04,570 --> 00:06:07,830
which you more than likely do,
you do have to open up some ports.

119
00:06:07,830 --> 00:06:12,625
It does unsecured connections
on TCP port 8800.

120
00:06:12,625 --> 00:06:13,670
Eighty eight hundred.

121
00:06:13,670 --> 00:06:18,490
And it does secure connections on 8843.

122
00:06:18,490 --> 00:06:19,640
So TCP port 8843.

123
00:06:19,640 --> 00:06:23,450
So you do have to make sure you
open those on the firewall.

124
00:06:23,450 --> 00:06:26,780
In my case, my client is on
the same network as my server, so

125
00:06:26,780 --> 00:06:28,530
I don't have to mess with firewalls or
anything like that.

126
00:06:28,530 --> 00:06:29,970
I'll have that connectivity.

127
00:06:29,970 --> 00:06:32,200
But if it's an external client,
you will have to open those ports.

128
00:06:32,200 --> 00:06:36,140
I'll put that in the show notes so
you guys will have it.

129
00:06:36,140 --> 00:06:38,740
All right, assuming we're on
the same network, we're good to go.

130
00:06:38,740 --> 00:06:42,800
I can fire up my contacts app, and
when I launch the contacts app,

131
00:06:42,800 --> 00:06:44,900
I'm gonna see two things.

132
00:06:44,900 --> 00:06:46,050
On my Mac.

133
00:06:46,050 --> 00:06:48,550
Those are contacts that
are right here on this Mac,

134
00:06:48,550 --> 00:06:52,230
not being synchronized anywhere else and
directories.

135
00:06:52,230 --> 00:06:54,640
So I see my directory
service that I'm bound to,

136
00:06:54,640 --> 00:06:56,830
in my case the open directory, right?

137
00:06:56,830 --> 00:06:58,000
Oh, well, mine is saying no results.

138
00:06:58,000 --> 00:06:59,730
Maybe this machine isn't bound,
I don't remember, but

139
00:06:59,730 --> 00:07:02,630
those are what I'm going
to see by default.

140
00:07:02,630 --> 00:07:07,190
I need to add in my contacts server and
then I'll be able to synchronize and

141
00:07:07,190 --> 00:07:07,990
access those contacts.

142
00:07:07,990 --> 00:07:11,330
So the way we do that is we go
up to our contacts menu and

143
00:07:11,330 --> 00:07:13,260
you choose to add an account.

144
00:07:13,260 --> 00:07:16,640
Now when you go to add an account
you'll see iCloud, Exchange, Google,

145
00:07:16,640 --> 00:07:19,460
Facebook, right all these different ones
that are out there those are the ones

146
00:07:19,460 --> 00:07:20,860
that they want you to use.

147
00:07:20,860 --> 00:07:25,890
But we can go to other contacts account
and we can add in the apple server.

148
00:07:25,890 --> 00:07:29,410
Now, notice it doesn't say
the Apple server app, right.

149
00:07:29,410 --> 00:07:31,510
It says Card DAV, CardDAV.

150
00:07:31,510 --> 00:07:32,750
What's that all about?

151
00:07:32,750 --> 00:07:37,570
Well, the contact server, it's actually
just a modified web server, and it's

152
00:07:37,570 --> 00:07:41,740
using a modified version of Web DAV, the
web distributed authoring and versioning.

153
00:07:41,740 --> 00:07:42,730
And it's very effective.

154
00:07:42,730 --> 00:07:43,380
It works.

155
00:07:43,380 --> 00:07:46,030
That open standards called CardDAV.

156
00:07:46,030 --> 00:07:48,620
And so we can connect to
any CardDAV server we want.

157
00:07:48,620 --> 00:07:51,290
The Apple server app is just one of them.

158
00:07:51,290 --> 00:07:52,160
And so I'm going to do that.

159
00:07:52,160 --> 00:07:54,950
I'm going to connect and
I'll punch in my User Name now.

160
00:07:54,950 --> 00:07:58,850
For the User Name, because it's CardDAV,
you have to use your short name,

161
00:07:58,850 --> 00:08:00,840
the Unix name for your user account.

162
00:08:00,840 --> 00:08:04,200
It won't take the pretty name,
the display name.

163
00:08:04,200 --> 00:08:06,130
So I'm going to log in as John Doe.

164
00:08:06,130 --> 00:08:11,900
I'll put in my password and
then I'll put in the name of the server.

165
00:08:11,900 --> 00:08:13,970
Now if you want to have access
from the outside world,

166
00:08:13,970 --> 00:08:16,340
you need to register a DNS name for
your server.

167
00:08:16,340 --> 00:08:18,720
You'll need to have that in there.

168
00:08:18,720 --> 00:08:22,480
Mine is called osx-server1.lab.itpro.tv,

169
00:08:22,480 --> 00:08:26,230
so you may need to go add a DNS entry for
it.

170
00:08:26,230 --> 00:08:29,530
You probably already have one for it
though so it's probably not a big issue.

171
00:08:29,530 --> 00:08:33,008
If you're just using it internally, it's
okay to go ahead and just put OSX-sever1,

172
00:08:33,008 --> 00:08:37,060
or server1.local or whatever yours is
called, you can punch that in too.

173
00:08:37,060 --> 00:08:42,360
All right so I'll go ahead and
hit create and it's gonna reach out.

174
00:08:42,360 --> 00:08:45,890
Notice it's verifying, it's reaching
out to that server and talking to it.

175
00:08:45,890 --> 00:08:47,420
Now one of two things
is gonna happen here.

176
00:08:47,420 --> 00:08:49,580
Well, I guess there's three things.

177
00:08:49,580 --> 00:08:52,720
The first thing is it's gonna connect and
everything's gonna work great.

178
00:08:52,720 --> 00:08:55,670
The second possibility is that I
might get a certificate warning.

179
00:08:55,670 --> 00:08:59,890
If you brought this up as internal server
and you're not bound to the directory,

180
00:08:59,890 --> 00:09:03,070
you probably don't trust the root
certificate of that server.

181
00:09:03,070 --> 00:09:05,700
So when that happens,
you'll have the opportunity to trust,

182
00:09:05,700 --> 00:09:08,150
that you can choose to always
trust the certificate.

183
00:09:09,180 --> 00:09:11,180
The third possibility is
that it doesn't connect.

184
00:09:11,180 --> 00:09:13,590
If it doesn't connect you've got
to do a little troubleshooting.

185
00:09:13,590 --> 00:09:15,730
And it normally comes down to DNS.

186
00:09:15,730 --> 00:09:18,570
So what I normally do for
my first stage of troubleshooting

187
00:09:18,570 --> 00:09:22,220
is fire up the terminal and
just see if I can even ping that server.

188
00:09:22,220 --> 00:09:27,730
Can I ping osx-server1.lab.itpro.tv,
all right.

189
00:09:27,730 --> 00:09:28,720
Can I ping it?

190
00:09:28,720 --> 00:09:31,440
If I can't even ping it, then there's
no way the contact service is going to

191
00:09:31,440 --> 00:09:34,110
connect, so I may need to check that.

192
00:09:34,110 --> 00:09:38,110
If I can ping it, I might need to
check those firewall ports, you know,

193
00:09:38,110 --> 00:09:40,890
are those ports being blocked
between me and the server?

194
00:09:40,890 --> 00:09:42,780
And then other things we
start kind of drilling down.

195
00:09:42,780 --> 00:09:44,710
Is the server actually running?

196
00:09:44,710 --> 00:09:46,780
Am I using the right credentials?

197
00:09:46,780 --> 00:09:50,274
We just need to double check all the
information that we're putting in there.

198
00:09:52,202 --> 00:09:55,820
All right, in my case though, I did trust
the certificate because I'm bound to

199
00:09:55,820 --> 00:09:58,520
the open directory, and so
it automatically added it in.

200
00:09:58,520 --> 00:10:00,520
And now I see a lot of new
stuff that's appeared.

201
00:10:00,520 --> 00:10:05,020
All right, before I had on my Mac,
and I had Directories.

202
00:10:05,020 --> 00:10:06,420
And Directories was kind of empty, right.

203
00:10:06,420 --> 00:10:07,660
It had All Directories.

204
00:10:07,660 --> 00:10:12,820
But now when I go in, I see I've
got Contacts stored on the server.

205
00:10:12,820 --> 00:10:15,850
As well as the directories, all right?

206
00:10:15,850 --> 00:10:20,030
So, when I look at it on my Mac, well,
I can see I've got one contact for

207
00:10:20,030 --> 00:10:21,300
Apple Inc., and that's it.

208
00:10:22,350 --> 00:10:26,080
If I go and look on the server,
I can see I don't have any contacts.

209
00:10:26,080 --> 00:10:28,200
So I can go in and I can add some.

210
00:10:28,200 --> 00:10:31,960
I can add in, I'll create a contact,
maybe I'll create one for me, right.

211
00:10:31,960 --> 00:10:36,035
So I'll do a new contact for
Don Pezet, and I work for

212
00:10:36,035 --> 00:10:41,180
ITProTV, and I'll put in an email address.

213
00:10:41,180 --> 00:10:43,980
So I am Don@itprotv, there we go.

214
00:10:43,980 --> 00:10:47,080
So I punch in that information,
and now I've got a contact.

215
00:10:47,080 --> 00:10:51,380
And instead of being stored right here
on my Mac, it's stored on the server.

216
00:10:51,380 --> 00:10:53,680
So if I have five computers,
or if I have a laptop and

217
00:10:53,680 --> 00:10:57,590
a desktop, when I go between them,
I'll have all my contacts right there.

218
00:10:57,590 --> 00:11:00,850
And now it's centralized,
it's synchronized between the systems.

219
00:11:00,850 --> 00:11:02,780
Now, what about my previous contacts?

220
00:11:02,780 --> 00:11:05,110
I've already got one right here on my Mac.

221
00:11:05,110 --> 00:11:08,900
Well, you can just take them and
drag and drop them, and

222
00:11:08,900 --> 00:11:13,330
it'll move it off of just being on your
own Mac to being up on the server.

223
00:11:13,330 --> 00:11:15,650
And so now I've got that right up there.

224
00:11:15,650 --> 00:11:19,230
So really easy to migrate to this if
you had a bunch of local contacts.

225
00:11:20,600 --> 00:11:23,470
Now, I am connected to the directory,
too, though, so I can search and

226
00:11:23,470 --> 00:11:25,220
find contacts on the directory.

227
00:11:25,220 --> 00:11:30,180
If I go down here to Directories and
I pick my Open Directory I can search for

228
00:11:30,180 --> 00:11:32,050
somebody like Jane Doe.

229
00:11:32,050 --> 00:11:33,440
Jane, she's got a contact and

230
00:11:33,440 --> 00:11:36,920
there she is, that's coming
right out of the Open Directory.

231
00:11:36,920 --> 00:11:38,950
And I can call, FaceTime, audio,

232
00:11:38,950 --> 00:11:41,570
whatever it is,
those contacts are now available to me.

233
00:11:41,570 --> 00:11:44,890
Even if I wasn't bound to the directory,
I would be able to see this,

234
00:11:44,890 --> 00:11:47,180
cuz I'm connected to that contact server,
right?

235
00:11:47,180 --> 00:11:50,360
That gives us that centralized
contacts database, and

236
00:11:50,360 --> 00:11:52,500
now we have everybody in the company.

237
00:11:52,500 --> 00:11:56,280
And you can even take some of these
people and drag and drop them.

238
00:11:56,280 --> 00:12:00,690
Just in case you're traveling and
you can't access the directory,

239
00:12:00,690 --> 00:12:05,050
well now I've made a copy of Jane, so when
I go and look at my individual contacts,

240
00:12:05,050 --> 00:12:08,100
I can see that I've got Jane added right
there copied out of the directory.

241
00:12:08,100 --> 00:12:10,150
So we can kind of move
those things around.

242
00:12:10,150 --> 00:12:11,980
And I'm just using the contacts app.

243
00:12:11,980 --> 00:12:14,060
But there's a number of apps
out there that support this.

244
00:12:14,060 --> 00:12:19,580
So, if you were to fire up Apple mail,
I use Fantastical, programs like that.

245
00:12:19,580 --> 00:12:21,700
They can all interact with
the same contacts database and

246
00:12:21,700 --> 00:12:23,000
pull up the same record.

247
00:12:23,000 --> 00:12:24,040
So very powerful.

248
00:12:24,040 --> 00:12:25,110
You get a lot of a functionality there.

249
00:12:26,190 --> 00:12:29,750
But as far as the server is concerned,
there's not much to it, right?

250
00:12:29,750 --> 00:12:34,050
It's maintaining a little database of
all of the individual user contacts.

251
00:12:34,050 --> 00:12:36,140
It maintains a separate database for
each individual user.

252
00:12:36,140 --> 00:12:39,525
They're very small Inside of the database,

253
00:12:39,525 --> 00:12:41,545
it's really just got a bunch of vCards,
right?

254
00:12:41,545 --> 00:12:44,335
A vCard for each contact that
it stores that information in,

255
00:12:44,335 --> 00:12:47,175
and it's all accessed via CardDAV.

256
00:12:47,175 --> 00:12:50,872
It's open standards technologies
that are extremely compatible.

257
00:12:50,872 --> 00:12:52,907
Now, remember what I said at
the beginning of the episode,

258
00:12:52,907 --> 00:12:55,132
the contact service is not for everybody.

259
00:12:55,132 --> 00:12:56,762
And if you've got iCloud,

260
00:12:56,762 --> 00:13:00,692
you probably don't need this, so, a lot of
people don't necessarily mess with this.

261
00:13:00,692 --> 00:13:01,682
I know me personally,

262
00:13:01,682 --> 00:13:04,682
most of my contacts are stored in
my Google Apps for work account.

263
00:13:04,682 --> 00:13:07,452
But if you want to maintain a local copy,

264
00:13:07,452 --> 00:13:11,572
you don't want it stored in the cloud, the
contact service is a great solution, and

265
00:13:11,572 --> 00:13:13,442
it's easy to activate and
get up and running.

266
00:13:13,442 --> 00:13:14,789
So, one of the simpler ones to go with.

267
